Authors: Ottaviani C., Capozi M., Quaresima C., Matteucci M., Crotti C., Perfetti P., Astaldi C., Zacchigna M., Comicioli C., Evans M., Prince K.C.
Title: Surface core level shifts in III-V semiconductors: a high resolution photoemission study
Source title: Journal of Electron Spectroscopy and Related Phenomena
Affiliations: ISM-CNR - V. Enrico Fermi 38, I-00044 Frascati, Italy; Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A. - Padriciano 99, I-34012 Trieste, Italy

Abstract: We have performed photoemission experiments to determine the surface versus bulk contributions of In4d, Ga 3d and P 2p core level spectra in InP and GaP. The experiments were performed at the new VUV High Energy Resolution Photoemission beamline at the storage ring ELETTRA in Trieste. We obtained the values ΔEIn 4d=-0.32 eV and ΔEP 2p=0.31 eV for the surface core level shifts of Indium and Phosphorous in InP(110), while the shifts for Ga 3d and P 2p in GaP(110) were -0.30 eV and 0.40 eV respectively. These results are discussed in terms of a simple model based on the difference between bulk and surface Madelung potentials. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Calculations; Electron energy levels; Mathematical models; Photoemission; Semiconducting gallium compounds; Semiconducting indium phosphide; Storage rings; Surfaces; High energy resolution photoemission; Madelung potentials; Surface core level shifts; Photoelectron spectroscopy

Authors: Kim D.-M., Lee K.-Y., Lee J.-Y.
Title: The electrode characteristics and modified surface properties of V0.9Ti0.1 alloy sintered with Ni powder
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Kusong-dong 373-1, Yusung-gu, Taejon, South Korea, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, D.-M., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Kusong-dong 373-1, Yusung-gu, Taejon, South Korea, South Korea; Lee, K.-Y., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Kusong-dong 373-1, Yusung-gu, Taejon, South Korea, South Korea; Lee, J.-Y., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Kusong-dong 373-1, Yusung-gu, Taejon, South Korea, South Korea
Abstract: The V0.9Ti0.1 alloy absorbs a large amount of hydrogen, but it has never been used for the anode material for a NiMH battery due to the poor discharge behavior in KOH electrolyte. V0.9Ti0.1 alloy powder has been sintered with Ni powder to provide a catalytic effect on the absorption/desorption of hydrogen in KOH electrolyte. The optimal sintering condition was 5 min at 900°C and the amounts of Ni powder were varied to investigate the effects of surface modification on the discharge characteristics. All electrodes sintered with Ni powder were fully activated within 10 cycles in KOH electrolyte. The discharge capacities of the electrodes showed a maximum behavior with Ni content of the sintered alloy. The optimal amount of Ni powder showing the highest discharge capacity of 302 mA h g-1 was found to be 25 wt.%. From the results of the various analysis such as scanning electron microscopy (energy dispersive spectroscopy) and X-ray, it is found that VNi3 is formed during sintering. The VNi3 phase formed on the surface of V0.9Ti0.1 particles provides the optimum discharge capacity for the electrode. In accordance with the Brewer-Engel theory, VNi3 phases are found to be highly electrocatalytic, which is reflected in an increase of the exchange current density and a decrease of the discharging overpotential. In order to develop an anode material using metal hydride which has a large hydrogen storage capacity but is inactive for electrochemical hydrogenation, it has been suggested as a new process to modify the surface by sintering with Ni powder. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Electrode; Modification; Nickel; Sintering; Surface
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Electrodes; Electrolytes; Gas absorption; Hydrogen; Scanning electron microscopy; Secondary batteries; Sintering; Spectroscopic analysis; Surface treatment; X ray analysis; Discharging overpotential; Hydrogen storage capacity; Optimum discharge capacity; Vanadium alloys

Authors: Yu J.Y., Lei Y.Q., Chen C.P., Wu J., Wang Q.D.
Title: The electrochemical properties of hydrogen storage Zr-based Laves phase alloys
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China
Authors with affiliations: Yu, J.Y., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Lei, Y.Q., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Chen, C.P., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Wu, J., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Wang, Q.D., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China
Abstract: Zr-based Laves phase alloys Zr(MnCrVNi)2 were designed by means of the orthogonal method, and the electrochemical properties of the alloy electrodes were investigated. It was found that the maximum discharge capacity reached 343 mA h g-1, the discharge capacity ratio at a discharge rate of 200-50 mA g-1 was more than 80%, the number of activation cycles is less than 13 and the self-discharge ratio after 2 weeks varied between 16.1 and 53.1%. X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and energy-dispersive X-ray analysis tests showed that the as-cast Zr-based Laves phase alloy consisted of at least eight phases. The major cubic C15-type Laves phase coexisted with the hexagonal C14-type Laves phase, orthorhombic Zr7Ni10 phase, tetragonal, Zr9Ni11 phase and a few other phases. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy proved that Zr and Mn were richer in the outer layer of the Zr-based Laves phase hydride electrode; Ni and Cr were deficient on the surface of the electrode. After 540 charging-discharging cycles, the discharge capacities of the Zr-based Laves phase hydride electrodes decreased by 20-30%. This was mainly caused by the formation of oxides at the surface of the electrodes. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Electrochemical properties; Hydride electrode; Laves phases
Index Keywords: Chemical activation; Electric discharges; Electrodes; Hydrides; Phase transitions; Scanning electron microscopy; Surfaces; X ray diffraction; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Discharge capacity; Energy dispersive X ray analysis; Hydrogen storage alloys; Laves phase alloys; Zirconium alloys

Authors: Iwakura C., Miyamoto M., Inoue H., Matsuoka M., Fukumoto Y.
Title: Kinetics of hydrogen evolution reaction at nonstoichiometric hydrogen storage alloys for nickel-hydrogen batteries
Affiliations: Department of Applied Chemistry, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka, 593, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Iwakura, C., Department of Applied Chemistry, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka, 593, Japan; Miyamoto, M., Department of Applied Chemistry, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka, 593, Japan; Inoue, H., Department of Applied Chemistry, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka, 593, Japan; Matsuoka, M., Department of Applied Chemistry, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka, 593, Japan; Fukumoto, Y., Department of Applied Chemistry, College of Engineering, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka, 593, Japan
Abstract: The kinetics of the hydrogen evolution reaction at Mm(B5)x electrodes (Mm = misch metal, B5 = Ni3.6Mn0.4Al0.3Co0.7 x = 0.88, 1.00 and 1.12) was investigated by measuring the potential decay immediately after the interruption of an applied cathodic current. The total overvoltage (η) for the hydrogen evolution reaction was divided into two components (η1 and η2) corresponding to the Volmer and the Tafel reactions. The exchange current densities of the elementary reactions (iOV and iOT) were then evaluated by extrapolating the Tafel lines for η1 and η2. The values of η1 and η2 at the Mm(B5)0.88 electrode were found to be almost the same as those at the Mm(B5)1.00 electrode. At the Mm(B5)1.12 electrode, however, the values of η2, i0V i0T and activation energy for the Tafel reaction were very large, compared with those at the other two electrodes, indicating, that the Tafel reaction was fairly depressed at the Mm(B5)1.12 electrode. The Mm(B5)1.12 electrode gave a high-rate chargeability owing to the high overvoltage for the Tafel reaction. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Activation energy; High-rate chargeability; Hydrogen storage alloy; Nonstoichiometric composition; Volmer-Tafel mechanism
Index Keywords: Alloys; Chemical activation; Current density; Electric currents; Electrochemical electrodes; Hydrogen; Reaction kinetics; Storage (materials); Voltage measurement; Chargeability rate; Hydrogen evolution reaction; Nickel hydrogen batteries; Nonstoichiometric hydrogen storage alloys; Volmer Tafel mechanism; Secondary batteries

Authors: Limacher B., Leroy D., Arnoux C., Gaspard F.
Title: Aging effects in LaNiMn tritides
Affiliations: Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, BP12, 91680 Bruyeres-le-Chatel, France
Authors with affiliations: Limacher, B., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, BP12, 91680 Bruyeres-le-Chatel, France; Leroy, D., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, BP12, 91680 Bruyeres-le-Chatel, France; Arnoux, C., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, BP12, 91680 Bruyeres-le-Chatel, France; Gaspard, F., Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, BP12, 91680 Bruyeres-le-Chatel, France
Abstract: Aging effects on LaNi5-xMnx tritides (0 ≤ x ≤ 2) stored at room temperature have been investigated for 3-5 years. Almost all helium generated in the compounds by tritium decay was retained in the solid. Helium-induced changes in tritium P-C isotherms were observed: lowering of plateau pressure and reduction of storage capacity. These aging effects can be reversed, at least for younger tritides, by heating at 300-380°C. Thermal desorption experiments performed on aged LaNi4Mn samples showed that helium release from older samples occurs at lower temperatures. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Aging; LaNiMn tritides; Tritium
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Desorption; Energy storage; Helium; Intermetallics; Isotherms; Lanthanum alloys; Tritium; Lanthanum nickel manganese tritides; Storage capacity; Thermal desorption; Hydrides

Abstract: Hydrogen absorption and desorption properties of UTi and UZr alloys were investigated at hydrogen pressures below 105 Pa and temperatures up to 873 K. Under such conditions, some uranium alloys showed as good characteristics as pure uranium and resulted in less degree of powderization after hydrogenation under an atmospheric pressure. © 1995.

Authors: Soubeyroux J.L., Bououdina M., Fruchart D., de Rango P.
Title: Phase stability and neutron diffraction studies of Laves phases Zr(Cr1-xMx)2 with M = (Cu0.5Ni0.5) and 0 < x < 0.2 and their hydrides
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Cristallographie, CNRS, associea l'Universite J. Fourier, 166X, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 09, France
Authors with affiliations: Soubeyroux, J.L., Laboratoire de Cristallographie, CNRS, associea l'Universite J. Fourier, 166X, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 09, France; de Rango, P., Laboratoire de Cristallographie, CNRS, associea l'Universite J. Fourier, 166X, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 09, France
Abstract: Laves phases of composition Zr(Cr1-xMx)2 with M = (Cu0.5Ni0.5) and 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2 have been synthesised with the hexagonal C14- and/or cubic C15-type structures. By X-ray and neutron diffraction we have determined the structures of the alloys, and in particular the sites for the 3d metal substitution. The position of the hydrogen atoms in the structures and the occupation of the different sites of the hydrides have been determined. Purity and quality of polycrystalline alloys have been checked by using scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray analysis techniques. The effects of the M Cr substitution have been studied for phase stability, maximum hydrogen content and hydrogen site stability and analyzed in view of applications as electrodes in HM batteries. © 1995.

Authors: Friedlmeier G., Manthey A., Wanner M., Groll M.
Title: Cyclic stability of various application-relevant metal hydrides
Affiliations: Institut für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme (IKE), University of Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Friedlmeier, G., Institut für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme (IKE), University of Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Manthey, A., Institut für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme (IKE), University of Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Wanner, M., Institut für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme (IKE), University of Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany; Groll, M., Institut für Kernenergetik und Energiesysteme (IKE), University of Stuttgart, Pfaffenwaldring 31, D-70569 Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: Six metal hydrides relevant for practical applications (four AB5 alloys, one AB2 alloy and Mg(Ni)) were thermally cycled at constant volume under a hydrogen gas atmosphere. Up to 64 000 absorption-desorption cycles have been completed so far (with LaNi4.7Al0.3). The respective reversible hydrogen capacities as a function of the number of cycles were determined for the selected cycling conditions. Regeneration conditions were determined when applicable. Various investigations (pressure-composition isotherms, thermal desorption spectroscopy, X-ray powder diffractometry, magnetization, laser granulometry, scanning electron microscopy-energy-dispersive X-ray analysis) were performed in order to determine the degradation and regeneration mechanisms involved. The reversible storage capacity of the AB5 alloys decayed during cycling. This effect is stronger at higher temperatures and pressures. However, the original capacity of all four materials could be recovered by heating to about 400-500 °C in vacuum. Disproportionation was found to be the degradation mechanism for the AB5 alloys. The AB2 alloy showed no degradation after 42 400 cycles. Mg(Ni) degrades as a consequence of a reduction of the comparatively slow absorption kinetics probably caused by sintering of the original powder. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Intermetallic compounds; Magnesium hydride; Metal hydrides
Index Keywords: Degradation; Desorption; Gas absorption; Hydrogen; Intermetallics; Isotherms; Magnesium compounds; Magnetization; Reaction kinetics; Scanning electron microscopy; X ray analysis; X ray powder diffraction; Application relevant metal hydrides; Cyclic stability; Magnesium hydride; Reversible energy storage capacity; Hydrides

Authors: Blok K.
Title: Carbon dioxide removal studies in the Netherlands
Affiliations: Department of Science Technology and Society, Utrecht University, Padualaan 14, 3584 CH Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Blok, K., Department of Science Technology and Society, Utrecht University, Padualaan 14, 3584 CH Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: An explorative research programme on CO 2 removal has been carried out in the Netherlands. The goal of this programme was to obtain a better understanding of the technical and economic feasibility of the recovery of CO 2 from flue gases and synthesis gases and the sustainable storage of CO 2 outside the atmosphere. As far as CO 2 recovery from power plants is concerned, options based on coal gasification with CO 2 recovery turn out to be most energy- efficient. Of the remaining recovery options chemical absorption from flue gases, using amines, seems most promising. A number of recovery options based on membrane technologies have been identified, but most of them still require considerable development. In manufacturing industry, attractive options for CO 2 recovery are available in refineries equipped with residue gasification, and in the ammonia fertilizer industry. More costly options were identified in the iron and steel industry and in the petrochemical industry. CO 2 storage in aquifers is technically feasible. When injecting CO 2 in aquifers part of the water already present will be displaced. The main mechanisms for this displacement will be gravity segregation and viscous fingering, as was shown by simulation calculations. The Dutch subsurface contains a large number of aquifers that are potentially suitable for CO 2 storage. © 1995 Elsevier B.V.

Authors: Yakimets I.V., Astakhov Yu.N., Labuntsov V.A., Gluzkin I.Z., Mokhov V.B.
Title: Superconducting energy storage for russian power systems
Authors with affiliations: Yakimets, I.V.; Astakhov, Yu.N.; Labuntsov, V.A.; Gluzkin, I.Z.; Mokhov, V.B.
Abstract: The paper considers the application efficiency of low-capacity superconducting magnetic energy storage systems for improvement of the dynamic stability of some Russian regional electrical power systems. Tentative calculation of design characteristics for the main elements of the base capacity storage is carried out. © 1996.
Author Keywords: calculation; dynamic stability; Electrical power system; Russia; superconducting magnetic energy storage

Authors: Antonov B.M., Kuvshinov A.A., Kurnosov B.D., Labuntsov V.A., Lazarev N.S., Stukachev A.V.
Title: Characteristics and design of valve converters for superconducting magnetic energy storage devices
Authors with affiliations: Antonov, B.M.; Kuvshinov, A.A.; Kurnosov, B.D.; Labuntsov, V.A.; Lazarev, N.S.; Stukachev, A.V.
Abstract: The paper outlines the first stages of development in the U.S.A. and U.S.S.R. of superconducting magnetic energy storage systems (SMES) intended for improving the dynamic stability of electrical power systems and reliability of power consumption. The energy performance of power thyristor converters, one of the main components of such SMES, is considered. The construction of a converter designed for an experimental SMES plant at the Institute of High Temperatures of the Russian Academy of Sciences in 1989-1992 is described. Versions of converter circuits with GTO for SMES are briefly considered. © 1996.
Author Keywords: power characteristics; power systems; power thyristor converter; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; transient stability

Title: Bose-Einstein correlations in e+e- annihilation in the γ(1S) and continuum
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik C: Particles and Fields
Affiliations: Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Blinov, A.E., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Blinov, V.E., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Bondar, A.E., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Bukin, A.D., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Groshev, V.R., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Klimenko, S.G., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Onuchin, A.P., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Panin, V.S., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Protopopov, I.Y., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Shamov, A.G., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Sidorov, V.A., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Skovpen, Yu.I., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Skrinsky, A.N., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Tayursky, V.A., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Telnov, V.I., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Tikhonov, Y.A., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Tumaikin, G.M., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Undrus, A.E., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Vorobiov, A.I., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Zhilich, V.N., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation
Abstract: Bose-Einstein correlations in direct γ(1S) decays and continuum in the energy region √s=7.2-10.3 GeV have been studied using data taken with the MD-1 detector at VEPP-4 storage ring. Assuming gaussian density of the pion source the data indicate the radius of the source π=0.73±0.10±0.04 fm for direct γ (1S) decays and π=0.83±0.22±0.05 fm for the continuum. The correlation strengths λ for both data samples also are similar. Thus Bose-Einstein correlations do not reveal a noticeable difference between quark and gluon fragmentation. © 1996 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Srivastava S.C., Singh B.P., Singh K.P., Srivastava S.K.
Title: Interaction of magnetic field with biological system for health care
Source title: IEEE/ Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society Annual Conference
Affiliations: Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Srivastava, S.C., Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India; Singh, B.P., Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India; Singh, K.P., Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India; Srivastava, S.K., Madan Mohan Malaviya Engineering, Coll, Gorakhpur, India
Abstract: The terrestrial radiations govern the biological activities of all systems. The non-coordinated activities between man and the environment is responsible for malfunctioning of cells. The herb loses its vitality in the storage process. The chemotherapy, a substitute of herbal therapy, often fails to eradicate the root cause. The radiation has been adopted for both diagnostic and therapeutic use. The excess dose of radiation is prone to develop 'hot spots'. The depth of penetration often may not coincide with the site of lesion. The radiation therapy produces energy due to induction coupling confined to muscle fibers only. In this paper, the theoretical and clinical aspects of controlling inflammatory activities due to chemical and mechanical trauma using d.c. and a.c. steady state magnetic field have been reported.
Index Keywords: Cells; Charged particles; Diagnosis; Drug therapy; Electric fields; Health care; Hemodynamics; Maxwell equations; Radiation effects; Radiotherapy; Edema; Herbal therapy; Lesion; Trauma; Magnetic field effects

Authors: De Leitenburg C., Trovarelli A., Zamar F., Maschio S., Dolcetti G., Llorca J.
Title: A novel and simple route to catalysts with a high oxygen storage capacity: The direct room-temperature synthesis of CeO2-ZrO2 solid solutions

Abstract: High-energy mechanical alloying of pure CeO2 and ZrO2 at room temperature results in the formation of a single phase Ce 1-xZrxO2 fluorite structured solid solution in all the examined composition ranges; the compounds are characterized by a high oxygen storage capacity and an excellent reducibility.

Authors: Frahm R., Weigelt J., Meyer G., Materlik G.
Title: X-ray undulator beamline BW1 at DORIS III
Affiliations: Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Frahm, R., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany; Weigelt, J., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany; Meyer, G., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany; Materlik, G., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: The BW1 x-ray undulator beamline at HASYLAB offers high intensity for a wide variety of diffraction and absorption experiments. The x-ray undulator is a 4-m-long device with 127 periods. At 4.5 GeV energy of the positron storage ring DORIS III it can be tuned in its 3rd harmonic to photon energies from 9 to 15 keV. The basis for such a beamline is a high precision monochromator which has to be able to cope with high heat loads from the insertion device. There are four operating modes: (i) focused white beam using two mirrors with a cutoff energy of approximately 11 keV, (ii) focused monochromatic beam using both mirrors with a cutoff energy of ≈12 keV and a double-crystal monochromator, (iii) unfocused monochromatic beam using the monochromator without mirrors, and (iv) focused monochromatic beam using the monochromator without mirrors but with a sagittally focusing second crystal. Currently, a horizontal diffractometer for the investigation of liquid surfaces, an ultrahigh vacuum chamber for standing wave measurements and a versatile x-ray multicircle diffractometer are installed in the experiment hutch. Typical scientific investigations performed at this beamline will be discussed to demonstrate the capabilities of the whole setup. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Mehta S.K., Srinivasan T., Dubey G.C., Jain R.K.
Title: Influence of hydrogenation on photoluminescence of GaAlAs grown by molecular beam epitaxy
Affiliations: Solidstate Physics Laboratory, Lucknow Road, Timarpur, Delhi 110054, India
Authors with affiliations: Mehta, S.K., Solidstate Physics Laboratory, Lucknow Road, Timarpur, Delhi 110054, India; Srinivasan, T., Solidstate Physics Laboratory, Lucknow Road, Timarpur, Delhi 110054, India; Dubey, G.C., Solidstate Physics Laboratory, Lucknow Road, Timarpur, Delhi 110054, India; Jain, R.K., Solidstate Physics Laboratory, Lucknow Road, Timarpur, Delhi 110054, India
Abstract: The effects of hydrogenation on GaAlAs layer grown by molecular beam epitaxy stored over a long period of time was investigated using photoluminescence (PL) measurement. Upon hydrogenation, the defects in the GaAlAs are passivated and the PL intensity increased many times. Hydrogenation changes the energy of the defect produced on storage of GaAlAs and new features appear in excitonic emissions. On annealing the hydrogenated GaAlAs at temperatures ≳500°C, the defects are depassivated and the PL intensity degraded. Hydrogenation improves the PL intensity of emission from a stack of GaAs/GaAlAs quantum wells (QW) of different well widths by a factor which varies with the depth of the QW from the surface. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Gonçalves Da Silva C.E.T., Rodrigues A.R.D., Craievich A.F.
Title: LNLS status report
Affiliations: LNLS - Laboratório Nacional de Luz Síncrotron, Cx. Postal 6192, Campinas, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Gonçalves Da Silva, C.E.T., LNLS - Laboratório Nacional de Luz Síncrotron, Cx. Postal 6192, Campinas, Brazil; Rodrigues, A.R.D., LNLS - Laboratório Nacional de Luz Síncrotron, Cx. Postal 6192, Campinas, Brazil; Craievich, A.F., LNLS - Laboratório Nacional de Luz Síncrotron, Cx. Postal 6192, Campinas, Brazil
Abstract: The Brazilian synchrotron light source consists of a 1.15 GeV electron storage ring with a 100 MeV injector. Most of their components have already been developed in-house and production has started. The increase of injection energy is being considered via a booster, for full energy, or by recirculating the beam in the LINAC (200 MeV) [R. H. Farias et al. (unpublished)]. An update of the production and characterization of the accelerators components and beamlines is presented. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Takahashi E., Cho T., Hirata M., Kohagura J., Sakamoto Y., Yamaguchi N., Tamano T., Yagishita A., Maezawa H.
Title: Photoelectron spectroscopy for plasma x-ray measurements
Affiliations: Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, E., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Cho, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Hirata, M., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kohagura, J., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sakamoto, Y., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yamaguchi, N., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Tamano, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yagishita, A., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Maezawa, H., Photon Factory, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: A new x-ray spectrometer using the principle of a photoelectron spectroscopy method is developed for the purpose of the observations of plasma-electron temperatures in the range of a hundred of eV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy is a widely utilized method for surface-physics analyses; here, we employ a parallel-plate energy analyzer. This new type spectrometer is calibrated using synchrotron radiation from a 2.5 GeV positron storage ring at the Photon Factory (KEK). Theoretical calculations for photoelectron spectra from plasmas with various electron temperatures are carried out using the calibration data. This spectrometer is set up at the central cell of the GAMMA 10 tandem mirror for the measurements of potential-confined electron temperatures. Experimentally observed spectra are compared with the calculated spectra as well as the data from the other x-ray detection method. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Van Silfhout R.G., Hermes C.
Title: X-ray instrumentation for a focused wiggler beamline at the EMBL Outstation Hamburg
Affiliations: EMBL Hamburg Outstation, c/o DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Van Silfhout, R.G., EMBL Hamburg Outstation, c/o DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany; Hermes, C., EMBL Hamburg Outstation, c/o DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-22603 Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: A flexible setup consisting of two independent water-cooled X-ray monochromators providing radiation for two separate beamlines (A and B) has been installed on the multipole wiggler BW7 at the DORIS III storage ring. The first optical element of both lines is a Rh-coated SiC mirror that reduces the heat load on subsequent energy defining elements. Line B, which will be predominantly used for protein crystallography, is optimized for flux and employs a triangular monochromator and segmented glass mirror for horizontal and vertical focusing, respectively; it can be operated in a wavelength range from 0.5 to 1.8 Å. Line A features a high-energy resolution fixed exit, nondispersive double monochromator, optimized for accurate and fast energy scans. It will mainly be used for anomalous scattering, EXAFS, and small-angle scattering. The use of encoders, intelligent stepper/dc-motor controllers, and position sensitive beam monitors allow a comfortable and fast alignment of all axes. Both experimental hutches are equipped with large motorized optical tables, offering a versatile and convenient mounting surface for experiments. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Zapfe K., Braun B., Gaul H.-G., Grieser M., Povh B., Rall M., Steffens E., Stock F., Tonhäuser J., Montag C., Rathmann F., Fick D., Haeberli W.
Title: High density polarized hydrogen gas target for storage rings
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Philipps-Universität, Fachbereich Physik, 35032 Marburg, Germany; Department of Physics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zapfe, K., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Braun, B., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Gaul, H.-G., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Grieser, M., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Povh, B., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Rall, M., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Steffens, E., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Stock, F., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Tonhäuser, J., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, 69029 Heidelberg, Germany; Montag, C., Philipps-Universität, Fachbereich Physik, 35032 Marburg, Germany; Rathmann, F., Philipps-Universität, Fachbereich Physik, 35032 Marburg, Germany; Fick, D., Philipps-Universität, Fachbereich Physik, 35032 Marburg, Germany; Haeberli, W., Department of Physics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
Abstract: A target of gaseous polarized hydrogen was formed by injecting polarized hydrogen atoms (produced by Stern-Gerlach spin separation) into a storage cell consisting of a cylindrical tube open at both ends. The target was placed in a storage ring to study the target characteristics (nuclear polarization, target thickness, radiation resistance). A weak transverse guide field (5 G) was applied to define the polarization direction. When atoms in a single hyperfine state were selected, the nuclear polarization of the target was measured to be 0.80±0.02. The areal density of the target under these conditions was (5.5±0.2)×1013 H/cm2, while for two spin states (applicable to experiments in high energy rings where a strong magnetic field can be applied to the target) the target thickness was found to be (8.2±0.3)×1013 H/cm2. The target polarization was unaffected by prolonged exposure of the target to beams up to 1 mA. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Tsang K.-L., Lee C.-H., Jean Y.-C., Dann T.-E., Chen J.-R., D'Amico K.L., Oversluizen T.
Title: Wiggler x-ray beamlines at Synchrotron Radiation Research Center
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, Taiwan; X-ray Analytics Ltd., P. O. Box 678, Upton, NY 11973; National Synchrotron Light Source, Upton, NY 11973
Authors with affiliations: Tsang, K.-L., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Lee, C.-H., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Jean, Y.-C., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Dann, T.-E., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chen, J.-R., Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, Taiwan; D'Amico, K.L., X-ray Analytics Ltd., P. O. Box 678, Upton, NY 11973; Oversluizen, T., National Synchrotron Light Source, Upton, NY 11973
Abstract: We have designed three x-ray beamlines extracted out from one 25-pole 1.8 T wiggler insertion device. This wiggler insertion device at the Synchrotron Radiation Research Center 1.3 GeV storage ring will increase the usable x-ray photons with an energy up to 15 keV. In order to satisfy the big x-ray user community at Taiwan, we need to have at least three different types of beamlines to cover various kinds of experiments. Due to limitation of radiation source and space, we have specially designed three x-ray beam lines sharing the 13 mrad horizontal radiation output from the insertion device. The design and construction of these three beamlines will be described in this article. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Kim Y.S., Han K.S., Namkung W., Lee T.N., Kim H.
Title: Present status of the Pohang Light Source
Affiliations: Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), San 31, Hyoja Dong, Pohang, Kyungbuk 790-784, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Y.S., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), San 31, Hyoja Dong, Pohang, Kyungbuk 790-784, South Korea; Han, K.S., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), San 31, Hyoja Dong, Pohang, Kyungbuk 790-784, South Korea; Namkung, W., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), San 31, Hyoja Dong, Pohang, Kyungbuk 790-784, South Korea; Lee, T.N., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), San 31, Hyoja Dong, Pohang, Kyungbuk 790-784, South Korea; Kim, H., Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH), San 31, Hyoja Dong, Pohang, Kyungbuk 790-784, South Korea
Abstract: The Pohang Light Source (PLS) Project is now in its final year of the construction phase. The machine consists of a full energy (2 GeV) linear accelerator injector, a storage ring with a 12-period TBA structure, and 32 eventual beamlines from insertion devices and bending magnets. The commissioning of the injector linac was completed in June 1994. The overall commissioning of the PLS is expected to be completed by the end of 1994. The facility will provide high brightness, tunable radiation in a wide spectral range up to 30 keV of photon energy, and will serve national and international users starting in mid-1995. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Jiang X., Tang E., Xian D.
Title: Beijing synchrotron radiation facility
Affiliations: Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute of High Energy Physics, P.O. Box 918, Beijing, 100039, China
Authors with affiliations: Jiang, X., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute of High Energy Physics, P.O. Box 918, Beijing, 100039, China; Tang, E., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute of High Energy Physics, P.O. Box 918, Beijing, 100039, China; Xian, D., Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Institute of High Energy Physics, P.O. Box 918, Beijing, 100039, China
Abstract: The storage ring for the Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF) is the 1.6-2.8 GeV Beijing Electron-Positron Collider, which was constructed for China's first project on high-energy physics research. The storage ring was designed to be operating either in the colliding mode or in the dedicated synchrotron-radiation mode. The project was approved by the Chinese government at the end of 1983, and was completed in 1989. The Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory was founded in July of 1985, and the construction of the first beam line was completed in 1989. The first phase construction of BSRF was finished in 1991; three beam ports, seven beam lines, and nine experimental stations were constructed. Since 1991, BSRF has been opened to users from all over the country. The description of the beam lines and experimental stations and present research activities is given in this paper. The second phase construction of BSRF as well as the plan of constructing a third-generation new synchrotron-radiation source, the Beijing Light Source, adjacent to BSRF, are described. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Andersson Å., Eriksson M., Lindgren L.-J., Röjsel P., Werin S.
Title: The new 1.5 GeV storage ring for synchrotron radiation: MAX II
Affiliations: MAX-lab, Lund University, P. O. Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, Å., MAX-lab, Lund University, P. O. Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Eriksson, M., MAX-lab, Lund University, P. O. Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Lindgren, L.-J., MAX-lab, Lund University, P. O. Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Röjsel, P., MAX-lab, Lund University, P. O. Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Werin, S., MAX-lab, Lund University, P. O. Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden
Abstract: The MAX laboratory at Lund University, Sweden, today operates an accelerator system consisting of a 100 MeV racetrack microtron and a 550 MeV storage ring (MAX I). At the moment (July 1994) a new storage ring MAX II is near completion and will start first injections within 2 months. This work gives an overview of the MAX II project including the first beamlines and a description of the accelerator system. MAX II is a 1.5 GeV third generation light source optimized for the VUV and soft-x-ray region. It consists of a ten cell double bend achromat lattice forming the 90 m circumference ring. Injection is done at 500 MeV from the existing storage ring MAX I, and ramping up to full energy will take place in MAX II. The straight sections have a length of 3.2 m and eight sections are free to house insertion devices. At start up the ring will be equipped with one 7.5 T superconducting wiggler and one 1.8 T multipole wiggler. Two more undulators are ordered and under construction. To be able to achieve the project a few shortcuts have been made in the design of the storage ring: (1) Nonzero dispersion is allowed in the straight sections, (2) chromaticity correction is built into the quadrupole magnets, and (3) the length of the straight sections is limited to 3.2 m. The project is progressing on time. Extraction of an electron beam from the MAX I storage ring has been achieved and has successfully been transported into the MAX II building. The MAX II ring is under assembly with most of the sections already mounted. First injection is planned to take place in August 1994. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Anghinolfi M., Ripani M., Cenni R., Corvisiero P., Longhi A., Mazzaschi L., Mokeev V., Ricco G., Taiuti M., Teglia A., Zucchiatti A., Bianchi N., Fantoni A., Muccifora V., Levisandri P., Lucherini V., Polli E., Reolon A.R., Rossi P., Simula S.
Title: Inclusive electron scattering from an oxygen and argon jet target
Source title: Journal of Physics G: Nuclear and Particle Physics
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy
Authors with affiliations: Anghinolfi, M., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Ripani, M., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Cenni, R., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Corvisiero, P., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Longhi, A., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Mazzaschi, L., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Mokeev, V., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Ricco, G., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Taiuti, M., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Teglia, A., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Zucchiatti, A., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Bianchi, N., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Fantoni, A., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Muccifora, V., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Levisandri, P., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Lucherini, V., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Polli, E., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Reolon, A.R., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Rossi, P., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy; Simula, S., Dipartimento di Fisica, Genoa Univ., Italy
Abstract: An inclusive electron scattering experiment on 16O and 40Ar is presented. The ADONE electron storage ring, a clustered jet-target and a BGO calorimeter to detect electrons were used. Spectra were collected at beam energies from 0.5 up to 1.5 GeV and at laboratory scattering angles from 32 degrees to 83 degrees . The Coulomb sum rule integrated in the quasi-elastic peak at 570 and 800 MeV/c momentum transfer was measured in 16O and our 40Ar results were compared with the available data on 40Ca.

Authors: Murk V., Yaroshevich N.
Title: Exciton and recombination processes in YAG crystals
Affiliations: Inst. of Phys., Tartu, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Murk, V., Inst. of Phys., Tartu, Estonia; Yaroshevich, N., Inst. of Phys., Tartu, Estonia
Abstract: The excitation spectra of the recombination luminescence of YAG single crystals doped with isovalent impurities of Sc and La are studied. The excitation band of the excitons trapped near impurity ions is observed at 6.7 eV, adjacent to the YAG intrinsic absorption edge. The processes of energy transfer and storage as well as their relation to the problem of the origin of the 4.9 eV emission band (supposed to be self-trapped exciton emission) are studied and discussed. The overlapping of the spectral region of direct creation of excitons with the interband transition edge (causing a metastable character of excitons) is shown. The features of relaxation processes are discussed from the viewpoint of the specificity of the electron structure of complex oxides.

Authors: Gröwe N., Römisch W., Schultz R.
Title: A simple recourse model for power dispatch under uncertain demand
Affiliations: Konrad-Zuse-Zentrum für Informationstechnik Berlin, Heilbronner Straße 10, Berlin, D-10711, Germany; Institut für Mathematik, Humboldt-Universität Berlin, Unter den Linden 6, Berlin, D-10099, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gröwe, N., Konrad-Zuse-Zentrum für Informationstechnik Berlin, Heilbronner Straße 10, Berlin, D-10711, Germany; Römisch, W., Institut für Mathematik, Humboldt-Universität Berlin, Unter den Linden 6, Berlin, D-10099, Germany; Schultz, R., Konrad-Zuse-Zentrum für Informationstechnik Berlin, Heilbronner Straße 10, Berlin, D-10711, Germany
Abstract: Optimal power dispatch under uncertainty of power demand is tackled via a stochastic programming model with simple recourse. The decision variables correspond to generation policies of a system comprising thermal units, pumped storage plants and energy contracts. The paper is a case study to test the kernel estimation method in the context of stochastic programming. Kernel estimates are used to approximate the unknown probability distribution of power demand. General stability results from stochastic programming yield the asymptotic stability of optimal solutions. Kernel estimates lead to favourable numerical properties of the recourse model (no numerical integration, the optimization problem is smooth convex and of moderate dimension). Test runs based on real-life data are reported. We compute the value of the stochastic solution for different problem instances and compare the stochastic programming solution with deterministic solutions involving adjusted demand portions. © 1995 J.C. Baltzer AG, Science Publishers.
Author Keywords: asymptotic stability; Power dispatch under uncertainty; stochastic programming

Authors: Derossi A., Lama F., Piacentini M., Prosperi T., Zema N.

Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy
Abstract: A dedicated beamline with a broad energy range of photons and with high flux and a high degree of circular polarization has been designed for the ELETTRA storage ring. The beamline exploits the circularly polarized radiation produced by an electromagnetic elliptical wiggler and cover the (5-1200) eV photon energy range using a double-incidence spherical grating monochromator. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Munakata Tetsuo, Lior Noam, Tanasawa Ichiro
Title: Study of double-diffusive rollover in cylindrical enclosures
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Munakata, Tetsuo, Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States; Lior, Noam, Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States; Tanasawa, Ichiro, Univ of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, United States
Abstract: The spontaneous destabilization of stably-stratified fluids due to the reversal of the density gradient, caused by heat and/or mass transfer, sometimes in conjunction with evaporation, is known as 'rollover'. This phenomenon occurs in nature and in industrial processes, best known in the storage of liquefied natural gas (LNG). This study models the process by numerically solving the transient momentum, energy, and mass transfer equations for a binary solution in a cylindrical enclosure. Initially the fluid is stably stratified with the upper layer having a higher concentration of the lighter component. Heating through the walls is then applied, resulting in buoyancy-driven convection accompanied by heat and mass transfer, and often finally in rollover. Computations are performed for a Prandtl number of 30, Schmidt number of 5500 and for the range of modified thermal Rayleigh numbers of (1.64)109≤Ra*T≤(9.02)109 and solutal Rayleigh numbers of (4.415)109≤Ras≤(1.776)1010. As expected, the tendency to rollover increases with increasing Ra*T and decreases with increasing Ras. The most important mechanism which triggers rollover is buoyancy-driven penetration of the lower liquid into the upper layer along the heated side wall. The basic phenomena in the cylindrical and rectangular enclosures were found to be similar, but the interface descent velocity and the intensity of mixing in the cylindrical enclosure are higher, resulting in somewhat different times to onset of rollover.
Index Keywords: Calculations; Enclosures; Fluids; Heat transfer; Mass transfer; Natural convection; Numerical analysis; Prandtl number; Thermal conductivity; Thermal stratification; Cylindrical enclosures; Double diffusive rollover; Rayleigh numbers; Schmidt number; Thermodynamic stability

Authors: Jalalzadeh-Azar Ali A., Glenn Steele W., Adebiyi George A.
Title: Performance comparison of high-temperature packed bed operation with PCM and sensible-heat pellets
Affiliations: Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jalalzadeh-Azar, Ali A., Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi, United States; Glenn Steele, W., Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi, United States; Adebiyi, George A., Mississippi State Univ, Mississippi, United States
Abstract: A comparison is made between two specific thermal energy storage materials, zirconium oxide (ZrO2) as a sensible-heat material and a salt/ceramic composite (Na2SO4/SiO2) as a phase change material, for high-temperature applications. Second-law thermodynamic analyses along with material stability tests are employed as criteria for the assessment of these materials. To facilitate the analysis, case studies are presented, and the thermal behavior of the packed bed for each scenario is simulated by an experimentally validated computational model. The case studies are designed to examine the role of the heat of fusion and the material quantity in the thermal performance of the packed bed. For stability evaluation, these materials are exposed to a number of thermal cycles in a high temperature test environment. The zirconium oxide pellets not only offer excellent physical stability but proved to be thermodynamically promising as well.
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Computer simulation; Heat storage; Heat transfer coefficients; High temperature applications; Materials testing; Nusselt number; Prandtl number; Reynolds number; Thermoanalysis; Thermodynamic properties; Zirconium compounds; Heat of fusion; Material stability tests; Phase change material; Sensible-heat pellets; Superficial velocity; Thermal energy storage materials; Packed beds

Authors: Petford-Long A.K., Doole R.C., Afonso C.N., Solís J.
Title: In situ studies of the crystallization kinetics in Sb-Ge films
Affiliations: Department of Materials, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PH, United Kingdom; Instituto de Optica, CSIC, Serrano 121, 28006 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Petford-Long, A.K., Department of Materials, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PH, United Kingdom; Doole, R.C., Department of Materials, University of Oxford, Parks Road, Oxford OX1 3PH, United Kingdom; Afonso, C.N., Instituto de Optica, CSIC, Serrano 121, 28006 Madrid, Spain; Solís, J., Instituto de Optica, CSIC, Serrano 121, 28006 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The crystallization process in SbxGe1-x alloy films has been observed during in situ annealing in a transmission electron microscope. Results are presented for two films with x=0.89 (89 at. % Sb) and x=0.71 (71 at. % Sb), which lie on either side of the eutectic composition (x=0.85). In the former films radial crystals are observed to grow rapidly from discrete nuclei, whereas in the latter films the crystallization process occurs through a near-planar front. In addition, quantitative data obtained from these experiments show that the Sb0.89Ge0.11 films have a higher activation energy for crystal growth and a lower temperature for the nucleation of crystals. Significant differences are observed between the crystallization processes for the two films studied, with the Sb0.89Ge0.11 film showing better potential for development as an ultrafast optical phase-change storage medium. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Gupta D., Donaldson W.R., Kadin A.M.
Title: Rapid flux motion and critical state dynamics in a superconducting disk
Affiliations: Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, D., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Donaldson, W.R., Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14623, United States; Kadin, A.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY 14627, United States
Abstract: A disk of superconducting thin film partially screens an externally applied magnetic field. If the film temperature is increased, the depression of the critical current density allows the excluded flux to move in. When the film is driven to its resistive state by rapid heating, the fast decay of the screening currents results in rapid flux motion. We have developed a numerical technique for analyzing this transient flux motion along with the temporal variation of current density and magnetic field. Our theoretical model has been verified experimentally by heating a high-temperature superconducting film with short laser pulses and by measuring the induced voltage across a coil coupled closely to the film. This concept can be used to make a fast contactless opening switch for high-power applications, such as energy extraction from inductive energy storage systems. © 1995 American Institute of Physics. .

Authors: Zhou G.F., Zwanenburg M.J., Bakker H.
Title: Atomic disorder and phase transformation in L12-Ni3Al by mechanical milling
Affiliations: Van der Waals-Zeeman Laboratorium, Universiteit Van Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, 1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, G.F., Van der Waals-Zeeman Laboratorium, Universiteit Van Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, 1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands; Zwanenburg, M.J., Van der Waals-Zeeman Laboratorium, Universiteit Van Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, 1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands; Bakker, H., Van der Waals-Zeeman Laboratorium, Universiteit Van Amsterdam, Valckenierstraat 65, 1018 XE Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: Mechanical milling of the ordered L12-Ni3Al was performed in a high-energy ball mill. The milling process was monitored by x-ray diffraction, high-field magnetization, ac magnetic susceptibility, and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). It was found that antisite disorder is generated in the early stages of milling and a phase transformation from the disordered L12 compound to the disordered fcc solid solution of Al in Ni was observed after milling for long periods. Partial amorphization occurs after prolonged periods of milling. The long-range-order parameter decreases monotonously with time in the early stages of milling and attains a zero value after relatively short periods of milling. The lattice parameter and the relative strain increase with milling time. Magnetic properties of ball-milled Ni3Al at 4.2 K differ markedly from those of the ordered state. Based on the magnetic data, it is concluded that short-range disordering could be the third source of energy storage during milling of Ni3Al. Exothermic heat effects resulting from atomic reordering and phase restoration and/or crystallization are evident in the DSC scans of ball-milled Ni3Al. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Carr R., Kortright J.B., Rice M., Lidia S.
Title: Performance of the elliptically polarizing undulator on SPEAR
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94309; Center for X-Ray Optics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Physics Department, University of California, Davis, CA 95616
Authors with affiliations: Carr, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford, CA 94309; Kortright, J.B., Center for X-Ray Optics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Rice, M., Center for X-Ray Optics, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Lidia, S., Physics Department, University of California, Davis, CA 95616
Abstract: This is a description of the first tests of the elliptically polarizing undulator (EPU) on the SPEAR storage ring at SSRL. The EPU is the first device of its type; it is capable of producing vertically and horizontally plane-polarized light, and right and left circularly polarized light in the 500-1000 eV range. Tests of the EPU were done to characterize its effect on the electron beam in SPEAR. Even at minimum gap, motion of the EPU magnets to vary the polarization of the output radiation caused negligible changes in the tune or the steering of the electron beam, even with no compensation of the steering trim coils. Also measured was the polarization of x rays generated by the EPU using a newly developed multilayer polarimeter built to be efficient in the EPU's energy range. The EPU produces nearly 100% plane and circularly polarized x rays. Using left and right circularly polarized radiation, tests of magnetic circular dichroism on magnetic multilayers were also performed. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Wende B.
Title: Radiometry with synchrotron radiation
Affiliations: PTB
Authors with affiliations: Wende, B., PTB
Abstract: Electron storage rings are in use or planned for use in the extension of radiometry into ranges of higher photon energies, from the visible spectral region continuously to the x-ray region up to photon energies of at least 100 keV. The storage rings serve as broadband primary standard sources for the development of a source-based radiometry and as sources of tuneable monochromatic photon fluxes for the development of a detector-based radiometry in combination with primary standard detectors. The state of the art is briefly summarized based on results obtained at the Berlin storage ring BESSY I (maximum electron energy 850 MeV), which was optimized for radiometry from the outset. Further progress in radiometry is expected at the future storage ring BESSY II (start of operation in 1998). At this third-generation storage ring (maximum electron energy 1,9 GeV) radiation from undulators, wigglers and wavelength shifters will be used for radiometry in addition to traditional synchrotron radiation from bending magnets. Furthermore, there are prospects at BESSY II to extend radiometry into the γ-ray range with photon energies in the MeV region by scattering laser and undulator photons at stored relativistic electrons.
Index Keywords: Bending magnets; Detector based radiometry; Electron storage rings; Photon energies; Source based radiometry; Undulators; Wavelength shifters; Wigglers; Accelerator magnets; Electron beams; Electrons; Particle detectors; Photons; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Radiometry

Authors: Hartmann R., Lechner P., Strüder L., Scholze F., Ulm G.
Title: The radiation entrance window of pn junction detectors
Affiliations: Max Planck Inst., PTB
Authors with affiliations: Hartmann, R., Max Planck Inst., PTB; Lechner, P., Max Planck Inst., PTB; Strüder, L., Max Planck Inst., PTB; Scholze, F., Max Planck Inst., PTB; Ulm, G., Max Planck Inst., PTB
Abstract: The performance of high-resolution, fully depleted silicon detectors at low photon energies has been found to be dominated by incomplete charge collection due to the pn junction entrance window. Two alternative experimental methods to characterize this behaviour have been investigated by using monochromatized synchrotron radiation at the radiometry laboratory of the Physikalisch- Technische Bundesanstalt with the electron storage ring BESSY: the measurement of the dc photocurrent relative to a calibrated diode and the measurement of the energydispersive response function in the single photon counting mode. Both methods are discussed and compared with a theoretical model including a microscopic description of the photoelectric absorption and a charge-collection probability function.
Index Keywords: Change collection probability function; Energy dispersive response function; Impact ionization; Monochromatized synchrotron radiation; Photocurrent; Photoelectric absorption; Photon energies; pn junction detectors; Pn junction entrance window; Radiation entrance window; Charge carriers; Electron absorption; Ionization; Mathematical models; Performance; Photons; Probability; Radiometry; Semiconductor diodes; Semiconductor junctions; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Silicon sensors

Authors: Thornagel R., Fischer J., Friedrich R., Stock M., Ulm G., Wende B.
Title: The electron storage ring BESSY as a primary standard source - A radiometric comparison with a cryogenic electrical substitution radiometer in the visible
Affiliations: PTB
Authors with affiliations: Thornagel, R., PTB; Fischer, J., PTB; Friedrich, R., PTB; Stock, M., PTB; Ulm, G., PTB; Wende, B., PTB
Abstract: The electron storage ring BESSY in Berlin is used as a primary standard source with a calculable spectral radiant power from the near-infrared to the x-ray region. In order to reduce the uncertainties of the realized radiant power scale, improvements have been made in the measurement of the electron beam current and in the instrumentation of the radiometry laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB). Diffraction at the stray light aperture stops in the beam line, stray light and fluorescence of the exit window were investigated in the visible. Thus, the spectral radiant power can now be realized with a relative uncertainty (1σ level) of 3 × 10 -3 at a photon energy of 15 keV in vacuum and of 8 × 10 -4 in the visible in air behind an exit window. To investigate the agreement with other well-established radiometric primary standards, BESSY was compared in the visible with the highly accurate laser-based cryogenic radiometer of the PTB Berlin, using two filter radiometers (centre wavelengths 676 nm and 800 nm) as transfer standards. The results of four comparison runs confirm the uncertainty of the realized radiant power scale of BESSY in the visible.
Index Keywords: Cryogenic radiometer; Electron storage ring; Spectral radiant power; Transfer standards; Cryogenic equipment; Distance measurement; Electron beams; Radiometers; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Radiometry

Authors: Eschen F., Heyerhoff M., Morgner H., Vogt J.
Title: The concentration-depth profile at the surface of a solution of tetrabutylammonium iodide in formamide, based on angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy
Affiliations: Inst. of Exp. Phys., Witten/Herdecke Univ., Witten, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Eschen, F., Inst. of Exp. Phys., Witten/Herdecke Univ., Witten, Germany; Heyerhoff, M., Inst. of Exp. Phys., Witten/Herdecke Univ., Witten, Germany; Morgner, H., Inst. of Exp. Phys., Witten/Herdecke Univ., Witten, Germany; Vogt, J., Inst. of Exp. Phys., Witten/Herdecke Univ., Witten, Germany
Abstract: We have investigated a solution of tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI) in the polar solvent formamide (FA) using angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy at the Berlin Electron Storage Ring for Synchrotron Radiation (BESSY). The concentration was set to 0.5 molality. We have evaluated the signals from C 1s pertaining to TBAI and FA separately, varying the photon energy between 310 and 540 eV as well as the e-emission angle with respect to the surface normal. The combination of these data with earlier results from ARXPS obtained by Siegbahn and co-workers allowed us to establish a concentration-depth profile of the surface-active salt TBAI. For this purpose we have employed a new theoretical formulation and developed a new elaborate fitting program based on a genetic algorithm. The concentration of the salt could be followed down to a depth of about 45 AA below the surface. Cross sections for the inelastic energy loss of electrons in the liquid could be established as a function of electron energy. Comparison with conventional surface tension measurements allowed us to derive absolute values for the cross sections.
Index Keywords: Concentration depth profile; Formamide; Inelastic energy; Molality; Tetrabutylammonium iodide; Electron energy levels; Energy dissipation; Genetic algorithms; Photoelectron spectroscopy; Photons; Solutions; Solvents; Storage rings; Surface active agents; Surface tension; Surfaces; Ammonium compounds

Authors: Steffes Dale W.
Title: Natural gas industry faces more uncertainty in the upcoming decade
Source title: Strategic Planning for Energy and the Environment
Affiliations: Planning & Forecasting, Consultants
Authors with affiliations: Steffes, Dale W., Planning & Forecasting, Consultants
Abstract: The natural gas industry in the US faces more turmoil in the next decade than in the previous decade. While energy experts were not totally accurate in 1984, they did foresee some of the many discontinuities that took place in the natural gas industry during the past decade. The monumental discontinuity of the past decade in the natural gas industry was change of the interstate gas pipeline industry from serving a merchant function to a common carrier function. The main reason for this change was due to a past strategic error on the part of the interstate pipeline companies. This strategic mistake essentially bankrupted all of the companies. Their submittal to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) forced them to allow open access on their pipelines. The FERC then allowed them to buy their way out of their bad take.
Index Keywords: Electric utilities; Energy policy; Fuel storage; Laws and legislation; Marketing; Natural gas pipelines; Petroleum industry; Purchasing; Deregulation; Gas pipeline industry; Natural gas industry; Outsourcing; Natural gas

Authors: Kondracki S., Glowinski S.
Title: Adenine nucleotide metabolites in the ischemically injured rat kidney
Affiliations: Dept. Vasc. Surg. and Transplantol., University School of Medicine, 24a M. Sklodowskiej-Curie Street, 15-276 Bialystok, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Kondracki, S., Dept. Vasc. Surg. and Transplantol., University School of Medicine, 24a M. Sklodowskiej-Curie Street, 15-276 Bialystok, Poland; Glowinski, S., Dept. Vasc. Surg. and Transplantol., University School of Medicine, 24a M. Sklodowskiej-Curie Street, 15-276 Bialystok, Poland
Abstract: The number of the kidneys harvested from heart-beating (HB) donors is currently decreasing in Poland as well as all over the world. Thus organs harvested from so-called non-heart-beating (NHB) donors are going in importance. The aim of the study was to investigate adenine nucleotide compound concentrations in kidneys ischemically damaged due to preservation methods. 40 kidneys were harvested from 20 adult male inbred Lewis rats. The organs were divided into 4 groups. The normal (control) kidneys were included in group I, the kidneys after 30 min. of warm ischemia (WI) in group II, the kidneys after 30 min. of WI and 24 hours of simple cold storage in UW solution in group m and kidneys after 30 min. of WI and 24 hours of 4°C machine perfusion in UW solution in group IV. The concentration of adenine nucleotides (ATP, ADP, AMP) and their degradation products in the kidney tissue were determined by high-performance liquid chromatography. The study showed that the amount of ATP and AMP decreases in the ischemically damaged kidneys tissue during 24 hours of hypothermic preservation. Kidneys preserved in the simple cold storage showed an increase of adenine nucleotide degradation products and nucleotide pool, in contrast hypothermic machine perfusion resulted in a flushing of the degradation products subsequently a decrease in the nucleotide pool. We conclude that catabolism of high energy metabolites and exogenous adenosine occurs during both methods of hypothermic kidney preservation.
Index Keywords: adenine nucleotide; adenosine; adenosine diphosphate; adenosine phosphate; adenosine triphosphate; animal tissue; article; high performance liquid chromatography; kidney perfusion; kidney transplantation; male; nonhuman; organ preservation; rat

Authors: Kishimoto T., Sayama H., Takai M., Ohno Y., Sonoda K., Nishimura T., Kinomura A., Horino Y., Fujii K.
Title: Suppression of ion-induced charge collection by high-energy B+-implanted layer
Affiliations: Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kishimoto, T., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Sayama, H., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Takai, M., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Ohno, Y., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Sonoda, K., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Nishimura, T., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Kinomura, A., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Horino, Y., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan; Fujii, K., Osaka Univ, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Control of charge carrier collection by high-energy boron-implanted layers has been investigated to clarify the validity of buried well structures against soft errors in dynamic random-access memories (DRAMs) by ion-induced-current measurements using high-energy proton microprobes. A finely focused 1.3 MeV proton beam has been used to irradiate normal to n+p diodes with buried layers fabricated by B+ implantation at 160 - 1000 keV and to doses of 1 × 1012 - 1 × 1013 ions/cm2, and reverse-biased at 1 to 5 V. The measured current was induced by carriers generated by ion microprobes. The collection of charge carriers induced by microprobe irradiation could be reduced by a buried layer formed by boron implantation. It was found that the rate of charge collection depended not on the depth but on the implantation dose of the buried layer. The carrier collection efficiency of the n+p diode with twin wells (i.e., a retrograde well) was two thirds of that with a conventional well.
Index Keywords: Electric current measurement; Fabrication; Ion implantation; Irradiation; Random access storage; Semiconductor diodes; Buried layers; Buried well structures; High energy boron implanted layers; Ion induced charged collection; Ion microprobes; Charge carriers

Authors: Yang Sheng-Hui, Smith Suzanne, Fitz John, Lee Chi H.
Title: Generation of high power gain-switched pulses from a two-section ridge-waveguide laser diode with a laterally tapered energy-storage section
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Lasers and Electro-Optics Society Annual Meeting-LEOS
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yang, Sheng-Hui, Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Smith, Suzanne, Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Fitz, John, Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States; Lee, Chi H., Univ of Maryland, College Park, United States
Abstract: The achievable pulse energy of a gain-switched single-section laser is mainly limited by the amplitude and abruptness of the initial carrier overshoot and by the nonlinear gain compression factor. One possible way to increase the pulse energy is to add an energy storage element to a gain-switched device. This can be implemented by using a multi-section structure. This paper reports the generation of gain-switched picosecond laser pulses with energies above 20 pJ and peak powers around 1 W from a simple two-section ridge-waveguide laser. This type of devices can be used as compact sources in energy-demanding applications such as photoconductive switching and optical soliton generation without the need of post-amplification.

Authors: Le Berre P.
Title: Space charge influence generated by electronic beam on insulator secondary emission
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, Bruyeres le Chatel, France
Authors with affiliations: Le Berre, P., Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, Bruyeres le Chatel, France
Abstract: The effect of space charge development on secondary emission of insulators irradiated by electronic beam is studied. Experiments are driven by checking up electron beam energy (keV), current density (A/cm2), dose of charges (pC), current (pA) and sample's temperature. Several effects, not observed by now in insulator electronic emission studies, are taken into account. Experimental evidences are about the temporal fluctuations of secondary emission during experimental sequence, the existence of a critical storage energy from which a non classical electron-material interaction is observed, the releasing of breakdown and flashover processes depending on electrostatic field, the effect of temperature on charge trapping. The interpretation of these results need to know: 1- The spatial beam implanted charge distribution 2- The effect of the double layer (positive layer in depth corresponding to secondary electron exhausting distance, negative layer due to trapping of the thermalized primary electrons) 3- The effect of the storage energy in a dielectric under three simultaneous stresses (thermal, electrical, mechanical) on material structural stability.
Index Keywords: Current density; Electric breakdown; Electric charge; Electric fields; Electric insulators; Electron beams; Electron emission; Electrostatics; Flashover; Relaxation processes; Stresses; Thermal effects; Charge distribution; Charge trapping; Dielectric process; Dose of charges; Electron beam energy; Inelastic electron insulator interaction; Material structural stability; Secondary emission; Temporal fluctuations; Electric space charge

Authors: Zhuang Xinhua
Title: Relaxation labeling and associative memory
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Neural Networks - Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri, Columbia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhuang, Xinhua, Univ of Missouri, Columbia, United States
Abstract: This paper attempts to consolidate the theoretical foundation of the relaxation labeling processes, explore the connections between the relaxation labeling model and the Hopfield associative memory model, and seek for their unification. We start by defining a new labeling assignment space and then formulating relaxation labeling process as a dynamic system of Lyapunov type, which is equipped with a well defined energy function and described by a naturally fitted updating rule. We present consistency condition and show each ω - limit point of the dynamic system gives a consistent labeling. We finally make a peace between the multi-label and one-label relaxation labeling and reveal an interesting result that, for a one-label case, the newly formulated relaxation labeling model reduces to the Hopfield associative memory model.
Index Keywords: Associative storage; Computer vision; Error correction; Lyapunov methods; Mathematical models; Hopfield associative memory model; Labeling assignment space; Relaxation labeling processes; Neural networks

Authors: Ko Uming, Balsara P.T.
Title: Characterization and design of a low-power, high-performance cache architecture
Source title: International Symposium on VLSI Technology, Systems, and Applications, Proceedings
Affiliations: Texas Instruments Inc, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ko, Uming, Texas Instruments Inc, Dallas, United States; Balsara, P.T., Texas Instruments Inc, Dallas, United States
Abstract: We present results of characterization of power dissipation in on-chip cache memories. Details of power dissipated in different sub-circuits are presented. These results reveal that the memory peripherals and bit array dissipate comparable power. To optimize performance and power of a processor's cache, a multi-divided module (MDM) cache architecture is proposed to save power at memory peripherals as well as the bit array. Comparisons of MDM with conventional cache architectures for energy utilization and performance are presented.

Authors: Cross J.Kevin, Beckman William A., Mitchell John W., Reindl Douglas T., Knebel David E.
Title: Modeling of hybrid combustion turbine inlet air cooling systems
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cross, J.Kevin, Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Beckman, William A., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Mitchell, John W., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Reindl, Douglas T., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Knebel, David E., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States
Abstract: Thermal energy storage has been proposed as a viable cost-effective capacity enhancement method when applied to cool inlet air for combustion turbines. Emphasis has been placed on the use of ice-only thermal energy storage systems for inlet air cooling. In this paper, the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of ice storage compared with chilled water storage, hybrid (ice/chilled water) storage, and evaporative cooling are explored. Detailed mechanistic models of a combustion gas turbine, ice harvester, chiller, and associated storage components are developed and calibrated using manufacturer's data. The performance of different systems with a series of four power plant load profiles is determined by simulation. Appropriate storage systems are sized to provide inlet air cooling for a combustion turbine dispatched to meet the load profiles. Capacity enhancement costs are determined for chilled water storage, ice storage, and the hybrid storage systems providing inlet air cooling for the combustion turbine.

Abstract: The soft-error evaluation method using the nuclear microprobe is demonstrated for the first time. In particular, the method is used to quantitatively investigate the role of buried p+ layers and against the charge collection into n+ layer in the well structure. Results obtained in this investigation are validated by simulation results. Basing from the results, it is concluded that the presented evaluation method gives the principle to optimize the well structure for the soft-error immunity of advanced DRAMs. 1
