Authors: Morash Richard T.
Title: Improved power quality with 'written-pole' motor-generators and motors
Affiliations: Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morash, Richard T., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Abstract: Written-Pole motor-generators and motors improve power quality because the magnetic pattern of rotor field poles can be changed while the machines operate. Applied in a motor-generator set, pole writing allows the generator to produce high quality constant frequency output at variable speed. The motor efficiently operates its own high inertial energy rotor as a flywheel energy storage device. The M-G set provides continuous on-line isolation between the electrical distribution system and load. It also rides through blackouts of 15 seconds or more while supplying full load at exact frequency and regulated voltage. Rotating flywheel energy is used, thereby eliminating the need for batteries for uninterruptible power. Power quality is also improved for the electrical distribution system because the generator prevents harmonic feedback. The motor is a unity power factor load with negligible harmonics and has added advantages of high efficiency and very low inrush current during across-the-line starts. Mechanical loads such as pumps and fans can be driven by written-pole motors. These can also have advantages of load ride-through during momentary power interruptions and can instantly restart. Additionally, low starting current significantly reduces voltage sags on the distribution system, improving power quality. Such motors are being developed in single-phase with the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI) and member utilities. The paper describes the benefits for power quality as a result of written-pole machines.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric motor generator sets; Electric motors; Electric power distribution; Electric power factor; Energy storage; Flywheels; Rotors (windings); Starting; Voltage control; Flywheel energy storage device; Unity power factor; Written pole motor generators; Electric machinery

Authors: Aulagner E., Guillet J., Seytre G., Hantouche C., Le Gonidec P., Terzulli G.
Title: (PVDF/BaTiO3) and (PP/BaTiO3) films for energy storage capacitors

Abstract: Nowadays, many studies encourage the use of films filled with ceramic for energy storage applications. This paper, reports on films based on PVDF/BaTiO3 or PP/BaTiO3 which are prepared using a modular twin screw extruder. For energy storage capacitor, the best results are obtained with the PVDF matrix. Considering a functional dielectric strength equals to 100 V/μm, the energy density reaches 0,13 Wh/kg for a filler volume content of 30%. It is low compared to a battery, but the capacitor to accumulator energy ration is now 1/460. Such product may be suitable for energy storage applications.

Title: 0.29-μm2 trench cell technologies for 1G-bit DRAMs with open/folded-bit-line layout and selective growth technique
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - Symposium on VLSI Technology
Affiliations: Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Noguchi, M., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Ozaki, T., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Aoki, M., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Hamamoto, T., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Habu, M., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Kato, Y., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Takigami, Y., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Shibata, T., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Nakasugi, T., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Niiyama, H., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Tokano, K., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Saito, Y., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Hoshi, T., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Watanabe, S., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan
Abstract: We present substrate-plate-trench cell technologies for 1G-bit DRAMs. With an open/folded-bit-line layout, the smallest cell area of 0.29 μm2 was realized for a 0.20 μm design rule. A pause time of 4.2 s at 85 °C and an activation energy of 0.70 eV were achieved for a 0.25-μm Φ x 4-μm trench capacitor. A new Si selective epitaxial growth (SEG) technique was developed to reduce connection formation between the capacitor and transistor to one fabrication step, and also reduce a distance between the trench and gate. The gate capacitors on the SEG showed a breakdown electric field over 11MV/cm even when the distance was less than 0.1μm.

Authors: Spaeth J.M., Hangleiter T., Koschnick F.K., Pawlik T.
Title: X-ray storage phosphors
Source title: Radiation Effects and Defects in Solids
Affiliations: Universitat-GH Paderborn, Fachbereich Physik, 33095 Paderborn, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Spaeth, J.M., Universitat-GH Paderborn, Fachbereich Physik, 33095 Paderborn, Germany; Hangleiter, T., Universitat-GH Paderborn, Fachbereich Physik, 33095 Paderborn, Germany; Koschnick, F.K., Universitat-GH Paderborn, Fachbereich Physik, 33095 Paderborn, Germany; Pawlik, T., Universitat-GH Paderborn, Fachbereich Physik, 33095 Paderborn, Germany
Abstract: In X-ray storage phosphors an image is formed and stored by generation of room temperature stable radiation-induced electron and hole trap centres. The image is read-out by recording a photo-stimulated luminescence (PSL) from a doped activator, generally stimulating the electron trap centres. The best-known and hitherto most efficient X-ray storage phosphor is BaFBr:Eu2+. However, the exact mechanism of its functioning is not yet understood. The present discussion of the storage and read-out mechanisms is critically reviewed. New results about the role of oxygen contamination of BaFBr:Eu2+are presented: If there is much less oxygen present than Eu2+, then the PSL efficiency decreases and the stimulation energy increases. A new efficient X-ray storage phosphor is presented: Cs2NaYF6doped with trivalent rare earth activators. Its properties are described and preliminary results on X-radiation-induced radiation damage centres in undoped Cs2NaYF6are presented. © 1995, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: elpasolites; fluorohalides; ODEPR; Phosphors; radiation damage; X-ray imaging

Authors: Nara Koichi, Hasegawa Jun
Title: Advanced flexible and reliable distribution system
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Ibaraki Univ, Ibaraki, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nara, Koichi, Ibaraki Univ, Ibaraki, Japan; Hasegawa, Jun, Ibaraki Univ, Ibaraki, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, the authors propose a new concept of electrical power distribution system named 'Flexible, Reliable and Intelligent and Energy coNservative Distribution System (FRIENDS)'. In the near future, electrical power systems will be facilitated by dispersed energy resources and dispersed energy storages on the demand side. The electrical power distribution system itself will have to be changed to cope with these facilities. The authors propose a flexible power distribution system for such a situation. Noticeable characteristics for the proposed system (FRIENDS) are flexible network reconfiguration for uninterrupted power supply through power electronics devices, new protective relaying schemes, on-line information service to customers (including automated metering), DSM and home automation as well as multi-quality power supply. In this paper, the new concept of the power distribution system of FRIENDS is explained, and how the new functions can be realized is discussed.

Authors: Pessotto P., Liberati R., Petrella O., Hulsmann W.C.
Title: Alteration of tissue carnitine content following anaesthesia with barbiturate and surgery in rat
Source title: International Journal of Clinical Pharmacology Research
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, Sigma-Tau S.p.A., Km 30.400 Via Pontina, 00040 Pomezia, Rome, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Pessotto, P., Department of Biochemistry, Sigma-Tau S.p.A., Km 30.400 Via Pontina, 00040 Pomezia, Rome, Italy; Liberati, R., Department of Biochemistry, Sigma-Tau S.p.A., Km 30.400 Via Pontina, 00040 Pomezia, Rome, Italy; Petrella, O., Department of Biochemistry, Sigma-Tau S.p.A., Km 30.400 Via Pontina, 00040 Pomezia, Rome, Italy; Hulsmann, W.C., Department of Biochemistry, Sigma-Tau S.p.A., Km 30.400 Via Pontina, 00040 Pomezia, Rome, Italy
Abstract: The hypercatabolic state leads to urinary carnitine loss. Anaesthesia and surgical intervention cause stress conditions. The stress is accompanied by the alteration of hormone states and energy processes. Carnitine, which physiologically promotes the fatty acid metabolism and so plays a very important role for the heart, can be involved in these alterations. The aim of this study was to examine the effects of anaesthesia and surgical intervention on carnitine distribution in the tissues. Rats were anaesthetized with thiopental and surgical intervention was performed on the femoral artery and vein. Carnitine levels, as well as parameters indicative of energy metabolism, were measured in the blood and tissues. It was found that anaesthesia and surgical intervention increased the corticosterone levels in blood and decreased the carnitine levels in blood and kidney. Carnitine accumulated in the liver, whereas in heart and skeletal muscle it was redistributed by a decrease in the acylated form and an increase in the free form. Glycogen was accumulated in cardiac and skeletal muscle. Compared to anaesthesia, the surgical intervention increased glycogen storage and carnitine redistribution in heart and skeletal muscle. Moreover, it caused a decrease in cholesterol and an increase in urea in the blood. The fall in blood and kidney carnitine levels indicates a possible depletion of carnitine. The deacylation of carnitine in heart and skeletal muscle represents an important alteration in heart and muscle energetic metabolism. The increase in urea is a consequence of high proteolysis. Acylcarnitine administration during pre- and operative step might prevent the loss of carnitine, promoting the heart energetic metabolism and reducing the proteolysis. Moreover, in accordance with a recent interpretation of carnitine action as a membrane-stabilizing agent, the acylcarnitine supply could reduce the risk of 'oedema' that follows the anaesthesia and surgical intervention.
Index Keywords: anesthetic agent; carnitine; thiopental; amino acid analysis; amino acid metabolism; anesthesia induction; animal experiment; animal model; article; deacylation; femoral artery; femoral vein; intraperitoneal drug administration; male; nonhuman; rat; tissue distribution; vascular surgery; Anesthetics, Intravenous; Animals; Carnitine; Corticosterone; Femoral Artery; Femoral Vein; Glucose; Kidney; Male; Muscle, Skeletal; Myocardium; Rats; Rats, Wistar; Stress; Surgical Procedures, Operative; Thiopental

Abstract: This paper describes an inductive energy storage system for the production of pulsed power, that is light weight and more compact than the more familiar capacitive system. The overall system contains two stages of pulse conditioning, a foil followed by a plasma erosion opening switch, and can provide an output of 200kA at 100kV.

Authors: Lachs W.R., Sutanto D.
Title: Uncertainty in electricity supply controlled by energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Univ of NSW, Sydney, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Lachs, W.R., Univ of NSW, Sydney, Australia; Sutanto, D., Univ of NSW, Sydney, Australia
Abstract: The hour by hour changes of demand cannot be accurately forecast because consumers are free to switch appliances at any instant. The greatest uncertainty are posed by the peak periods even though they are of short duration and only use a small proportion of daily energy consumption. Sufficient quantities of Energy Storage could curtail daily peak demand changes so permitting replacement of demand forecasting by more predictable daily energy forecasts. Not only would it eliminate peaking generation and simplify generator scheduling, but it would also produce a single daily tariff and allow easier financial planning for power system development. The Electricity Supply Industry would incur capital and operating expenditures for the entire power network and additional generators of $6000 to $7000 for each kW of peak demand growth. This expense could be avoided by Battery Energy Storage Systems which could curtail peak demand at a cost of $2000 per kW so gaining savings of $4 to $5 billion for a period with 1000MW growth of peak demand.
Index Keywords: Daily tariff; Load demand forecasting; Uncertainty; Electric generators; Electric load flow; Electric load forecasting; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Outages; Planning; Probability; Reliability; Scheduling; Electric load management

Authors: Litvinenko Vladimir N., Madey John M.
Title: High-power inverse Compton y-ray source at the Duke storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Duke Univ., Durham, NC, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Litvinenko, Vladimir N., Duke Univ., Durham, NC, USA, United States; Madey, John M., Duke Univ., Durham, NC, USA, United States
Abstract: A 1.1 GeV electron storage ring dedicated for UV-VUV FEL operation was commissioned last year at the Duke University Free Electron Laser Laboratory (DFELL). The UV-VUV OK-4 FEL project, based on the collaboration of the Duke FEL Laboratory and Budker Institute for Nuclear Physics (BINP, Novosibirsk, Russia) is under way. The OK-4 FEL has arrived at the Duke FEL Laboratory from Novosibirsk and is in the process of installation. High average intracavity power and natural synchronization of electron and optical pulses in the OK-4 FEL allow the production of intense inverse Compton γ-rays (5-150 MeV) on the return pass of the optical pulse. The projected intensity of this γ-ray source allows high energy resolution with simple geometric collimation of the γ-rays. The wide tunability of the OK-4 FEL also allows us to control the γ-ray energy. In this paper we discuss the processes involved in γ-ray production, the influence of beam parameters and geometry on γ-ray energy spread, and present projected performance of the Duke/OK-4 inverse Compton γ-ray source for two simple cases. The studies reported in this paper were performed in 1993. Results were presented at the 1994 Free Electron Laser Conference (22-26 August 1994, Stanford, CA) but were published only as internal DFELL reports. A group of scientists from the Triangle University Nuclear Laboratory (TUNL) also ran independent simulations in 1994 which confirm our predictions. A workshop on the DFELL-TUNL γ-ray facility was held in Durham from December 16-17, 1994 to discuss unique features of this facility and its utilization for nuclear physics and pion spectroscopy.
Index Keywords: Duke storage ring; Inverse Compton gamma sources; Electron accelerators; Free electron lasers; Laser pulses; Nuclear physics; Storage rings; Ultraviolet radiation; Gamma rays

Authors: Moser Alfred, Schalin Alois, Off Frank, Yuan Xiaoxiong
Title: Numerical modeling of heat transfer by radiation and convection in an atrium with thermal inertia
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Moser, Alfred, Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Schalin, Alois, Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Off, Frank, Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland; Yuan, Xiaoxiong, Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: The thermal comfort and buoyancy-induced motion of air in a room are determined by the interaction of different types of heat transfer and of thermal storage in building components. Heat transfer includes energy transport by radiation, convection, and conduction (within air and the building fabric). The driving forces of buoyancy of air become more pronounced for tall spaces. Therefore, proper modeling of these interactions becomes more crucial in the design of large enclosures. In atria, in particular, solar and infrared radiation are important because of large-area glazing. The boundary conditions for airflow, surface-to-surface radiation, and building dynamics are linked by surface temperatures that may vary in time and space. Numerical methods for the direct coupling of computational fluid dynamics with thermal dynamics and radiation are proposed and demonstrated at a case study building of IEA Annex 26.

Title: Electrostatic properties of insulating sheets close to a conductor: a review

Abstract: Dielectric sheets and films are used in various forms in a large number of industrial applications. The important electrostatic properties of such sheets are reviewed to highlight the significance of the surface potential, the electric field within and adjacent to the sheet and the electric energy stored. Selected industrial examples in the fields of electrophotography, electrostatic painting and materials handling are discussed. A case study of a specific industrial problem involving charge retention on plastic boxes treated in an ac corona discharge is described.

Abstract: Hybrid generation systems are nowadays increasingly considered as a viable solution to obtain savings of oil consumptions in small isolated grid. This paper deals with the analysis of several layouts of a hybrid generation system prototype. The problem of energy flows among the components of hybrid generating systems, that is strongly related to the grid configuration, is considered. Moreover, it is shown that high efficiencies and economic advantages are strictly related to the management strategy. Analysis and comparison among four possible configurations, with all components mainly delivering energy on a DC bus or on an AC bus, are presented and discussed in detail.

Title: Intrinsic oscillations in resonant tunneling structures
Affiliations: U.S. Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Authors with affiliations: Woolard, D.L., U.S. Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Brown, E.R., U.S. Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Buot, F.A., U.S. Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Lu, X.J., U.S. Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Rhodes, D.L., U.S. Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States; Perlman, B.S., U.S. Army Research Lab, Fort Monmouth, United States
Abstract: A comprehensive study was recently performed of various nonlinear second-order circuit forms in an effort to reproduce the high-frequency self-oscillations observed in previous quantum-transport simulations of a resonant tunneling diode structure. A comparison between these two theoretical results allows one to deduce intrinsic oscillations which are free of external resonances. These studies show that a series-resonance effect can not simultaneously explain the hysteresis and oscillatory behavior predicted by the intrinsic quantum simulations. On the other hand, a parallel-resonance effect can reproduce all the important features present if nonlinearity is properly incorporated into the 'access' resistance and energy-storage elements.

Title: MeV radiography: storage phosphors imaging plate adaptations

Abstract: OSL (optically stimulated luminescence/photostimulated luminescence-PSL-) storage phosphors imaging plates are well known to present advantages in terms of sensitivity, spatial resolution, linearity, and signal dynamics in comparison with classical 'scintillating screen-film' packs for radiology (soft x-rays). Are these OSL so useful for high energy (MeV) radiography (non destructive testing or flash radiography)? Experiments show that only linearity and dynamics are better than those of screen-film cells. We present some improvement directions for this promising imager: metallic screens, thicker OSL plate, densification, sensitization methods.

Authors: Rambaut C., Oh K.H., Jaffrezik H., Kohanoff G., Fayeulle S.
Title: Molecular dynamics simulation of the trapping of electrons in sapphire lattice
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: Ecole Centrale de Lyon, Ecully, France
Authors with affiliations: Rambaut, C., Ecole Centrale de Lyon, Ecully, France; Oh, K.H., Ecole Centrale de Lyon, Ecully, France; Jaffrezik, H., Ecole Centrale de Lyon, Ecully, France; Kohanoff, G., Ecole Centrale de Lyon, Ecully, France; Fayeulle, S., Ecole Centrale de Lyon, Ecully, France
Abstract: The mechanism of electric charge trapping can be used to describe the storage of energy in dielectric materials. The analysis of the mechanism has been obtained by the space charge physics [1,2]. Technical simulation such as molecular dynamics applied to this problem allows us to complete the preceding results with a dynamic approach. We show that an excess electron introduced into the sapphire lattice (α-Al2O3) can be trapped only at a limited number of sites. The energy gained by allowing the electron to localize in these sites is of the order of 4-5 eV, in good agreement with the results of the space charge model. Displacements of the neighboring ions due to the implanted charge are shown to be localized in a small region of about 5 angstrom. Detrapping is observed at 250 K. The ionic displacements turn out to play an important role in modifying the potential landscape by lowering, in a dynamical way, the barriers that cause localization at low temperature.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Crystal lattices; Electric energy storage; Electric space charge; Electrons; Ion implantation; Ions; Low temperature effects; Mathematical models; Polarization; Sapphire; Detrapping; Electric charge trapping; Modified shell model; Solvated electron; Space charge model; Molecular dynamics

Abstract: Some design considerations for small, flyback transformers are presented. These transformers are used to charge energy storage capacitors to 0.1 to 5 KV from a low voltage DC source. Authors: Izumi Teruyuki, Boyagoda Prasanna, Nakaoka Mutsuo, Hiraki Eiji
Title: Optimal control of a servo system regenerating conservative energy to a condenser
Source title: International IEEE/IAS Conference on Industrial Automation and Control: Emerging Technologies, Proceedings
Affiliations: Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Izumi, Teruyuki, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Boyagoda, Prasanna, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nakaoka, Mutsuo, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan; Hiraki, Eiji, Yamaguchi Univ, Yamaguchi, Japan
Abstract: An Optimal controller for a servo system with a manipulator is developed. The emphasis is on the minimization of the overall energy consumption of the system. The optimum current function is obtained under the minimization criteria of the consumption energy for a manipulator under gravity conditions and otherwise. The solution to the two-point-boundary-value-problem is obtained by using the Generalized Newton-Raphson method. Further when the link of the manipulator is decelerated, the generated electric power from the motor is stored in a condenser. This is achieved while supplying the optimal current by using a DC Chopper circuit. It is shown from experiment that the efficiency of energy storage is improved by increasing the capacitance of the condensers. The overall energy is shown to decrease by this method.

Authors: Crosa G., Ferrari G., Torelli A., Troilo M.
Title: Non linear and linearized model of a heavy-duty gas turbine plant
Affiliations: Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi, Energetici, Genova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Crosa, G., Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi, Energetici, Genova, Italy; Ferrari, G., Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi, Energetici, Genova, Italy; Torelli, A., Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi, Energetici, Genova, Italy; Troilo, M., Istituto di Macchine e Sistemi, Energetici, Genova, Italy
Abstract: This paper considers the single-shaft, variable inlet guide vane (VIGV), heavy-duty 65 MW gas turbine, suitable for gas-steam combined units. Through the use of a non linear lumped-parameters model, the dynamic behaviour has been investigated in the time domain, and then reported in the frequency domain using the transfer functions of the linearized model. Every plant component (compressor, combustion chamber, turbine) has been included as a block, when considering the evolving flow subjected to mass, momentum and energy storage, building in this way a mathematical model made of 13 first order ordinary differential equations and 26 algebraic equations. The turbomachinery characteristics are represented as polynomial curves: the compressor flow and efficiency maps are given for selected inlet guide vane (IGV) opening values. For the dynamic study, the thermo-fluid-dynamic upstream and downstream conditions have been evaluated for each block, choosing proper status variables. Significant results are obtained by analysing, after the linearization (done for many different operating points and utilising also an original method), the four most important transfer functions for plant control, which link the rotational speed and exhaust temperature with fuel flow and IGV opening angle. From the results, one can see that the quasi-linearity of the real system is not checked for any transfer function; this occurrence has to be considered when using the linearized model for setting up the control system (for instance, in the rpm-IGV angle transfer function the static gain sign is variable with the operating point).
Index Keywords: Compressors; Control systems; Differential equations; Flow of fluids; Frequency domain analysis; Linearization; Mathematical models; Nozzles; Polynomials; Time domain analysis; Transfer functions; Turbomachinery; Nonlinear lumped parameters model; Thermo-fluid-dynamic stream conditions; Variable inlet guide vane; Gas turbine power plants

Title: Scientific data management in the Environmental Molecular Sciences Laboratory

Abstract: The Environmental Molecular Sciences Laboratory (EMSL) is being constructed for use in molecular and environmental sciences research to identify comprehensive solutions to the U.S. Department of Energy's environmental problems. It is anticipated that at least six terabytes of data will be archived in the first year of operation. An object oriented database management system (OODBMS) and a mass storage system will be integrated to provide an intelligent, automated mechanism to manage data. Authors: Yamada M., Fukusako S., Kim M.H.
Title: Melting heat transfer characteristics of liquid ice in a rectangular enclosure heated from above
Affiliations: Hokkaido Univ, Sapporo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamada, M., Hokkaido Univ, Sapporo, Japan; Fukusako, S., Hokkaido Univ, Sapporo, Japan; Kim, M.H., Hokkaido Univ, Sapporo, Japan
Abstract: An experiment is conducted to characterize the melting heat transfer of constrained liquid ice in a rectangular vessel with top-heated wall. Within the parameter range covered, there exists necessarily the liquid melt between the top-heated wall and the melting interface, in which heat transport is mainly dominated by conduction. Some of fine ice particles depart from the melting interface to ascend along with their melting through the liquid melt, which gives marked influence on the transport process and hence constrains the increase in temperatures of both the liquid melt and the top-heated wall. Because the temperature of the top-heated wall does not increase in proportion to heat flux, the average heat transfer coefficient increases with increasing heat flux. At the initial stage of melting, the average heat transfer coefficient decreases with an increase in initial solution concentration, while the difference among the values of the average heat transfer coefficient becomes small to be neglected as the time elapses.
Index Keywords: Heat conduction; Heat flux; Heat transfer; Heat transfer coefficients; Ice; Phase interfaces; Temperature distribution; Walls (structural partitions); Ice-storage systems; Liquid ice; Liquid melt; Melting interface; Phase change materials; Solid phase; Solid-liquid phase; Thermal energy; Top heated wall; Melting

Authors: Kintner-Meyer Michael, Emery Ashley F.
Title: Cost optimal analysis and load shifting potentials of cold storage equipment
Affiliations: Science Applications Int Corp, McLean, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kintner-Meyer, Michael, Science Applications Int Corp, McLean, United States; Emery, Ashley F., Science Applications Int Corp, McLean, United States
Abstract: Cold storage systems are sized on the basis of economic considerations and constraints imposed by the cooling system components. In this study, a cost optimal analysis is presented for sizing cold storage equipment and a chiller. The analysis is based on life-cycle costs with energy rates for the City of Seattle. The optimal operating protocol for storage charging and discharging is determined by a dynamic programming method that minimizes the operating cost over an entire year. A sensitivity analysis is presented to provide insights into the importance of electricity rates and demand charges as they affect the optimal size of the storage and the chiller. Due to the extensive computation times for a whole year's optimization, a reduction of the time horizon was investigated. The paper also discusses the economics of reducing the electric power demand during peak periods in terms of the reduction of peak electric power (kW) and electric energy (kWh). The paper will discuss the incremental cost for implementing full storage operation in which the entire cooling load is produced during off-peak hours.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Costs; Dynamic programming; Economics; Optimization; Sensitivity analysis; Chiller; Cost optimal analysis; Electric power demand; Seattle; Cold storage

Authors: Grätzel M.
Title: Low cost and efficient photovoltaic conversion by nanocrystalline solar cells
Source title: Proceedings of the Indian Academy of Sciences - Chemical Sciences
Affiliations: Institut de Chimie Physique, Ecole polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne, Lausanne, Ch-1015, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Grätzel, M., Institut de Chimie Physique, Ecole polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne, Lausanne, Ch-1015, Switzerland
Abstract: The quality of human life depends to a large degree on the availability of energy sources. The present worldwide energy consumption already exceeds the level of 6000 gigawatt and is expected to further increase sharply. This implies enhanced depletion of fossil fuel reserves, leading to further aggravation of the environmental pollution. Adding to this the dangers arising from the accumulation of plutonium fission products from nuclear reactors, the quality of life on earth is threatened unless renewable energy resources can be quickly developed. Photovoltaic solar energy converters are expected to make important contributions to the identification of environmentally friendly solutions to the energy problem. One attractive strategy discussed in this paper is the development of systems that mimic natural photosynthesis in the conversion of solar energy for the fixation of carbon dioxide. We have developed a molecular photovoltaic device whose overall efficiency for solar energy conversion to electricity has already attained 10%. The system is based on the sensitization of nanocrystalline films by transition metal charge transfer sensitizers. In analogy to photosynthesis, the new chemical solar cell achieves the separation of the light absorption and charge carrier transport processes. Extraordinary yields exceeding 90% for the conversion of incident photons into electric current are obtained, in contrast to conventional photovoltaic cells which are not economical for base load utility electricity production. The low cost and ease of production of the new cell should benefit large-scale applications, in particular in underdeveloped or developing countries, which benefit from generous sunshine. Aside from its intrinsic merits as a photovoltaic device, nanocrystalline film development opens up a large number of additional avenues for energy storage ranging from intercalation batteries to the formation of chemical fuels. These systems will undoubtedly promote the acceptance of renewable energy technologies, not least by setting new standards of convenience and economy. © 1995 Indian Academy of Sciences.

Authors: Nicoud Jean-Daniel
Title: Microengineering: When is small too small? Nanoengineering: When is large too large?
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium on Micro Machine and Human Science
Affiliations: Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Nicoud, Jean-Daniel, Swiss Federal Inst of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Miniaturizatlon, as exemplified by watches, was initially required for convenience. Cost-effectiveness was the drive for computer peripherals. New applications now push the research into microengineering and nanotechnologies. Mimicking animals has always been the dream of mobile robot builders. Nature has however developed extraordinary solutions for energy storage, scalable muscles with sizes down to few microns in diameter, multitudes of sensitive sensors and efficient distributed control mechanisms. Reducing the robot's size make them more appropriate to study collective behaviour, but at some point the intelligence must be reduced. Below one cubic centimeter, there is even no solution to just make the robot move autonomously. Nanotechnology open the door to smaller sensors and motors have been built in the 100 micron range. These motors are far from performing reliably, their control electronics is cumbersome and the assembly is critical. The artificial insect is not yet for tomorrow.
Index Keywords: Distributed parameter control systems; Micromachining; Miniature instruments; Mobile robots; Nanotechnology; Sensors; Microengineering; Nanoengineering; Mechanisms

Authors: Potter Jr. Robert A., King Dion J., Weitzel Douglas P., Boettner Daisie D.
Title: ASHRAE RP-766: study of operational experience with thermal storage systems
Affiliations: U.S. Military Acad, West Point, United States
Authors with affiliations: Potter Jr., Robert A., U.S. Military Acad, West Point, United States; King, Dion J., U.S. Military Acad, West Point, United States; Weitzel, Douglas P., U.S. Military Acad, West Point, United States; Boettner, Daisie D., U.S. Military Acad, West Point, United States
Abstract: This paper presents an overview of a comprehensive national study commissioned by ASHRAE to evaluate the performance and operational experiences of cool thermal energy storage (TES) systems. Nearly 200 owners and operators participated in the survey. All three TES system types (ice, water, and eutectic salt) are examined. The survey collected system and facility data on each installation, as well as information in the following eight functional areas: decision process design process installation commissioning operation maintenance economic performance system satisfaction. Included in this paper is a description of the project's research methodology, an examination of survey population statistics, and analyses of selected system operational parameters. Findings generated from the replies to the eight functional area sections of the surveys also are discussed. Due to space limitation, only a fraction of the study's findings are discussed in this publication. Interested readers are referred to the ASHRAE Technical Report, Study of Operational Experience with Thermal Storage Systems - Results of a National Survey of Cool Thermal Energy Storage Systems (Potter 1994.) This report presents a detailed analysis of the survey findings and includes the compiled surveys for each TES system type.

Authors: Moya-Siesse D., Sami A., Moya G.
Title: Characterization of charge trapping/detrapping phenomena by calorimetric measurements in charged dielectrics
Source title: Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena (CEIDP), Annual Report
Affiliations: Lab de Physique des materiaux, Marseille, France
Authors with affiliations: Moya-Siesse, D., Lab de Physique des materiaux, Marseille, France; Sami, A., Lab de Physique des materiaux, Marseille, France; Moya, G., Lab de Physique des materiaux, Marseille, France
Abstract: Dielectric behavior of insulators can be explained using the space charge physics [1], [2], based on the concept of polaron. The local variation of polarisability due to crystal defects is responsible for trapping charges. In polycrystalline ceramics, point and extended defects, grain boundaries or impurities are sites of trapping charges. The charge detrapping can be initiated by any perturbation and corresponds to the free energy minimization occurring when an activation barrier height is reached. Any kind of variation (for example electrical, mechanical or thermal variation) contributes to approach this barrier. So a soft relaxation of a charged dielectric can be obtained by annealing the sample with slow heating rates to avoid a rapid destabilization of the space charge leading to inevitable breakdown. In this work we have tried to investigate the effect of detrapping/trapping of the space charge on the relaxation/polarization of charged dielectrics from measurements of the heat flow as function of the temperature by a differential scanning microcalorimetric method.

Authors: Mizuno Hiroyuki, Nagano Takahiro
Title: Driving source-line (DSL) cell architecture for sub-1-V high-speed low-power applications
Source title: IEEE Symposium on VLSI Circuits, Digest of Technical Papers

Abstract: A novel SRAM cell architecture for sub-1-V high-speed operation is proposed without using either low-Vth MOSFETs or modifying the cell layout pattern. A source-line connected to the source terminals of driver MOSFETs is controlled to be negative and floating in the read- and write-cycles, respectively. The cell-access time is reduced to 1/4 /- 1/2 at a supply voltage of 0.5-1.0V. Limiting the bit-line swing reduces the writing power needed to charge the bit-lines to 1/10, and it realizes a faster write-recovery. The feasibility of low-power 100-MHz operation over a wide range of supply voltages is demonstrated.

Authors: Hughes Patrick J.
Title: Residential gas heat pump assessment: a market-based approach
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hughes, Patrick J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: There has been considerable activity in recent years to develop technologies that could reduce or levelize residential and light-commercial building space cooling electrical use and heating/cooling energy use. For example, variable-or multispeed electric heat pumps, electric ground-source heat pumps, dual-fuel heat pumps, multifunction heat pumps, and electric cool storage concepts have been developed; and several types of gas heat pumps are emerging. A residential gas heat pump (GHP) benefits assessment is performed to assist gas utility and equipment manufacturer decision making on the level of commitment they should make to this technology. The methodology and generic types of results that can be generated are described. National market share is estimated using a market segmentation approach. The assessment design requires dividing the 334 Metropolitan Statistical Areas (MSAs) of the United States into 42 market segments of relatively homogeneous weather and gas/electric rates (14 climate groupings by 3 rate groupings). Gas and electric rates for each MSA are evaluated to arrive at population-weighted rates for the market segments. GHPs are competed against 14 conventional equipment options in each homogeneous segment.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Decision making; Electric rates; Energy utilization; Heating equipment; Marketing; Gas rates; Market segmentation approach; Metropolitan Statistical areas; Residential gas heat pump; Segmentation parameters; Heat pump systems

Abstract: A 256 entry by 14-bit dual compare content addressable memory (CAM) with a fast hit detect access time of 5.5ns and a cycle time of 7ns is described in this paper. The chip was fabricated using Vitesse's 0.6μm H-GaAsIII enhancement/depletion MESFET technology.

Authors: Lazraq T., Oberg J., Tenhunen H.
Title: FPGA based ATM traffic shaper for event-building networks

Abstract: It has been proposed to use ATM multi-stage switching fabrics in high energy physics experiments to assemble the data associated with a collision, that are spread amongst many sources, and transmit it to one of many destinations where it will be analysed. This concentration of data, together with the burstiness caused by the simultaneous trigger of data sources for every event would inevitably produce congestion in the switching fabrics unless traffic shaping is applied at the input. We have studied several traffic shaping schemes. These include three types of barrel shifters and a traffic randomization method. For the latter case we have designed and implemented hardware components, based on ASICs and FPGAs, that will be integrated in a VME based ATM data source module.

Abstract: This paper introduces digital video image processing and analysis systems that are being developed at Los Alamos for application to nuclear safeguards. Authors: Jones Jr. R.E., Maniar P.D., Moazzami R., Zurcher P., Witowski J.Z., Lii Y.T., Chu P., Gillespie S.J.
Title: Ferroelectric non-volatile memories for low-voltage, low-power applications
Affiliations: Materials Research and Strategic Technologies, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States; Advanced Products Research, Development Laboratory, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States; 39 Saint Germain Street, Boston, MA 02115, United States; MOS-2, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd., Austin, TX 78721, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jones Jr., R.E., Materials Research and Strategic Technologies, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States; Maniar, P.D., Advanced Products Research, Development Laboratory, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States; Moazzami, R., 39 Saint Germain Street, Boston, MA 02115, United States; Zurcher, P., Materials Research and Strategic Technologies, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States; Witowski, J.Z., MOS-2, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd., Austin, TX 78721, USA, United States; Lii, Y.T., Advanced Products Research, Development Laboratory, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States; Chu, P., Materials Research and Strategic Technologies, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States; Gillespie, S.J., Materials Research and Strategic Technologies, Motorola, 3501 Ed Bluestein Blvd, Austin, TX 78721, United States
Abstract: Non-volatile ferroelectric random access memories (FERAM) offer substantial advantages over conventional floating-gate electrically erasable programmable read only memory (EEPROM) and flash EEPROM devices. FERAMS can be written at high speeds (≈100 ns) and at standard supply voltages 95 V or less) without the use of charge pumps. Switching of ferroelectric capacitors at voltages of 1.5 V or below has been demonstrated. FERAMS also have a high endurance for writes (>1012 cycles demonstrated). The combination of high-speed and low-voltage writing means a FERAM requires far less energy to program than a EEPROM. However, FERAMs use a destructive read followed by a rewrite so that endurance limits also apply to reading. Other reliability concerns include retention (loss of data with time) and imprint (loss of ability to write into the opposite state). We discuss the present ability of ferroelectric materials (lead zirconate titanate and Bi layered perovskites) to meet the electrical requirements and reliability requirements of practical non-volatile memory applications. We also review some of the process challenges in integrating ferroelectrics into typical complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) integrated circuit fabrication. © 1995.

Authors: Ducharme Stephen
Title: Applicability of the band transport (Kukhtarev) model to photorefractive polymers
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of Nebraska/Lincoln, Lincoln,, NE, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ducharme, Stephen, Univ. of Nebraska/Lincoln, Lincoln,, NE, USA, United States
Abstract: The band transport model of space-charge production has proved very successful in describing photorefractive phenomena in a wide range of inorganic crystals, ranging from high-mobility semiconductors like GaAs, to highly insulating ferroelectrics like BaTiO 3. This success is primarily due to the applicability of a generic picture of charge transport in extrinsic crystalline semiconductors, a picture that becomes cloudy in noncrystalline systems like the new photorefractive polymers. Photorefractive polymers exhibit the classic photorefractive behaviors such as photoconduction, electro-optic response, hologram formation and storage, and two-beam energy coupling, all without benefit of a crystalline lattice or well defined conduction band. In this report, I will outline how the band transport model can be adapted to describe photorefraction in noncrystalline materials by the dual expediencies of renaming certain embarrassing 'constants' and admitting that they are strongly dependent on the total electric field.
Index Keywords: Band transport model; Kukhtarev model; Photorefractive polymers; Amorphous materials; Electric field effects; Light refraction; Mathematical models; Polymers; Optical materials

Source title: Digest of Technical Papers - Symposium on VLSI Technology
Affiliations: Hitachi, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan

Abstract: A high-performance microprocessor-compatible small size full CMOS SRAM cell technology has been developed. A 0.3-μm gate length load pMOSFET, formed utilizing amorphous-Si-film through-channel implantation, is merged with a 0.25-μm gate length pMOSFET for the peripheral circuits. Mask-free contact for TiN local interconnect is developed with wet etching. A 6.93-μm2 cell area and a high-performance 1.8-V circuit are thus realized.

Authors: Jacob Gerald
Title: Clean power essential to today's PC systems
Authors with affiliations: Jacob, Gerald
Abstract: In networked computer systems, several personal computers are connected to one or several servers distributed throughout a building. The server's power source must be protected at all times, hence, the need for an uninterruptible source (UPS). The standby UPS feeds the load from utility power until an outage is detected. Upon outage detection, the load is switched to a local battery and AC converter combination. Online UPS converts AC line power to DC to keep a battery charged and convert DC battery power back to AC. Line-interactive UPS includes intelligent line-monitoring and control circuits and an energy storage source that is continuously ready to supply power to the load.

Abstract: Jitter-free photoconductive (PC) switching is employed to generate a jam-resistant, time-coherent ultra-wideband (UWB) pulse train. The power from multiple PC switch triggered antenna elements is combined in free space to produce a steerable UWB beam.

Authors: Frescaline L., Lamain H., Auvray P., Rouille C., Etlicher B., Buzzi J.M., Roques B., Lassalle F., Morell A., Leon J.F.
Title: Very low inductance triggered multichannel surface switch
Source title: Electrical Contacts, Proceedings of the Annual Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts
Affiliations: Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Frescaline, L., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Lamain, H., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Auvray, P., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Rouille, C., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Etlicher, B., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Buzzi, J.M., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Roques, B., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Lassalle, F., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Morell, A., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France; Leon, J.F., Lab de Physique des Milieux ionises, Palaiseau, France
Abstract: A very low inductance pressurized surface discharge switch has been developed for an inductive energy storage generator. This switch was developed as an integral part of a strip-line MARX assembly [1]. This technology performed reliably up to 50 KV - 700 kA with a switch inductance as low as the inductance of the equivalent strip-line. The measured inductance was less than 4.5 nH. Part of this development was done to improve the reliability of the switch and its electrical characteristics including the effects of the trigger pulse on the current distribution along the width of the strip-line. We will show that jitter and current distribution can be controlled by the trigger pulse voltage and rise time. For the first quarter period of the discharge we correlated the number of channels during operation with the trigger pulse parameters. We carried out experiments to estimate the main characteristics (self-breakdown voltage, number of channels, inductance, peak current discharge value) of such a switch for synthetic air dielectric gas. Optimized parameters are deduced. These studies give us a model of switch operation which enables this kind of design for very low inductance multi-megajoule systems.

Authors: Sengschmied Franz, Haselbacher Hermann
Title: Flow structure of the non-reacting flow field of cyclone combustors for wood fired gas turbines
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Vienna, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Sengschmied, Franz, Technical Univ of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; Haselbacher, Hermann, Technical Univ of Vienna, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The evaluation of energy conversion systems based on wood as primary energy carrier has led to the conclusion that gas turbines directly fired with wood wastes can be an attractive solution in the low output range of a few megawatts. Two major design requirements are a high fuel input per unit combustion chamber volume and complete burn-out of the fuel. In order to realize these goals, a cyclone combustor has been chosen. As a first step in the development of the combustor, the flow structure of the non-reacting flow field was analyzed. The 3-D and 2-D calculations are based on a finite volume formulation. The standard κ - ε model and a Reynolds-stress model are used to account for the turbulent flow. Basically the flow field is three dimensional and the complexity of the flow field requires a fine discretization in axial and radial direction. However, gradients in circumferential direction are very strong only in some regions. Based on 3-D calculations, it is shown how the boundary conditions for a reduction to a 2-D problem should be chosen. This simplification results in a reduction of calculation time and storage requirements. Nevertheless, the 2-D calculations are in good agreement with the 3-D calculation.
Index Keywords: Boundary conditions; Energy conversion; Finite volume method; Flow patterns; Gas turbines; Mathematical models; Reynolds number; Three dimensional; Turbulent flow; Wood wastes; Cyclone combustors; Flow structure; Non-reacting flow field; Reynolds-stress model; Two dimensional; Wood-fired gas turbines; Combustors

Abstract: As the demand of high-performance and low-power RISC processors for handy terminals increases, the need to develop an embedded cache memory that automatically reduces power dissipation in low frequencies and high-speed operation in high frequencies becomes more significant. In view of this, an 8-kB cache memory is fabricated using 0.5-μm CMOS technology. In this paper, a proposed architecture that automatically saves power dissipation at low frequencies is described. Following this, two circuit techniques that save the power at high frequencies are presented. Finally, experimental results of the fabricated 8-kB cache memory are discussed.

Authors: Lee Mike Tien-Chien, Tiwari Vivek
Title: Memory allocation technique for low-energy embedded DSP software

Abstract: Embedded DSP applications are characterized by the presence of a dedicated DSP processor and application specific software that runs on it. Energy consumption is increasingly becoming a critical design constraint for such applications. This necessitates the analysis and optimization of the energy consumption of the software component of these systems. This paper investigates an energy optimization technique in this regard. It involves the problem of allocating memory to variables in embedded DSP software to maximize simultaneous data transfers from different memory banks to registers. A memory allocation technique based on simulated annealing is proposed. Experimental results for example DSP programs demonstrate that energy reductions of up to 47% can be achieved by this approach.

Abstract: This Paper deals with magnetics design of tank inductors for resonant switching converters for power levels in the range 10kVA to 30kVA. The problem of HF AC inductors is especially critical as energy storage requirements are high. The use of gapped cores leads to fringing flux across air gaps which causes gap heating and increases in winding losses caused by induced eddy currents. As a result, special attention must be given to the winding arrangement and core geometry.

Title: Novel, high-frequency, per-phase static var compensator

Affiliations: Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mohan, Ned, Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States; Kamath, Girish R., Univ of Minnesota, Minneapolis, United States
Abstract: Static var compensators are being used to provide voltage control, var compensation, damping of oscillations, and improved transient stability in power systems. Conventional SVCs which consist of thyristor-switched capacitors and thyristor controlled inductors suffer from disadvantages of size and slow dynamic response. This makes it unsuitable for applications such as controlling the voltage flicker due to arc furnace loads. Advanced SVCs (STATCON or STATCOM) eliminate the above disadvantages. However, they have a disadvantage due to the presence of a large line-frequency transformer. In this paper, a novel, high-frequency, per-phase static var compensator is proposed, which has all the advantages of the advanced SVC. Various related topologies and control strategies are also enumerated and their advantages and disadvantages are discussed.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Dynamic response; Electric arcs; Electric loads; Electric network topology; Electric power systems; Electric transformers; Oscillations; Stability; Thyristors; Transients; Voltage control; Arc furnace loads; Magnetic energy storage; Static var compensator; Var compensation; Voltage flicker; Electric control equipment

Authors: Bonanno F., Consoli A., Raciti A., Leotta A., Nocera U.
Title: Dynamic model of hybrid generation systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bonanno, F., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Consoli, A., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Raciti, A., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Leotta, A., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Nocera, U., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy
Abstract: The paper deals with the definition of an accurate dynamic model of Hybrid Generation Systems (HGS) in order to investigate their transient behaviours. A software simulation program has been developed using an advanced simulation language, and a graphical user interface is also available to easily handle the settings of the system configuration, and parameters. The package allows to define the system simulation by sequence of events in the grid with all generators connected in parallel on the AC bus. Several simulation runs have been performed and the results are quite satisfactory giving the possibility to experience any transient behaviour before the experimental tests on the hybrid plant are done.

Authors: Xu Mingzhou, Tindall C.E.
Title: Investigation of induction generator with improved characteristics
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Queen's Univ of Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Xu, Mingzhou, Queen's Univ of Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom; Tindall, C.E., Queen's Univ of Belfast, Belfast, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper describes the wave energy conversion system located on the Island of Islay, which lies off the western coast of Scotland. Based on previous research work on wave power utilization, a simulation study has been conducted to this system which consists essentially of a Wells turbine and an induction generator. The simulation process is validated by a comparison between predicted and measured results from the existing system. In order to reduce the fluctuations of generated electrical power, an attempt is made to improve the machine characteristics through the modification of rotor structure.

Affiliations: Queen's Univ, Belfast, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Peters, G., Queen's Univ, Belfast, United Kingdom; Beattie, W.C., Queen's Univ, Belfast, United Kingdom
Abstract: A fundamental problem in the extraction of energy from sea waves lies in the difficulty in handling the relatively large excursions of power associated with each wave group. These energy peaks must be discarded or stored or a combination of the two, and this paper examines the use of storage batteries versus flywheels as a means of energy storage.

Authors: Uchihori Y., Kawamura Y., Morita S., Yasutune H., Nakaoka M.
Title: State-of-the art electromagnetic induction flow-through pipeline package type fluid heating appliance using series resonant PWM inverter with self-tuning PID controller-based feedback implementation
Source title: International IEEE/IAS Conference on Industrial Automation and Control: Emerging Technologies, Proceedings
Affiliations: Seta Kosan Chemical Industry Co Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Uchihori, Y., Seta Kosan Chemical Industry Co Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Kawamura, Y., Seta Kosan Chemical Industry Co Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Morita, S., Seta Kosan Chemical Industry Co Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Yasutune, H., Seta Kosan Chemical Industry Co Ltd, Osaka, Japan; Nakaoka, M., Seta Kosan Chemical Industry Co Ltd, Osaka, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes a newly-developed prototype of an electromagnetic induction flow-through metallic package-in-nonmetallic pipeline type fluid heating appliance, which is composed of series loaded resonant phase-shift PWM inverter using IGBT modules and their intelligent driver modules, in addition to an auto-tuning PID controller incorporated into the feedback loop. This inverter-fed fluid heating appliance is to be more acceptable for high-quality heat energy transfer and delivery under a precise temperature control scheme, heat-energy storage and heat exchange processing plants as well as vessel and tank heating plants in the pipeline because of clean processing, high-efficient, compactness in volumetric size, high-reliability, and best control ability. In particular, the series capacitor-compensated resonant PWM inverter system with a power factor correction and active sinewave line current-shaping functions is introduced for induction-heated pipeline fluid heating appliance in industrial medical and consumer applications. The original new structure of electromagnetic induction-heated magnetic and metallic package inside nonmetallic pipeline for high-efficient quick temperature rise fluid heating is to be proposed from a practical point of view, in which specially-designed flow-through induction-heated metallic package assembly to induce the eddy currents with a large heating surface is incorporated into the nonmetallic cylindrical vessel or tank with a working coil connected to a high-frequency AC. The inherent salient features of this inverter-type fluid heating appliance are schematically presented as compared with the other electrical heating schemes. Its operating characteristics in steady-state are illustrated and evaluated in experiment as well as computer simulation results. The promising applications of this fluid heating appliance are mentioned herein.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Eddy currents; Electric control equipment; Electric network topology; Electric power factor correction; Electromagnetism; Feedback control; Induction heating; Pipelines; Pulse width modulation; Self tuning control systems; Three term control systems; Active sinewave line current-shaping function; Electromagnetic induction flow; High frequency inverter; Pipeline type fluid heating appliance; Series-loaded resonant inverter; Electric inverters

Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Acarnley, P.P., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Mecrow, B.C., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Burdess, J.S., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Fawcett, J.N., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Kelly, J.G., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom; Dickinson, P.G., Univ of Newcastle upon Tyne, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper introduces a flywheel energy storage device capable of enhancing the fuel economy of a hybrid-type road vehicle. A number of possible drive types is considered and the permanent magnet machine drive is shown to provide the best solution. Reasons for selecting a device using an axial-field configuration with single rotor and double stator sections are described. Electrical, magnetic and mechanical design data are presented for a full-scale prototype device with 240kJ of usable energy storage and 25kW of power transfer, operating at speeds up to 50 000revs per minute, with a 10% duty cycle.

Authors: Meneghesso Gaudenzio, De Bortoli Eros, Cova Paolo, Menozzi Roberto
Title: On temperature and hot electron induced degradation in AlGaAs/InGaAs PM-HEMT's
Source title: Workshop on High Performance Electron Devices for Microwave and Optoelectronic Applications, EDMO
Affiliations: Universita' di Padova, Padova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Meneghesso, Gaudenzio, Universita' di Padova, Padova, Italy; De Bortoli, Eros, Universita' di Padova, Padova, Italy; Cova, Paolo, Universita' di Padova, Padova, Italy; Menozzi, Roberto, Universita' di Padova, Padova, Italy
Abstract: AlGaAs/InGaAs pseudomorphic HEMT's (PM-HEMT's) have been submitted to either hot electron or high temperature storage stress tests. A non-permanent increase of the drain current is observed after the tests and is correlated with the presence of deep levels in the devices. Trapping of holes generated by impact ionization (during the hot electron stress) or thermally activated electron detrapping (during the high temperature storage) are responsible for the observed shifts of the PM-HEMT's characteristics. We also present a new DC-based investigation technique that gives information about the localization of the trapped/detrapped charge.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electron energy levels; High temperature effects; Semiconducting aluminum compounds; Semiconducting gallium arsenide; Semiconducting indium compounds; High temperature storage stress test; Hot electron induced degradation; Impact ionization; High electron mobility transistors

Authors: Ribeiro Enio R., Roy Gilles, April Georges-E.
Title: Implementation of a DFC topology under scalar control algorithm with a voltage gain beyond unity
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: Escola Federal de Engenharia de, Itajuba, Itajuba, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Ribeiro, Enio R., Escola Federal de Engenharia de, Itajuba, Itajuba, Brazil; Roy, Gilles, Escola Federal de Engenharia de, Itajuba, Itajuba, Brazil; April, Georges-E., Escola Federal de Engenharia de, Itajuba, Itajuba, Brazil
Abstract: The implementation of a novel direct frequency changer topology is proposed. This converter is controlled using the scalar control algorithm. The performance of the scalar algorithm has already been demonstrated in a direct frequency changer using bidirectional switches in a unique matrix topology. The proposed converter is made of two units called Semi Direct Frequency Changer (SDFC). Each unit has six unidirectional switches which are operated under the scalar control algorithm. The two units are connected by a dc link. It would seem this setup results in double conversion, but contrary to real intermediate conversion frequency changers, energy storage elements in the dc link are associated only with the commutation frequency. This converter improves the voltage transfer ratio by effectively removing the 0.87 limit normally imposed by direct conversion. A set of four standard microcontrollers is used to implement the control unit which also provides real time operation. Finally, laboratory test results from a 100 W prototype are presented.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Electric commutation; Electric network topology; Electric switches; Microcomputers; Power electronics; Real time systems; Voltage control; Commutation frequency; DC link; Direct frequency changer topology; Microcontrollers; Scalar control algorithm; Unidirectional switches; Voltage gain; Voltage transfer ratio; Frequency converters

Authors: Rahman Mahmudur, Shuttleworth Roger
Title: Thermoelectric power generation for battery charging
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Energy Management and Power Delivery, EMPD
Affiliations: Bangladesh Univ of Engineering and, Technology, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Authors with affiliations: Rahman, Mahmudur, Bangladesh Univ of Engineering and, Technology, Dhaka, Bangladesh; Shuttleworth, Roger, Bangladesh Univ of Engineering and, Technology, Dhaka, Bangladesh
Abstract: Thermoelectric generators use the Seebeck effect to produce electrical power from a temperature difference caused by heat energy flow. In this paper the principle of using thermoelectrically converted heat energy for powering portable electronic equipment or charging its battery has been investigated for a lap-top computer. The thermoelectric battery charger developed, consists of a thermoelectric converter system, powered from buttane gas, and a dc-to-dc boost up converter. Both the sub-assemblies are designed using computer models and constructed. The unit produces an output power of 5 watts which doubles the life of the lap-top computer's internal batteries.

Abstract: This paper deals with optimal voltage regulation methods in power distribution systems including Dispersed Energy Storage and Generation (DSG) systems. In order to deliver suitable voltages to as many customers as possible, optimal sending voltages should be decided by the effective operation of voltage regulators at distribution substations. In this paper, optimal voltage regulation methods are presented based on statistical analysis considering the customer voltage conditions and operation characteristics of DSG systems. Optimal operation methods of multiple voltage regulators are also suggested. In addition, the introduction impacts of DSG systems such as optimal location sites and introduction capacity are evaluated.

Abstract: The first observation of electro-optical holographic storage grating effect in C60-doped nematic liquid crystal films is presented. The effect is attributed to molecular axis orientation caused by the combination of an applied dc field and the optically induced dc space charge field. To generate such reorientation effect, the applied dc field strength needed is on the order of 100 V/cm. This corresponds to a 'battery-size' voltage of 1 V in typical films with thickness around 100 μm.

Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Jordan, Amman, Jordan

Abstract: A built-in solar water heater was tested both experimentally and theoretically under three different operation modes namely; no flow, continuous flow and intermittent flow. It was found that the average efficiency (n) of the system is of maximum value under the continuous flow condition, while it has a maximum hourly efficiency under the intermittent flow condition. © 1995 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. Abstract: A 0.35μm ECL-CMOS technology has been developed to achieve high speed and high density LSIs for mainframe computers. A high speed bipolar transistor with cut off frequency fT of 30GHz and a 30μm2 6T-CMOS memory cell with a trench isolation are introduced to SOI substrate. This technology has been applied to a 40ps, 120K gate logic LSI and a 1ns, 2.3Mbit SRAM with 50K gate array.

Authors: Worcester Peter F., Hardy Kevin R., Horwitt David, Peckham Douglas A.
Title: Deep ocean data recovery module
Affiliations: Univ of California, San Diego, La Jolla, United States
Authors with affiliations: Worcester, Peter F., Univ of California, San Diego, La Jolla, United States; Hardy, Kevin R., Univ of California, San Diego, La Jolla, United States; Horwitt, David, Univ of California, San Diego, La Jolla, United States; Peckham, Douglas A., Univ of California, San Diego, La Jolla, United States
Abstract: Recent developments in undersea acoustic telemetry make it feasible to read low to moderate amounts of data from subsea instruments from shipboard. When it is necessary to recover gigabytes of data, however, the time and energy required by an acoustic telemetry link can become prohibitive, particularly for battery powered instrumentation. A pop-up module has been developed to allow the recovery of 2-4 Gigabytes of data from both moored and bottom-mounted subsea systems, without the need for recovery of the primary oceanographic instrumentation. The pop-up module is based on a recoverable acoustic transponder, to which are added a 3.5-inch, 2.1-Gigabyte, SCSI hard disk drive and a 80386SL-based controller. The pop-up controller is connected to the subsea system using pressure-balanced, oil-filled, underwater mateable connectors that separate when the pop-up is released. Two channels of data can be transferred from the subsea system to the pop-up at 125 kbps each. The initial application of the pop-up module is to recover data from autonomous vertical hydrophone arrays developed for the Acoustic Thermometry of Ocean Climate (ATOC) program. Four pop-up modules mounted on the subsurface float supporting the array allow the recovery of data at approximately quarterly intervals during a year-long deployment.
Index Keywords: Acoustic receivers; Computer software; Control equipment; Data transfer; Design; Hard disk storage; Hydrophones; Acoustic transponder; Deep ocean data recovery module; Subsurface instrument; Oceanographic instruments

Abstract: In a detailed dynamic analysis of power electronics devices installed in power system, it is important to coordinate the digital simulation for the slow dynamic model of generators and for the fast dynamic model of power electronics devices in which the commutation characteristics of converter are taken into account. A practical simulation method is developed for the aim to combine the slow and fast dynamic models of power electronics systems on the basis of a dual-time-scale modeling. The simulation results by the proposed method are compared with the conventional approach.

Title: Bearings and energy storage
Affiliations: Univ of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Coombs, T.A., Univ of Cambridge, Cambridge, United Kingdom
Abstract: Passive magnetic bearings are ideal components for energy storage flywheels which require small dynamic loads and low-maintenance bearings with minimal power requirements. High temperature superconductors such as YBCO can be used to fabricate these bearings and achieve the desired magnetic properties. Stiffness and gap decay due to high speed can be addressed by dynamically altering bearing geometry to provide active control with bulk materials.

Authors with affiliations: Hamamoto, T., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Sugiura, S., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan; Sawada, S., Toshiba Corp, Kawasaki, Japan
Abstract: A novel scaling limitation factor derived from DR AM retention time and its modeling has been proposed. So far, the well concentration has been optimized from the viewpoint of the scaling of the transistor dimensions. However, it has been found that the DRAM retention time strongly depends on the well concentration. Increase of the well concentration enhances thermionic field emission (TFE) current from the storage node. This leakage current makes 'tail distribution' of the retention time. Therefore, the well concentration must be optimized taking into account the retention time distribution.

Authors: Sprecher Patrik, Gasser Beat, Bock Oskar, Kofoed Peter
Title: Control strategy for cooled ceiling panels
Affiliations: Sulzer Infra Lab, Winterhur, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Sprecher, Patrik, Sulzer Infra Lab, Winterhur, Switzerland; Gasser, Beat, Sulzer Infra Lab, Winterhur, Switzerland; Bock, Oskar, Sulzer Infra Lab, Winterhur, Switzerland; Kofoed, Peter, Sulzer Infra Lab, Winterhur, Switzerland
Abstract: Water-cooled ceiling panels are mostly used in office buildings. They are generally connected with thermally comfortable conditions. The main factor for heat exchange is radiation. A new control strategy for cooled ceiling panels has been developed. With this control strategy it is possible to use the cooled ceiling panels not only during working hours when an internal load is present, but also at night. With night cooling, it is possible to use the thermal mass of the building for energy storage. Night cooling helps to reduce the peak load during working hours. It makes it possible to produce part of the cold water at lower outside temperatures and when the costs for electricity are lower. For some examples, the effect of night cooling has been calculated with a simulation program. The control strategy is based on a simple physical model. A formula has to be programmed into the normal control unit.

Abstract: The hydraulic energy-storing workover rig is a new type of rig invented by the authors of this paper. The first experimental rig has passed through field test. This rig differs from other types of workover rigs not only in appearance but also in working principle. There is an energy-storing system, so some energy issued from motors or from running down pipestring can be stored and used later when needed. This new invention has obtained a lot of advantages such as energy saving, safety, less noisy, possibility of using hydraulic tubing tongs without another hydraulic system, etc.

Abstract: A MOSFET gate oxide reliability and power consumption have been the concerns in developing DRAMs, and the most effective solution to them has been the lowering of power supply voltage. However, the supply voltage can hardly be lowered to less than 1V. Hence, the conventional scaling method may be inoperable in 4Gb/16Gb DRAMs. In this paper, a new 1/4 Vcc bit-line swing architecture is proposed as well as a related sense amplifier for 1V 4Gb DRAM and beyond. These schemes reduce power dissipation to 40% without degradation of the read-out signal and also improve device reliability.

Affiliations: Valence Technology, Inc, Henderson, United States

Abstract: The growth rate for small sealed rechargeable cells has ranged between 15% and 20% per year for the past several year. Various forecasts estimate that over one half of the portable electronic devices made in the year 2000 will be battery-powered. If this proves true, the growth rate in this market segment should continue. Outlook for the four major small sealed battery chemistries, namely nickel cadmium, sealed lead acid, nickel metal hydride, and lithium ion are discussed.

Authors: Ogasawara M., Ito Y., Muranaka M., Yanagisawa Y., Tadaki Y., Natsuaki N., Nagata T., Miyai Y.

Abstract: The low power application of DRAMs requires longer data retention time. Since the p-n junction current leakage is the main cause of the cell capacitor discharge, the leakage should be minimized to meet the requirement. However, the leakage taking place in all small area of sub μm2 largely varies from bit to bit. Thus, the mechanism of the variation for the minimization is studied. A physical model, based on newly obtained experimental results, is proposed wherein the leakage variation is mainly due to a variation of local electric field strength enhancement.

Abstract: Today, the beginning of a comeback of the specialty car manufacturers in the kit car industry is seen. The challenge for the manufacturers is to design an electric hybrid car specifically for the custom kit car manufacturing market. The kit car builders of today focus on body style and on a new brand of propulsion system, the hybrid power plant. One of the strongest forces driving the alternative propulsion system movement is the need for clean air which is what the hybrid module designed to do.
