Authors: Burlingame Gary A., Korntreger Gerson, Lahann Clifford
Title: Configuration of standpipes in distribution affects operations and water quality
Source title: Journal of the New England Water Works Association
Affiliations: Philadelphia Water Dep, Philadelphia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burlingame, Gary A., Philadelphia Water Dep, Philadelphia, United States; Korntreger, Gerson, Philadelphia Water Dep, Philadelphia, United States; Lahann, Clifford, Philadelphia Water Dep, Philadelphia, United States
Abstract: A study was conducted during December, 1992 and January, 1993 on the hydraulics of a set of standpipes by measuring fluoride residuals at keys points in the system when fluoride treatment was stopped and later resumed at the treatment plant. Daily water elevation measurements were compared to changes in fluoride residual. Approximately six to nine feet of water that leaves the standpipes daily, was found to be reentering again. This reduced the effective turnover of water in the standpipes. Attempts to control water quality deterioration, as seen in a seasonal loss of chloramine residual followed by an increase in bacterial growth and an increase in nitrite, were frustrated by this interaction between the tanks and the distribution system. More consideration needs to be given to the configuration of standpipes or storage tanks in the distribution system in order to balance water quality needs with other needs such as pressure, supply and energy costs. A better appreciation is needed of mean residence time and the usefulness of water elevation as a means for monitoring the turnover of fresh water in standpipes having various distribution configurations.
Index Keywords: Deterioration; Energy utilization; Hydraulics; Monitoring; Potable water; Pressure; Water pipelines; Water quality; Water supply; Water tanks; Water treatment; Water treatment plants; Bacterial growth; Fluoride treatment; Nitrite; Standpipes; Water elevation measurement; Water distribution systems

Authors: Argante E., Stok P.v.d., Willers I.
Title: On-line event reconstruction using a parallel in-memory database
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE International Conference on Engineering of Complex Computer Systems, ICECCS
Affiliations: Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Argante, E., Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Stok, P.v.d., Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands; Willers, I., Eindhoven Univ of Technology, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: PORS is a system designed for on-line event reconstruction in high energy physics (HEP) experiments. It uses the CPREAD reconstruction program. Central to the system is a parallel in-memory database which is used as communication medium between parallel workers. A farming control structure is implemented with PORS in a natural way. The database provides structured storage of data with a short life time. PORS serves as a case study for the construction of a methodology on how to apply parallel in-memory databases to HEP software, providing systematic structuring of HEP data, easier parallelization and consequently a simpler development and maintenance of code. PORS runs on a SPARCcenter 2000 8-node shared memory computer.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Computer software; Computer systems; Data storage equipment; High energy physics; Online systems; Online event reconstruction; Parallel in memory database; Parallel online reconstruction system; Parallelization; Software Package CPREAD; Database systems

Authors: Alowersson Jonas, Andersson Per
Title: SRAM cells for low-power write in buffer memories
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics
Affiliations: Lund Univ, Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Alowersson, Jonas, Lund Univ, Lund, Sweden; Andersson, Per, Lund Univ, Lund, Sweden
Abstract: We present a novel approach to SRAM cell operation for low-power write. Instead of providing read stability by using much stronger inverter than access transistors, we do so by using a lower word-line voltage during read. Thus, the cell can be written to with low bit-line voltage swing, thereby significantly reducing the energy required to write.

Authors: Sri-Jayantha
Title: Trends in mobile storage design
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics
Affiliations: IBM Research Div, Yorktown Heights, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sri-Jayantha, IBM Research Div, Yorktown Heights, United States
Abstract: The impact of form factor and technology is considered in the evolution of hard disk drives (HDDs). Low power and ruggedness are key features that distinguish the design of HDDs targeted for mobile storage applications. Electronic and electromechanical subsystems dissipate about equal amounts of power in idle mode. Form factor reduction generally results in improved power saving, with spin-up and seek power showing a linear dependence.
Index Keywords: Electromechanical devices; Electronic equipment; Energy conservation; Energy dissipation; Performance; Personal computers; Reliability; Form factor; Laptop computers; Mobile storage; Ruggedness; Hard disk storage

Authors: Geraci Alberto L., Risitano Antonino, Fargione Giovanna A.
Title: Study of deformations in objects under stress using digital image analysis
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of Catania, Catania, Italy, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Geraci, Alberto L., Univ. of Catania, Catania, Italy, Italy; Risitano, Antonino, Univ. of Catania, Catania, Italy, Italy; Fargione, Giovanna A., Univ. of Catania, Catania, Italy, Italy
Abstract: Deformations of a plate under different loading conditions were determined using remote sensing techniques. Imagery of the plate under investigation, acquired with a TV-camera based system, was analyzed, in order to measure electronically the average radiance over the plate through the digital numbers in each pixel. Moving from the knowledge of the radiant energy, it was possible to determine deformations, directly related to radiance, analyzing pixel-by-pixel image variations. Radiometric and geometrical considerations allowed determining deflections of the plate, after introducing a correction factor, to consider the response of the acquisition system. They were found in good accordance with those resulting from the use of traditional methods, and proved the working of the proposed technique.
Index Keywords: Digital image analysis; Plate deflections; Radiance measurement; Deformation; Digital image storage; Image analysis; Plates (structural components); Television cameras; Remote sensing

Authors: Blaise G.
Title: Fundamental approach to the storage of energy in dielectrics
Source title: IEEE International Conference on Conduction & Breakdown in Solid Dielectrics
Affiliations: Universite Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Blaise, G., Universite Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Abstract: The conventional approach to the storage of energy in dielectrics and their degradation does not consider the fact that charge injection and charge trapping always occur in capacitors subjected to high electric fields. When a charge is trapped in an insulating material and localized at an atomic scale, a quasi static polarization is induced, producing a local increase of the internal energy of the order of 5 to 10 eV. This change of the internal energy affects all the thermal properties of the material. Hence, due to the electromechanical energy stored round a trapped charge, molecular damage can be produced at a macroscopic level by the detrapping of a space charge.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric breakdown of solids; Electric energy storage; Electric fields; Electric insulating materials; Electric space charge; Electrons; Phase transitions; Polarization; Charge injection; Charge trapping; Electromechanical energy; Dielectric materials

Authors: Rogulis U., Tale I., Ruza I.

Source title: Radiation Effects and Defects in Solids

Abstract: The results of measurements of the magnetic circular dichroism of the optical absorption (MCDA) and optically detected electron paramagnetic resonance (ODEPR) of X-irradiated KBr:In crystals are presented. The MCDA bands and ODEPR parameters of In°(l) centers and In2+ centres have been measured. The mechanism of the energy storage in KBr:In crystals is found not to be simply the formation of correlated F centre-In2+ centre pairs as was assumed previously. Considerable similarities to the storage phosphor BaFBr:Eu2+ were found for the photostimulated emission and read-out properties. © 1995, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: Somasekhar Dinesh, Ye Yibin, Roy Kaushik
Title: Energy recovery static RAM memory core
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics
Affiliations: Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States
Authors with affiliations: Somasekhar, Dinesh, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States; Ye, Yibin, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States; Roy, Kaushik, Purdue Univ, West Lafayette, United States
Abstract: In the design of low power circuits, recovered energy or adiabatic logic shows great promise. However work done till date has largely concentrated on implementing logic circuits/families using the principle of energy recovery. Today's VLSI systems integrate random logic, mega-modules and memories. Hence, the success of recovered energy logic will depend on the efficient implementation of not just random logic, but also the other components of a VLSI system. In this paper we present a Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) Core which operates on the principles of energy recovery, and can be implemented without compromising greatly on area or circuit complexity. The design addresses the issue of building very low powered memory circuits in VLSI systems. Our results indicates energy savings of 84% for read operations and 85% savings for write operations.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Electric inverters; Energy conservation; Energy dissipation; Integrated circuit layout; Logic circuits; Logic design; Topology; Transistors; VLSI circuits; Energy recovery; Mega modules; Random logic; SRAM core; Random access storage

Authors: Blumenkrantz E.M.
Title: Analog floating point technique
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics

Authors with affiliations: Blumenkrantz, E.M., CSEM Cent Suisse d'Electronique et, de Microtechnique SA, Neuchatel, Switzerland
Abstract: A technique for avoiding signal distortion when applying Compression/Range Switching to circuits with functional State Variables is presented. It is applicable to analog circuits/systems with memory, like Switched Capacitor, Switched Current and Continuous Time filters, Σ-Δ Data Converters, Chopper and Lock-in Amplifiers. Distortion free operation is obtained by properly updating the circuit's State Variables. Power consumption is significantly reduced due to the elimination of unnecessary SNR.
Index Keywords: Analog storage; Energy utilization; Signal distortion; Signal processing; Signal to noise ratio; Spurious signal noise; Switching; Absolute error; Analog floating point technique; Analog signal processor; Compression/range switching; State variables; Analog computers

Authors: Gonzalez Ricardo, Horowitz Mark
Title: Energy dissipation in general purpose processors
Source title: IEEE Symposium on Low Power Electronics
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gonzalez, Ricardo, Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Horowitz, Mark, Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: In this paper we investigate how super-scalar issue and pipelining affect the energy-delay product of general purpose processors. We show that for idealized machines pipelining gives approximately a 2× improvement in energy-delay product, while super-scalar issue only improves the energy-delay product by a small amount. We then show that real processors are roughly half as efficient as the idealized machines. We also show that improving the efficiency will be difficult since the overhead is distributed among many units, none of which represent a significant fraction of the energy dissipation.
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; Data storage equipment; Energy dissipation; Models; Personal computers; Clock storage elements; Data cache bandwidth; Global clock signal; Pipeline processing systems

Authors: Morash Richard T.
Title: Case histories of selected applications with 'written-pole' machines
Affiliations: Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Morash, Richard T., Precise Power Corp, Bradenton, United States
Abstract: 'Written-Pole' technology has been patented and commercialized for electric motors and generators. It advances the state-of-the-art for AC motors and electrical energy storage systems. Efficient use is made of the inherent flywheel energy stored in the rotor of a written-pole motor-generator set. The machine is a continuous on-line power conditioner, and is also an electro-mechanical battery that delivers useful precise frequency AC power for extended time during utility power sags, surges and blinkouts. If momentary power interruptions extend into blackouts after 15 or more seconds, the motor-generator allows time to transfer to a dual feeder system, or to tie into an engine generator for a no-break transfer. Also called the Roesel Motor-Generator (RMG), it is used as an Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) system without batteries. The machines have been applied and demonstrated to provide at least 15 seconds of ride-through with exact 60 Hz frequency and full voltage at full load. The written-pole motor is synchronous, has low starting current, and reflects a unity power factor, sine wave load to the utility. The motors unique features provide solutions to niche problems. Case histories are presented in this paper.
Index Keywords: AC motors; Electric batteries; Electric currents; Electric generators; Electric motor generator sets; Electric power factor; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric surges; Energy storage; Flywheels; Continuous on line power conditioner; Electromechanical battery; Momentary power interruptions; Utility power sags; Written pole machines; Written pole motor generator set; Electric machinery

Authors: Child D., Smith I.R.
Title: Long term performance modelling of a combined energy generation system
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Loughborough Univ of Technology, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Child, D., Loughborough Univ of Technology, United Kingdom; Smith, I.R., Loughborough Univ of Technology, United Kingdom
Abstract: A combined energy generation system (CEGS) at West Beacon Farm, Loughborough, Leicestershire (WBF) has three electrical generating sources (wind, photovoltaic and combined heat and power (CHP)). Electricity is exported to and imported from the grid, dependent on the particular control strategy in effect. A long term performance model of the energy distribution has been developed based on SOMES (Simulation and Optimisation Model for Renewable Energy Systems). This paper presents the operational characteristics of the CEGS, the integration of the CEGS into SOMES and model results obtained to date.
Index Keywords: Autonomous period of operation; Battery state of charge; Combined energy generation system; Combined heat and power; DC busbar voltage; Grid connected period of operation; Operational characteristics; Simulation and optimisation model for renewable energy systems; Cogeneration plants; Computer simulation; Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Performance; Solar energy; Switching; Voltage control; Wind power; Electric power generation

Authors: Davies T.S., Nouri H., Jefferson C.M.
Title: Study of wind energy conversion systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of the West of Engl, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davies, T.S., Univ of the West of Engl, Bristol, United Kingdom; Nouri, H., Univ of the West of Engl, Bristol, United Kingdom; Jefferson, C.M., Univ of the West of Engl, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper considers the issues associated with the operation of wind energy systems which are situated in areas remote from a strong grid. System stability can be improved by addition of energy storage. Fluctuations due to the gusting effect of the wind can be most effectively reduced by using a flywheel energy storage system. Alternative ways of introducing flywheel energy storage into the power system are discussed.

Authors: Willows M., Lefley P.
Title: Versatile input converter for battery charging in renewable energy power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Willows, M., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom; Lefley, P., Univ of Leicester, Leicester, United Kingdom
Abstract: Stand-alone renewable energy power systems are becoming a viable and widespread option for supplying small amounts of power. Their general function is to charge batteries that can deliver power as required. Presented in the paper is the flyback converter for use in battery charging. The design and operation of the flyback converter are discussed and its unique converter characteristics that make it possible to charge batteries from a wide range of input voltages, above and below the nominal battery voltage. A circuit is presented with a simple but effective control system, which ensures maximum power transfer up to the maximum peak operational current. An initial circuit model was investigated to determine suitable circuit parameters from which a prototype was built. A discussion on the performance and efficiency of the prototype will be given.

Authors: Cavallaro C., Musumeci S., Raciti A., Leotta A., Nocera U.
Title: Hardware and software simulations of hybrid generation systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Universities Power Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cavallaro, C., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Musumeci, S., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Raciti, A., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Leotta, A., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy; Nocera, U., Univ of Catania, Catania, Italy
Abstract: The paper deals with the software and hardware simulations of Hybrid Generation Systems (HGS) in order to investigate transient behaviours as well as logistical simulations. A software package has been developed using an advanced simulation tool, and a graphical user interface is also available to easily handle the settings of the system configuration system and parameters. The package allows to define the system simulation by sequence of events in several configurations. Software simulation runs have been performed, and the results have been compared with the experimental tests executed on the simulator hybrid plant in order to investigate the validity of the proposed approach.

Authors: Dupuis V., Perez J.P., Tuaillon J., Paillard V., Mélinon P., Guiraud G., Dupin J.P., Perez A., Thomas L., Barbara B., Bouchet B.
Title: Nanocrystallized thin films of transition metal obtained by low energy cluster beam deposition
Affiliations: Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Laboratoire de Magnétisme Louis Néel BP166X -, F38042 Grenoble Cedex, France; LURE Bat. 209D - Centre Universitaire Paris Sud -, F91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Dupuis, V., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Perez, J.P., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Tuaillon, J., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Paillard, V., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Mélinon, P., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Guiraud, G., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Dupin, J.P., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Perez, A., Département de Physique, Matériaux - Université Claude Bernard Lyon I, F69622 Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Thomas, L., Laboratoire de Magnétisme Louis Néel BP166X -, F38042 Grenoble Cedex, France; Barbara, B., Laboratoire de Magnétisme Louis Néel BP166X -, F38042 Grenoble Cedex, France; Bouchet, B., LURE Bat. 209D - Centre Universitaire Paris Sud -, F91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: Nanocrystallized thin films of iron obtained from low energy cluster beam deposition (LECBD) have been produced by adjusting different source parameters and elaboration conditions in an attempt to control the size distribution of supported clusters, In all cases, the films exhibit a nanostructure characteristic of the LECBD technique (mean 5 nm-diameter of the particles) and only the percentage of oxide in the form of a thin skin surrounding the particles changes. The specific magnetic behavior of these weakly correlated entities is described by ferromagnetic resonance and magnetization measurements. We showed that the magnetic properties of these cluster assembled materials can be interpreted using the random anisotropy model with a scale law related to grain size. The increasing interest of the scientific community in the magnetism of "small particles"1 is mainly driven by their potential application as high density storage devices2,3. From the Stoner criterion, the size and the first-neighbor number reduction would be favourable to ferromagnetism in transition metals. In this context, metallic clusters are interesting for their large surface volume ratio but they are very oxygen reactive. By varying the elaboration conditions (vacuum quality, substrate temperature, size distribution of the incident clusters...) we obtained nanostructured iron-films by Low Energy Cluster Beam Deposition (LECBD). This paper is mainly concerned with the structural and magnetic properties of these original cluster assembled materials. The laser vaporization source operating in the laboratory of Lyon4 allows the production of an intense cluster beam in a wide range of size (from few to a thousand atoms per cluster), to synthetize thin films of any kind of materials even the most refractory. Roughly, the plasma created at the laser impact on the iron rod, is thermalized by a synchronized high pressure (5 bars) helium pulse. The nascent clusters are then rapidly quenched during the following isentropic expansion into the vacuum (10-4 torr) chamber containing the source. The size distributions of clusters are checked by time-of-flight mass spectrometry before deposition. The deposit of neutral clusters at low energy on various substrates are subsequently realized after the retraction of the time-of-flight acceleration grids. This type of source produces cold clusters and we succeeded previously in the stabilisation of very low size fullerenes4. In particular we deposited C20-clusters without fragmentation on the substrate in order to produce original diamondlike structures4. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Deposition; Grain size and shape; Magnetic properties; Magnetic variables measurement; Magnetism; Mossbauer spectroscopy; Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy; Thermal effects; Thin films; Transition metals; Transmission electron microscopy; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Demagnetizing field; Low energy cluster beam deposition; Magnetocrystalline materials; Nanocrystallized thin films; Saturation magnetization; Nanostructured materials

Authors: Lin C.E., Tsai M.T., Tsai W.I., Huang C.L.
Title: Development of a general-purpose demand-side battery energy storage system
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Natl Cheng Kung Univ, Tainan, Taiwan

Abstract: This paper presents a design and implementation of battery energy storage system (BESS) for general applications in demand-side power system. Different control modes for operating BESS to improve demand-side power supply capability is studied. Basic principle using the conventional control method is implemented to accomplish the desired control functions. The proposed methods are both proved by theoretical simulations and experimental test results by a prototype BESS.

Authors: Hu X., Kawazoe Y.
Title: Anisotropy, exchange coupling and phase transition in bilayer systems
Affiliations: Institute for Materials Research, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hu, X., Institute for Materials Research, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Kawazoe, Y., Institute for Materials Research, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Phase transitions in magnetic multilayer structures are studied with mean-field theory. Transitions between different magnetization configurations in bilayer systems with different anisotropies are discussed by means of variational method. The responsible mechanism is the competition between the anisotropy energy and the exchange coupling. The para-ferro magnetic phase transition in a ferromagnetic bilayer system is investigated with the Ginzburg-Landau theory. The effect of finiteness of the layer thickness has been revealed. Critical phenomena according to the variance of the layer thickness are clarified. © 1995.

Authors: Klamp Spentzouris Linda, Colestock Patrick L., Ostiguy Francois
Title: Experimental observations of nonlinear coupling of longitudinal modes in unbunched beams
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klamp Spentzouris, Linda, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Colestock, Patrick L., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Ostiguy, Francois, Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: In an unbunched beam in a synchrotron, under conditions where the beam distribution is marginally stable, coherent fluctuations can cause a nonlinear coupling of longitudinal modes. Experimental observations of this parametric resonance have been reported previously. Frequency domain measurements in the Fermilab Main Ring show pathological beam distributions associated with regions of marginal stability in longitudinal phase space; these are believed to be a requirement for the manifestation of the observed coupling. We have extended this investigation to the case of the beam response to an impulse excitation. The temporal development of the response indicates the formation of soliton-like structures within the beam distribution whose characteristics depend on beam conditions and the machine impedance.

Abstract: Employing a previously developed formalism, we have performed ground-state and melting calculations of the expected crystalline beams in ion storage rings ASTRID and TSR.

Abstract: A lattice has been developed for a third generation ultraviolet and soft X-ray light source. The storage ring has an energy of 2 GeV, a circumference of about 400 m and an emittance of less than 5 nm rad. It is made up of four 13 m long straight sections and twelve 7 m semi-long straight sections. The horizontal dynamic aperture is 30 mm at the maximum position of horizontal betatron function, while the vertical dynamic aperture is 13 mm at the center of the insertion device.

Authors: Johnston R.Eugene, Washburn David, Pisano Etta D., Thomlinson William C., Chapman Dean, Gmur Nicholas F., Zhong Zhong, Sayers Dale
Title: Preliminary experience with monoenergetic photon mammography
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnston, R.Eugene, Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States; Washburn, David, Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States; Pisano, Etta D., Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States; Thomlinson, William C., Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States; Chapman, Dean, Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States; Gmur, Nicholas F., Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States; Zhong, Zhong, Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States; Sayers, Dale, Univ. of North Carolina/Chapel Hill,, Chapel Hill, NC, USA, United States
Abstract: We are using a beam port at the National Synchrotron Light Source Facility at Brookhaven National Laboratory as a source of monoenergetic photons. The photon source is radiation from a bending magnet on the x-ray storage ring and provides a usable x- ray spectrum from 5 keV to over 50 keV. A tunable crystal monochromotor is used for energy selection. The beam is 79 mm wide and 0.5 mm high. We imaged the ACR mammography phantom and a contrast-detail phantom using a phosphor plate as the imaging detector. Phantom images were obtained at 16, 18, 20, and 22 keV. Phantom thickness varied from 15 mm to 82 mm. These images were compared to images obtained with a conventional dedicated mammography unit. Subjective preliminary results show that image contrast of the monoenergetic images is similar to those obtained from the conventional x-ray source with somewhat sharper and cleaner images from the monoenergetic source. Quantitative analysis shows that the monoenergetic images have improved contrast compared to the polyenergetic derived images. Entrance skin dose measurements show a factor of 5 to 10 times less radiation for the monoenergetic images with equivalent or better contrast. Although there remain a number of technical problems to be addressed and much more work to be done, we are encouraged to further explore the use of monoenergetic imaging.
Index Keywords: Monoenergetic photon mammography; Tunable crystal monochromotor; X ray storage ring; Detectors; Dosimetry; Image quality; Image sensors; Monochromators; Photons; Synchrotron radiation; X ray radiography

Title: Analysis of positron focusing section for SPring-8 linac
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Authors with affiliations: Mizuno, A., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Suzuki, S., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Yoshikawa, H., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Hori, T., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Yanagida, K., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Sakaki, H., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Taniuchi, T., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Kotaki, H., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan; Yokomizo, H., JAERI-RIKEN, Hyogo, Japan
Abstract: In the SPring-8, positron beams will be used and generated in the linac. In this paper, simulations and experiments of a test apparatus for the convertor are described. Results of simulations are qualitatively coincident with that of experiments, and from simulation results, an electron/positron conversion efficiency of 0.5% is obtained at the end of the convertor, with a feasible design of the convertor system. A future plan of superconducting magnet system for the convertor is also mentioned.

Authors: Deng D.-P., Peggs S.
Title: Rebucketing after transition in RHIC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deng, D.-P., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Peggs, S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: Rebucketing in the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider, RHIC, describes the process of moving the beam from the 26MHz accelerating system to the 196MHz storage system with as little beam loss as possible. This puts a stringent requirement on the beam longitudinal area done at top energy. The ample bucket space after, but not too close to, transition is explored by computer simulation to relax such stringent conditions.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Ion beams; Particle beam dynamics; Synchrotrons; Accelerating system; Beam loss; Relativistic heavy ion collider; Storage system; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: MacKay W.W., Blaskiewicz M., Deng D., Mane V., Peggs S., Ratti A., Rose J., Shea T.J., Wei J.
Title: Estimation of collective instabilities in RHIC
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: MacKay, W.W., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Blaskiewicz, M., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Deng, D., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Mane, V., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Peggs, S., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Ratti, A., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Rose, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Shea, T.J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States; Wei, J., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: We have estimated the broadband impedance in RHIC to be |Z/n| < 1.2 Ω for frequencies above 100 MHz. The Z/n threshold is set for Au+79 ions at transition with an estimated 10% growth in emittance for Z/n = 1.5 Ω. We summarize the sources of broad and narrow band impedances in RHIC and investigate the multibunch instability limits throughout the machine cycle. The largest contribution to the broadband impedance comes from the abort and injection kickers (see [1]). Since RHIC is designed to accelerate fully stripped ions from H+ up to Au+79 we give results for both protons and gold ions; other ions should give results somewhere between these two extremes. All ion species are expected to be stable during storage. At lower energies damping systems and chromaticity corrections will limit any growth to acceptable levels during the short time it takes to inject and accelerate the beams.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Electric impedance; Electric impedance measurement; Estimation; Ions; Particle beam injection; Protons; Broadband impedance; Collective instabilities; Kickers; RF cavity impedance; Colliding beam accelerators

Authors: Schirmer D., Hartrott M.v., Khan S., Kraemer D., Weihreter E.
Title: Beam transport lines at BESSY-II
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: BESSY II, Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schirmer, D., BESSY II, Berlin, Germany; Hartrott, M.v., BESSY II, Berlin, Germany; Khan, S., BESSY II, Berlin, Germany; Kraemer, D., BESSY II, Berlin, Germany; Weihreter, E., BESSY II, Berlin, Germany
Abstract: The injection system for the BESSY-II storage ring consists of a 50 MeV microtron and a synchrotron booster which ramps the electron beam to the final operation energy of max. 1.9 GeV. The requirements to be met by the transfer lines from the microtron to the booster and from the booster to the storage ring are discussed and the respective magnetic structures are presented. A 'genetic' fitting algorithm to optimize the quadrupole settings in the transfer lines is briefly discussed.

Title: RF-power upgrade system with resonant loading
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference

Authors with affiliations: Shalnov, A., Moscow State Engineering-Physics, Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation; Bogdanovich, B., Moscow State Engineering-Physics, Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation; Ignatyev, A., Moscow State Engineering-Physics, Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation; Senyukov, V., Moscow State Engineering-Physics, Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The RF-power upgrade systems with RF-field energy compression are intended for accelerating wave power increase in order to increase an accelerated beam energy or decrease the feeding RF-generators power. At present a number of energy compression system (ECS) types and designs with various properties are known [1]. Among these a system with a resonant load presents the certain interest for practical use. The main difference of such ECS from the other types is that here a resonant load is an essential part of the system that influence significantly on its parameters. They can be named as systems with connected resonators also.

Authors: Nesterov V.V., Donaldson A.R.
Title: High current high accuracy IGBT pulse generator
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nesterov, V.V., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States; Donaldson, A.R., Stanford Linear Accelerator Cent, Stanford, United States
Abstract: A solid state pulse generator capable of delivering high current triangular or trapezoidal pulses into an inductive load has been developed at SLAC. Energy stored in a capacitor bank of the pulse generator is switched to the load through a pair of insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBT). The circuit can then recover the remaining energy and transfer it back to the capacitor bank without reversing the capacitor voltage. A third IGBT device is employed to control the initial charge to the capacitor bank, a command charging technique, and to compensate for pulse to pulse power losses. The rack mounted pulse generator contains a 525 μF capacitor bank. It can deliver 500 A at 900V into inductive loads up to 3 mH. The current amplitude and discharge time are controlled to 0.02% accuracy by a precision controller through the SLAC central computer system. This pulse generator drives a series pair of extraction dipoles.

Authors: Roser T.
Title: Polarized proton beams
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roser, T., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: The acceleration of polarized proton beams in circular accelerators is complicated by the presence of numerous depolarizing spin resonances. Careful and tedious minimization of polarization loss at each of these resonances allowed acceleration of polarized proton beams up to 22 GeV. It has been the hope that Siberian Snakes, which are local spin rotators inserted into ring accelerators, would eliminate these resonances and allow acceleration of polarized beams with the same ease and efficiency that is now routine for unpolarized beams. First tests at IUCF with a full Siberian Snake showed that the spin dynamics with a Snake can be understood in detail. We now have results of the first tests of a partial Siberian Snake at the AGS, accelerating polarized protons to an energy of about 25 GeV. These successful tests of storage and acceleration of polarized proton beams open up new possibilities such as stored polarized beams for internal target experiments and high energy polarized proton colliders.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Magnetic fields; Magnetic resonance; Particle accelerators; Polarization; Protons; Storage rings; Targets; Circular accelerators; Depolarizing spin resonances; Lorentz factor; Polarization loss; Polarized proton beams; Proton beams; Ring accelerators; Siberian snake tests; Spin dynamics; Spin rotators; Particle beams

Abstract: Properties of the wall impedance of a storage ring are studied for a low relativism, γ - 1 ≤ 1. Both broad and narrow band impedances are shown to be damped at low energies, the damping factors are found. Coherent motion of a coasting beam is discussed; Landau decrements are calculated.

Title: Determining electron beam parameters from edge radiation measurement results on Siberia-1 storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Kurchatov Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Chubar, O.V., Kurchatov Inst, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The paper deals with practical application of the method for electron beam diagnostics by means of edge radiation (ER) [1] on the Siberia-1 storage ring. In this application, each measurement of the ER intensity distribution allows one to determine a linear combination of three second-order moments of particle density distribution in transverse phase space. It is shown that, when combining data on the storage ring magnet lattice with the results of two ER intensity distribution measurements (performed at different distances from bending magnet edges), the totality of beam parameters, including horizontal and vertical RMS transverse sizes, angular divergences, energy spread, emittances and mixed moments can be determined.

Title: Test results of a combined distributed ion pump/non-evaporable getter pump design developed as a proposed alternative pumping system for the PEP-II asymmetric B-factory collider
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl Lab, Livermore, United States

Abstract: We have built and tested an all-in-one combination plate-type distributed ion pump/non-evaporable getter pump design (DIP/NEG) considered as a proposed alternative pumping system for the PEP-II B-Factory High Energy Ring (HER). The DIP portion of the design used a Penning cell hole size of 12 mm in a mostly uniform magnetic field of 0.18 T. The NEG portion of the design used commercially available non-evaporable getter material type St-707. A detailed description of the design is presented along with results of pumping speed measurements.

Authors: Jason Andrew J.
Title: Linac-driven spallation-neutron source
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jason, Andrew J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Strong interest has arisen in accelerator-driven spallation-neutron sources that surpass existing facilities (such as ISIS at Rutherford or LANSCE at Los Alamos) by more than an order of magnitude in beam power delivered to the spallation target. The approach chosen by Los Alamos (as well as the European Spallation Source) provides the full beam energy by acceleration in a linac as opposed to primary acceleration in a synchrotron or other circular device. Two modes of neutron production are visualized for the source. A short-pulse mode produces 1 MW of beam power (at 60 pps) in pulses, of length less than 1 ms, by compression of the linac macropulse through multi-turn injection in an accumulator ring. A long-pulse mode produces a similar beam power with 1-ms-long pulses directly applied to a target. This latter mode rivals the performance of existing reactor facilities to very low neutron energies. Combination with the short-pulse mode addresses virtually all applications.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Laser modes; Laser pulses; Linear accelerators; Nuclear reactors; Particle beam injection; Particle beams; Protons; Storage rings; Synchrotrons; Targets; Accumulator ring; Beam power; Full beam energy; Linac driven spallation neutron source; Long pulse mode; Multi turn injection; Short pulse mode; Spallation target; Neutron sources

Abstract: An acceleration of high energy polarized protons is a long term issue of spin physics. The application of Lie algebra method for the calculation of the strength spin resonances (both intrinsic and imperfection) in the high energy proton ring is discussed. The simulation results of the polarized proton acceleration in RHIC with two Siberian snakes are presented.

Authors: Kelly D.R.C., Bialowons W., Brinkmann R., Ehrlichmann H., Kouptsidis J.
Title: Electron beam lifetime problem in HERA
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, (DESY), Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kelly, D.R.C., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, (DESY), Hamburg, Germany; Bialowons, W., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, (DESY), Hamburg, Germany; Brinkmann, R., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, (DESY), Hamburg, Germany; Ehrlichmann, H., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, (DESY), Hamburg, Germany; Kouptsidis, J., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, (DESY), Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: The electron beam lifetime in the HERA storage ring is not only uniformly lower than the positron beam lifetime, but the electron beam lifetime curves display complicated structures not present in the smoothly behaved positron beam lifetime curves. Summaries of characterising quantities are presented for large numbers of runs in 1993 and 1994, enabling the identification of trends in the beam lifetime behaviour. The lifetime reduction seems to be due to many discrete lifetime reduction events. The lifetime achieved at given current depends in a complicated (and stochastic) manner on the filled current, energy and integrated ion getter pump voltage. The properties of the lifetime problem are overwhelmingly consistent with the capture of material by the electron beam (most likely dust particles of size 0.1-1μm) which - being then highly positively charged - scatters beam electrons. The source of this material, or the mechanism of its liberation from the chamber or pump walls, is not entirely understood. Moves towards curing the electron beam lifetime problem are discussed.
Index Keywords: Dust; Electric currents; Particle beam dynamics; Pressure effects; Storage rings; Thermodynamic stability; Vacuum pumps; Electron beam lifetime; Ion pump voltages; Lifetime curves; Positron beam; Electron beams

Authors: Gluskin E., Frachon D., Ivanov P.M., Maines J., Medvedko E.A., Trakhtenberg E., Turner L.R., Vasserman I.
Title: Elliptical multipole wiggler project
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gluskin, E., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Frachon, D., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Ivanov, P.M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Maines, J., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Medvedko, E.A., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Trakhtenberg, E., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Turner, L.R., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States; Vasserman, I., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: The elliptical multipole wiggler (EMW) has been designed, constructed, and installed in the X13 straight section of the NSLS X-ray Ring. The EMW generates circularly polarized photons in the energy range of 0.1-10 keV with AC modulation of polarization helicity. The vertical magnetic field of 0.8 T is produced by a hybrid permanent magnet structure with a period of 16 cm. The horizontal magnetic field of 0.22 T is generated by an electromagnet, the core of which is fabricated from laminated iron to operate with a switching frequency up to 100 Hz. There are dynamic compensation trim magnets at the wiggler ends to control the first and second field integrals with very high accuracy throughout the AC cycle. The residual closed orbit motion due to the electromagnet AC operation is discussed.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Codes (symbols); Computer simulation; Magnetic cores; Magnetic fields; Optimization; Permanent magnets; Photons; Polarization; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; X rays; AC modulation; Elliptical multipole wiggler; Laminated iron; Polarization helicity; X ray ring; Electromagnets

Authors: O'Shea P.G., Carter F., Dickey C., Hower N., Litvinenko V.N., Sachtschale R., Swift G., Wang P., Wu Y., Madey J.M.J.
Title: Accelerator archeology - the resurrection of the Stanford MarkIII electron linac at Duke
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Duke Univ, Durham, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Shea, P.G., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Carter, F., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Dickey, C., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Hower, N., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Litvinenko, V.N., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Sachtschale, R., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Swift, G., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Wang, P., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Wu, Y., Duke Univ, Durham, United States; Madey, J.M.J., Duke Univ, Durham, United States
Abstract: In the early 1960s, the Mark III accelerator at the Stanford High Energy Physics Laboratory was used as the prototype test-bed for the SLAC Two-Mile accelerator. In the mid 1980s the accelerator was dismantled and a large part of it was transported to the Duke University Free-Electron Laser Laboratory to form the basis of the injector for the 1-GeV Duke Storage Ring. The plan was to use the original accelerator sections and some rf equipment with new magnetic optics, vacuum system, gun and a modern control system. The first 295-MeV portion of the linac is now operational at Duke. The linac currently consists of eleven sections from the old linac with a single-cell rf gun. Our guiding principal has been one of economy and simplicity. We have not attempted to restore the accelerator to its original form, but have added modern components where necessary. We discuss some of the more interesting features of the linac, and how we have given new life to this venerable machine here at Duke.
Index Keywords: Cavity resonators; Electric currents; Free electron lasers; Klystrons; Measurements; Particle beam injection; Performance; Storage rings; Vacuum applications; Accelerating sections; Accelerator archeology; Mark III electron linear accelerators; Linear accelerators

Authors: Biggeri U., Borchi E., Bruzzi M., Lazanu S., Li Z.
Title: Self annealing effect on neutron irradiated silicon detectors by Hall effect analysis
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Energetica, Firenze, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Biggeri, U., Dipartimento di Energetica, Firenze, Italy; Borchi, E., Dipartimento di Energetica, Firenze, Italy; Bruzzi, M., Dipartimento di Energetica, Firenze, Italy; Lazanu, S., Dipartimento di Energetica, Firenze, Italy; Li, Z., Dipartimento di Energetica, Firenze, Italy
Abstract: High resistivity n-type silicon samples have been irradiated with approx.1MeV neutrons at fluences between 1012 and 1.4×1014 n/cm-2. The radiation induced changes in the effective free carrier concentration have been analysed by Hall Effect measurement during a storage time of approximately seven months at room temperature. The Hall coefficient measured for the most irradiated samples, exposed to fluences higher than 4×1013 cm-2, has switched from negative to positive values approximately 200 days after the irradiation. This experimental evidence explains the reverse annealing effect observed in neutron irradiated silicon detectors as being related to the creation of a deep acceptor level which causes the change in conductivity from n to p-type of the irradiated silicon bulk during self annealing. The behaviour of irradiated device has been analyzed with a model taking account of donor removal and acceptor creation. Results are in agreement with others obtained with different experimental techniques.
Index Keywords: Annealing; Carrier concentration; Electric conductivity; Electron energy levels; Hall effect; Mathematical models; Neutron irradiation; Radiation damage; Semiconducting silicon; Thermal effects; Acceptor creation; Donor removal; Hall effect analysis; Hall effect measurement; Reverse annealing; Reverse annealing effect; Self annealing; Self annealing effect; Silicon detectors; Particle detectors

Title: Solar two power tower project: a 10 MWe power plant
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chavez, James M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Reilly, Hugh E., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Kolb, Greg J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Gould, Bill, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Zavoico, Alex, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Sutherland, Paul, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: A consortium of US utilities led by Southern California Edison Company has begun a cooperative project with the US Department of Energy and industry to convert the 10 MWe Solar One Power Tower Pilot Plant to molten nitrate salt technology. Successful operation of the converted plant, to be called Solar Two, will reduce the economic risks in building the initial commercial power tower projects and accelerate the commercial acceptance of this promising renewable energy technology. In a molten salt power tower, sunlight is concentrated by a field of sun-tracking mirrors, called heliostats, onto a centrally located receiver, atop a tower. Molten salt is heated in the receiver and stored until it is needed to generate steam to power a conventional turbine generator.
Index Keywords: Heat storage; Heat transfer; Mirrors; Molten materials; Nitrates; Pilot plants; Renewable energy resources; Sodium chloride; Solar energy; Steam; Turbogenerators; Economic risks; Molten nitrate salt technology; Solar power towers; Solar thermal energy; Sun tracking mirrors; Solar power plants

Authors: Wyczalek Floyd A.
Title: Electric vehicle parametric analysis
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: FW Lilly Inc, Bloomfield Hills, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wyczalek, Floyd A., FW Lilly Inc, Bloomfield Hills, United States
Abstract: During the period from 1990 to 1995, the automobile manufacturers of Europe, America, and Japan have been responsive to the need to re-evaluate the battery electric vehicle (EV) an a zero emission vehicle, and have released key design specifications and vehicle performance characteristics for more than thirty electric vehicles displayed at the: 55th IAA International Motor Show in Frankfurt, NAIAS'95 North American International Auto Show in Detroit, and the 30th International Motor Show in Tokyo. This paper includes a comparative parametric correlation analysis of these key design parameters which include: vehicle test mass, tire coefficients, overall aerodynamic drag and skin friction drag coefficients, equivalent flat plate frontal area, length to hydraulic diameter ratio, peak tractive force, peak traction motor power, and battery energy storage capacity. The conclusions show that the automobile manufacturers have achieved dramatic improvements in many of these key design parameters, and as a result the battery electric vehicle now promises to have a brighter future.

Authors: Blank Edward, Farahmandi C.J., Dispennette John
Title: Materials and processes of ultracapacitors for high energy and high power applications
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blank, Edward, Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Farahmandi, C.J., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Dispennette, John, Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Ultracapacitors, a synonym for double layer capacitors, are electrochemical energy storage devices that are able to store more energy per unit weight than traditional capacitors and are capable of delivering and absorbing energy at higher power ratings and cycle life than batteries. Maxwell Laboratories has been developing advanced ultracapacitors for electric vehicle applications funded by the U.S. Department of Energy since 1991. The ability to meet the near term goals of the DOLE have been demonstrated in small scale devices. Maxwell ultracapacitor cells are constructed with electrodes consisting of high surface area carbon fiber and metal in a three dimensional matrix. The most advanced design uses electrodes that are impregnated with an organic electrolytic solution and separated by a porous ionic conducting membrane. This paper provides a description of the operation and configuration of ultracapacitors, outlines the progress attained in the research and development of the devices, and presents performance data for recent prototype devices.
Index Keywords: Carbon fibers; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrochemistry; Electrolytes; Energy storage; Ion selective membranes; Metals; Organic compounds; Porous materials; Solutions; Technology; Electrochemical energy storage devices; Organic electrolytic solution; Ultracapacitors; Capacitors

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Blas, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Bossard, P., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Cappi, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Cyvoct, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Garoby, R., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Gelato, G., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Haseroth, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Jensen, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Manglunki, D., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Metzmacher, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Pedersen, F., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Rasmussen, N., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schindl, K., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schneider, G.C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Schonauer, H., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Several modifications have been made on the existing accelerators of the CERN Heavy Ion Accelerating Facility, aside from the addition of a new linac. These modifications were brought about by the low speed and low intensity of the ion beams and, crucially at low energy, by the short lifetime of the partially stripped ions due to charge exchange with the atoms of the residual gas. Once the optimum charge state and energy of the injector had been chosen, the operational pulse-to-pulse variability of particle species and intensities in the PS and its four ring Booster dictate the main beam parameters.

Authors: Nesemann H., Brefeld W., Brinker F., Decking W., Kaul O., Sarau B.
Title: DORIS III as a dedicated source for synchrotron radiation
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: DESY, Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Nesemann, H., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Brefeld, W., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Brinker, F., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Decking, W., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Kaul, O., DESY, Hamburg, Germany; Sarau, B., DESY, Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: In May 93 the operation of DORIS for high energy physics was discontinued and the ring became a dedicated source for synchrotron radiation operated at 4.5 GeV. Meanwhile a multibunch feedback system to control beam instabilities had been installed and positrons were stored instead of electrons. The resulting improvements and also the present status are described by discussing some important parameters and their limitations. These parameters include the beam lifetime, the maximum stored currents, the number of bunches, the beam dimensions and aperture, orbit distortions, position control of the photon beams, the reliability and the influence of the 10 insertion devices on the stored beam.

Abstract: Plans are being made to replace the 15 year old Daresbury SRS light source with a new 3rd generation ring at an energy of 3 GeV. An earlier concept was based on a TBA lattice which permitted simple inclusion of superconducting dipoles at the centre of selected achromats. A recent design review has recommended changing to a DBA version with the addition of two super long straights. An outline design of this racetrack light source is presented here.

Abstract: The cooling curve for the storage tank of a clathrate (crystalline compounds made of gaseous refrigerant and water) thermal energy storage system using finite element analysis is predicted. The analysis involves modeling of a storage medium which changes its phase from liquid to solid within the storage tank. The solidification of the storage medium takes place during the storage tank's heat extraction simulation process (charging process). The enthalpy-based standard approach is used to overcome the phase change discontinuities. The governing equations count for the phase change, 2-D conduction, and convection modes. The cooling of the storage medium is simulated as energy loss from the storage tank contents.

Abstract: Solar thermophotovoltaics (STPV) potentially have high system power efficiency together with other attractive attributes for both space and terrestrial applications. This paper presents a summary of work that has been conducted by NASA Lewis Research Center (LeRC) and McDonnell Douglas Aerospace (MDA). The paper discusses analytical modeling and subsystem testing, laboratory, and field testing that has been conducted. The features which make solar thermophotovoltaics attractive for both space and terrestrial applications are discussed. Based upon these investigations and the work of others, a conceptual design has been formulated, and an estimate of system performance is presented. This estimate indicates a solar thermophotovoltaics system can result in competitive energy costs for the utility electrical market applications and a high power-to-mass ratio for space power applications.

Authors: Truong Long V.

Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Truong, Long V., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the Decision Support System (DSS), a personal computer software graphics tool for designing conceptual space and/or planetary electrical power systems. By using the DSS, users can obtain desirable system design and operating parameters, such as system weight, electrical distribution efficiency, and bus power. With this tool, a large-scale specific power system was designed in a matter of days. It is an excellent tool to help designers make tradeoffs between system components, hardware architectures, and operation parameters in the early stages of the design cycle. The DSS is a user-friendly, menu-driven tool with online help and a custom graphical user interface. An example design and results are illustrated for a typical space power system with multiple types of power sources, frequencies, energy storage systems, and loads.

Authors: Hoffstaetter G.H.
Title: Nonlinear dependence of synchrotron radiation on beam parameters
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, DESY, Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hoffstaetter, G.H., Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron, DESY, Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: Synchrotron radiation has been traditionally treated as an effect which only depends on the linear beam dynamics. Electrons in advanced accelerators and storage rings, however, can lose several percent of their energy in one turn, especially when the ring incorporates synchrotron radiation sources or free electron lasers. In these machines nonlinear effects can become important, not only because of the high variation of the particle's energy around the ring, but also because of the necessity to have very good beam quality in wigglers, undulators, and free electron lasers. Since these instruments can have helical structure, a general reference frame with torsion is used and the Lorentz-Dirac radiation reaction of the charged particle is taken into account. We will utilize the Differential Algebra technique to compute nonlinear transfer maps of general optical elements. Applications include radiation damping in multipoles, its effect on closed orbit distortion in a storage ring, and nonlinear tune shifts due to various radiating devices. The software provided will also be useful in simulating Siberian snakes.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Algebra; Computer simulation; Computer software; Electrons; Equations of motion; Free electron lasers; Nonlinear equations; Optical devices; Particle beam dynamics; Particle optics; Storage rings; Differential algebra; Dipoles; Lorentz-Dirac equation; Multipoles; Quadrupoles; Radiation damping; Siberian snakes; Taylor maps; Undulators; Wigglers; Synchrotron radiation

Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Jan, G.J., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Chen, Jenny, Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Kuo, C.H., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Lin, T.F., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Pan, K.T., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Lin, Glory, Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Hsu, K.T., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: The prototype bunch killer has been set up at SRRC recently. The system includes two subsystems, the multibunch filling pattern shaping system and single bunch killer system. Gate RF knockout approach is used to shape the filling pattern of multibunch and to obtain a well-defined gap for machine study. The gate processes synchronize with revolution frequency. Widths of the gate signal determine the empty gap of the filling pattern. Beam knockout systems with nanosecond impulse current are also implemented which used to kill the individual electron bunch with bucket addressing capability. The purity of the single bunch is improve by the nanosecond knockout system, despite the difference of the tune and tune spread of the main and parasitic bunches, that lifts the requirement of the narrow tune spread for standard single bunch purification process. The nanosecond knockout technique also applied to kill undesired bunches in the multibunch operation mode. The preliminary results are present.

Abstract: Measurements of longitudinal beam properties in the Stanford Linear Collider (SLC) damping rings have been made using a Hamamatsu, model N3373-02, 500-femtosecond streak camera[1]. The dependence of bunch length on current and accelerating RF voltage was measured. The energy spread dependence of current was also measured. The turbulent instability threshold for the SLC damping ring is at the current of I=1.5-2.0×1010 particles per bunch.

Abstract: The Duke storage ring is a dedicated facility for the UV-VUV FEL operation. The low level computer control system for the Duke storage ring is developed using EPICS. The control hardware employs several different architectures including CAMAC, GPIB, Allen Bradley, and VME. The high level control is implemented in Tcl-Tk scripts running on SPARCstations. Tcl-Tk provides the global control capabilities such as the energy ramping, the orbit compensation, and the tune and chromaticity control. The Duke storage ring control system was tested and operational for storage ring commissioning in Nov. 1994. During commissioning, additional control tools were developed to facilitate the operation.

Abstract: A printed-circuit quadrupole has been designed for low-energy electron beam research in the Institute for Plasma Research at the University of Maryland. This quadrupole is expected to allow more realistic beam studies to be performed in straight beams. Applications include high-current, high-energy accelerators and heavy-ion inertial fusion.

Authors: Bertsche K., Ostiguy J.-F., Foster W.B.
Title: Temperature considerations in the design of a permanent magnet storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bertsche, K., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Ostiguy, J.-F., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States; Foster, W.B., Fermi Natl Accelerator Lab, Batavia, United States
Abstract: To improve the luminosity of the Fermilab Tevatron proton-antiproton collider in the post Main-Injector era, the most straightforward approach is to increase the intensity of the antiproton beam. A number of schemes based on fixed energy storage rings have been suggested to accomplish this goal. A fixed energy ring can be used to accumulate freshly produced antiprotons and/or to recycle used antiprotons at the end a store. For reasons of cost and reliability, permanent magnets are strong contenders for the magnet assemblies, with ceramic ferrite the material of choice. Since ferrite magnetization has a relatively large temperature coefficient, temperature considerations are very important. In this paper, we investigate the expected temperature environment for a fixed energy ring at Fermilab, the required temperature stability and possible methods of compensating temperature dependent effects.

Abstract: A new concept of solar engine (Rincon, 1994) is presented based on the trends of energy conversion and the new development of materials looking for the highest efficiency of conversion and lowest manufacturing cost. Passive elements implemented are one of the new energy conversion concepts; a stationary CPC type collector (18° half acceptance angle), a radial magnetization pattern of magnetic bearings (made of SmCo), and a passive coolant recirculating system removing the internal irreversibilities. The elimination of friction, electrical resistance, spontaneous expansion and compression, magnetic drag, scattering of beam radiation, finite pressure drop and finite temperature differences are key elements of this engine. Its main novelty consists of an adiabatic, frictionless rotor integrating an inertial propulsion engine purely electromechanical and electromagnetic radiation as two modes of propulsion for rotation.

Authors: Bergher M.
Title: Supercooling of bunched beams by coherent synchrotron radiation
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Cent Universitaire Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Authors with affiliations: Bergher, M., Cent Universitaire Paris-Sud, Orsay, France
Abstract: Longitudinal and transverse dimensions of bunched beams may be cooled by coherent synchrotron radiation in storage rings. The cooling starts if the bunches are short enough. Coherent synchrotron radiation with wavelengths of the order of the length of the bunch will propagate in the vacuum chamber of the bending magnet. Achievement of such condition, linked to the bunch dimensions, is generally not possible if only the main RF system is used. Therefore it is necessary to add a tunable idle or powered extra RF cavity, whose frequency depends on the transverse dimensions of the vacuum chamber of the bending magnet and on the radius of the orbit curvature. By this mean, a self-consistent effect can be achieved. The energy transfer among particles of the same bunch leads to a dynamic reduction of all bunch dimensions. For these reasons the whole radiated spectrum becomes coherent. This should be true for all storage rings with particles which emit synchrotron radiation. Our experimental results observed on a e+/e- storage ring are described.
Index Keywords: Calculations; Cavity resonators; Cooling; Energy transfer; Magnets; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Vacuum technology; Bunched beams; Microbunches; Radiofrequency cavity; Supercooling; Vacuum chamber; Particle beams

Abstract: RF-energy compression systems have become widely used as RF-source for linear charged particles accelerators. With the development of new types of energy compression systems, questions emerged regarding the necessity of these systems classification and researching the questions on perspectivity and expediency of their use as the RF-feed sources for electron linacs. Abstract: We are designing an experiment to study physics, engineering, and costing issues of an extended Relativistic Klystron Two-Beam Accelerator (RK-TBA). The experiment is a prototype for an RK-TBA based microwave power source suitable for driving a 1 TeV linear collider. Major components of the experiment include a 2.5-MV, 1.5-kA electron source, a 11.4-GHz modulator, a bunch compressor, and a 8-m extraction section. The extraction section will be comprised of 4 traveling-wave output structures, each generating about 360 MW of rf power. Induction cells will be used in the extraction section to maintain the average beam energy at 5 MeV. Status of the design is presented.

Authors: Bizek Hana M.
Title: Effects of vertical aperture on beam lifetime at the advanced photon source (APS) storage ring
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bizek, Hana M., Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States
Abstract: When a positron's energy deviation δE/E exceeds the rf acceptance, or when it receives an angular kick for the betatron motion that exceeds some limiting admittance, the positron will be lost. The main contributions to the total beam lifetime come from single Coulomb and Touschek scattering. In this report we investigate the dependence of the residual gas pressure and the vertical aperture of the Advanced Photon Source storage ring on the total beam lifetime. We present results of calculating the total beam lifetime as a function of vertical aperture for varying average ring pressure, beam current, and coupling coefficient.

Authors: Zimmermann F., Seeman J.T., Zolotorev M., Stoeffl W.
Title: Trapped macroparticles in electron storage rings
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zimmermann, F., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Seeman, J.T., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Zolotorev, M., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States; Stoeffl, W., Stanford Univ, Stanford, United States
Abstract: Sudden drops of the beam lifetime ascribed to the capture of positively charged macroparticles (`dust') are observed at many high-energy electron storage rings. A trapped macroparticle has a certain thermal lifetime due to energy transfer from the beam; the interplay of different ionizing and discharging processes gives rise to an equilibrium charge. The beam lifetime is reduced by bremsstrahlung both in the field of the atomic nuclei and in the macroscopic field of the highly charged dust particle. Recent observations at some storage rings can be explained by the capture of a single macroparticle of about micron size, possibly made from silicon dioxide. In the two B factories under construction, PEP-II and TRISTAN-II, trapped macroparticles will be thermally unstable and explode after a few tens of microseconds, thanks to the much higher beam current as compared with other storage rings.
Index Keywords: Electron ring accelerators; Electrons; Particle beams; Particle optics; Beam lifetime; Charged dust particles; Trapped macroparticles; Storage rings

Abstract: During The Fermilab fixed target program, the Antiproton Accumulator is available for internal experiments. We have investigated the possibility of using this machine as a p̄p̄ collider in the energy range of 8.9 to 2.2 GeV. This would require upgrades to the current RF systems, the addition of stochastic cooling systems for the protons, and the installation of electrostatic separators. We calculate luminosities in the range of 1028 cm-2sec-1 at a single interaction region with beam intensities of 4×1011 and a beam-beam tune shift of .0015.

Authors: Karnaukhov I., Kononenko S., Shcherbakov A., Nemoshkalenko V., Molodkin V., Shpak A.
Title: Combined magnet lattice of the synchrotron light source ISI-800
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Kharkov Inst of Physics and, Technology, Kharkov, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Karnaukhov, I., Kharkov Inst of Physics and, Technology, Kharkov, Ukraine; Kononenko, S., Kharkov Inst of Physics and, Technology, Kharkov, Ukraine; Shcherbakov, A., Kharkov Inst of Physics and, Technology, Kharkov, Ukraine; Nemoshkalenko, V., Kharkov Inst of Physics and, Technology, Kharkov, Ukraine; Molodkin, V., Kharkov Inst of Physics and, Technology, Kharkov, Ukraine; Shpak, A., Kharkov Inst of Physics and, Technology, Kharkov, Ukraine
Abstract: An electron storage ring for low emittance mode operation has been developed. The parameter optimization was based on the spectrum and beam source sizes, as well as general specifications for the machine performance such as dynamic aperture and beam lifetime. To produce high-brightness photon beams with sufficiently high energy, a compact storage ring based on three bend achromat cell was constructed.
Index Keywords: Accelerator magnets; Electron ring accelerators; Light sources; Linear accelerators; Particle optics; Storage rings; Superconducting magnets; Combined magnet lattice; Three bend achromat lattice; Synchrotron radiation

Authors: Massoletti D., Kim C.H., Jackson A.
Title: Emittance measurements in the ALS Booster Synchrotron
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Authors with affiliations: Massoletti, D., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Kim, C.H., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States; Jackson, A., Univ of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Beam emittance measurements in the Advanced Light Source Booster Synchrotron are presented. Electrons are injected at 50 MeV and extracted at various energies ranging from 150 MeV to 1,520 MeV. The extracted beam is then transported in the Booster-to-Storage-Ring beam transfer line where the emittances are measured. Beam sizes are measured at 7 locations using scintillators and CCD cameras. The measured emittances are then compared with the theory based on intra-beam scattering, betatron coupling, radiation damping, and radiation excitation.
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Linear accelerators; Particle beam extraction; Particle beam injection; Storage rings; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Advanced light source booster synchrotron; Beam emittance; Light sources
