Abstract: To provide electric energy for devices and equipment in apiaries, a suggestion is made of using a solar power installation consisting of a photoelectric 80-watt unit composed of silicon photocells, a buffer storage battery, and a voltage converter of a power of 100 W.
Index Keywords: Design; Performance; Solar cell arrays; Apiculture; Battery; Photovoltaic system; Running; Solar energy

Authors: Cornette James B., Marshall Richard A.
Title: Optimal simulation techniques for distributed energy store railguns with solid state switches
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cornette, James B., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States; Marshall, Richard A., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: The objective of this paper is to present an optimal design methodology to determine the best firing strategy, energy store sizing, energy store spacing and maximum system efficiency for a Distributed Energy Store (DES) railgun. System simulations/designs will be based on the assumption that switching of the energy storage units will be accomplished using solid state devices. Candidate semiconductor technologies are promising in relation to solving the high energy, low weight requirements of a railgun system and other pulsed power systems requiring high energy, compact switching. A simulation code has been developed and used to produce non-dimensional data files that are then scaled to physical railgun values based on input parameters. Energy stores are assumed to be capacitive in nature with diodes to prevent negative currents and crowbar diodes to prevent voltage reversal of the capacitors. The main thrust of this simulation effort is to produce a DES design that optimizes the efficiency of the conversion of stored electrical energy to projectile kinetic energy, while also considering the abilities of near term solid state switching devices.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Codes (symbols); Computer simulation; Diodes; Electric energy storage; Semiconductor switches; Solid state devices; Distributed energy store (DES) railgun; Rail guns

Authors: Khakhaev B.N., Pevzner L.A., Kozyrev V.N.
Title: Problem of highly active waste disposal
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Authors with affiliations: Khakhaev, B.N.; Pevzner, L.A.; Kozyrev, V.N.
Abstract: The highly active wastes (HAW) generated by nuclear energy and radiochemical plant operations, nuclear research institutes and energy power units are stored in temporary repositories and HAW accumulation results to unsafe radioactive levels. According to MAGATE recommendations and government rules, it is necessary to provide reliable radioactive waste isolation system for long-term storage and disposal. A number of proposals on application deep wells with a large diameter for ecologically safe isolation of solid and solidified HAW from the biosphere in deep seated geological formation has been developed. However, real implementation of the proposals still requires detailed studies of structure, properties and parameters of deep geological environment.
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Environmental protection; Geological repositories; Plutonium; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Radioactivity; Radioisotopes; Sedimentary rocks; Spent fuels; Underground structures; Geological formations; Highly active wastes; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Goforth J.H., Anderson B.G., Anderson W.E., Atchinson W.L., Bartram E., Benage J.F., Bowers R.L., Brownell J.H., Findley C.E., Fowler C.M., Garcia O.F., Heltne G.J., Herrera D.H., Herrera T.J., Hockaday M.Y.
Title: Procyon: 18-MJ, 2-μs pulsed power system
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goforth, J.H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Anderson, B.G., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Anderson, W.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Atchinson, W.L., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bartram, E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Benage, J.F., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bowers, R.L., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Brownell, J.H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Findley, C.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Fowler, C.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Garcia, O.F., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Heltne, G.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Herrera, D.H., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Herrera, T.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Hockaday, M.Y., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: With the Procyon, an 18 MJ, 2 μs pulsed power system, considerable reproducibility in powering vacuum loads was demonstrated, showing the possibility of delivering around 20 MA to a solid/liquid liner for high pressure physics studies. Using plasma flow switches, good switching to an implosion load was achieved, albeit no useful radiation was observed. Moreover, the upstream electrode was significantly shaped to enhance the axial jet which was stagnated on a tantalum plate, producing a 45 ns wide pulse of around 40 KJ and creating a void in the plasma along the shaped electrode. Most importantly, 1.5 MJ of radiation was produced at a temperature of roughly 60 eV, in a pulse with a full width half maximum of 250 ns.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric inductors; Electric switches; Electrodes; High energy physics; Magnetic fields; Pinch effect; Plasma flow; Explosive pulsed power systems; Procyon power system; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Kupinski Jr. Anthony F., Goldberg Steven C., Harvey Brent F.
Title: Life of a remedial design contractor (what it means to be first!)
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Parsons Engineering Science Corp, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kupinski Jr., Anthony F., Parsons Engineering Science Corp, United States; Goldberg, Steven C., Parsons Engineering Science Corp, United States; Harvey, Brent F., Parsons Engineering Science Corp, United States
Abstract: In August of 1990, the Department of Energy (DOE) awarded the Parsons Corporation a contract to perform architectural/engineering (A/E) remedial design (RD) services for the Fernald Environmental Management Project (FEMP). Parsons was the fast engineering firm hired as a full-service RD contractor on a DOE site placed on the Superfund National Priorities List. Complicating the implementation of the first RD contract were other contract firsts, such as 1) working initially under DOE as a prime contractor, then under a management and operations (M&O) contractor as a subcontractor, and, currently, under an environmental restoration management contractor (ERMC) as a subcontractor; 2) operating under the then new DOE risk-sharing liability and indemnification regulation (termed the `Accountability Rule'); and 3) operating under new, legally enforceable DOE nuclear safety regulations instead of pre-existing, contractually enforceable DOE Orders. In addition to these contract `firsts.' Were a number of funding and technical changes resulting from shifting priorities in the environmental program. These changes include 1) a decreased local emphasis on implementing innovative remediation technologies; 2) promoting ways to accomplish remedial activities faster, better, and cheaper without sacrificing safety; 3) a new emphasis on land use planning as a means of formulating cleanup levels; and 4) the increased involvement of the public. This combination of contract `firsts' and funding and technical influences has resulted in a dynamic project environment. Managing these dynamic aspects requires systems, protocols, resources and expertise, interface mechanisms and controls, and client/customer relationships that are disciplined, yet adaptive to frequent change. An RD Contractor must recognize that a substantial part of the job will be done in the regulatory, legal, environmental, and public arenas, while the other part involves the more traditional design protocols and skills.
Index Keywords: Environmental restoration management contractor (ERMC); Nuclear safety regulations; Contracts; Environmental impact; Health risks; Laws and legislation; Project management; Public policy; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Rutberg Ph.G., Kasharskiy E.G., Platonova M.Yu., Hutoretskiy G.M.
Title: Choice of the technical decision in the process of power supply source design on the basis of synchronous flywheel generator
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Rutberg, Ph.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Kasharskiy, E.G., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Platonova, M.Yu., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Hutoretskiy, G.M., Russian Acad of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: The statement of the system method of characteristics prediction of the flywheel synchronous generator is investigated. The power supply system for the tokamak was created on the basis of units with inertia energy storages designed and produced by `Electrosila' amalgamation. Each generator with peak power of 242 MVA is accomplished in the form of two-poles synchronous turbogenerator with solid-forged rotor and indirect air cooling of rotor and stator windings. Generator's rotor is directly tied in with flywheel via half-couplings. The flywheel is performed as the solid-forged cylinder, made from steel forging with high mechanical properties.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric motors; Flywheels; Tokamak devices; Synchronous flywheel generators; Power supply circuits

Authors: Maveety J.G., Razani A.
Title: Energy analysis and optimal removal time for a lithium-fluoride phase change material
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Intel Corp, Rio Rancho, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maveety, J.G., Intel Corp, Rio Rancho, United States; Razani, A., Intel Corp, Rio Rancho, United States
Abstract: In this study we consider the transient analysis of a thermal energy storage system modeled as a rectangular thermal system. The working fluid is assumed to be incompressible, which passes through a pipe. The energy transfer from the higher temperature surrounding domain to the working fluid is due to conduction through the phase change material and by convection to the working fluid. We apply an integral technique to determine the behavior of the different temperature profiles as a function of time. In addition we consider second law aspects of the system and isolate those irreversibilities which reduce the availability. Lastly, we propose a normalized figure of merit characterizing the optimal ratio of exergy extraction to exergy change of the storage system as a function of removal time.
Index Keywords: Fluorine compounds; Heat conduction; Integral equations; Lithium; Phase transitions; Pipe; Thermal effects; Energy analysis; Figures of merit; Thermal energy storage system; Working fluids; Energy storage

Authors: Zenouzi M., Mankarios E., Metghalchi M.
Title: Dynamic simulation of a double effect lithium bromide-water absorption cooling system with refrigerant storage tank
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Youngstown State Univ, Youngstown, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zenouzi, M., Youngstown State Univ, Youngstown, United States; Mankarios, E., Youngstown State Univ, Youngstown, United States; Metghalchi, M., Youngstown State Univ, Youngstown, United States
Abstract: A dynamic simulation and performance analysis of a double effect lithium bromide-water absorption air conditioning system is presented. The energy input at the generator can be from a variety of sources including hot water, steam, industrial waste energy, and exhaust energy from engines or gas turbines which are in general time dependent. The absorption cycle utilizes a refrigerant storage tank to enable the system to satisfy the cooling load when the energy input at the generator is insufficient. A mathematical model based on mass, species (lithium bromide), and energy balances for each component of the system is developed to predict the performance of this double-effect absorption cycle. The computer code is capable of predicting various heat transfer rates, temperatures, mass flow rates, concentrations, and the storage rates in the refrigerant storage and absorber tanks. The cycle is simulated under two conditions. The first condition is with a constant energy input, and the second condition is with a fluctuating energy input. The results obtained indicates that the system is capable of satisfying a given total cooling coil load, provided that a sufficient net amount of energy is being supplied to the first generator.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Computer software; Cooling; Energy efficiency; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Mathematical models; Refrigerants; Tanks (containers); Water absorption; Double effect absorption cycle; Lithium bromide; Air conditioning

Authors: Etlicher B., Frescaline L., Lamain H., Auvray P., Rouille C., Buzzi J.M., Roques B., Leon J.F., Lassalle F., Morell A.
Title: Low inductance triggered multichannel surface switch for inductive energy storage generator
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Etlicher, B., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Frescaline, L., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Lamain, H., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Auvray, P., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Rouille, C., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Buzzi, J.M., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Roques, B., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Leon, J.F., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Lassalle, F., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Morell, A., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Abstract: A very low inductance pressurized surface discharge switch has been developed for an inductive energy storage generator. This switch was developed as an integral part of a strip-line MARX assembly. This technology performed reliably up to 50 KV - 700 kA with a switch inductance as low as the inductance of the equivalent strip-line. The measured inductance was less than 4.5 nH. Part of this development was done to improve the reliability of the switch and its electrical characteristics including the effects of the trigger pulse on the current distribution along the width of the strip-line. We will show that jitter and current distribution can be controlled by the trigger pulse voltage and rise time. For the first quarter period of the discharge we correlated the number of channels during operation with the trigger pulse parameters. We carried out experiments to estimate the main characteristics (self-breakdown voltage, number of channels, self inductance, peak current discharge value) of such a switch for different gases (synthetic air, SF6, SF6/N2O2 mixture). Optimized parameters are deduced. These studies give us a model of switch operation which enables this kind of design for very low inductance multi-megajoule systems.
Index Keywords: Air; Asynchronous generators; Electric current distribution; Electric energy storage; Inductance measurement; Nitrogen oxides; Optimization; Reliability; Sulfur compounds; Surface discharges; Inductive energy storage generators; Low inductance triggered surface discharge switches; Electric switches

Authors: Yanshin E.V., Korobeynikov S.M., Ovchinnikov I.T., Sarin S.G., Yahshin K.V., Kopylov V.M., Klepikov A.V.
Title: Physical processes limiting the pulse energy release in liquid dielectrics
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Yanshin, E.V., Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Korobeynikov, S.M., Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Ovchinnikov, I.T., Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Sarin, S.G., Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Yahshin, K.V., Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kopylov, V.M., Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Klepikov, A.V., Siberian Research Inst of Energetics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Our study is intended to increase the energy density of liquid dielectric energy storage to about 1 MJ per cubic meter in large volumes of liquids with charging times up to 50-100 μs. To accomplish this, we studied different physical processes limiting the pulse energy density in liquid dielectrics.
Index Keywords: Dielectric materials; Dielectric properties of liquids; Electric breakdown of liquids; Electric charge; Electric fields; Liquid dielectric energy storage; Electric energy storage

Authors: Rix W., Thompson J., Crumley R., Davis S., Melcher P., Waisman E.
Title: Microsecond plasma opening switch performance at currents above 2 MA
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rix, W., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Thompson, J., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Crumley, R., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Davis, S., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Melcher, P., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States; Waisman, E., Maxwell Lab, Inc, San Diego, United States
Abstract: A coaxial geometry plasma opening switch (POS) was tested on the 4 MJ ACE 4 driver. For the conduction phase a snowplow model indicated that the square root of the plasma density is proportional to the product of the conduction time and peak conduction current for fixed radii and lengths of switches. For the opening phase a model of gap formation enabled the investigation of plasma density thinning. The gap distance was investigated from the voltage and current measurements using a magnetic insulation model. Opening voltages of 1.4 MV after 850 ns of POS conduction time corresponding to a POS conduction of 2.4 MA were observed. A vacuum gap of 1.5 mm±12% was calculated for conduction times between 850 and 1.3 μs.
Index Keywords: Carrier concentration; Electric current measurement; Electron beams; Interferometers; Plasma density; Plasma devices; Plasma sources; Short circuit currents; Spectrometers; Voltage measurement; Magnetic energy storage; Plasma opening switches (POS); Electric switches

Authors: Stevenson G.Bert, Wherley Patricia
Title: Communicating with the public on nuclear materials disposition issues
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Dep of Energy
Authors with affiliations: Stevenson, G.Bert, Dep of Energy; Wherley, Patricia, Dep of Energy
Abstract: The storage and disposition of weapons grade fissile materials involves complex technical issues. The goal of reaching consensus on the best method or methods for storing and ultimately disposing of these materials can only be achieved after an open public discussion of all reasonable alternatives. The United States Department of Energy considered a number of factors in developing a program for public involvement. These factors included defining the affected public, public knowledge about the proposed action, decisions to be made, availability of pertinent information, current public perceptions, and responding to public input. Based upon an analysis of these factors, three primary techniques were selected for communicating with the public. The techniques are distribution of a quarterly newsletter, establishment of an electronic bulletin board, and holding periodic conference calls and public meetings. The newsletter is designed to reach the widest segment of the public and to be meaningful regardless of the reader's level of familiarity with the project. Periodic conference calls and meetings are used to reach the members of the public who have a real but periodic interest in the issues. The electronic bulletin board is used to communicate with a core group of stakeholders who have a continuing high interest in the total storage and disposition program. Initial indications are that these techniques are effective in reaching a wide segment of the public on highly technical and complex questions related to weapons grade nuclear materials. The effectiveness is not the result of these being new techniques but rather using each technique, to the maximum extent possible, to provide open, on-going, two way communications.
Index Keywords: Information dissemination; Public relations; Radioactive waste storage; Nuclear materials disposition; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Avezov R.R., Baadgh A.K., Avezova N.P.
Title: The efficiency of absorptive solar collectors based on cylindrical heat absorbers combined with hot-water storage tanks
Source title: Applied Solar Energy (English translation of Geliotekhnika)
Affiliations: Physicotechnical Institute, Fizika-Solntsa,, Scientific-Industrial Association, Uzbekistan

Abstract: The efficiency of absorptive solar collectors based on cylindrical heat absorbers combined with hot-water storage tanks (accumulators) is estimated by design methods with the aim to study the effect of the thermal characteristics of individual elements of a collector on its total efficiency and on the stage-by-stage optimization of the parameters of these elements.

Authors: Gehman Jr. Victor H., Gripshover Ronald J., Berger Thomas L., Bowen Samuel P., Zia Royce K.P.
Title: Effects of filtration on the impulse breakdown strength of high-purity water
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gehman Jr., Victor H., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Gripshover, Ronald J., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Berger, Thomas L., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Bowen, Samuel P., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States; Zia, Royce K.P., Naval Surface Warfare Cent, Dahlgren, United States
Abstract: High-purity water is the dielectric of choice for most pulsed-power machines. Increasing the electrical breakdown strength of high-purity water is one of the principle goals for pulsed power, because the energy density stored in the water increases as the square of the electric field. This paper concentrates on the impulse breakdown strength for long-stress times (i.e., greater than 65 microseconds). Previous work at Dahlgren has shown that the breakdown strength is independent of stress time in this regime. Our hypothesis is that impurities control the breakdown behavior of nominally high-purity water. Specifically, we will present experimental data that shows the use of filtration methods designed to remove organic material and particulates (which don't affect the resistivity of water), improves the breakdown strength. Earlier results that showed a time variation for improvements in breakdown strength will be explained. An experimental design to achieve even greater improvements in breakdown strength will be presented.
Index Keywords: Electric field effects; Energy storage; Impurities; Particles (particulate matter); Water filtration; Pulsed power machines; Electric breakdown of liquids

Authors: Bhasavanich D., Gilman C.M., Hammon H.G., Nielsen K.
Title: 80 kW, 1/3 Hz repetitive-fire PFN for electrothermal launchers
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhasavanich, D., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Gilman, C.M., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Hammon, H.G., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States; Nielsen, K., Physics Int Co, San Leandro, United States
Abstract: A modular PFN storing 1/4 MJ at 16 kV has been operated to 1/3 Hz into an electrothermal-chemical gun-like dummy load. Repetition rate performance of the critical PFN components was validated: i) low prefire rate and good blocking performance for the triggered vacuum gaps as output switches, ii) low loss, shielded inductors at energy density near 10 J/cc, with vastly reduced external magnetic fields, iii) thermal limitations of the 2.5 J/cc metallized electrode, PVDF dielectric capacitors, and iv) noise-immune performance of the computer-based command, control, and diagnostics system. The PFN module accumulated over 1,600 full energy shots. Superb rep-fire repeatability was indicated with a standard deviation for the output energy of less than ±0.25%.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Capacitors; Computer control; Electric inductors; Electric loads; Electric losses; Electrodes; Magnetic fields; Pulse circuits; Electrothermal chemical (ETC) gun systems; Pulse forming networks (PFN); Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Shropshire David, Feizollahi Fred
Title: Life cycle cost estimation and systems analysis of waste management facilities
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Lockheed Idaho Technologies Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shropshire, David, Lockheed Idaho Technologies Co, Idaho Falls, United States; Feizollahi, Fred, Lockheed Idaho Technologies Co, Idaho Falls, United States
Abstract: This paper presents general conclusions from application of a system cost analysis method developed by the United States Department of Energy (DOE), Waste Management Division (WM), Waste Management Facilities Costs Information (WMFCI) program. The WMFCI method has been used to assess the DOE complex-wide management of radioactive, hazardous, and mixed wastes. The Idaho Engineering Laboratory, along with its subcontractor Morrison Knudsen Corporation, has been responsible for developing and applying the WMFCI cost analysis method. The cost analyses are based on system planning level life-cycle costs. The costs for life-cycle waste management activities estimated by WMFCI range from bench-scale testing and developmental work needed to design and construct a facility, facility permitting and startup, operation and maintenance, to the final decontamination, decommissioning, and closure of the facility. For DOE complex-wide assessments, cost estimates have been developed at the treatment, storage, and disposal module level and rolled up for each DOE installation. Discussions include conclusions reached by studies covering complex-wide consolidation of treatment, storage, and disposal facilities, system cost modeling, system costs sensitivity, system cost optimization, and the integration of WM waste with the environmental restoration and decontamination and decommissioning secondary wastes.
Index Keywords: Cost accounting; Industrial waste treatment; Optimization; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Life cycle cost estimation; Radioactive waste management facilities; Radioactive waste treatment; Environmental protection

Authors: Cygelman Andre I., Guenther Charles D., Wood Warren T.
Title: Long-term plutonium storage: Design concepts
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cygelman, Andre I., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Guenther, Charles D., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Wood, Warren T., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: The dismantlement of nuclear weapons in the United States initiated a comprehensive review by the United States Department of Energy of alternatives for the storage and disposal of plutonium resulting from dismantlements. These alternatives include the long-term storage of plutonium. This paper describes how a concept for storage of plutonium was selected and also describes the feasibility design for a consolidated special nuclear material storage plant that incorporated the selected storage concept (an air-cooled, dry-well storage). The results of operational and cost evaluations of this feasibility design are presented.
Index Keywords: Cost accounting; Ordnance; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Long term plutonium storage; Nuclear weapons; Plutonium

Authors: Jaeger Calvin D., Moya Ronald W., Duggan Ruth A., Tolk Keith M., Rutherford Debra A., Fearey Bryan, Markin Jack, Erikkila Bruce, Close Dan, Wilkey Dennis, Moore Lonnie, Strait Scott
Title: Safeguards and security issues for the U.S. Fissile Materials Disposition Program
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jaeger, Calvin D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Moya, Ronald W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Duggan, Ruth A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Tolk, Keith M., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Rutherford, Debra A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Fearey, Bryan, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Markin, Jack, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Erikkila, Bruce, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Close, Dan, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Wilkey, Dennis, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Moore, Lonnie, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Strait, Scott, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy's Office of Materials Disposition (MD) is analyzing long-term storage and disposition options for fissile materials, preparing a Programmatic Environmental Impact Statement (PEIS), preparing for a Record of Decision (ROD) regarding this material, and conducting other related activities. A primary objective of this program is to support U.S. nonproliferation policy by reducing major security risks. Particular areas of concern are the acquisition of this material by unauthorized persons and preventing the reintroduction of the material for use in weapons. This paper presents some of the issues, definitions, and assumptions addressed by the Safeguards and Security Project Team in support of the Fissile Materials Disposition Program (FMDP). The discussion also includes some preliminary ideas regarding safeguards and security criteria that are applicable to the screening of disposition options.
Index Keywords: Public policy; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Fissile materials disposition; Nuclear materials safeguards

Authors: Shen I.Y., Ku C.-P.Roger
Title: On the rocking motion of a rotating flexible-disk/rigid-shaft system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Information Storage and Processing Division, ISPS
Affiliations: Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shen, I.Y., Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States; Ku, C.-P.Roger, Univ of Washington, Seattle, United States
Abstract: This paper studies free vibration of a spinning elastic disk with a rigid shaft, which is mounted between a pair of elastic bearings and is subjected to precessional and nutational motion. Based on the kinetic and potential energies of the disk/shaft system, the equations of motion are derived through Lagrange's equations. Equilibrium conditions of the equations of motion indicate the existence of steady precession (or rocking modes). In addition, the angular speed φ0 of the steady precession (or the frequencies of the rocking modes) depends substantially on the natural frequencies of one nodal diameter disk modes, the bearing stiffness, and the bearing span. During the steady precession, one nodal diameter sine modes undergo a static deformation and other disk modes remain undeformed. In particular, equilibrium conditions of the equations of motion simultaneously predict the critical speeds of a spinning disk with steady precession. Besides, an analysis of small oscillations about the steady precession indicates that the nutation of the rigid shaft and the transverse vibration of one nodal diameter sine modes of the elastic disk are coupled together. Finally, calibrated experiments are conducted to validate the theoretical predictions above. The theoretical predictions and experimental results are in close agreement.
Index Keywords: Bearings (machine parts); Deformation; Equations of motion; Lagrange multipliers; Natural frequencies; Oscillations; Rotating disks; Shafts (machine components); Stiffness; Vibrations (mechanical); Nutational motion; Precessional motion; Magnetic disk storage

Authors: Aranchuck L., Frescaline L., Auvray P., Etlicher B., Lassalle F., Leon J.F.
Title: Analytical model for multimodule IES generator efficiency optimization
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Aranchuck, L., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Frescaline, L., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Auvray, P., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Etlicher, B., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Lassalle, F., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France; Leon, J.F., Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau, France
Abstract: The topics of this paper is to optimize the current transfer from the MARX generator to the load of a multimodule Inductive Energy Storage Generator (IES). On the base of POS we carried out this work for the optimization of a generator called MAG2 in IES configuration driving a Z-pinch load (stored energy 160 kJ, Z-pinch peak current 2 MA). The first part is devoted to an analytical analysis of the multimodule IES scheme driving a dynamic load (0D model) in the case of ideal opening of Plasma Opening Switches (POS). We estimate the main characteristics as critical voltages, load peak current and efficiency of the design during the different operation steps: MARX discharge on inductive storage line, POS opening and transfer to an imploding load. Using these data some scaling principals based on the efficiency optimization of the IES concept are proposed to find the optimum values of upstream and downstream inductance and MARX voltage (number of capacitors in series) of this kind of generator driving a PRS load.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Semiconductor plasmas; Semiconductor switches; Voltage control; Multimodule inductive energy storage (IES) generator; Asynchronous generators

Authors: Del Guercio M., Stobie I., Katulka G., Oberle W.
Title: Pulse forming network design for electrothermal-chemical combustion characteristics of solid propellants
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: US Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States
Authors with affiliations: Del Guercio, M., US Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States; Stobie, I., US Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States; Katulka, G., US Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States; Oberle, W., US Army Research Lab, Aberdeen Proving Ground, United States
Abstract: The combustion of solid propellants subjected to plasma augmentation, has been studied with a 300 kJ maximum stored energy pulse forming network (PFN) in the range of 1 kJ/g of electrical energy over a 1.2 ms pulse length. A closed chamber vessel is used for the combustion of these solid propellants in which the plasma is injected via a plasma generator. To characterize the effects of such plasma augmentation on propellant combustion over a longer pulse length, this PFN was upgraded to a maximum stored energy output of 400 kJ with a 2.4 ms pulse length. This report discusses the theoretical calculations, PFN upgrade design and fabrication details. Also provided are the design and modifications of the plasma generator that allows a delayed plasma injection with respect to the propellant ignition. Details of the plasma delay firings are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Ignition; Plasma sources; Plasmas; Electrothermal chemical combustion; Storage energy pulse forming networks; Solid propellants

Authors: Diakov Anatoli S.
Title: Disposition of already separated plutonium in Russia: Consideration of short- and long-term options
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Energy and Environmental Studies at, the Moscow Inst of Physics and, Technology, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Diakov, Anatoli S., Energy and Environmental Studies at, the Moscow Inst of Physics and, Technology, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: The utilization of already separated plutonium, particularly excess plutonium from retired nuclear weapons, involves a complex set of political, technical, economical, and environmental problems. These problems are closely-related and mutually-reinforcing. The official Russian concept of plutonium utilization views it as a valuable energy source. This concept entails two measures: storage of both surplus weapons and civil plutonium and fabrication of mixed oxide fuels for future use in a different type of reactor, light water and fast-neutron reactors. The effort of utilizing this wastes must be carried out in short-term options.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Environmental impact; Mixed oxide fuels; Plutonium; Waste utilization; Abstract only; Weapons grade plutonium; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Gago Jose A., Gravalos Jose M.
Title: Development of dual purpose (storage and transport) metal casks in Spain
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: ENRESA, Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Gago, Jose A., ENRESA, Madrid, Spain; Gravalos, Jose M., ENRESA, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The Spanish Nuclear Program consists of nine nuclear power plants with an overall capacity of 7.4 GWe, representing around 38% of the electricity share. In 1982 the National Energy Plan established the open cycle as the strategy to be followed thereby halting the reprocessing option. As a consequence of this Plan, a state-owned company, ENRESA, responsible to the Ministry of Industry and Energy, was created in 1984 with the responsibility to manage all kinds of radioactive wastes. To comply with its responsibilities for the interim storage of spent fuel, ENRESA has designed a strategy based on the use of dual purpose metal casks for the initial demand of additional storage capacity.
Index Keywords: Containers; Radioactive waste transportation; Spent fuels; Dual purpose spent fuel metal casks; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Anderson W.E., Armijo F.V., Bartos J.J., Bush H.M., Garcia F.P., Gobby P.L., Gomez V.M., Gurule V.A., Hatch D.J., Manzanares R., Moore J.E., Rivera G., Salzer L.J.
Title: Fabrication of the 3.2 gram Pegasus-II aluminum liner and load components of the liner ejecta experiment
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anderson, W.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Armijo, F.V., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bartos, J.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bush, H.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Garcia, F.P., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Gobby, P.L., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Gomez, V.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Gurule, V.A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Hatch, D.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Manzanares, R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Moore, J.E., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Rivera, G., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Salzer, L.J., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Fabrication of the 3.2 gram Pegasus-II 1100 series aluminum liner is described. This liner is driven by nominally 5 MA from the Pegasus-II two-stage Marx bank charged to approximately 35 kV net. The liner will accelerate symmetrically to a final velocity of 3 mm/μs while it remains in contact with an annular glide plane surface at each electrode for a radial distance of 7.5 mm. At this drive level, up to 300 kbar shocks are expected when the solid density liner wall collides with the surface of a cylindrical liner experiment assembly mounted on axis within the liner bore. Components of the Los Alamos Liner Ejecta Experiment are described as one example of a Pegasus-II liner experiment.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Electrodes; High energy physics; Aluminum liner; Liner ejecta experiments; Pulse power loads; Capacitor storage

Authors: Prisyankov V.F., Gabrinets V.A., Gontarev Yu.K., Kapulkin A.M., Lyagushin S.F., Statsenko I.N., Trofimenko A.V.
Title: Potential uses of HYDECS type energy converters in space power plants
Authors with affiliations: Prisyankov, V.F.; Gabrinets, V.A.; Gontarev, Yu.K.; Kapulkin, A.M.; Lyagushin, S.F.; Statsenko, I.N.; Trofimenko, A.V.
Abstract: The feasibility of utilizing work done at our University in a hybrid energy converter, including thermionic and photovoltaic converters (the Japanese HYDECS project) is analyzed. The desirability of employing solar energy in the lunar energy park (LEP) project is confirmed. Analytic results, and experience in the construction of concentrators, heat receivers, thermal storage, heat pipes, cesium supply systems and systems for suppression of plasma instabilities for the solar-energy heated hybrid converter are described.
Index Keywords: Lunar missions; Plasma stability; Solar cells; Thermionic power generation; Lunar energy park (LEP) project; Solar energy heated hybrid converters; Power converters

Authors: Clement Gilles, David Gilles
Title: Evolution of the LR56 type B(U) cask system for the transportation of radioactive liquid wastes
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: SGN, St Quentin en Yvelines, France
Authors with affiliations: Clement, Gilles, SGN, St Quentin en Yvelines, France; David, Gilles, SGN, St Quentin en Yvelines, France
Abstract: The LR56 cask system has been initially developed by the French Atomic Energy Commission (CEA) for off-site radioactive liquids transportation. Two models of this IAEA, Type B(U) certified cask have been in day-to-day use in France and Europe since 1988. Recently the US DOE has decided to purchase two LR 56 systems, one each for use at the Hanford and Oak Ridge sites. Modifications have been made to the original design (such as the addition of an integrated spray rinsing system for removal of particulates) in order to comply with the needs of the DOE sites. Salient characteristics of the system and its new applications are described in the paper.
Index Keywords: Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Tanks (containers); Casks; Radioactive liquid wastes; Radioactive waste transportation

Authors: Devgun Jas S., Larson Gregg S.
Title: Development of low-level radioactive waste disposal capacity in the United States - progress or stalemate?
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argone, United States
Authors with affiliations: Devgun, Jas S., Argonne Natl Lab, Argone, United States; Larson, Gregg S., Argonne Natl Lab, Argone, United States
Abstract: It has been fifteen years since responsibility for the disposal of commercially generated low-level radioactive waste (LLW) was shifted to the states by the United States Congress through the Low-Level Radioactive Waste Policy Act of 1980 (LLRWPAA). In December 1985, Congress revisited the issue and enacted the Low-Level Radioactive Waste Policy Amendments Act of 1985 (LLRWPAA). No new disposal sites have opened yet, however, and it is now evident that disposal facility development is more complex, time-consuming, and controversial than originally anticipated. For a nation with a large nuclear power industry, the lack of availability of LLW disposal capacity coupled with a similar lack of high-level radioactive waste disposal capacity could adversely affect the future viability of the nuclear energy option. The U.S. nuclear power industry, with 109 operating reactors, generates about half of the LLW shipped to commercial disposal sites and faces dwindling access to waste disposal sites and escalating waste management costs. The other produces of LLW - industries, government (except the defense related research and production waste), academic institutions, and medical institutions that account for the remaining half of the commercial LLW - face the same storage and cost uncertainties. This paper will summarize the current status of U.S. low-level radioactive waste generation and the status of new disposal facility development efforts by the states. The paper will also examine the factors that have contributed to delays, the most frequently suggested alternatives, and the likelihood of change.
Index Keywords: Geological repositories; Laws and legislation; Public policy; Radioactive waste storage; Low level wastes (LLW); Radioactive waste generation; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Lightner Ralph, Cormier Charles, Bierley Denise
Title: UMTRA - the US Uranium Mill Tailings Remedial Action Project
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lightner, Ralph, U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Cormier, Charles, U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Bierley, Denise, U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: In the late 1970s, the United States (U.S.) established the first comprehensive regulatory structure for the management, disposal, and long-term care of wastes produced from its domestic uranium processing industry. This regulatory framework was established through the passage of the Uranium Mill Tailings Radiation Control Act of 1978, often referred to as UMTRCA. This legislation created the Uranium Mill Tailings Remedial Action (UMTRA) Project and assigned the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) the lead in conducting the required remedial action at 24 designated inactive uranium ore processing sites. With the majority of these 22 sites complete, the DOE's UMTRA Project has established a distinguished reputation for safely and effectively remediating these low-level waste sites in a complex regulatory and socioeconomic environment. This paper describes the past accomplishments and current status of the UMTRA Project and discusses the DOEs plans for addressing ground water contamination associated with these sites and its commitment to continuing the long-term care and management of these disposal cells.
Index Keywords: Environmental impact; Groundwater pollution; Laws and legislation; Project management; Radioactive waste storage; Uranium; Uranium ore treatment; Uranium ore processing sites; Uranium ore tailings; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Summa W.J., Gullickson R.L., Hebert M.P., Rowley J.E., Leon J.F., Vitkovitsky I.
Title: Advances in X-ray simulator technology
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Defense Nuclear Agency, United States
Authors with affiliations: Summa, W.J., Defense Nuclear Agency, United States; Gullickson, R.L., Defense Nuclear Agency, United States; Hebert, M.P., Defense Nuclear Agency, United States; Rowley, J.E., Defense Nuclear Agency, United States; Leon, J.F., Defense Nuclear Agency, United States; Vitkovitsky, I., Defense Nuclear Agency, United States
Abstract: Inductive energy storage offers X-ray simulators the promise of more compact and affordable energy storage and delivery for larger systems. The DECADE simulator will store approximately 10 MJ of energy and deliver about 2 MJ to separate bremsstrahlung sources or to a combined plasma radiation source load. Inductive energy storage involves the use of an opening switch connected parallel to the load. Energy is delivered to the load when the switch rapidly increases its resistance. The most commonly used switch is the plasma opening switch which opens as charge carriers are depleted or move out of the conduction region under the influence of magnetic forces. Switch performance can improve as plasma radiation source loads operate at longer implosion times.
Index Keywords: Inductive energy storage; X ray simulators; Charge carriers; Electric inductors; Electric switches; Plasma density; Plasma devices; Plasma sources; Simulators; X rays; Energy storage

Authors: Fish Jerry R., Nelson Robert A.
Title: Building your own underground storage project: from leasing to open season under FERC Order No. 636
Source title: Proceedings of the American Gas Association, Operating Section
Affiliations: Stoel Rives Boley Jones & Grey, Portland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fish, Jerry R., Stoel Rives Boley Jones & Grey, Portland, United States; Nelson, Robert A., Stoel Rives Boley Jones & Grey, Portland, United States
Abstract: Following Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) Order No. 636, the underground storage of natural gas has become more valuable than ever as an alternative to building new interstate pipeline capacity. Today, underground gas storage can already be developed by producers, marketers, and large industrial gas users as well. This article attempts to survey the technical and legal issues involved in developing new underground gas storage project.
Index Keywords: Costs; Economics; Facilities; Gas industry; Gas pipelines; Gas supply; Laws and legislation; Natural gas; Personnel; Project management; Federal energy regulatory commission; Interstate gas pipeline companies; Local gas distribution companies; Underground gas storage

Authors: Balz Werner, Haijtink Bert
Title: European community R&D activities on management and storage of radioactive waste
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: European Commission, Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Balz, Werner, European Commission, Brussels, Belgium; Haijtink, Bert, European Commission, Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: The European Commission is implementing since twenty years R&D programs in the field of Management and Storage of Radioactive Waste. These programs are being carried out either under shared-cost contracts by national laboratories in the various Member States of the European Union or in the Joint Research Centres of the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom). The Council of the European Union took on 16 December 1994 a decision concerning a new Community R&D program on Nuclear Fission Safety (1994-1998) including research on radioactive waste management and disposal. One of the main objectives of the activities to be carried out is to contribute to a further integration of the efforts undertaken by the Member States and the Community to develop the technical basis and a common understanding of the scientific issues of the disposal of long-lived radioactive waste, specifically spent fuel and vitrified high level waste. The need to establish the scientific basis for guidelines for waste management practices, where necessary from review of past work, is also recognized.
Index Keywords: Contracts; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste vitrification; Research and development management; Research laboratories; Spent fuels; Radioactive waste management; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Peretrukhin V.F., Delegard C.H.
Title: Studies of the chemistry of transuranium elements and technetium at the Institute of Physical Chemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Peretrukhin, V.F., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Delegard, C.H., Russian Acad of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Alkaline high-level wastes produced in the separation of plutonium for defense are stored underground in reinforced concrete tanks lined with mild steel at the U.S. Department of Energy's (USDOE) Hanford and Savannah River Sites. Retrieval, treatment, and immobilization of these wastes into separate high-level and low-level forms for long-term storage is planned to occur over the next few decades. Key to the separation of the low- and high-level fractions is knowledge of the chemical behaviors of the radioactive transuranic elements (TRU; principally neptunium - Np, plutonium - Pu, and americium - Am) and technetium (Tc) in the wastes' alkaline media.
Index Keywords: Americium; Industrial waste treatment; Neptunium; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Plutonium; Radiation chemistry; Technetium; Uranium; Alkaline high level wastes; Transuranic (TRU) elements; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Motzkus K.-H., Weil L.
Title: Decommissioning Russian type power plants in eastern Germany - conceptions and experience
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Federal Office for Radiation, Protection
Authors with affiliations: Motzkus, K.-H., Federal Office for Radiation, Protection; Weil, L., Federal Office for Radiation, Protection
Abstract: All water water energy reactor (WWER) type nuclear power plant units operating on the area of the former GDR were finally shut down in 1990, and their decommissioning was decided in 1990/91. The disassembly of power components will commence in inactive and low-active areas and will proceed to areas of high activity. It should be noted that there is no decommissioning fund, that the shutdown of the plants is not being planned in the usual way, that many technical connections exist between the Greifswald unit, that more than 5200 fuel elements are still available on the sites, and that the disposal of in-plant and decommissioning wastes still has to be clarified.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Decision making; Nuclear fuel elements; Nuclear reactor licensing; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Water water energy reactors; Decommissioning (nuclear reactors)

Authors: Kruse Peter W., Carteret Betty
Title: Light duty utility remote manipulator for underground storage tank inspection and characterization
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Spar Aerospace Ltd, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Kruse, Peter W., Spar Aerospace Ltd, Canada; Carteret, Betty, Spar Aerospace Ltd, Canada
Abstract: The Light Duty Utility Arm (LDUA) is a remote manipulator system which is being designed and fabricated to perform surveillance and characterization activities in support of the remediation of underground storage tanks at the Hanford site as well as other DOE sites. The LDUA is a mechanical manipulator which utilizes an advanced control system to safely and reliably deploy a series of sensors to characterize underground storage tanks. The electrical components of the in tank system are radiation hardened and the mechanical components are designed to operate in the corrosive environment which exists in the tanks. The use of this system will allow the U.S. Department of Energy to sample and characterize the waste material in the tanks prior to the initiation of waste retrieval operations. In addition to its use for inspecting and characterizing underground storage tanks, the system has the potential to be used in other environments where accessibility is limited and where high radiation levels exist.
Index Keywords: Light duty utility arm (LDUA); Underground storage tanks; Industrial robots; Inspection; Radioactive waste storage; Robotic arms; Sensors; Tanks (containers); Underground structures; Manipulators

Abstract: The proceedings contains 20 papers from the 1995 ASME International Joint Power Generation Conference. Authors: Corley J.P., Pankuch P.J., Hamil R.A., Ramirez J.J., Law K.D., Bennett L.F., Mazarakis M.G., Prestwich K.R., Alexander J.A., Drennan S.A., Ruscetti J.R., Pritchard C.A., Corcoran P.A., Fockler J., Smith I.D.
Title: Component design, development, and testing of an Inductive Voltage Adder (IVA) system for Jupiter
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Corley, J.P., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Pankuch, P.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Hamil, R.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Ramirez, J.J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Law, K.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Bennett, L.F., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Mazarakis, M.G., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Prestwich, K.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Alexander, J.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Drennan, S.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Ruscetti, J.R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Pritchard, C.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Corcoran, P.A., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Fockler, J., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Smith, I.D., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: Jupiter is a proposed 15-20 MJ laboratory x-ray source. It would store approximately 100 MJ in the Marx generators and deliver approximately 500 TW to drive high power z-pinch implosions. The pulsed power requirements for Jupiter were evaluated by a national review panel which concluded that the modular IVA technology as used in HERMES III is capable of meeting these requirements. Modularity of construction permits design verification with less than a full size system and offers the flexibility to meet changing requirements. A program to validate this approach at the required power levels has begun with the construction and testing of components that will comprise a full scale IVA generator module. The IVA module will provide a nominal 10 MV, 1.8 MA, 100 ns FWHM output pulse and will consist of four submodules. Each submodule is composed of a Marx generator, two Intermediate Energy Storage Capacitors (ISCs) four Pulse Forming Lines (PFLs), one Voltage Adder Cavity (VAC), plus other associated switches and hardware. A conceptual design for this IVA module has been completed. Initial designs for the ISC, PFL, and their gas switches are also complete and hardware has been procured. Testing of these components is underway at Sandia National Laboratories. Discussions of these designs and results of tests are presented in this paper.
Index Keywords: Electric drives; Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Equipment testing; X rays; Inductive voltage adder (IVA) system; Adders

Authors: Ihara Satoshi, Kamatani Masaki, Satoh Saburo, Yamabe Chobei, Akiyama Hidenori
Title: Characteristics of a TEA-CO2 laser oscillation by an inductive energy storage pulsed power system
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Saga Univ, Saga, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ihara, Satoshi, Saga Univ, Saga, Japan; Kamatani, Masaki, Saga Univ, Saga, Japan; Satoh, Saburo, Saga Univ, Saga, Japan; Yamabe, Chobei, Saga Univ, Saga, Japan; Akiyama, Hidenori, Saga Univ, Saga, Japan
Abstract: A pulsed-power technology is used to develop the laser system. Blumlein generator, magnetic compression and capacitor-transfer type circuits, can be applicable as a power supply. Inductive energy storage pulsed-power generator can probably realize the lightweight, compact, and high power laser system. The experiments for TEA-CO2 laser oscillation are carried out using the inductive energy storage pulsed-power generator and the efficiency of laser oscillation of 3.9% was obtained and this was compared with the capacitor-transfer type method.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide lasers; Electric generators; Energy storage; Oscillations; Blumlein generators; Inductively energy storage pulsed power systems; Magnetic compression; Transversely excited atmosphere carbon dioxide laser oscillations; High power lasers

Authors: Scott M.C., O'Loughlin J.P., Copeland R.P.
Title: 350 kV dual resonant transformer for charging a 40 pF PFL at kilo-hertz rep-rates
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Maxwell Lab, Inc, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Scott, M.C., Maxwell Lab, Inc, Albuquerque, United States; O'Loughlin, J.P., Maxwell Lab, Inc, Albuquerque, United States; Copeland, R.P., Maxwell Lab, Inc, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: A dual resonant transformer, capable of charging a 40 pF pulse forming line to 350 kV, has been developed. Peak repetition rates of two kilo-Hertz have been obtained with the use of a self break high pressure hydrogen spark gap switch. The primary energy store of the device consists of 17.6 nF at 30 kV. This paper will discuss the design of the transformer, the development of the high pressure hydrogen switch, and the use of a high pressure SF6 environment to house the pulse transformer. Also the method used to repetitively charge the primary energy store will be presented. Data obtained under rep-rate operation will be shown to illustrate repeatability of the self break voltage and the subsequent output voltage pulse of the transformer.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric spark gaps; Dual resonant transformers; Electric transformers
