Affiliations: Federal Railroad Administration, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tsai, T.N., Federal Railroad Administration, Washington, United States; Price, J.H., Federal Railroad Administration, Washington, United States
Abstract: One of the major objectives of the Federal Railroad Administration's (FRA) Next Generation High-Speed Rail (NGHSR) program is to develop a non-electric propulsion system to provide cost-effective service in corridors other than Amtrak's Northeast Corridor. FRA plans to focus on the final development and testing of potential propulsion systems which can be easily adapted for installation in a locomotive or trainset. The goal of this project is to have a non-electric locomotive capable of sustained speeds of 150 mph, with acceleration comparable to that of an electric locomotive. The system should be reliable, fuel efficient, and in compliance with applicable noise and air emission requirements. This paper describes a hybrid propulsion system of gas turbine, energy storage flywheel and high-speed alternator designed to meet the propulsion power and reduced emissions performance goals of the NGHSR program. This project has been designated the Advanced Locomotive Propulsion System (ALPS). Other relevant propulsion technologies such as fuel cells, light-weight diesels and turbines are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Flywheel propulsion; Locomotives; Railroad transportation; Steam propulsion; High speed railroad transportation; Locomotive propulsion systems; Gas turbine locomotives

Authors: Parsons W.M., Reass W.A., Griego J.R., Bowman D.W., Thompson C., Gribble R.F., Shlachter J.S., Ekdahl C.A., Goldstone P.D., Younger S.M.
Title: Atlas - a facility for high energy density physics research at Los Alamos National Laboratory
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Parsons, W.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Reass, W.A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Griego, J.R., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Bowman, D.W., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Thompson, C., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Gribble, R.F., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Shlachter, J.S., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Ekdahl, C.A., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Goldstone, P.D., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Younger, S.M., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: Atlas is a facility designed for high-energy experiments in support of weapon-physics and basic research programs at Los Alamos. For hydrodynamic and radiation transport experiments, this facility can achieve pressures exceeding 30 Mbar <cm3 volumes capable of producing greater than 3 MJ of soft X-rays. It is composed of a capacitor bank which consists of a 36-MJ array of 600-kV Marx modules designed to deliver a peak current of 20-25 MA with a 2-3 μs rise time. The capacitor bank is resistively damped to limit fault currents and capacitor voltage reversal. Both oil and air-insulated Marx module designs are evaluated.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Capacitors; Electric charge; Electric fault currents; Electric generators; Electric inductors; Electric rectifiers; Electric switches; Electrohydrodynamics; High energy physics; X ray production; Marx modules; Pulse charging system; Soft X rays; Research laboratories

Authors: Grater Guy F., MacDougall Frederick W., Hudis Martin, Yang Xiao Hui
Title: Characterization of high energy density capacitors under projected U.S. Navy ETC gun operating conditions
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: NSWC Carderock, Annapolis, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grater, Guy F., NSWC Carderock, Annapolis, United States; MacDougall, Frederick W., NSWC Carderock, Annapolis, United States; Hudis, Martin, NSWC Carderock, Annapolis, United States; Yang, Xiao Hui, NSWC Carderock, Annapolis, United States
Abstract: The US Navy has been developing ETC gun system technologies since 1990 for use in ship self defense and surface fire support missions. Emphasis has been placed on the capacitor-based pulse forming network (PFN) as the primary means of energy storage and pulse shaping. Defining and understanding the electrical and mechanical performance characteristics of high energy density capacitors is critical for both the PFN designer and overall weapons system engineering. Aerovox Type LM capacitors (2.4 MJ/m3) were evaluated under the projected Navy operating scenarios, including rep-rate and burst modes. The Aerovox Type LM capacitors, first used in the US Army 8.5 MJ Pulsed Power Module in 1991, are known to be nonlinear with respect to capacitance and voltage. Additionally, the charge/discharged efficiency is known to be lower for this capacitor than for other, lower energy density capacitors. The life characteristics of the capacitor have been established under normal operating conditions. This paper discusses the performance of the Aerovox Type LM capacitors in both normal and fault mode conditions. The parameters discussed include temperature variations, voltage reversal, and peak current performance. Thermal stability and fault mode performance for the capacitor is also defined.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electromagnetic launchers; Pulse shaping circuits; Thermodynamic stability; Aerovox type LM capacitors; High energy density capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Goetz V., Gardie P., Spinner B., Heinry D.
Title: Two practical storage applications of thermochemical transformers (STELF process)
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Universite de Perpignan, Perpignan, France
Authors with affiliations: Goetz, V., Universite de Perpignan, Perpignan, France; Gardie, P., Universite de Perpignan, Perpignan, France; Spinner, B., Universite de Perpignan, Perpignan, France; Heinry, D., Universite de Perpignan, Perpignan, France
Abstract: The thermochemical energy storage is a suitable solution for the design of self-contained units (during the production phase) for air-conditioning. This paper gives two examples of application of such processes. The first one is the heating in winter and the cooling in summer of electric vehicles. The simulations show that a machine which is composed of an ammonia evaporator/condenser and a solid/gas reactor is able to achieve these two functions. The second one is the air-conditioning of persons equipped with a total insulation garment. It is presented the experimental results obtained with the resorption process that consists of the coupling by the gaseous phase of two solid/gas reactors.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Computer simulation; Condensers (liquefiers); Cooling; Evaporators; Heating; Two phase flow; STELF process; Thermochemical transformers; Energy storage

Authors: Blyukher Boris
Title: Oxygen deficiency hazard (ODH) analysis for pressure and cryogenic systems facilities
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Indiana State Univ, Term Haute, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blyukher, Boris, Indiana State Univ, Term Haute, United States
Abstract: The presence and use of pressure and cryogenic systems associated with storage, handling, and transfer of compressed and liquefied gases, and cryogenic liquids is commonplace at most industries, R&D and test facilities. The uncontrolled introduction of these materials into the workplace environment presents a hazard and increases the risk of asphyxiation or fatality from exposure to reduced atmospheric oxygen. This paper will generalize international experience gained by developing and establishing ODH control programs at Superconducting Super Collider Laboratory (SSCL), Fermi National Laboratory (FNL), and Cryogenic Co. `KISLORODMASH' (Ukraine). ODH Control program elements include quantitative ODH analysis and risk assessment, operations and ODH creating mechanisms study, ODH areas classification, ODH control measures, and personnel controls. This program involves analysis and basic calculations that show the quantity of the potential source in the area of assessment could or could not result in an ODH. This paper also includes some results of ODH analysis performed by the author at SSCL for the Linear Accelerator Building, Ion Source Low Energy Beam Lab, Vacuum R&D Lab, Ion Source Test Stand, and Corrector Magnets Test Pit. This have been presented by the author at a Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Workshop on Pressure Safety (Pleasanton, CA, Dec.6-8, 1994).
Index Keywords: Computer aided analysis; Computer software; Control system synthesis; Cryogenic equipment; Linear accelerators; Risk assessment; Oxygen deficiency hazard (ODH) analysis; Structural analysis

Authors: Rezvani Mohamad A., Webb Douglas S.
Title: Buckling analysis of an underground storage tank on the Oak Ridge Reservation
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rezvani, Mohamad A., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; Webb, Douglas S., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: Many tanks are stored underground on the Oak Ridge Reservation in the state of Tennessee. The construction of some of these tanks dates back to the 1940s. A major Department of Energy (DOE) initiative is to assess the integrity of these existing tanks. These tanks must be analyzed and evaluated to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. This paper presents the results of a buckling analysis for two horizontal tanks in an underground vault. The tanks are 3.7 m (12.0 ft) in diam, 18.7 m (61.4 ft) long, and supported on two saddles. The analysis addresses different loading scenarios to complement the safety evaluation of these tanks. The loading conditions consider empty and half-full tanks in the vault flooded with either waste material or flood water to different heights. The results indicate that the tank will neither yield nor buckle for flood water of 5.5 m (18.0 ft) above the tank top.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Buckling; Failure analysis; Underground structures; Underground storage tanks; Tanks (containers)

Authors: Johnson James V.
Title: Prioritization of proposed waste management construction projects for the waste management program within the Department of Energy
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, James V., U.S. Dep of Energy, United States
Abstract: A prioritization process is used to evaluate and rank proposed construction projects within the Department of Energy's Waste Management program. The process is used to determine which projects should proceed with conceptual design activities. The proposed construction projects are evaluated against a set of criteria which reflect Waste Management priorities. A management review team ranks and scores the projects thereby generating a prioritized list of projects. Despite decreasing budgets and changing political climates, the process has been a successful decision-aiding tool for selecting construction projects to carry out the Waste Management mission within the Department of Energy.
Index Keywords: Construction; Decision making; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste management construction projects; Project management

Authors: Griffin Bill, Trubatch Sheldon, Bader Joe
Title: Storage of spent fuel from power reactors in the United States
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Fluor Daniel, United States
Authors with affiliations: Griffin, Bill, Fluor Daniel, United States; Trubatch, Sheldon, Fluor Daniel, United States; Bader, Joe, Fluor Daniel, United States
Abstract: The spent fuel storage industry has developed considerable vitality in recent years to fill in missing pieces of the puzzle. While the Department of Energy moves forward toward the goal of a universal container system, a monitored retrievable storage facility, and a geologic repository, other organizations move forward to fill in other pieces of the puzzle. Several vendors are developing, certifying, and licensing hardware systems. Several utilities are developing new onsite facilities for dry storage of spent fuel. A large, privately financed facility has been proposed for a location on an Indian reservation.
Index Keywords: Spent fuel dry storage systems; Containers; Spent fuels; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Klein Dale E.
Title: What to do with 50,000 nuclear weapons?
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Nuclear Engineering Division (Publication) NE
Affiliations: Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klein, Dale E., Univ of Texas at Austin, Austin, United States
Abstract: After several decades of nuclear weapons build-up, the United States and the former Soviet Union are now reducing their nuclear weapons stockpiles by dismantling which requires developing new technology. Dismantling was the safe dispersal and storage of various nuclear components and their uses for peaceful purposes rather weapons of destruction. This process involves the disassembly of a nuclear weapon with numerous components which can be disposed or recycled after changing shape.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; International cooperation; Nuclear energy; Nuclear weapons; Ordnance

Authors: Lumkes Jr. John H., Hartzell Terry A., Fronczak Frank d., Beachley Norman H.
Title: Investigation of the dynamics of switching from pump to motor using external valving
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Dynamic Systems and Control Division (Publication) DSC
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lumkes Jr., John H., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Hartzell, Terry A., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Fronczak, Frank d., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Beachley, Norman H., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: Currently, some of the most efficient hydraulic pump/motors cannot go `over-center'. An experimental test setup and an analytical model investigate the dynamics, advantages, and disadvantages of using popper valves to switch operation between pump and motor, leading to development of optimal switching methods. This is of particular interest in hydraulic drive vehicles that use regenerative braking. Three major areas of concern are pressure spikes during the transition, event time span, and energy loss. The analytical model uses a bond graph to help construct the system state equations for numerical integration. Experiments measured pressure, speed, and torque using a Volvo V11-60 variable displacement hydraulic pump/motor and a modular valve block. Experimental results show that transition occurs within 150 ms, pressure spikes are within acceptable limits, while energy loss is quite large. The reason for large losses and lower than expected pressure spikes is an open valve overlap, a period of time when a direct flow path exists from high to low pressure. Valves were given a simultaneous electronic signal. However, actual valve opening and closing times are very different. Thus for a fraction of second, two valves are open simultaneously. A possible solution investigated with the analytical model is to activate valves sequentially. The challenge is balancing energy storage loss with higher pressure spikes.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; Hydraulic brakes; Integration; Mathematical models; Pumps; Torque; Valves (mechanical); Pressure spikes; Hydraulic motors

Authors: Wilson Rodney K., Clauss David B., Moyer John W.
Title: Environmental assessment of nuclear materials disposition options: A transportation perspective
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, Rodney K., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Clauss, David B., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Moyer, John W., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy has undertaken a program to evaluate and select options for the long-term storage and disposition of fissile materials declared surplus to defense needs as a result of the end of the Cold War. The transport of surplus fissile material will be an important and highly visible aspect of the environmental impact studies and other planning documents required for implementation of the disposition options. This report identifies the roles and requirements for transportation of fissile materials in the program and discusses an existing methodology for determining the environmental impact in terms of risk. While it will be some time before specific alternatives are chosen that will permit the completion of detailed risk calculations, the analytical models for performing the probabilistic risk assessments already exist with much of the supporting data related to the transportation system. This report summarizes the various types of data required and identifies sources for that data.
Index Keywords: Computational methods; Environmental impact; Mathematical models; Probability; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste transportation; Risk assessment; Fissile materials; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Redus Kenneth S., Sheriff Jennifer A.
Title: Applications of environmental decision making associated with site characterization at US facilities
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Radioactive Waste Management and Environmental Remediation, ICEM
Affiliations: MAC Technical Services Co
Authors with affiliations: Redus, Kenneth S., MAC Technical Services Co; Sheriff, Jennifer A., MAC Technical Services Co
Abstract: Results from two separate studies are presented to illustrate cost savings that can be achieved when effective waste characterization planning is accomplished. Significant factors that influenced the achievement of cost savings include US and applicable state environmental policies and regulations, stakeholder requirements, sampling and analysis methods, and acceptable levels of risk associated with levels of site contamination. Both studies were performed at the US Department of Energy's Hanford Site in southeastern Washington State. Stakeholders who participated in each case study included key management and technical personnel from the US Department of Energy, the US Environmental Protection Agency, the Washington State Department of Ecology, and Westinghouse Hanford Company. The 200-BP-11 operable unit is a contaminated site (1,175 acres) that contains multiple treatment, storage, and disposal units. Over $4 million ($US) was saved in sampling costs alone for this operable unit. The 242-A Evaporator is a mixed waste evaporation system designed to concentrate waste solutions associated with high-level radioactive waste tanks. Identification of critical sampling requirements for the 242-A Evaporator resulted in cost savings more than $65 K ($US) per evaporator campaign.
Index Keywords: Cost accounting; Decision making; Health risks; Industrial waste treatment; Public policy; Strategic planning; Radioactive waste management; Radioactive waste sites; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Buyko A.M., Bidylo N.P., Chernyshev V.K., Demidov V.A., Garanin S.F., Kostyukov V.N., Kulagin A.A., Kuzyaev A.I., Mezhevov A.B., Mokhov V.N., Pavlovskiy E.S., Petrukhin A.A., Yakubov V.B., Yegorychev B.T., Canada J.W.
Title: Results of Russian/US high performance DEMG experiment
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Buyko, A.M., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Bidylo, N.P., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Chernyshev, V.K., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Demidov, V.A., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Garanin, S.F., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Kostyukov, V.N., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Kulagin, A.A., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Kuzyaev, A.I., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Mezhevov, A.B., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Mokhov, V.N., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Pavlovskiy, E.S., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Petrukhin, A.A., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Yakubov, V.B., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Yegorychev, B.T., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation; Canada, J.W., All Russian Scientific Research Inst, of Experimental Physics, Nizhni Novgorod, Russian Federation
Abstract: In November 1992, the All Russian Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Russia and the Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos NM, USA embarked on a historic effort to conduct a joint explosive pulse-power experiment. With the concurrence of the Ministry of Atomic Energy (Russia) and the Department of Energy (USA), the two laboratories entered into a Laboratory-to-Laboratory collaboration in the areas of very high energy pulse power and ultrahigh magnetic fields in order to explore problems of mutual scientific interest. The first experiment was an explosively powered, fast, high-current pulse-power experiment. The experiment employed a flux compressor, inductive store, and opening switch to demonstrate the feasibility of supplying many megajoules of electrical energy on microsecond time scales, to high energy density physics experiments. The experiment was successfully conducted in Arzamas-16 on September 22, 1993.
Index Keywords: Compressors; Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric switches; International cooperation; Magnetic fields; Disk electromagnetic generators (DEMG); Explosive pulse power; Inductive storage; Opening switches; Electric generators

Authors: Akiyama H., Katschinski U., Murayama K., Katsuki S., Tsukamoto S.
Title: Repetitive pulsed power generators using an inductive energy storage system
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akiyama, H., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Katschinski, U., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Murayama, K., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Katsuki, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Tsukamoto, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Abstract: Pulsed power generators using an inductive energy storage system are extremely compact and lightweight in comparison with those using a capacitive energy storage system. A reliable opening switch operated repetitively is necessary to realize an inductive pulsed power generator. Two kinds of repetitively operated opening switches have been developed in Kumamoto University. One is an exploding wire set by an automatic wire setting device, and the other is a plasma opening switch using laser-produced plasma.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric switches; Exploding wires; Laser produced plasmas; Inductive energy storage systems; Inductive pulsed power generators; Opening switches; Asynchronous generators

Authors: Kanter M., Pokryvailo A., Shaked N., Kaplan Z.
Title: Factors in inductive storage system design
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Kanter, M., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Pokryvailo, A., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Shaked, N., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Kaplan, Z., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Abstract: The practical implementation of an inductive pulsed power supply depends on its size and EMI with neighboring environment. Parametric trade-off is made for the prime power battery and the coil. It is shown that the minimal volume of the battery-coil system with a Brooks coil is achieved at a ratio of their volumes 3:2, respectively. For such systems, a jellyroll coil is preferable to a pancake one in view of a higher transfer efficiency. At very high battery power density, a pancake coil may be a right choice due to a lower mechanical stress. The fringe field of cylindrical and quasitoroidal coils was calculated using dipole approximation. Measurements of the discharge efficiency and fringe field are in a good agreement with the theoretical analysis.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Electric batteries; Electric coils; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electromagnetic wave interference; Magnetic field measurement; Stresses; Electrothermal loads; Inductive storage systems; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Authors: Akiyama H., Kawamura K., Takeshita T., Katsuki S., Maeda S., Tsukamoto S., Murata M.
Title: Removal of NOX using discharges by pulsed power
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Akiyama, H., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Kawamura, K., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Takeshita, T., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Katsuki, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Maeda, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Tsukamoto, S., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan; Murata, M., Kumamoto Univ, Kumamoto, Japan
Abstract: Pollution control is one of important subjects in the world. The pollution control by pulsed power is a promising method for the removal of NOx and SO2. Experimental results of NOx removal by a repetitive pulsed power generator using an inductive energy storage system are described. The removal ratio of NO gas was measured by a gas analyzer and a laser induced fluorescence (LIF) method. The NO gas, mixed with N2 gas was removed up to about 100%, and the dependence of the removal ratio of NO gas on the shot number of pulsed power is in good agreement with results of computer simulation.
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Fluorescence; Laser beam effects; Nitrogen oxides; Removal; Sulfur dioxide; Laser induced fluorescence (LIF); Pulsed power applications; Air pollution control

Authors: Kevin Cross J., Beckman William A., Mitchell John W., Knebel David E., Reindl Douglas T.
Title: Evaluation of thermal storage options for combustion turbine inlet air cooling
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kevin Cross, J., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States; Beckman, William A., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States; Mitchell, John W., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States; Knebel, David E., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States; Reindl, Douglas T., Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, United States
Abstract: A transient simulation model was written to describe the performance of combustion turbine inlet air cooling systems based on a combination of chilled water and ice as thermal storage media. The transient simulation model was used in conjunction with simpler computer models to design inlet air cooling systems for four different power plant daily load profiles based on three alternative storage options: chilled water alone, ice alone, and an optimized combination of the two media. Alternative storage options were evaluated on the bases of first cost and a life cycle analysis of each system. Both the capacity enhancement cost and the incremental electrical energy production cost were found to be lowest for cooling systems based on chilled water storage alone. Systems based either partially or entirely on ice storage lead to greater power plant generating capacity increases than do systems based on chilled water alone. Systems based on the optimized combination of thermal storage media are significantly less expensive than are systems based purely on ice storage.
Index Keywords: Air; Combustion; Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Heat storage; Ice; Intake systems; Optimization; Power plants; Water cooling systems; Chilled water; Life cycle analysis; Turbines

Authors: Sopian K., Liu H.T., Yigit K.S., Kakac S., Veziroglu T.N.
Title: Investigation into the performance of a double pass photovoltaic thermal solar collector
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sopian, K., Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States; Liu, H.T., Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States; Yigit, K.S., Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States; Kakac, S., Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States; Veziroglu, T.N., Univ of Miami, Coral Gables, United States
Abstract: Combined photovoltaic thermal solar collectors provide an effective alternative to solar energy systems that collect either thermal or electrical energy. In such systems, the photovoltaic cells are usually pasted directly over the absorber or in some cases at the inner glass cover. Hence, part of the solar radiation evident on the photovoltaic cells is converted directly to electricity and part of it is collected by the flowing air as thermal energy. Up to date, only a limited number of studies on the photovoltaic thermal solar collectors have been carried out. This paper presents the analytical studies of a double pass air photovoltaic thermal collector. The effects of various parameters such as flow rates, packing factor or the fraction of the absorber area covered by solar cells, the absorber length and the duct height on the efficiencies of the photovoltaic cells and thermal collectors as well as the combined efficiency have been analyzed.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Energy efficiency; Light absorption; Solar cells; Photovoltaic thermal solar collectors; Solar collectors

Authors: Romary Ph., Eyl P., Angles J.M.
Title: Performances of AMBIORIX
Source title: Digest of Technical Papers-IEEE International Pulsed Power Conference
Affiliations: Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, Le Barp, France
Authors with affiliations: Romary, Ph., Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, Le Barp, France; Eyl, P., Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, Le Barp, France; Angles, J.M., Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique, Le Barp, France
Abstract: AMBIORIX is a high pulsed power generator designed and built by the HPP team of Valduc CEA center in 1985 (1). This generator is now located in CESTA, a center of CEA near Bordeaux (France). AMBIORIX is formed with a MARX generator (maximum energy storage = 300 kJ), water coaxial and triaxial lines. Output parameters are: 0,5 Ω impedance, 1.2 MV diode voltage, 2.4 MA load current with a 40 nsec pulse duration. Three kinds of loads can be used: two bremsthralung diodes (Vmax = 1.2 MV or Vmax = 400 kV) and a ZPINCH diode. In this paper we describe the generator and give major characteristics of various loads.
Index Keywords: Diodes; Electric generators; Electric loads; AMBIORIX high pulsed power generator; Pulse generators

Authors: Sun Y., Harris R., Swenson E., Hutchens C.
Title: Optimization of memory redundancy laser link processing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Advanced Development Laboratory, Electro Scientific Industries, Inc., Portland, OR, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Y., Advanced Development Laboratory, Electro Scientific Industries, Inc., Portland, OR, United States; Harris, R., Advanced Development Laboratory, Electro Scientific Industries, Inc., Portland, OR, United States; Swenson, E., Advanced Development Laboratory, Electro Scientific Industries, Inc., Portland, OR, United States; Hutchens, C., Advanced Development Laboratory, Electro Scientific Industries, Inc., Portland, OR, United States
Abstract: Memory repair through the use of laser processing of redundant elements is an industry standard procedure for memory chip manufacturing. But, shrinking memory feature sizes and the industry's tendency to use metals as link materials rather than polysilicon imposes new challenges for laser processing. So far, the majority of the research on memory link laser processing has concentrated on: The vertical structure of a link (such as the multiple layers of passivation, link, field oxidation and silicon substrate); the laser beam absorption; and, the different temperature distribution within the structure as the result of laser beam heating. Until now, the emphasis in laser link processing optimization has been aimed at creating uniform temperature distribution while severing the link before exploding the passivation layer. Our study has shown that the link width plays an important roll in the processing as well. Analysis of the mechanical stress beneath the passivation layer using finite element modeling has been carried out. Different link width and passivation layer thicknesses vary the stress dramatically. The results of this simulation will be presented and their implication on link processing optimization will be discussed. To optimize the laser processing further, we have proven that absorption contrast of laser energy between the link material and the silicon substrate beneath the link must be maximized. Based upon the fact that while the absorption of most metal materials in the 1.3- to 2-micron range remains the same as that at 1 micron, it drops dramatically for silicon. By using laser wavelengths within the 1.3- to 2-micron range, a much wider laser processing window can be realized. Comparison analysis of link processing by different laser wavelengths will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Finite element method; Laser applications; Light absorption; Mathematical models; Passivation; Polysilicon; Laser link processing; Data storage equipment

Abstract: The proceeding contains 29 papers from the conference on Optical Characterization Techniques of High-Performance Microelectronic Device Manufacturing II. Topics discussed include: manufacturing challenges for sub-half-micron technologies; investigation of metal contamination by photocurrent measurements; advanced optical characterization techniques for borosilicate films; advances in infrared spectroscopic methods for epitaxial film characterization; energy spectra of electrons emitted from samples with an internal electric field; advanced ellipsometry and reflectometry; performance optimization of three-dimensional optoelectronic interconnection for intra-multi-chip-module clock signal distribution and laser scanning.

Authors: Chiu Chih-Chou, Occena Luis G.
Title: Neural models for characterization and interpretation of hardwood internal defect configurations
Source title: Intelligent Engineering Systems Through Artificial Neural Networks
Affiliations: Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chiu, Chih-Chou, Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States; Occena, Luis G., Texas A&M Univ, College Station, United States
Abstract: A methodology to assign an appropriate sawing pattern based on defect configuration was developed using neural networks. Two neural models, Generative Specification of Dominant Axes (GSDA) and Generative Specification of Sawing Pattern (GSSP) were constructed to help in the characterization and interpretation of hardwood internal defect configurations. In the GSDA model, a neural network algorithm was applied to detect the dominant axes of the defect configuration after one energy function was formalized based on the desired optimal standard of the detection problem. The associative recall ability and the information storage capacity of the GSSP model was utilized to assign a suitable sawing pattern from the detected dominant axis.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Defects; Functions; Mathematical models; Optimization; Sawing; Wood; Energy functions; Neural networks

Authors: Miller Joan M., Peterson James N.
Title: Image compression method using a KLT neural network
Source title: Intelligent Engineering Systems Through Artificial Neural Networks
Affiliations: Univ of Idaho, Moscow, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, Joan M., Univ of Idaho, Moscow, United States; Peterson, James N., Univ of Idaho, Moscow, United States
Abstract: An adaptive image coding scheme uses a neural network to calculate the Karhunen-Loeve transform of an image as preparation for encoding. The image is broken up into 8×8 pixel blocks and the Karhunen-Loeve transform of each block is calculated using an adaptive neural network. The Karhunen-Loeve transform bases are arranged in descending order with respect to eigenvalues to condense the maximum amount of energy into the least number of eigenvalues. The algorithm achieved compression ratios of 13:1 and storage savings of 90%, which does not include the additional compression achieved when a source code is applied to the transformed data. Encoding schemes combined with this transform method of compression have the potential to reach overall compression ratios of 45:1.
Index Keywords: Adaptive algorithms; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Image coding; Image compression; Mathematical transformations; Adaptive image coding; Karhunen-Loeve transform; Neural networks

Authors: Davies T.S., Nouri H., Jefferson C.M.
Title: Alternative approaches to wind energy conversion systems
Affiliations: Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Davies, T.S., Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom; Nouri, H., Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom; Jefferson, C.M., Univ of the West of England, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper considers the issues associated with the operation of wind energy systems which are situated in areas remote from a strong grid. System stability can be improved by addition of energy storage. Fluctuations due to the gusting effect of the wind can be most effectively reduced by using a flywheel energy storage system. Alternative ways of introducing flywheel energy storage into the power system are discussed.

Abstract: X-ray multilayer supermirrors for the energy range up to 20 keV have been theoretically studied and experimentally measured with synchrotron radiation. A multilayer mirror with 50 W/Si bilayers with different thicknesses on the Si substrate has a smooth reflectivity of up to 32% in the whole energy range from 5 to 22 keV at a grazing incidence angle of 0.32° which is considerably larger than using total external reflection. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Abstract: The article describes the ESCA microscopy beamline dedicated to high spatial resolution quantitative and qualitative analysis on surfaces and interfaces. The scanning microscope is constructed to work both in transmission and photoemission within the photon energy range from 200 to 1200 eV with a spatial resolution of ∼0.1 μm. A Fresnel zone plate demagnifies the photon beam to submicrometer dimensions with 109-1010 photons/s in the focus spot. A photodiode and a hemispherical electron energy analyzer are used as detectors for recording the transmitted x-rays and emitted photoelectrons, respectively. The operation modes in photoemission give the opportunity to obtain conventional energy distribution curve spectra from a microspot or a two-dimensional micrograph of the spatial distribution and local concentration of a selected element as the sample is mechanically scanned. For conductive specimen topography measurements of a selected surface area probed by SPEM are possible using a scanning tunnelling microscope. The first test images of a zone plate and an e-beam written specimen with 1 μm2 Au squares on Si have shown a spatial resolution better than 0.2 μm. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Abstract: The variation of intensity of the photostimulated luminescence (PSL) of BaFCl:Eu2+ after ultraviolet irradiation with temperature has been investigated. The results show that the PSL intensity is independent of temperature in the readout process, but the storage ability is temperature dependent. The measurements support the mechanism of PSL involving the F-center-interstitial-halogen pairs. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Randall K.J., Gluskin E., Xu Z.
Title: Spectroscopy beamline at the Advanced Photon Source for the photon energy region from 0.5 to 3 keV
Affiliations: Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S. Cass Ave., Argonne, IL 60439
Authors with affiliations: Randall, K.J., Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S. Cass Ave., Argonne, IL 60439; Gluskin, E., Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S. Cass Ave., Argonne, IL 60439; Xu, Z., Advanced Photon Source, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 S. Cass Ave., Argonne, IL 60439
Abstract: Interest in the 0.5 to 3 keV, intermediate x-ray, energy region has recently intensified as this spectral region covers, among others, the important L and M edges of transition-metal and rare-earth magnetic materials, respectively. Third-generation synchrotron facilities with their inherent high brightness have the unique potential to cover this energy region with high-resolution, high-flux x-ray beams ideal for spectroscopic studies. A 5.5-cm-period, planar undulator to be installed on the 7-GeV Advanced Photon Source will produce a high brightness source of intermediate-energy x rays. The 0.5- to 3-keV spectroscopy beamline is based on the spherical grating monochromator design that has already been shown to yield high resolution and throughput in the soft-x-ray region, below 1 keV. The beamline has been designed to cover the entire region with a peak resolving power of 6000-10 000. Photon flux at the sample is calculated to be in the range from 1011 to 1013 photons/s into a spot size of 1 mm2. A refocusing mirror will be used to further demagnify the image size at a second experimental station. As a second phase to the spectroscopy program, an elliptically polarized insertion device will be used. The polarization preserving nature of the grazing incidence optical elements in the SGM is crucial to obtain x rays of well-defined polarization. The beamline layout, together with calculations of resolution, throughput, power loading, and high harmonic suppression, will be presented. The photoemission experimental end stations for the spectroscopy station will also be briefly described. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic wave polarization; Focusing; Mirrors; Monochromators; Optics; Photons; Reflectometers; X rays; Advanced photon source; Demagnification; Harmonic suppression; Photon flux; Spectroscopy beamline; Spherical grating monochromator; X ray imaging; Storage rings

Authors: Schilling P.J., Morikawa E., Tolentino H., Tamura E., Kurtz R.L., Cusatis C.
Title: Installation and operation of the LNLS double-crystal monochromator at CAMD
Affiliations: J. Abstract: A new x-ray beamline has been installed at CAMD utilizing a two-crystal monochromator designed and built at LNLS. The beamline will operate in the 2-18 keV range using up to 4 mrad of dipole radiation from the CAMD storage ring. The monochromator maintains a fixed exit beam and fixed positions of the beam on the two crystals using mutually perpendicular elastic translations. With the ring operating at 1.5 GeV and 160 mA, Si(220) crystals will provide a flux of ∼3(109) photons/s/mrad at 8 keV, with an energy resolution ΔE<2 eV, to the experimental hutch. The beamline is equipped with an EXAFS endstation and will also be used for other x-ray applications at CAMD. First results are presented. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Holldack K., Peatman W.B., Schroeter Th.
Title: Vertical photon beam position measurement at bending magnets using lateral diodes
Affiliations: BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, 14195 Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Holldack, K., BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, 14195 Berlin, Germany; Peatman, W.B., BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, 14195 Berlin, Germany; Schroeter, Th., BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, 14195 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Commercial position sensitive diodes which were designed for measurements with visible light have been used to measure beam position in a white-light beamline, exposing them to the hard-x-ray part of the dipole spectrum. In preliminary studies it was found that the quantum efficiency of the lateral diodes is comparable to that of Si XUV diodes. At 1.5 keV a quantum efficiency of about 100 electrons per photon was measured in the central position. No long-term drifts of the efficiency have been observed. The position sensitivity of the diodes is almost independent of photon energy, but is at least a factor of 2 higher than in the visible range. Hence in a white-light beam, a photon energy window was defined by a water-cooled Al-absorber foil of 200 μm thickness. Behind the foil two lateral diodes were arranged at 3.5 (15 mm length) and 7 m (30 mm length) behind the source. The horizontal position of the diodes was staggered so that the first diode does not occlude the beam to the second one. With this system, the vertical source position in a bending magnet can be detected with 10 μm accuracy while the emission angle can be detected down to values of 2 μrad. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Aluminum foil; Electron beams; Light; Magnets; Monochromators; Photons; Position measurement; Quantum efficiency; Spectrum analysis; Storage rings; Bending magnets; Photon energy; Positive sensitive diodes; Spectral responsivity; White light beamline; Diodes

Authors: Arthur J., Materlik G., Tatchyn R., Winick H.
Title: The LCLS: A fourth generation light source using the SLAC linac
Affiliations: Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford, CA 94309
Authors with affiliations: Arthur, J., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford, CA 94309; Materlik, G., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford, CA 94309; Tatchyn, R., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford, CA 94309; Winick, H., Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory, Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford, CA 94309
Abstract: Recent technological developments make it possible to consider use of the Stanford linear accelerator to drive a linac coherent light source (LCLS) - a laser operating at hard x-ray wavelengths. In the LCLS, stimulated emission of radiation would be achieved in a single pass of a high-energy, extremely bright electron beam through an undulator, without the optical cavity resonator normally used in storage ring-based free-electron lasers. The x-ray laser beam would be nearly diffraction limited with very high transverse coherence, and would exhibit unprecedented peak intensity and peak brightness, and sub-picosecond pulse length. Such an x-ray source offers unique capabilities for a large number of scientific applications. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Abstract: A new vacuum ultraviolet beamline for Aladdin based on an electromagnetic undulator and a 4 m normal incidence monochromator is described. The combination of the undulator, new optics, and an improved version of the currently operational monochromator is expected to deliver more than 3×10 11 photons/s at a resolving power of 3×104 in the photon energy range 6-30 eV. At a lower resolving power of 104, more than 1011 photons/s will be available between 30 and 40 eV. Expecting a very high demand for the new beamline, two branches are planned to allow for time sharing. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Abstract: The SGM beamline (2B1), designed for photoemission spectroscopy, accepts a photon beam 10 mrad horizontally and 2 mrad vertically from a bending magnet source. The operating energy range of the monochromator is 12-1230 eV and the grating chamber has five exchangeable laminar gratings to cover the range. The monochromator employs a fixed entrance slit and a movable exit slit to satisfy the focusing condition during photon energy scan. The NIM beamline (2B2) is designed for 5-30 eV photon energy. The type of monochromator to be installed is 3 m normal incident, with off-Rowland circle mounting. A gas-phase experimental system, equipped with differential pumping stages, will be installed in the NIM beamline. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Jensen B.N., Mancini D.C., Nyholm R.
Title: Thermal effects of undulator radiation on Si optics for a plane grating monochromator
Affiliations: MAX-Lab, University of Lund, Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Jensen, B.N., MAX-Lab, University of Lund, Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Mancini, D.C., MAX-Lab, University of Lund, Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Nyholm, R., MAX-Lab, University of Lund, Box 118, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden
Abstract: Insertion devices on the third-generation 1.5 GeV electron storage ring MAX II will subject the grazing incidence mirrors and gratings of new soft x-ray beamlines to high thermal loads. These thermal loads will cause distortion in the optical surfaces which can be reduced to acceptable levels by the proper choice of substrate material and cooling. A finite element analysis of the temperature variation and thermal distortions is carried out for Si plane mirrors and gratings under thermal load from the 66 mm period undulator planned for MAX II. The energy dependence of the reflectivity for Au-coated mirrors is taken into account. The minimum cooling requirements are determined for each of these optical components in the beamline. The effect of the final induced figure errors on the performance of a plane grating monochromator are discussed. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Radiometry laboratory of Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt at BESSY

Authors with affiliations: Ulm, G., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestraße 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany; Wende, B., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestraße 2-12, D-10587 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: The Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB), the German national institute of metrology, operates a radiometry laboratory at the electron storage ring BESSY. Now, after more than ten years of BESSY operation, six experimental stations on four beamlines optimized for radiometric calibrations and characterization of optical components are in use. The calculable undispersed spectral photon flux of the primary radiation standard BESSY with relative uncertainties of below 0.4% is used in a broad spectral range from 1 eV to 15 keV for the calibration of energy-dispersive detectors and of monochromator-detector systems at one beamline and for the calibration of radiation sources in the spectral range from 3 eV to 1.8 keV at three experimental stations equipped with monochromators. Monochromatized synchrotron radiation, with emphasis placed on high spectral purity, is provided at three stations covering the spectral range from 3 eV to about 1.5 keV for detector calibrations and for reflectometry. Brief descriptions of the beamlines, experimental stations, and associated instruments are given. Furthermore, examples of recent radiometric calibrations and investigations and an outlook on radiometry at the future storage ring BESSY II are presented. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Abstract: A novel double-multilayer monochromator has been designed for the Advanced Photon Source x-ray undulator beamline at Argonne National Laboratory. The monochromator consists of two ultrahigh-vacuum compatible modular vessels, each with a sine-bar driving structure and a water-cooled multilayer holder. A high precision Y-Z stage is used to provide compensating motion for the second multilayer from outside the vacuum chamber so that the monochromator can fix the output monochromatic beam direction and angle during the energy scan in a narrow range. The design details for this monochromator are presented in this paper. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Perera R.C.C., Jones G., Lindle D.W.
Title: High-brightness beamline for x-ray spectroscopy at the advanced light source
Affiliations: Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Department of Chemistry, University of Nevada, Las Vegas, NV 89154-4003
Authors with affiliations: Perera, R.C.C., Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Jones, G., Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Lindle, D.W., Department of Chemistry, University of Nevada, Las Vegas, NV 89154-4003
Abstract: Beamline 9.3.1 at the Advanced Light Source (ALS) is a windowless beamline, covering the 1-6 keV photon-energy range, designed to achieve the goals of high energy resolution, high flux, and high brightness at the sample. When completed later this year, it will be the first ALS monochromatic hard-x-ray beamline, and its brightness will be an order-of-magnitude higher than presently available in this energy range. In addition, it will provide flux and resolution comparable to any other beamline now in operation. To achieve these goals, two technical improvements, relative to existing x-ray beamlines, were incorporated. First, a somewhat novel optical design for x rays, in which matched toroidal mirrors are positioned before and after the double-crystal monochromator, was adopted. This configuration allows for high resolution by passing a collimated beam through the monochromator, and for high brightness by focusing the ALS source on the sample with unit magnification. Second, a new ''Cowan type'' double-crystal monochromator based on the design used at NSLS beamline X-24A was developed. The measured mechanical precision of this new monochromator shows significant improvement over existing designs, without using positional feedback available with piezoelectric devices. Such precision is essential because of the high brightness of the radiation and the long distance (12 m) from the source (sample) to the collimating (focusing) mirror. This combination of features will provide a bright, high resolution, and stable x-ray beam for use in the x-ray spectroscopy program at the ALS. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Error analysis; Light sources; Mirrors; Monochromators; Monte Carlo methods; Optical design; Optical resolving power; Storage rings; X ray spectroscopy; Advanced light source; Double crystal monochromators; High brightness beamline; Photon energy; Ray tracing; Toroidal mirrors; Optical systems

Authors: Derreumaux S., Chavaudra J., Bridier A., Rossetti V., Dutreix A.
Title: A European quality assurance network for radiotherapy: Dose measurement procedure
Affiliations: Dept. of Phys., Inst. Gustave-Roussy, France
Authors with affiliations: Derreumaux, S., Dept. of Phys., Inst. Gustave-Roussy, France; Chavaudra, J., Dept. of Phys., Inst. Gustave-Roussy, France; Bridier, A., Dept. of Phys., Inst. Gustave-Roussy, France; Rossetti, V., Dept. of Phys., Inst. Gustave-Roussy, France; Dutreix, A., Dept. of Phys., Inst. Gustave-Roussy, France
Abstract: In the frame of the experimental implementation of a European quality assurance network for external radiotherapy, the methodology in the European Measuring Centre (MC) is presented. Mailed TL dosimeters are used for the check of the beam output and of the beam quality of photon beams. The thermoluminescent material is PTL 717 LiF powder. The readings were first performed on a manual, and then on an automatic reader, with standard deviations of the mean of 0.7% for one dosimeter. Corrections for supralinearity and for the energy dependence of the dosimeter response are applied. An original method has been developed to correct for the variation of the LiF response as a function of time. It is shown that the sensitivity of the powder changes during storage, leading to a kind of 'inverse fading'. The global uncertainty of the TL postal measurement procedure is estimated to be about 1.5% for the 60Co beams and 2% for the X-ray beams. Intercomparisons with the IAEA and with the EORTC have shown an agreement better than 2% for all energies. It can be concluded that the results of the MC are suitable for the requirements of a European quality assurance network.
Index Keywords: cobalt 60; article; dosimetry; europe; priority journal; quality control; radiotherapy; X ray; Cobalt Radioisotopes; Europe; Gamma Rays; Humans; Quality Assurance, Health Care; Radiotherapy; Radiotherapy Dosage; Regression Analysis; Reproducibility of Results; Thermodynamics; X-Rays

Authors: Kamada M., Sakai K., Tanaka S.-I., Ohara S., Kimura S.-I., Hiraya A., Hasumoto M., Nakagawa K., Ichikawa K., Soda K., Fukui K., Fujii Y., Ishiguro E.
Title: Monochromator for circularly polarized synchrotron radiation in the energy range of 5-250 eV
Affiliations: Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai 593, Japan; Fukui University, Fukui 910, Japan; Osaka City University, Osaka 558, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kamada, M., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Sakai, K., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Tanaka, S.-I., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Ohara, S., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Kimura, S.-I., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Hiraya, A., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Hasumoto, M., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Nakagawa, K., Institute for Molecular Science, Okazaki 444, Japan; Ichikawa, K., University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai 593, Japan; Soda, K., University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai 593, Japan; Fukui, K., Fukui University, Fukui 910, Japan; Fujii, Y., Osaka City University, Osaka 558, Japan; Ishiguro, E., Osaka City University, Osaka 558, Japan
Abstract: A new spherical grating monochromator with translational and rotational assembly including a normal incidence mount (SGM-TRAIN) is under construction at BL 5A of the UVSOR Facility, IMS, and its design concept is reported. The following points have been taken into account in the design: (1) Energy range of 5-250 eV, (2) use both of undulator and bending magnet radiation, (3) linear and circular polarizations, (4) spectral purity, (5) resolution, and (6) length of beamline. It should be stressed that the SGM-TRAIN is useful for experiments where circularly polarized synchrotron radiation is used. Moreover, the SGM-TRAIN has the advantage that the small emittance of storage ring and the large space for a long beamline are not necessary. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Pflüger J., Heintze G., Vasserman I.
Title: Search for possible radiation damage on a NdFeB permanent magnet structure after two years of operation
Affiliations: HASYLAB, DESY, Notkestr. 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; APS, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439
Authors with affiliations: Pflüger, J., HASYLAB, DESY, Notkestr. 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Heintze, G., HASYLAB, DESY, Notkestr. 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Vasserman, I., APS, Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439
Abstract: Recently there has been some concern about possible radiation damage due to ionizing particles present in high energy storage rings such as multi-GeV electrons, fast neutrons, or hard photons. Partial demagnetization has been observed on undulators after mis-steering of the injected electron beam. Our interest was focused to possible radiation damage of a permanent magnet insertion device during routine operation of a storage ring. Therefore, we repeated the magnetic measurements on one of the three 4.0 m long x-ray wigglers used at place #2 in DORIS III. This device is in operation since 1991. The results were compared to the data taken before installation. The total dose was determined from measurements with thermoluminescence dosimeters and the known number of stored ampere hours. The results which show no significant degradation of the magnetic performance are presented and discussed. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Nakanishi T., Ikegami K., Kodera I., Maruyama A., Matsuda T., Morita M., Nakagawa T., Nakamura S., Nakata S., Ohishi N., Okuda S., Shimohata K., Takeuchi T., Tanaka H., Tsukishima C., Yamamoto S., Yokoyama S., Yamada T.
Title: Construction and beam experiment of a compact storage ring at MELCO
Affiliations: Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakanishi, T., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Ikegami, K., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Kodera, I., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Maruyama, A., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Matsuda, T., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Morita, M., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Nakagawa, T., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Nakamura, S., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Nakata, S., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Ohishi, N., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Okuda, S., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Shimohata, K., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Takeuchi, T., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Tanaka, H., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Tsukishima, C., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Yamamoto, S., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Yokoyama, S., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan; Yamada, T., Mitsubishi Electric Corporation, 8-1-1 Tsukaguchi-honmachi, Amagasaki 661, Japan
Abstract: A compact storage ring has been developed for industrial research such as x-ray lithography and material analysis. This machine is of a racetrack type with two superconducting bending magnets and only two normal conducting quadrupole magnets. The circumference is as short as 9.2 m. One quadrupole magnet per cell contributes to making the smaller machine. The injector is a synchrotron, and a full energy injection of 600 MeV is performed. The bending magnets excite a field of 3.5 T, and are operated in a persistent current mode. A decrease in a coil current is ΔI/I<3×10-3/year. The helium consumption is as low as 2 l/h for two magnets. An iron shield of the magnet decreases a leakage flux to a terrestrial level at a point 3 m from the magnet. A beam current of 380 mA has been stored with no beam instability in spite of there being no correction of the chromaticities. Beam emittances were obtained from measured beam sizes and were in good agreement with calculated values. The coupling coefficient εy/εx is calculated as around 0.04. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Bernstorff S., Busetto E., Gramaccioni C., Lausi A., Olivi L., Zanini F., Savoia A., Colapietro M., Portalone G., Camalli M., Pifferi A., Spagna R., Barba L., Cassetta A.
Title: The macromolecular crystallography beamline at ELETTRA
Affiliations: SINCROTRONE TRIESTE, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy; Dipartimento di Chimica, Universitá di Roma La Sapienza, P. le A. Moro 8, 00100 Roma, Italy; Istituto di Strutturistica Chimica-CNR, C.P. 10, 00016 Monterotondo Stazione, Roma, Italy; Sezione dell' Istituto di Strutturistica Chimica, CNR, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy
