Moro 8, 00100 Roma, Italy; Portalone, G., Dipartimento di Chimica, Universitá di Roma La Sapienza, P. le A. Moro 8, 00100 Roma, Italy; Camalli, M., Istituto di Strutturistica Chimica-CNR, C.P. 10, 00016 Monterotondo Stazione, Roma, Italy; Pifferi, A., Istituto di Strutturistica Chimica-CNR, C.P. 10, 00016 Monterotondo Stazione, Roma, Italy; Spagna, R., Istituto di Strutturistica Chimica-CNR, C.P. 10, 00016 Monterotondo Stazione, Roma, Italy; Barba, L., Sezione dell' Istituto di Strutturistica Chimica, CNR, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy; Cassetta, A., Sezione dell' Istituto di Strutturistica Chimica, CNR, Padriciano 99, 34012 Trieste, Italy
Abstract: A new beamline for macromolecular crystallography has been constructed and is currently under commissioning. Its source is the high-power wiggler at the 2 GeV storage ring ELETTRA. The optics consists of a double-crystal monochromator in nondispersive configuration followed by a toroidal focusing mirror, and is designed to allow both diffraction experiments with monochromatized beam in the energy range 4-25 keV, and Laue experiments with white beam. The experimental station is based on an imaging plate area detector from MarResearch and a model 5020 Huber 4-circle diffractometer. To control the second apparatus, a plug-in board interface for a personal computer and a crystallographic package, CS, have been developed. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Guo J.-H., Wassdahl N., Skytt P., Butorin S.M., Duda L.-C., Englund C.J., Nordgren J.
Title: End station for polarization and excitation energy selective soft x-ray fluorescence spectroscopy
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Guo, J.-H., Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Wassdahl, N., Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Skytt, P., Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Butorin, S.M., Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Duda, L.-C., Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Englund, C.J., Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden; Nordgren, J., Department of Physics, Uppsala University, Box 530, S-751 21 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: An end station for soft x-ray fluorescence spectroscopy has been constructed, which includes an experiment chamber, rotatable 90° under ultrahigh vacuum conditions around the incoming synchrotron radiation beam, which is provided with a high-resolution soft x-ray spectrometer. A manipulator allowing three axes of rotation, three directions of translation, as well as LN2 cooling and resistive heating is mounted to the chamber and serves as the sample holder. Samples can be transferred under vacuum between the experiment chamber and two other chambers, one for sample preparation and another for introducing new samples and for sample storage. The end station has been used at two different synchrotron radiation laboratories (beamline BW3) at HASYLAB in Hamburg and at ALS (beamline 7.0) in Berkeley. Polarization-dependent and angular resolved, selectively excited x-ray emission studies have been made on ordered as well as nonordered systems, e.g., high-Tc superconducting systems, diamond, fullerenes, and molecular ices. The experimental system will be presented along with some recent scientific results. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Heimann P., Mossessian D., Warwick A., Wang C., Marks S., Padmore H., Kincaid B., Gullikson E.M.
Title: Experimental characterization of ALS undulator radiation
Affiliations: Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Center for X-Ray Optics, Materials Sciences Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720
Authors with affiliations: Heimann, P., Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Mossessian, D., Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Warwick, A., Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Wang, C., Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Marks, S., Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Padmore, H., Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Kincaid, B., Advanced Light Source, Accelerator and Fusion Research Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720; Gullikson, E.M., Center for X-Ray Optics, Materials Sciences Division, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720
Abstract: The radiation from the 5 cm period undulator at the Advanced Light Source (ALS) has been characterized using a transmission grating spectrometer. Spectral and angular distributions of radiation were measured for deflection parameter K values between 0.45 and 2.12 at low storage ring current (0.1-0.5 mA). From the calibration of the spectrometer, the absolute flux density of the undulator harmonics has been determined together with the spectral linewidth. The electron-beam emittance was determined by analyzing the angular distribution of the redshifted fundamental. Comparison has been made with radiation calculations based upon the measured magnetic-field data of the undulator. Including field errors, electron-beam emittance, and energy spread, good agreement is found between theoretically and experimentally determined harmonic widths and peak brightness. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Smirnov A.V., Smirnov V.N.
Title: Linac with integrated power source based on radio frequency energy compression
Affiliations: Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Smirnov, A.V., Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow 123182, Russian Federation; Smirnov, V.N., Russian Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Moscow 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: The basic feasibility of a proposal to simplify the conventional low energy rf electron linear accelerator (linac), is considered. The design suggested foresees replacement of the traditional high power systems of external rf generator and modulator by a more passive switched energy storage system. The proposed conception of a compact linac is based on known rf energy compression techniques and an efficient self-excited oscillation in a special accelerating/oscillating linac structure. The principal relations, performance estimations, and one-dimensional time-dependent simulation results for such a linac are presented. The possibility of self-excited oscillation by an unbunched low voltage beam in a waveguide linac section is proved and investigated experimentally. The common features and differences compared with a conventional backward-wave tube are analyzed. An application of this effect is proposed for impedance and group velocity measurements in slow-wave structures. Since the rf energy commutation may be one or two orders faster than the electric high voltage energy commutation (conventional modulator), combining the structure proposed and rf energy compression system can give high levels of the average beam power (10-100 kW). The linac facility would have considerably reduced weight and sizes (more than 2.5 times) as compared to similar industrial linacs. The power supply required is in 40-120 kV range dc source, and an estimated overall wall plug efficiency is a few percent. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Johansson U., Nyholm R., Törnevik C., Flodström A.
Title: The vacuum ultraviolet scanning photoelectron microscope at MAX-LAB
Affiliations: Department of Synchrotron Radiation Research, Institute of Physics, Lund University, Sölvegatan 14, S-223 62 Lund, Sweden; Materials Science, Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Johansson, U., Department of Synchrotron Radiation Research, Institute of Physics, Lund University, Sölvegatan 14, S-223 62 Lund, Sweden; Nyholm, R., Department of Synchrotron Radiation Research, Institute of Physics, Lund University, Sölvegatan 14, S-223 62 Lund, Sweden; Törnevik, C., Materials Science, Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden; Flodström, A., Materials Science, Royal Institute of Technology, S-100 44 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: The performance of a scanning photoelectron microscope at the MAX I storage ring in Lund is presented. The microscope utilizes undulator radiation in the energy range 15-150 eV and is comprised of a plane-grating monochromator with a Kirkpatrick-Baez objective and a gracing incidence ellipsoidal focusing mirror. The instrument with its high photon flux, 109-1010 photons/s, and narrow bandwidth, better than 0.2 eV, is excellently suited for high-resolution core-level spectroscopy and imaging of samples with lateral inhomogeneties in the micrometer range. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Björneholm O., Federmann F., Larsson C., Hahn U., Rieck A., Kakar S., Möller T., Beutler A., Fössing F.
Title: Performance of the extreme ultraviolet high resolution undulator beamline BW3 at Hasylab: First results and time-of-flight spectroscopy
Affiliations: Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; II. Institut. für Experimentalphysik, Universitat Hamburg, Luruper Chaussee 149, 22761 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Björneholm, O., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; Federmann, F., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; Larsson, C., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; Hahn, U., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; Rieck, A., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; Kakar, S., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; Möller, T., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor Hasylab, Deutsches Elektronen Synchrotron Desy, Notkestrasse 85, 22603, Hamburg, Germany; Beutler, A., II. Institut. für Experimentalphysik, Universitat Hamburg, Luruper Chaussee 149, 22761 Hamburg, Germany; Fössing, F., II. Institut. für Experimentalphysik, Universitat Hamburg, Luruper Chaussee 149, 22761 Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: The extreme ultraviolet beamline BW3 at Hasylab is a state of the art beamline for the energy range 15-2000 eV consisting of a triple undulator equipped with a modified high-flux SX-700 plane grating monochromator. The first three optical elements of the beamline are made of graphite coated with SiC to withstand the high heat load at the 4.5 GeV storage ring Doris III. Excellent spectral resolution of the order of 104 at the nitrogen K edge at 400 eV is obtained by replacing the elliptical focusing mirror of the original SX-700 design by a spherical mirror with very small tangent errors and with a large focal length in order to suppress spherical aberrations. In the energy range 50-1700 eV a photon flux of 1011-1013/s is obtained in a bandpass of 0.1%. Photoionization and photoemission measurements on atoms, molecules, and clusters making use of time-of-flight techniques demonstrate the excellent performance of the beamline. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Biscardi R., Ramirez G., Williams G.P., Zimba C.
Title: Effects of rf sidebands on spectral reproducibility for infrared synchrotron radiation
Affiliations: National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973; Polaroid Corporation, 750 Main Street, Cambridge, MA 02139
Authors with affiliations: Biscardi, R., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973; Ramirez, G., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973; Williams, G.P., National Synchrotron Light Source, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY 11973; Zimba, C., Polaroid Corporation, 750 Main Street, Cambridge, MA 02139
Abstract: The effects of audio sidebands from the main rf of the NSLS VUV storage ring on beam motion and specifically on spectral reproducibility in the infrared region were investigated. For this spectral region it is advantageous to use Michelson interferometers because of their high throughput (Jacquinot advantage). A second advantage is that interferometers inherently give a multiplex or Felgett advantage, since one is always looking at all the wavelengths for all of the measuring time, even though there is only one detector. In such instruments it is beneficial to scan the moving mirror at a fast rate so that any mechanical or other low-frequency noise shows up as a slow modulation in the interferogram and disappears altogether in the Fourier transform from the spectral region of interest. However, audio-frequency sidebands appear from the rf energy restoring cavity as noise on the beam. These always occur at multiples of 60 Hz and can thus be readily identified. They can also be confirmed by changing the mirror velocity which changes where they appear in the spectra in a predictable way. In the present work, spectra were measured while simultaneously reducing and shifting the sidebands in the rf and thus the effects were correlated and ultimately eliminated as a source of noise. Ultimately reproducibilities of <1% in 15 s of scanning time across the entire spectral region from 800 to 4000 cm-1 with a sample throughput of only 10-10 m2 sr were achieved. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Cho T., Hirata M., Kohagura J., Takahashi E., Sakamoto Y., Yatsu K., Tamano T., Miyoshi S., Hirano K., Yagishita A., Maezawa H., Saitoh Y., Akamine T., Sato K., Inoue M., Miyahara S., Kondoh T., Tanaka S.
Title: Development and characterization of silicon semiconductor x-ray detectors for plasma diagnostics
Affiliations: Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Cho, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Hirata, M., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kohagura, J., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Takahashi, E., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sakamoto, Y., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yatsu, K., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Tamano, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Miyoshi, S., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Hirano, K., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yagishita, A., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Maezawa, H., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Saitoh, Y., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Akamine, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sato, K., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Inoue, M., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Miyahara, S., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kondoh, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Tanaka, S., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: The x-ray energy responses of silicon semiconductor detectors, including surface-barrier and photodiode-type detectors, have been investigated, using synchrotron radiation from a 2.5 GeV positron storage ring at the Photon Factory (KEK) in order to study the fundamental physics mechanism of the output signals. These studies are essential to obtain the principles of the future designs of plasma x-ray detectors, as well as of their plasma data analyses. The characterization experiments and their physics interpretations were made using (i) a group of fully depleted detectors and (ii) another group of partially depleted detectors characterized by obviously different depletion-layer thicknesses and minority-carrier diffusion lengths, but with the same wafer thickness. Both results are well interpreted by our newly proposed formula for a semiconductor x-ray-detector response. The importance of these investigations for the plasma x-ray diagnostics is highlighted by significant errors for the estimation of plasma-electron temperatures when the commonly utilized conventional theory is employed for the plasma data analyses. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Chubar O.V.
Title: Precise computation of electron-beam radiation in nonuniform magnetic fields as a tool for beam diagnostics
Affiliations: RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Chubar, O.V., RRC Kurchatov Institute, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: Visual range radiation emitted by an ultrarelativistic electron beam at bending magnet edges and within elements of the beam optics (steering magnets, quadrupole lenses, etc.) in storage rings is very sensitive to horizontal and vertical angular divergences, transverse sizes, emittances, energy, position, and trajectory tilts of the electron beam. Precise computation of the radiation intensity distributions with due regard for nonzero beam emittances, layout of storage ring magnet structure, and measurement scheme peculiarities allows one to obtain the electron-beam parameters from the measured radiation intensity distributions. The radiation computation technique and the experimental equipment adjusted for the beam diagnostics on the Siberia-1 electron storage ring are described. Experimental results on measurements of the radiation intensity distributions in the Siberia-1 ring and the corresponding electron-beam parameters determined by the method under discussion are presented. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Petersen H., Senf F., Schäfers F., Bahrdt J.
Title: Monochromators for the undulator U49 at the BESSY II storage ring
Affiliations: BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-14195 Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Petersen, H., BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-14195 Berlin, Germany; Senf, F., BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-14195 Berlin, Germany; Schäfers, F., BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-14195 Berlin, Germany; Bahrdt, J., BESSY GmbH, Lentzeallee 100, D-14195 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Two types of monochromators will be built for use on the planned soft x-ray undulator U49 of the BESSY II storage ring: A plane grating monochromator using the plane grating focusing condition and a spherical grating monochromator using the spherical grating focusing condition. The optical layout of the instruments and calculated performance data, i.e., spectral resolution, grating efficiencies, and available photon flux are presented for the photon energy range available from the U49, 137-1516 eV in the first, third, and fifth harmonic. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Abstract: The partial decay width into electrons, Γee, of the Υ{hooked}(1 S) and Υ{hooked}(2 S) resonances have been measured with the detector ARGUS at the e+e- storage ring DORISII of DESY. Applying the formula of Kuraev and Fadin for the radiative corrections we find: Γee(Υ{hooked}(1 S))= (1.32±0.04±0.03) keV and Γee(Υ{hooked}(2 S))=(0.52±0.03±0.01) keV. The total decay width of the Υ{hooked}(4 S) resonance and its partial width into electrons have been determined as well. Fitting the data with a generalized Breit-Wigner function with an energy dependent decay width Γ(s) and a mass shift function m(s), we obtain the following resonance parameters: Γ(M2)=(10.0±2.8±2.7) MeV, Γee=(0.28±0.05±0.01)keV and Bee=(2.77±0.50±0.49)·10-5. We argue that the disagrecment of this result with the world average originates from our more adequate parametrization of the observed Υ{hooked}(4 S) resonance cross section. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: The Super-ESCA beamline has been designed for high resolution core level spectroscopy of adsorbates on single crystal surfaces using soft x-ray synchrotron radiation. It receives the light from an 81 period undulator with 5.6 cm period and 4.5 m length in the storage ring ELETTRA. The tunability of this insertion device, at a storage ring electron energy of 2.0 GeV and the connected modified SX700 monochromator allows the performance of experiments at this beamline in the photon energy range 100-2000 eV. This beamline is now operational and first absorption spectra are presented which show available resolving powers varying from 8000 to 3000 for photon energies between 240 and 850 eV. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Hirata M., Cho T., Kohagura J., Yatsu K., Tamano T., Miyoshi S., Kondoh T., Saitoh Y., Sato K., Miyahara S., Hirano K., Maezawa H.
Title: A newly developed multilayer semiconductor x-ray detector for the observations of wide energy-range x rays
Affiliations: Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hirata, M., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Cho, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kohagura, J., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yatsu, K., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Tamano, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Miyoshi, S., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kondoh, T., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Saitoh, Y., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sato, K., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Miyahara, S., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Hirano, K., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Maezawa, H., Plasma Research Centre, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: For the purpose of the developments of wide-energy-range-sensitive x-ray detectors, we have designed and fabricated a new-type multilayer semiconductor x-ray detector. This new-type detector has been characterized using synchrotron radiation from a 2.5-GeV positron storage ring at the Photon Factory of the National Laboratory for High Energy Physics (KEK). This new detector is essentially composed of four layers of commercially available photodiodes. Each photodiode is made from a 300-μm thick, and a 10×10-mm square-shaped wafer. For the common affiliation of these individual photodiodes, the quantum efficiency normalized by the photon energy η/E begins to decrease at 8 keV, and then η/E decreases down to 26% at 20 keV. On the other hand, for our newly designed detector a flat response even in the 10-20-keV energy regime (beam line 15C at the Photon Factory) is observed, and even at 100 keV η/E<30% is still anticipated. This new x-ray detector has various advantages: (i) A compact, and (ii) outgas-free detector for a high-vacuum use, along with (iii) a high degree of immunity to ambient magnetic fields. Furthermore, (iv) the combination of the x-ray signal outputs from each detector layer provides information on the x-ray emitting electron energies. These properties are quite suitable for the use of the fusion-oriented plasma x-ray diagnostics under intense-magnetic field and high-vacuum conditions so as to interpret wide-band x-ray emitting electron-velocity distribution functions from the x-ray data. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Illing G., Heuer J., Reime B., Lohmann M., Menk R.H., Schildwächter L., Dix W.-R., Graeff W.
Title: Double beam bent Laue monochromator for coronary angiography
Affiliations: Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Illing, G., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Heuer, J., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Reime, B., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Lohmann, M., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Menk, R.H., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Schildwächter, L., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Dix, W.-R., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany; Graeff, W., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronensynchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, 22603 Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: High photon fluxes are crucial in dichromatic digital subtraction angiography with line scan systems to allow for adequate image quality. To obtain images wide enough and with sufficient vertical resolution, each of the two beams used has to be at least 100 mm wide but not more than 0.5 mm high at the patient's heart with the beam energies bracketing the iodine-K edge at 33.17 keV. A new monochromator in Laue transmission geometry has been developed, successfully tested at beamline ID11 of the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF) and is now in use at the angiography wiggler beamline W2 at HASYLAB. The monochromator consists of two almost identical goniometer heads which are independently controlled. Within each head a bent silicon single crystal extracts a quasimonochromatic beam and focuses it vertically to the patient thus also increasing intensity compared to an unbent crystal. With a storage ring current of 50 mA the new monochromator provides 0.8×10 11 photons/mm2/s in front of the patient which is an increase by a factor of 6 compared to the formerly used Bragg design with Ge crystals. Also, it is remarkably more stable against variations of the input power load. © 1995 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Hsu I.C., Trzeciak W.S.
Title: Measurement of injection energy mismatch in circular accelerators using rf capture efficiency observations
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Science, National Tsing Hua University, Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30043, Taiwan; Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hsu, I.C., Institute of Nuclear Science, National Tsing Hua University, Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30043, Taiwan; Trzeciak, W.S., Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
Abstract: A general method for measuring the energy mismatch between a storage ring and its injector is presented. The energy mismatch is defined as the difference between the injector energy and the synchronous energy of the storage ring. Observations of the rf capture of the injected beam when the energy acceptance or synchronous energy are varied yield the energy mismatch. The energy acceptance and synchronous energy are easily varied by changing the rf accelerating voltage, the rf frequency, or both. As an example, measurements performed on the 1 GeV electron storage ring Aladdin show an energy mismatch of 0.666 MeV at the injection energy of 108 MeV. This agrees with theoretical predictions about injection stacking at a rate faster than the radiation damping rates. © 1995.

Authors: Dattoli G., Giannessi L., Ottaviani P.L., Renieri A.
Title: A model for the saturation of a storage ring free electron laser
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: ENEA Area INN, Dipartimento Sviluppo Tecnologie di Punta, CRE Frascati C.P. 65, I-00044 Frascati, Rome, Italy; ENEA-INN. FIS, CRE Bologna, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Dattoli, G., ENEA Area INN, Dipartimento Sviluppo Tecnologie di Punta, CRE Frascati C.P. 65, I-00044 Frascati, Rome, Italy; Giannessi, L., ENEA Area INN, Dipartimento Sviluppo Tecnologie di Punta, CRE Frascati C.P. 65, I-00044 Frascati, Rome, Italy; Ottaviani, P.L., ENEA-INN. FIS, CRE Bologna, Italy; Renieri, A., ENEA Area INN, Dipartimento Sviluppo Tecnologie di Punta, CRE Frascati C.P. 65, I-00044 Frascati, Rome, Italy
Abstract: The dynamical properties of a storage ring free electron laser oscillator are reproduced using a model combining three different saturation mechanisms: laser induced energy spread of the e-beam, associated bunch lengthening and longitudinal synchronism between laser and electron pulses. The stationary output power is shown to be always linked to the power emitted via synchrotron radiation in one machine turn by the circulating e-beam. © 1995.

Authors: Grinko D.A., Krujchin A.A.
Title: The formation of phase-change and relief-change recording media by joint oxidative thermodecomposition of hexacarbonyls on the surface
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Recording Information Problems, National Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, 2, Shpakst., Kiev, 252113, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Grinko, D.A., Institute of Recording Information Problems, National Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, 2, Shpakst., Kiev, 252113, Ukraine; Krujchin, A.A., Institute of Recording Information Problems, National Ukrainian Academy of Sciences, 2, Shpakst., Kiev, 252113, Ukraine
Abstract: In conditions of joint oxidative thermal decomposition of molybdenum and tungsten hexacarbonyls as members of oxide films can be complex compounds with the most probable structure: (- O -)4 W (- CO -)2 Mo (- O -)4, which are formed by adsorbed molybdenum and tungsten hexacarbonyls molecules coordination on the growing surface. The constant of complexes formation on the surface has a narrow pronounced maximum at short range of molybdenum and tungsten hexacarbonyls pressures. The entry of that complex into the film occurs parallel with film growth processes at the expensaof oxidative molybdenum, tungsten carbonyls and heterocarbonylic complex thermodecomposition [1]. The recording media on base of d-metals oxides doped by organic or complex compounds are intended for thermooptic single-repeate recording on thin films with subsequent repeated many times reading. Another intention is fabrication of microrelief devices. The information recording by intensity laser beam is not accompanied with mechanic film breaking, but only causes the educing of optic contrast phase or moulding the bubbles. Nonstoichiometric oxide films are used as matrix, which absorb laser radiation, ensure mechanic stability under irradiation influence and stability during a longtime storage. Organic compounds doped into a matrix at film growing ensure decrease of threshold power of recording by laser irradiation in visible and near-infrared range of spectrum on the order of magnitude in comparison with starting matrix and make the phase educing or bubble moulding effects in dependence of dopant concentration, show on fig.l. Spectral sensitivity range of recording media - is visible and near infrared range, have a threshold exposition characteristic. Recording energy for impulse duration of 200 ns and focused laser spot of 0.8 mkm. is about 3 nJ. The resolution makes realization of information carrier with track pitch of 1.2 mkm. The phase-change recording is accompanied with increasing both of imaginary and real part of refractive index. The relief-change recording is accompanied with hard stable bubbles moulding. The formation of recording media demonstrated on example of amorphous films of nonstoichiometric tungsten oxide doped with molybdenum oxidecarbonyl compounds. The preparation of functional films and coatings by joint deposition of carbonylic compounds became one of the widely spread methods allowing to obtain deposits with controllable composition. In this case as a member of deposit can also be the intermediates of carbonyls decomposition processes. Their structure and relationship of concentration to deposition conditions provide information about film growth mechanisms. The formation of molybdenum and tungsten heterocarbonylic complexes thermodynamically is profitable in the determined temperature range [1]. Their heterocarbonylic complexes of tetrahedral configuration were revealed in the gas phase in conditions of joint thermal hexacarbonyls decomposition in the inert gas-carrier. In this case the heterocarbonylic complex formation constant in the gas phase has a weakly pronounced maximum subject to the equality of carbonyls partial pressures [1]. The molybdenum and tungsten heterocarbonylic complexes were revealed as members of films prepared by joint thermal hexacarbonyls decomposition on the surface in neutral [2] and oxidative [3] media. The functional film properties depend substantially on ratios of molybdenum and tungsten hexacarbonyls vapour pressures [4] what cannot be explained by heterocarbonylic complex formation only in the gas phase. In the paper is investigated the relationship of film composition prepared in conditions of joint oxidative hexacarbonyls thermodecomposition to the ratio of molybdenum and tungsten hexacarbonyls vapors pressure. The films prepared in vacuum in the order hundreds pascal in the flow reactor by controlling the deposition process. As an oxidizer used air. The vapor pressure measured by means of thermoelectric converters using the technique [5] to an accuracy of 5 %. The film thickness was in the order of hundreds nanometres. For substrate used monocrystal silicon. The film composition was determined by layer-by-layer Auger spectroscopy method [6]. The investigations were pursued on the JSM-T-20 Auger analyzer by internal standards method in conditions of continuous film surface etching in an argon ions beam. © 1995 SPIE.

Title: Stability of O2/H2 mixtures at high pressure

Abstract: THE discovery1–3 of the stoichiometric compounds He(N2)11, Ne(He)2 and Ar(H2)2 in high-pressure mixtures has uncovered a new aspect of high-pressure chemistry. In contrast to these studies on inert species, we show here that high pressures can lead to unexpected behaviour in reactive compounds. We find that mixtures of O2 and H2 are stable at pressures of around 7.6 GPa, despite their explosive nature under ambient conditions. We use microscopy and Raman spectroscopy to identify the phase boundary of the stable region. The structure of the binary phase diagram at 296 K suggests that a stoichiometric compound (O2)3(H2)4 might exist. The stability of dense O2/H2 mixtures might be use-fully exploited in the development of rocket fuels and for energy storage, and might also be relevant to the composition of the interiors of the jovian planets. © 1995, Nature Publishing Group. All Rights Reserved.
Index Keywords: Composition; Explosives; Hydrogen; Microscopic examination; Mixtures; Oxygen; Phase diagrams; Phase equilibria; Phase transitions; Raman spectroscopy; Stoichiometry; Structure (composition); Binary system; High pressure chemistry; Phase boundary; Reactive compounds; Rocket fuels; Stoichiometric compounds; High pressure effects

Authors: Bennett M.B., Taylor G.C.
Title: Scaling of elastic strain energy in kangaroos and the benefits of being big
Affiliations: Department of Anatomical Sciences, University of Queensland, St Lucia, QLD, 4072, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, M.B., Department of Anatomical Sciences, University of Queensland, St Lucia, QLD, 4072, Australia; Taylor, G.C., Department of Anatomical Sciences, University of Queensland, St Lucia, QLD, 4072, Australia
Abstract: LARGE kangaroos are unique among mammals in their ability to uncouple aerobic metabolic energy costs from the speed of locomotion1, 2, making hopping an economical gait. During the first half of the ground-contact phase, kinetic energy lost from the body is stored as elastic strain energy, predominantly in the hind limbs3–5. The subsequent recoil returns kinetic and potential energy to the body. Here we show that the allometry of structures in the legs and feet of Macropodoidea is different from that of quadrupedal eutherian mammals. The potential for elastic energy storage in hoppers is shown to scale with strong positive allometry. This is a function of the structural properties of muscle–tendon units in the distal hind limbs and the postures adopted by hopping kangaroos. Our findings demonstrate how the use of tissue elasticity is strongly mass dependent and help explain the observed energetic phenomena. © 1995, Nature Publishing Group. All Rights Reserved.
Index Keywords: allometry; animal tissue; article; body size; elasticity; energy cost; energy transfer; foot; hindlimb; jumping; kangaroo; nonhuman; priority journal; Animal; Body Constitution; Elasticity; Energy Metabolism; Extremities; Gait; Kangaroos; Locomotion; Mammals; Muscle, Skeletal; Tendons

Authors: Manwell J.F., McGowan J.G.
Title: Wind diesel system simulation: A screening level model
Affiliations: Renewable Energy Research Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, 01003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Manwell, J.F., Renewable Energy Research Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, 01003, United States; McGowan, J.G., Renewable Energy Research Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, 01003, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a screening level solutions model for diesel systems. It is intended for use to give a quick overview of the possible appropriateness of a wind/diesel system and indicate whether more detailed analysis would be of use. The model was developed for use on personal computers and to trade complexity for ease of operation. The wind/diesel system modelled may include: 1) Wind regime: 2) One or more wind turbines: 3) System electrical load : 4) One or more diesel generators: 5) Dumo load: 6) Short term storage, and 7) System controller. The model does not consider storage explicitly, but does distinguish between the no storage and minimal storage (power smoothing) systems. This work is based on the more detailed simulation models previously developed at the University of Massachusetts, but uses probabilistic methods rather than time series data inputs. As such it requires only mean and standard deviation of wind speed and load for each month or season. The model functions by assuming that occuftences of wind speed can be modelled by a Weibull distribution and that the load follws either a Welbull Of normal distribution, In addition, both the wind speed and load are assumed to be uncorrelated within each month or season. The paper also includes a comparison of the model with the more detailed UMass model, HYBRID 1. © 1995, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Hybrid systems; Wind diesel systems; Wind generators
Index Keywords: Simulation; Wind Diesel Systems; Wind Generators; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Weibull distribution; Screening level model; Wind diesel system; Wind generators; Wind power

Authors: Carpenter S.H., Stuch T.E., Salzbrenner R.
Title: An investigation of the mechanical damping of ductile iron
Affiliations: Physics Department, University of Denver, Denver, 80208, CO, United States; Materials Performance and Reliability Program, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, 87185, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carpenter, S.H., Physics Department, University of Denver, Denver, 80208, CO, United States; Stuch, T.E., Physics Department, University of Denver, Denver, 80208, CO, United States; Salzbrenner, R., Materials Performance and Reliability Program, Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, 87185, NM, United States
Abstract: Ductile iron has been suggested as a candidate material for a number of practical applications, including turbine castings, automotive components, and transportation and storage casks for hazardous and radioactive materials. The applications require the enhanced ductility resulting from the presence of spherical graphite nodules in the ductile ferrite iron matrix. Proper design of such components requires a knowledge of the mechanical properties, including how energy is absorbed and dissipated (mechanical damping) by the test material. This article is a study of the mechanical damping of a series of well-characterized ductile iron materials (four separate materials) as a function of strain amplitude, temperature over the range of -100 °C to +100 °C, and magnetic field. The major sources of damping were found to be dislocation motion in the graphite phase and magnetomechanical damping in the ferrite phase. The magnitude of the magnetomechanical damping was much larger than that due to dislocation motion. An additional goal of the investigation was to determine if any correlation existed between the measured mechanical damping and the fracture toughness of the ductile iron materials; no correlation was found. © 1995 The Minerals, Metals & Material Society.
Index Keywords: Damping; Dislocations (crystals); Ductility; Ferrite; Fracture toughness; Graphite; Magnetic field effects; Metallographic microstructure; Strain rate; Thermal effects; Dislocation motion; Nodular iron

Authors: Wang Y.P., Smith R.
Title: Time pinch analysis
Affiliations: UMIST, Manchester, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Y.P., UMIST, Manchester, United Kingdom; Smith, R., UMIST, Manchester, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper introduces a new method of time pinch analysis for the design of batch processes. Heat integration, utility system design and water minimization are all considered. The method differs from previous approaches in that time is treated as the primary constraint with temperature and concentration driving forces treated as secondary constraints. The method also offers new graphical representations of the problem. Storage requirements and rescheduling opportunities for reduced energy and water storage requirements are readily identified.

Abstract: A new alpha/beta portable radiation spectrometer has been developed for the estimation of individual radon daughters. The instrument is equipped with a microprocessor and a memory or data storage system. The new instrument is currently in routine use in South African gold mines.

Authors: Maly D.K., Kwan K.S.
Title: Optimal battery energy storage system (BESS) charge scheduling with dynamic programming
Source title: IEE Proceedings: Science, Measurement and Technology
Affiliations: Motorola Electronics Taiwan Ltd, Chung-Li, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Maly, D.K., Motorola Electronics Taiwan Ltd, Chung-Li, Taiwan; Kwan, K.S., Motorola Electronics Taiwan Ltd, Chung-Li, Taiwan
Abstract: A dynamic programming algorithm for the optimal charge/discharge scheduling of BESS energy storage is presented. It ensures the minimization of the electricity bill for a given battery capacity, while reducing stress on the battery and prolonging battery life. Optimal scheduling of the battery charge state is in itself unique; the methods of multipass dynamic programming are used to accomplish this. Maximum payoff for load redistribution and peak load shaving is determined while accounting for charging rate, battery voltage fluctuation and internal losses as a function of charge state. The optimal charging curve is significantly different from the curve conventionally published for BESS.

Authors: Schneider A.D., Howell T.A.
Title: Grain sorghum response to sprinkler application methods and system capacity
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: USDA-Agricultural Research Service, Bushland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, A.D., USDA-Agricultural Research Service, Bushland, United States; Howell, T.A., USDA-Agricultural Research Service, Bushland, United States
Abstract: The crop yield response of grain sorghum to four sprinkler methods and four irrigation amounts which simulated varying irrigation capacities was evaluated during 1992 and 1993 at Bushland, Texas, in the Southern High Plains. Irrigation methods were LEPA sock, LEPA bubble, in-canopy spray near ground level, and overhead spray. The application devices were installed on a three-span, hose-fed, lateral-move sprinkler system. Irrigations were scheduled from neutron soil water measurements in a designated control treatment receiving 100% irrigation by the LEPA sock method. Soil water in the control plots was maintained above 75% of the plant available level by simultaneously applying 25-mm irrigations with all four sprinkler methods as the 100% irrigation amount. Deficit irrigation treatments received 75, 50, and 25% of the control treatment application on the same date. All furrows were diked to minimize runoff and enhance surface storage from irrigation and rainfall. The 100% irrigation treatments received 250 and 325 mm of irrigation in 1992 and 1993, respectively, along with 310 and 223 mm, respectively, of rainfall from emergence to the last irrigation. Grain sorghum yields were primarily affected by irrigation amount and to a lesser extend by sprinkler method, especially for the two smaller irrigation amounts. With deficit irrigation the LEPA bubble and sock methods yielded better than the spray methods likely due to reducing evaporation from the crop canopy and soil and thus increasing the amount of water available for transpiration. For example with LEPA in 1992, grain sorghum yields were reduced only 1% while the irrigation amount was reduced from 250 mm for 100% irrigation to 125 mm for 50% irrigation.
Index Keywords: Agricultural runoff; Crops; Grain (agricultural product); Irrigation; Rain; Simulation; Soils; Spraying; Water; Bushland, Texas; Crop yield; Grain sorghum; Low energy precision application; Sprinkler systems (irrigation)

Authors: Ono K., Gondo N., Arita M., Fozzard H.A., Hadama T., Uchida Y.
Title: University of Wisconsin solution preserves myocardial calcium current response to isoproterenol in isolated canine ventricular myocytes
Affiliations: Department of Surgery, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan; Department of Physiology, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan; Cardiac Electrophysiology Labs., Department of Medicine, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, United States; Second Department of Surgery, Oita Medical University, 1-1 Idaigaoka, Hasama, Oita 879-55, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ono, K., Department of Surgery, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan, Department of Physiology, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan, Second Department of Surgery, Oita Medical University, 1-1 Idaigaoka, Hasama, Oita 879-55, Japan; Gondo, N., Department of Physiology, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan; Arita, M., Department of Physiology, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan; Fozzard, H.A., Cardiac Electrophysiology Labs., Department of Medicine, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, United States; Hadama, T., Department of Surgery, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan; Uchida, Y., Department of Surgery, Oita Medical University, Hasama, Oita, Japan
Abstract: Background: University of Wisconsin (UW) solution has been shown to be an effective solution for cold storage of various organs. This study was designed to evaluate the subcellular protective mechanism of UW solution during cardiac myocyte storage using patch-clamp techniques for the first time as a tool for the detection of myocyte viability. Methods and Results: The protective effects of UW solution on the preservation of dihydropyridine- sensitive Ca2+ channel current response to catecholamine were evaluated in canine cardiac ventricular cells by measurement of single channel open probability. Single ventricular myocytes were isolated and stored in UW solution, in Stanford (SF) solution, or in St Thomas' (ST) solution at 4°C for 2, 6, 12, and 24 hours, and after each storage period, recordings were made of cell-attached single Ca2+ channel currents. When 0.1 μmol/L isoproterenol was applied, percent mean open probability of the Ca2+ channel tested in freshly isolated cells was 167±4% (n=24) of controls (100%). The response was decrescent with increased duration of the hypothermic storage and was only 130±12% (n=4) after 24 hours of storage in SF solution and 135±9% (n=7) in ST solution. However, it was significantly highly preserved as much as 165±9% (n=6) in UW solution. Ca2+ channel kinetics and channel conductance were not changed after up to 24 hours of hypothermic storage. Conclusions: Hypothermic storage of canine cardiac myocytes in UW solution preserved β-adrenergic response, which suggests that UW solution during cold storage preserved high-energy phosphates in myocytes that are responsible for Ca2+ channel phosphorylations.
Author Keywords: calcium channels; cardioplegia; catecholamines; electrophysiology; transplantation

Authors: Jehenson P., Leroy-Willig A., de Kerviler E., Merlet P., Duboc D., Syrota A.
Title: Impairment of the exercise-induced increase in muscle perfusion in McArdle's disease
Affiliations: Service Hospitalier Frédéric Joliot, Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, 4 place du Général Leclerc, Orsay, F-91406, France; INSERM U153 and Service de Cardiologie, Hôpital Cochin, Paris, F-75014, France
Authors with affiliations: Jehenson, P., Service Hospitalier Frédéric Joliot, Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, 4 place du Général Leclerc, Orsay, F-91406, France; Leroy-Willig, A., Service Hospitalier Frédéric Joliot, Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, 4 place du Général Leclerc, Orsay, F-91406, France; de Kerviler, E., Service Hospitalier Frédéric Joliot, Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, 4 place du Général Leclerc, Orsay, F-91406, France; Merlet, P., Service Hospitalier Frédéric Joliot, Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, 4 place du Général Leclerc, Orsay, F-91406, France; Duboc, D., INSERM U153 and Service de Cardiologie, Hôpital Cochin, Paris, F-75014, France; Syrota, A., Service Hospitalier Frédéric Joliot, Commissariat à l'Energie Atomique, 4 place du Général Leclerc, Orsay, F-91406, France
Abstract: In McArdle's disease (myophosphorylase deficiency) exercise intolerance is generally attributed to a lack of glycogenolysis, which decreases energy production during exercise. Magnetic resonance imaging data have recently suggested an impairment of the increase in muscle perfusion during exercise in these patients. We have tested this hypothesis by direct measurement of local muscle perfusion increase. Increase in muscle perfusion was assessed by positron emission tomography with oxygen-15 labelled water in five patients with McArdle's disease and five age- and sex-matched healthy volunteers. Radioactivity was measured in both forearms before and after exercise of the right forearm. The exercise intensity was biochemically assessed by in vivo phosphorus-31 magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The estimated increase in muscle perfusion with exercise was 5.7±5.5-fold in the patients (range 1.5-12.8) and 22.3±12.0-fold in the healthy subjects (range 10.1-37) (P=0.022). The results show a significant impairment of increase in muscle perfusion with exercise in McArdle's disease. Thus patients may suffer not only from a direct lack of glycogenolysis but also from indirectly impaired vasodilation. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Magnetic resonance spectroscopy; McArdle's disease; Muscle perfusion; Positron emission tomography

Authors: Hofmann T., Schieberle P.
Title: Studies on the Formation and Stability of the Roast-Flavor Compound 2-Acetyl-2-thiazoline
Source title: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry

Authors with affiliations: Hofmann, T., Deutsche Forschungsanstalt für Lebensmittelchemie, Universität München, Lichtenbergstrasse 4, 85748 Garching, Germany, Germany; Schieberle, P., Institut für Lebensmittelchemie der Technischen, Universität München, Lichtenbergstrasse 4, 85748 Garching, Germany
Abstract: 2-(1-Hydroxyethyl)-4,5-dihydrothiazole (HDT) was identified by 1H- and 13C-NMR measurements as the main volatile product formed by storage of an aqueous solution of cysteamine and methylglyoxal at low temperatures (6 °C). The structure of HDT was confirmed by synthesis. Systematic studies on the thermal stability of the HDT under different conditions either in aqueous solution or during high-resolution gas chromatography revealed that HDT is an important intermediate in the formation of the intensely roasty smelling food flavor compound 2-acetyl-2-thiazoline (AT). Model studies showed that more than 10% of the precursor HDT was converted into AT simply by heating for 10 min in water. The activation energy of this reaction was 57.4 kJ/mol. Experiments on the thermal stability of AT itself revealed that heating in aqueous solution also led to a degradation of AT, whereas heating in an oil significantly stabilized the flavor compound. © 1995, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Witztum A., Schulgasser K.
Title: The Mechanics of Seed Expulsion in Acanthaceae
Affiliations: Department of Life Sciences, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer Sheva, Israel; Pearlstone Center for Aeronautical Engineering Studies, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer Sheva, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Witztum, A., Department of Life Sciences, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer Sheva, Israel; Schulgasser, K., Pearlstone Center for Aeronautical Engineering Studies, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ben Gurion University of the Negev, P.O. Box 653, Beer Sheva, Israel
Abstract: The bilocular seed capsules of species on the Acanthaceae subfamily Acanthoideae are either hygrochastic or xerochastic, but in both cases the mechanism for seed expulsion is similar; only the "trigger" differs in the two instances. The drying of the capsule results in the storage of elastic energy in the capsule valves. The failure of the seam joining the two values precipitates the conversion of the elastic potential energy stored in the valves and seeds. In the hygrochastic case the failure is due to moisture absorption on wetting of the capsule beak which weakens the pectic "glue"; in the xerochastic case the seam failure is due simply to the high stress in the bonding layer at some degree of desiccation. This paper explains quantitatively how the anatomy of the capsule efficiently imports high initial expulsion velocity to the seeds in order to maximize their range. The specific example considered inRuellia brittonianaLeonard, a cultivated shrub native to Mexico, but the situation is similar for the entire Acanthoideae subfamily. © 1995 Academic Press. All rights reserved.

Authors: Warkentin A., Semercigil S.E.
Title: Variable stiffness control of a single-link flexible robotic arm
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, McMaster University, Hamilton, ON L8S 4L7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Warkentin, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, McMaster University, Hamilton, ON L8S 4L7, Canada; Semercigil, S.E., Department of Mechanical Engineering, McMaster University, Hamilton, ON L8S 4L7, Canada
Abstract: A case study is presented to demonstrate the use of variable stiffness control to attenuate the excessive oscillations of a single-link robotic arm. This relatively simple control technique actively changes the system’s stiffness to take advantage of strain energy storage capabilities for different stiffnesses. The stiffness changes required for vibration control can be accomplished with minimal effort and without adding energy to the system, ensuring the stability of control. Numerical simulations predicted significant suppression of both transient and random vibrations. Simple experiments were performed to test the validity of the numerical predictions. © 1995 by Academic Press, Inc.

Authors: Balint-Kurti G.G., Pulay P.
Title: A new grid-based method for the direct computation of excited molecular vibrational states: test application to formaldehyde
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Authors with affiliations: Balint-Kurti, G.G., Department of Chemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Pulay, P., Department of Chemistry, University of Arkansas, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Abstract: A new method is presented for the direct computation of excited vibrational energy levels of molecules. The method combines the advantages of grid-based approaches to molecular dynamics problems with those of the Davidson diagonalization technique, which has found widespread usage in molecular electronic structure theory. It permits the direct computation of a prespecified vibrational state without the need to compute all lower lying levels. The wavefunctions used in the present test applications are extremely accurate and are the vibrational analogues of "full configuration interaction (CI)" wavefunctions in electronic structure theory. The method is applicable to large problems in that it requires the storage of only a few vectors, between six and eleven in the examples given, and no large matrices need to be retained. The theory of the new method is presented, first for the case of a single degree of vibrational freedom and then for the general case. Test results are given both for a diatomic model system and for a realistic ab initio potential energy surface computed for the formaldehyde molecule. The method is expected to provide a starting point for the development of future techniques for computing highly accurate vibrational wavefunctions for much larger molecules. As with all grid-based methods, no matrix elements of the potential need to be evaluated. The value of the potential is required only at the grid points of the multidimensional grid in coordinate space. © 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Anon
Title: Manufacturing of aluminium rolled products - the Kobe steel and Kaal Moka plants
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In recent years, aluminum has been more widely used as a material enabling energy and resource conservation as a material that is clean and environmentally sound. This paper describes the Kobe Steel Ltd and KAAL Moka Plant, and the processes used for manufacturing aluminum rolled products. These include can stock used for aluminum cans which are currently the main type of beverage cans; aluminum sheet for vehicles to achieve weight reduction, energy conservation and higher speed; and disk blanks and substrates for hard disk used as the data storage medium of personal computers.

Authors: Rasin Tek M.
Title: Verification of inventory in underground storage [Yeralti gas depolamasinda stok kontrolu]
Source title: Turkish Journal of Oil and Gas
Authors with affiliations: Rasin Tek, M.
Abstract: A study on the attributes critical in the underground storage of natural gas, e.g., verification of inventory, assurance of deliverability, and safeguards against migration, was carried out. The methodologies developed for auditing the inventory actually residing in the storage horizon were documented. Inventory was a critical attribute in underground storage related to the other two attributes. Review of present state of the art in inventory verification could range from totally empirical observation of pressure-content charts to more scientific and approximate engineering methods based on thermodynamic concepts and to more sophisticated simulation of hysteresis performance through additional concepts of material balance and reservoir engineering. In underground storage reservoirs subject to water drive, the pressure-content performance could be accurately predicted via proper characterization of energy support from the surrounding aquifer. A set of equations developed for predicting the hysteresis performance could be utilized to determine the presence, nature, extent, and timing of storage gas loss due to migration, seepage, or other causes.

Authors: Nishida S., Takahashi Y., Kittaka J.
Title: Structural changes in the hepatopancreas of the rock lobster, Jasus edwardsii (Crustacea: Palinuridae) during development from the puerulus to post-puerulus
Affiliations: Ocean Research Institute, 1-15-1 Minamidai, Nakano, Tokyo, 164, Japan; School of Fisheries Sciences, Kitasato University, 160-4 Okirai, Sanriku-cho, Iwate, 022-01, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishida, S., Ocean Research Institute, 1-15-1 Minamidai, Nakano, Tokyo, 164, Japan; Takahashi, Y., School of Fisheries Sciences, Kitasato University, 160-4 Okirai, Sanriku-cho, Iwate, 022-01, Japan; Kittaka, J., School of Fisheries Sciences, Kitasato University, 160-4 Okirai, Sanriku-cho, Iwate, 022-01, Japan
Abstract: There is evidence for non-feeding in pueruli of palinurid lobsters during their long-distance swim to the coast and the succeeding post-settlement phase until they molt to the juveniles. For a better understanding of the nutritional supply during the puerulus stage, structural changes in the hepatopancreas were studied in post-settlement pueruli and first-molt, postpueruli of the rock lobster, Jasus edwardsii, collected on the southeast coast of the North Island, New Zealand between 1989 and 1990. In newly settled (transparent) pueruli, the epithelium of the hepatopancreas is dominated by presumed "young R-(resorptive) cells", which are devoid of lipid droplets, but show active uptake of material from the hemolymph through pinocytosis at the basal region. In the fully pigmented puerulus, the hepatopancreas is dominated by R-cells containing massive lipid droplets; also present are small numbers of F-(fibrillar) and B-(blister-like) cells. This increase of lipid inclusion in the R-cells corresponds to the reduction in size of the fat bodies as the lobster develops from the transparent to the pigmented puerulus. After the molt to the post-puerulus, the R-cells are compressed, and the lipid droplets almost disappear, while the B-cells increase both in size and number. A mechanism is proposed in the present paper to explain energy storage and utilization during the puerulus and post-puerulus stages, wherein the fat bodies and the lipid inclusions play a vital role. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: Jasus edwardsii

Authors: McDonald Dick, Lasday Stanley B.
Title: Vacuum furnaces with variable speed cooling are being used for precise control in thermal processing aircraft engine parts
Affiliations: United Technologies, North Berwick, United States
Authors with affiliations: McDonald, Dick, United Technologies, North Berwick, United States; Lasday, Stanley B., United Technologies, North Berwick, United States
Abstract: Variable fan speeds are being used to control cooling rates of Ni-based alloy parts in vacuum furnaces at Pratt & Whitney Div. of United Technologies in North Berwick, MF. P&W, a major manufacturer of engines for the aircraft and aerospace industries, produces and processes many of the components that need to be heat treated or brazed for the engines or both. P&W has installed vacuum furnaces equipped with a variable fan speed system to meet tighter cool down tolerances in order to attain desired properties while eliminating parts distortion, improving efficiency, saving energy, and increasing processing flexibility. Instrumentation controls the elements and the variable frequency fan driver. A programmable logic controller is used with remote i/o for data collection and storage. Diffusion pumps have also been fitted with energy saving devices to cut power usage.

Authors: Daugherty Lawrence R.
Title: How's your hot water supply?
Affiliations: Armstrong-Yoshitake, Inc, Three Rivers, United States
Authors with affiliations: Daugherty, Lawrence R., Armstrong-Yoshitake, Inc, Three Rivers, United States
Abstract: Feed-forward water heaters provide many of the desirable features. Such units provide the temperature accuracy of storage tanks without wasting valuable floor space. They provide the compactness of a tankless feedback system without the dangerous thermal lags and potentially hazardous overheating with controller failure. This fail-safe design means that only cool water will exit the unit should the diaphragm ever fail. Feed-water domestic hot water units are energy efficient because water is heated only when heated. Moreover, because there are fewer moving parts, feed-forward domestic steam hot water systems require less maintenance and experience fewer premature failures.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Diaphragms; Feedback; Heat exchangers; Heating equipment; Pressure drop; Steam; Temperature control; Valves (mechanical); Water heaters; Water quality; Water tanks; Differential pressure diaphragm value; Pressure differential; Steam flow; Steam heating systems; Storage tank feedback systems; Temperature sensing; Hot water distribution systems

Authors: Duffin John
Title: Ice storage monitoring and control for optimum performance
Affiliations: Caradon Trend
Authors with affiliations: Duffin, John, Caradon Trend
Abstract: An advanced control strategy is required to take full advantage of the economies offered by ice storage and to ensure the safety of heat exchangers and other equipment. The ice store can be placed in parts of the building where it would not be practicable to site chillers. The store produces no vibration or noise, and need no electrical supply. Even burying it seem advantageous. Finally, the chillers and valves tend to last longer as the chillers are run for long periods at full load with no modulation. Ice storage may be used in a number of different ways, and the selection of different options will depend on the requirements and limitations of each building. The main advantages of ice storage are due to the price difference between peak and off-peak electricity, coupled with more efficient use of the chillers. With increasing competition between electricity suppliers the price difference may increase in the future.
Index Keywords: Costs; Energy conversion; Heat exchangers; Monitoring; Performance; Pipe; Storage (materials); Temperature control; Thermal effects; Chiller; Cooling pipe; Ice storage; Air conditioning

Authors: Sievers Robert K., Ivanenok III Joseph F., Hunt Thomas K.
Title: Alkali metal thermal to electric conversion
Affiliations: Advanced Modular Power Systems Inc, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sievers, Robert K., Advanced Modular Power Systems Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Ivanenok III, Joseph F., Advanced Modular Power Systems Inc, Ann Arbor, United States; Hunt, Thomas K., Advanced Modular Power Systems Inc, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: Alkali Metal Thermal to Electric Conversion (AMTEC), a direct power-conversion technology, is emerging from the lab for use in a number of applications that require lightweight, long-running, efficient power systems. AMTEC is compatible with many heat and fuel sources, and it offers the reliability of direct thermal to electric conversion. These features make it an attractive technology for small spacecraft used in deep-space missions and for ground power applications such as self-powered furnaces and the generators used in recreational vehicles. The ability of AMTEC systems is made possible by a number of engineering advances. Replacing the electromagnetic pump with wicks reduces the cell design complexity, eliminates parasitic heat losses, and makes the cell more compact. Introducing remote condensing increases efficiency by isolating the hot zone from the cold zone of the cell.
Index Keywords: Aircraft fuels; Alkali metals; Electric converters; Electric generators; Electric power systems; Electromagnetic pumps; Energy efficiency; Energy storage; Heat losses; Radioisotopes; Reliability; Technology; Alkali metal thermal to electric conversion; Ground power applications; Radioisotopes power system; Solid oxide fuel cells; Thermal energy storage material; Thermoelectric energy conversion

Authors: Wall Simon
Title: Vector control: a practical approach to electric vehicles
Affiliations: Wavedriver Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Wall, Simon, Wavedriver Ltd
Abstract: The Wavedriver combined electric vehicle drive and fast charging system is presented. By augmenting standard rotor flux indirect field oriented control the demanding requirements of an electric vehicle drive system are met. A novel structure is presented for the digital control of motor currents. Finally results are given to demonstrate the excellent performance of the drive system.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Digital control systems; Electric currents; Electric drives; Electric energy storage; Electric vehicles; Performance; Power control; Rotors; Torque control; Traction motors; Quadrant motor drive; Rotor flux; Traction battery; Vector control; Wavedriver; Induction motors

Authors: Szurkowski J., Tukaj Z.
Title: Characterization by photoacoustic spectroscopy of the photosynthetic Scenedesmus armatus system affected by fuel oil contamination
Source title: Archives of Environmental Contamination and Toxicology
Affiliations: Institute of Experimental Physics, University of Gdansk, Wita Stwosza 57, Gdansk, 80-952, Poland; Department of Plant Physiology, University of Gdansk, Al. Marszalka J. Pilsudskiego 46, Gdynia, 81-378, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Szurkowski, J., Institute of Experimental Physics, University of Gdansk, Wita Stwosza 57, Gdansk, 80-952, Poland; Tukaj, Z., Department of Plant Physiology, University of Gdansk, Al. Marszalka J. Pilsudskiego 46, Gdynia, 81-378, Poland
Abstract: The effect of aqueous fuel oil extract (AFOE)1 on the photosynthetic system in green algae Scenedesmus armatus cultures was examined by photoacoustic spectroscopy. After a 24-h culture growth, the photosynthetic energy storage (ES) decreased, with increasing AFOE concentration in the culture. In these algae, ES is lowered by 41% by a 90% AFOE concentration. The plot of relative ES vs the measuring light intensity, i.e., analogous to the classic photosynthesis light-saturation curve, was determined for the fuel oil-affected culture, and a simple mathematical formula was adopted to derive the photosynthetic system parameters. © 1995 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.
Index Keywords: fuel oil; article; green alga; mathematical analysis; nonhuman; photosynthesis; phytoplankton; pollution; priority journal; algae; Armatus; Chlorophyta; Scenedesmus armatus

Authors: Sandstrom O., Neuman E., Thoresson G.
Title: Effects of temperature on life history variables in perch
Affiliations: National Board of Fisheries, Institute of Coastal Research, Gamla Slipvagen 19, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Sandstrom, O., National Board of Fisheries, Institute of Coastal Research, Gamla Slipvagen 19, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden; Neuman, E., National Board of Fisheries, Institute of Coastal Research, Gamla Slipvagen 19, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden; Thoresson, G., National Board of Fisheries, Institute of Coastal Research, Gamla Slipvagen 19, S-740 71 Oregrund, Sweden
Abstract: Population structure, recruitment, mortality, life expectancy, age at maturity, gonad development, fecundity, net reproductive rate and energy storage were studied in a perch population exposed to thermal discharge. The experiment was conducted during 1978-1990 in an artificial enclosure at a nuclear power plant on the Baltic Sea coast. Abundance increased after the plant started operating, although the proportion of larger perch dropped to a low level. Recruitment improved, but adult mortality increased. This effect was accentuated as the fishes matured very early and at a very small size, reducing their ability to support a growing gonad in high winter temperatures. During the spawning period, condition dropped to very low levels accompanied by increased mortality. Surviving fish delayed the next spawning by one or more years and reduced their fecundity. Body condition thus improved in large perch at the end of the study period. Life-time fecundity was reduced, and reproductive performance shifted to younger ages.\m\C 1995 The Fisheries Society of the British Isles. © 1995 The Fisheries Society of the British Isles.
Author Keywords: life history; mortality; reproduction strategy; sexual maturation; temperature
Index Keywords: fecundity; life history; mortality; perch; recruitment; temperature; thermal pollution; adult; Baltic Sea; electric power plant; fertility; fish; gonad development; life expectancy; life history; maturity; mortality; nuclear energy; nuclear power plant; perch; plant; population; population structure; seashore; spawning; storage; temperature; thermal pollution; Perca fluviatilis

Authors: Konings W.N., Lolkema J.S., Poolman B.
Title: The generation of metabolic energy by solute transport
Affiliations: Department of Microbiology, Groningen Biomolecular Sciences and Biotechnology Institute, University of Groningen, Biology Centre, Kerklaan 30, Haren, 9751 NN, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Konings, W.N., Department of Microbiology, Groningen Biomolecular Sciences and Biotechnology Institute, University of Groningen, Biology Centre, Kerklaan 30, Haren, 9751 NN, Netherlands; Lolkema, J.S., Department of Microbiology, Groningen Biomolecular Sciences and Biotechnology Institute, University of Groningen, Biology Centre, Kerklaan 30, Haren, 9751 NN, Netherlands; Poolman, B., Department of Microbiology, Groningen Biomolecular Sciences and Biotechnology Institute, University of Groningen, Biology Centre, Kerklaan 30, Haren, 9751 NN, Netherlands
Abstract: Secondary metabolic-energy-generating systems generate a proton motive force (pmf) or a sodium ion motive force (smf) by a process that involves the action of secondary transporters. The (electro)chemical gradient of the solute(s) is converted into the electrochemical gradient of protons or sodium ions. The most straightforward systems are the excretion systems by which a metabolic end product is excreted out of the cell in symport with protons or sodium ions (energy recycling). Similarly, solutes that were accumulated and stored in the cell under conditions of abundant energy supply may be excreted again in symport with protons when conditions become worse (energy storage). In fermentative bacteria, a proton motive force is generated by fermentation of weak acids, such as malate and citrate. The two components of the pmf, the membrane potential and the pH gradient, are generated in separate steps. The weak acid is taken up by a secondary transporter either in exchange with a fermentation product (precursor/product exchange) or by a uniporter mechanism. In both cases, net negative charge is translocated into the cell, thereby generating a membrane potential. Decarboxylation reactions in the metabolic breakdown of the weak acid consume cytoplasmic protons, thereby generating a pH gradient across the membrane. In this review, several examples of these different types of secondary metabolic energy generation will be discussed. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Decarboxylases; End-product efflux; Malolactic fermentation; Metabolic energy; Precursor/product exchange; Proton motive force; Secondary transport
Index Keywords: carboxylyase; lactic acid; proton; energy metabolism; energy transfer; fermentation; nonhuman; ph; priority journal; review

Authors: Opfermann J., Hädrich W.
Title: Prediction of the thermal response of hazardous materials during storage using an improved technique
Affiliations: Netzsch-Gerätebau GmbH, D-95100 Selb, Germany; Sandoz Technologie AG, CH-4002 Basel, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Opfermann, J., Netzsch-Gerätebau GmbH, D-95100 Selb, Germany; Hädrich, W., Sandoz Technologie AG, CH-4002 Basel, Switzerland
Abstract: In order to achieve predictions with a high degree of confidence concerning the thermal behaviour of high-energy materials, the heat-generating process in the inhomogenous thermal conduction equation is described by a one- to four-step reaction process. Deconvolution and kinetic analysis, using multivariate non-linear regression of DSC measurements together provide the basis for relevant kinetic parameters to describe the thermal behaviour of Zoalen above the melting temperature. It is shown that only when one has a combination of DSC measurements and measurements with highly-sensitive micro calorimeters, can predictions with a high degree of confidence be achieved over the entire temperature range. © 1995.
Author Keywords: DSC; Microcalorimetry; Multiple step decomposition kinetics; Simulation

Authors: Quaresima C., Ottaviani C., Matteucci M., Crotti C., Antonini A., Capozi M., Rinaldi S., Luce M., Perfetti P., Prince K.C., Astaldi C., Zacchigna M., Romanzin L., Savoia A.
Title: First results from the high energy resolution photoemission beam line at ELETTRA
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Istituto di Struttura della Materia CNR, Via E. Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy; Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Padriciano 99, Trieste, Italy
