Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy; Antonini, A., Istituto di Struttura della Materia CNR, Via E. Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy; Capozi, M., Istituto di Struttura della Materia CNR, Via E. Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy; Rinaldi, S., Istituto di Struttura della Materia CNR, Via E. Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy; Luce, M., Istituto di Struttura della Materia CNR, Via E. Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy; Perfetti, P., Istituto di Struttura della Materia CNR, Via E. Fermi 38, 00044 Frascati, Italy; Prince, K.C., Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Padriciano 99, Trieste, Italy; Astaldi, C., Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Padriciano 99, Trieste, Italy; Zacchigna, M., Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Padriciano 99, Trieste, Italy; Romanzin, L., Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Padriciano 99, Trieste, Italy; Savoia, A., Sincrotrone Trieste S.C.p.A., Padriciano 99, Trieste, Italy
Abstract: We report the first results obtained from the high energy resolution beam line at the storage ring ELETTRA of Trieste. The beam line has been designed to perform photoemission experiments in the vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) and soft X-ray (SXR) energy range. The radiation source is an undulator which consists of three sections, with 36 periods and a period length of 12.5 cm. It allows scanning of an energy range 17-900 eV using the 1st, 3rd and 5th harmonics. The monochromator is a spherical grating type and the resolving power at 400 eV, estimated from the K-shell photoabsorption of the N2 molecule is well above 10 000. The spectra are better than any other spectra taken while operating with high flux, i.e. first order diffraction and grating not masked. Measurements taken at the oxygen and neon K-edges, the argon L23 edges and of the helium double ionization spectra, indicate that the resolution is excellent from 65 to 870 eV. © 1995.

Authors: Iucci G., Xing K., Lögdlund M., Fahlman M., Salaneck W.R.
Title: Polaron to bipolaron transition in a conjugated polymer. Rubidium-doped poly(p-phenylenevinylene)
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Linköping University, S-581 83 Linköping, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Iucci, G., Department of Physics, Linköping University, S-581 83 Linköping, Sweden; Xing, K., Department of Physics, Linköping University, S-581 83 Linköping, Sweden; Lögdlund, M., Department of Physics, Linköping University, S-581 83 Linköping, Sweden; Fahlman, M., Department of Physics, Linköping University, S-581 83 Linköping, Sweden; Salaneck, W.R., Department of Physics, Linköping University, S-581 83 Linköping, Sweden
Abstract: Photoelectron spectroscopy has been used to study the evolution of the electronic structure induced by n-type doping of two π-conjugated systems: poly(p-phenylenevinylene), or PPV, and trans,trans-1,4-distyrylbenzene, a model molecule for PPV. Doping was carried out in UHV by physical vapor deposition of rubidium atoms. In both systems, two different doping regimes are observed. At low doping levels, for both materials, one new electronic state appears in the originally forbidden energy gap, and a finite density of states is observed at the Fermi level. Upon increased doping, the observed state moves to lower binding energy and a second state appears within the original energy gap. The evolution of the gap states, together with the appearance of a finite density of states at Fermi level at low doping levels, indicates a transition from polaron to bipolaron charge storage states in these conjugated systems. It should be stressed that these results constitute the first direct measurements of a polaron to bipolaron transition in a conjugated polymer using ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy. © 1995.

Authors: Crivellari L., Simonneau E.
Title: Iteration profiles in radiative transfer problems. I. From vectorial to scalar coupling
Affiliations: Osservatorio Astronomico di Trieste; Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, Via Lactea s/n, E-38200 La Laguna, Tenerife, Spain; Institut d' Astrophysique, CNRS, 98 bis, Boulevard Arago, F-75014 Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Crivellari, L., Osservatorio Astronomico di Trieste, Instituto de Astrofisica de Canarias, Via Lactea s/n, E-38200 La Laguna, Tenerife, Spain; Simonneau, E., Institut d' Astrophysique, CNRS, 98 bis, Boulevard Arago, F-75014 Paris, France
Abstract: We have recently introduced a new algorithm, the implicit integral method (IIM), for solving radiative transfer problems in which the specific source functions (for each frequency and direction) depend linearly on the radiation field via a single quantity which is independent of both frequency and direction. We define this kind of relationship as scalar coupling. The fact that our method turned out to be fast, robust, and highly reliable leads us to seek its extension to include those problems where the above, necessary condition is not fulfilled. In these problems, the specific source functions depend on the radiation field through a nonfactorable redistribution operator. In our definition, these are cases of vectorial coupling. In this paper we present the successful application of the IIM, through an iterative procedure, to two specific instances of vectorial coupling. The first is the determination of the temperature distribution, self-consistent with the energy conservation constraint, within a LTE stellar atmosphere model. Here the physical processes other than radiative transfer require an iterative procedure for the global solution of the problem. Thus we take advantage of this circumstance to solve iteratively the radiative transfer part as well. The second is the case of the non-LTE two-level-atom line formation problem in which partial redistribution is taken into account in the presence of a background continuum. This problem allows a direct solution, but at the cost of using algorithms that necessarily require the storage and inversion of very high order matrices. On the contrary, we show that a solution based on the iterative application of the IIM, thanks to the outstanding features of the latter, is not only fast, but above all much more reliable in numerical terms.
Author Keywords: Line: formation; Methods: numerical; Radiative transfer; Stars: atmospheres

Authors: Ehlermann D.A.E., Khan H.M.
Title: Analysis of fading characteristics of quartz sand as a dosimeter and in irradiation identification applications
Affiliations: Institute of Food Engineering, Federal Research Centre for Nutrition, Engesserstr. 20, D-76131 Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ehlermann, D.A.E., Institute of Food Engineering, Federal Research Centre for Nutrition, Engesserstr. 20, D-76131 Karlsruhe, Germany; Khan, H.M., Institute of Food Engineering, Federal Research Centre for Nutrition, Engesserstr. 20, D-76131 Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: Fading characteristics of the thermoluminescent (TL) signal from laboratory fine quartz sand was studied in the temperature range from ambient to 150 °C. Glow curves were unfolded by an iterative, non-linear regression of superimposed Gaussian distributions. The activation energy for the fading of the first peak was estimated at 6 kJ/mol; the temperature range studied was not sufficient to estimate activation energies of the other two peaks. These peaks appearing at higher glow-curve temperatures are relatively stable during prior storage at room temperature (for several weeks) and are suitable for dosimetric purposes as well as for certain identification applications. © 1995 Elsevier Science Ltd.
Author Keywords: dosimetry; Fading; identification; quartz sand; thermoluminescent dosimetry
Index Keywords: silicon dioxide; conference paper; dosimetry; thermoluminescence dosimetry

Authors: Zhao F., Zeng X.
Title: An energy based macro-element method via a coupled finite element and boundary integral formulation
Affiliations: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Florida International University, Miami, FL 33199, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, F., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Florida International University, Miami, FL 33199, United States; Zeng, X., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Florida International University, Miami, FL 33199, United States
Abstract: An energy-based, systematic method for the coupling of the finite element (FE) method and the boundary integral equation (BIE) method is described in this paper. This method allows the use of the BIE method to represent those subdomains of a structure that are best suited to BIE method, and the use of the FE method to represent the rest of the structure. Different subdomains and their associated FE or BIE representations are coupled naturally through the total potential energy functional of the system. The associated discretized problem from the proposed method consists of a linear system of equations with a symmetric and blockwise banded matrix. As in regular FE methods, the derivation is started from the total potential energy principle. However, in those subdomains that are best suited to the BIE method, the exact solution of the associated free field equation is used to represent the true solution. The size and shape of each BIE subdomain, called "macro-element" in this paper, may be designed freely to meet various practical requirements concerning, for example, numerical efficiency, machine storage limitations, mesh generations, etc. Most significantly, unlike the existing BIE techniques, the present method does not seem to require special treatments for corner effects, thus reducing the computational complexity. Numerical experiments have been performed for generalized Poisson's equation as a prototype situation. The extension to 2D-3D elastic problems is straightforward. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Boundary element method; Computational complexity; Elasticity; Finite element method; Integral equations; Matrix algebra; Structures (built objects); Boundary integral equation; Energy based macro element method; Poissons equation; Variational techniques

Authors: Rodrigues-Mendoza U.R., Rodrigues V.D., Lavin V., Martin I.R., Nunez P.
Title: Optical spectroscopy of Cr3+ and Cr3+-Tm3+ in alkaline silicate glasses
Affiliations: Dpto. de Fisica Fundamental y Experimental, Universidad de La Laguna, La Laguna, Tenerife, 38206, Spain; Dpto. Quimica Inorganica, Universidad de La Laguna, La Laguna, Tenerife, 38206, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Rodrigues-Mendoza, U.R., Dpto. de Fisica Fundamental y Experimental, Universidad de La Laguna, La Laguna, Tenerife, 38206, Spain; Rodrigues, V.D., Dpto. de Fisica Fundamental y Experimental, Universidad de La Laguna, La Laguna, Tenerife, 38206, Spain; Lavin, V., Dpto. de Fisica Fundamental y Experimental, Universidad de La Laguna, La Laguna, Tenerife, 38206, Spain; Martin, I.R., Dpto. de Fisica Fundamental y Experimental, Universidad de La Laguna, La Laguna, Tenerife, 38206, Spain; Nunez, P., Dpto. Quimica Inorganica, Universidad de La Laguna, La Laguna, Tenerife, 38206, Spain
Abstract: Alkaline silicate glasses seem to be good candidates as host materials for codoping with Cr3+ and Tm3+. Cr3+ ions occupy mainly low-field sites in them, and their broadband emission overlaps Tm3+ excitation. As a consequence very high efficiency for the energy transfer Cr3+→Tm3+ is achieved with moderate concentrations of these ions. Moreover, the average lifetime of the Cr3+ ions in codoped glasses is long enough to allow significant energy storage by flashlamp pumping. © 1996 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Akrabawi, M.D., Ph.D., VA Medical Center and Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX and Mead Johnson Research Center, Evansville, IN. USA
Abstract: In HIV-infected individuals, malnutrition and wasting are common complications, which may be associated with diminished functional and cognitive capacity. Although nutritional therapy has been advised in such patients, few data are available concerning the effects of this intervention. We performed a 6-week randomized clinical trial which compared dietary counselling alone (control) versus dietary counselling plus enteral supplement (Lipisorb) in 118 male HIV-infected outpatients. The inclusion criteria were: age ≥ 18 yr; CD4+ cell count <500/mm3; and <90% usual weight for height or loss of > 10% body weight in the previous 6 months. Each patient was instructed to consume a diet which contained 960 calories greater than estimated total energy expenditure. Nutritional outcomes were: skinfold measurements, fat free mass and total body water (Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis). Functional outcomes were: grip strength (Jamar dynamometer), cognitive function (Buschke Selective Reminding test) and Quality of Life (instrument designed for this study). Ninety-nine (99) men completed the study. No differences in skinfold measurements or Quality of Life parameters were observed between the treatment groups. Compared with the control group, the Lipisorb group experienced significantly fewer decreases in total body water (p =.04). Fat free mass (p =0.07) and grip strength (p = 0.07) were increased in the Lipisorb group, although the differences did not reach statistical significance. Significant improvements in short-term memory (p = 0.03) and long-term memory storage and retrieval (p = 0.05) were observed in the Lipisorb group. In malnourished HIV-infected outpatients, dietary counselling with enteral supplementation is associated with improved cognitive function. In addition, the effects of this intervention on nutritional parameters and muscle function are promising. © 1995 American Dietetic Association.

Authors: Breschi R., Fano V., Ortalli I.
Title: Convection in the bridgman growth of narrow-gap semiconductors
Affiliations: CRESAM, S. Piero a Grado, Italy; Istituto Scienze Fisiche, Università di Parma, Parma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Breschi, R., CRESAM, S. Piero a Grado, Italy; Fano, V., Istituto Scienze Fisiche, Università di Parma, Parma, Italy; Ortalli, I., Istituto Scienze Fisiche, Università di Parma, Parma, Italy
Abstract: The free convection in the melt during the crystal growth of small-gap semiconductors, and its influence on the electrical properties are discussed. Dimensionaless parameters of the fluid flow, electrical properties of PbTe, Pb1-x Snx Te and Hg1-x Cdx Te single crystals, grown by vertical Bridgman technique at very low velocity, and some structures, found in these materials, support the presence of free convection. © 1995 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Direct energy conversion and energy storage; PACS 85.60.Gz; Photodetectors and infrared detectors

Authors: POPKOV N.F., RYASLOV E.A., KARGIN V.I., PIKAR' A.S., KOTEL'NIKOV D.V., MELKOZEROV A.V.
Title: A 10-TW Pulsed Facility "PIRIT" for Investigation of Short-Wave Radiation Generation
Source title: Journal of X-Ray Science and Technology
Affiliations: All-Russia Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Nizhni Novgorod Region 607200, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: POPKOV, N.F., All-Russia Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Nizhni Novgorod Region 607200, Russian Federation; RYASLOV, E.A., All-Russia Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Nizhni Novgorod Region 607200, Russian Federation; KARGIN, V.I., All-Russia Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Nizhni Novgorod Region 607200, Russian Federation; PIKAR', A.S., All-Russia Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Nizhni Novgorod Region 607200, Russian Federation; KOTEL'NIKOV, D.V., All-Russia Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Nizhni Novgorod Region 607200, Russian Federation; MELKOZEROV, A.V., All-Russia Scientific Research Institute of Experimental Physics (VNIIEF), Arzamas-16, Nizhni Novgorod Region 607200, Russian Federation
Abstract: The results of experiments with a plasma x-ray source in the PIRIT-2000 facility are presented in this paper. The facility is designed with module capacitive energy storage energizing vacuum inductive storage. The formation of a rapidly growing current pulse as well as its commutation on a load was carried out by a plasma opening switch. A vacuum diode as well as various types of plasma loads can be used for the generation of a high-power x-ray flux. The storage energy of a 54-module capacitive storage is up to 2 MJ, its inductance is 15 nH, and its output voltage is 500 kV. The peak current in the plasma load constituted 4 MA with a 150-ns rise time. The maximum integral energy output of x radiation measured by an open thermocouple calorimeter was as high as 100 kJ, while the primary storage energy was 1 MJ. The plasma load usage at a current of 4 MA ensured a 100-kJ generation in x-ray radiation and the density of the radiation flux at a distance of 1 m from the source was as much as 0.8 J/cm2, while near the source it was 10 J/cm2. © 1995.

Authors: Lehtonen K.K.
Title: Geographical variability in the bioenergetic characteristics of Monoporeia/Pontoporeia spp. populations from the northern Baltic Sea, and their potential contribution to benthic nitrogen mineralization
Affiliations: Finnish Institute of Marine Research, P.O. Box 33, Helsinki, FIN-00931, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Lehtonen, K.K., Finnish Institute of Marine Research, P.O. Box 33, Helsinki, FIN-00931, Finland
Abstract: The physiological condition, determined as the ammonia excretion rate (V NH4+), total lipid level and lipid class composition, of two deposit-feeding benthic amphipods, Monoporeia (=Pontoporeia) affinis and Pontoporeia femorata, was studied from 12 opensea stations in the northern Baltic Sea between 24 May and 11 June 1993. The M. affinis populations can be geographically grouped according to their physiological condition: (1) eastern Gulf of Finland, with moderate lipid level (mean 24.4% of dry wt) and high V NH4+(45.2 μmol NH4+g-1 dry wt d-1); (2) Bothnian Sea, wigh high lipid level (34.5%) and low V NH4+(24.6 μmol NH4+g-1 dry wt d-1); and (3) Bothnian Bay, with low lipid level (15.2%) and high V NH4+(44.3 μmol NH4+dry wt d-1). A similar pattern could be observed also in the level of triacylglycerols and the neutral-to-polar lipid ratio. P. femorata, the dominating species in the western Gulf of Finland, showed variable "station-specific" excretion rates (22.3 to 43.0 μmol NH4+g-1 dry wt d-1) and lipid levels (23.4 to 30.4%). The spatial variability in the weight-specific V NH4+of M. affinis could not be explained by the differences in the size of individuals, lipid level or lipid class composition; this emphasizes the significance of the effects of spatially differing nutritional conditions, which manifest themselves as different modes of metabolic energy production and different intensities of energy storage. In addition, the potential contribution of the amphipod populations to benthic nitrogen mineralization was estimated; in May to June, the NH4+release of different populations ranged from 12 to 237 μmol NH4+m-2d-1. In general, populations with high abundance and/or biomass release the greatest amounts of NH4+, but the values are modified by the physiological condition of the individuals. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: bioenergetics; geographical variability; nitrogen; population characteristics; Baltic Sea; Monoporeia; Pontoporeia; Pontoporeia

Authors: Dunn Joseph, Ott Thomas, Clark Wayne
Title: Pulsed-light treatment of food and packaging
Affiliations: PurePulse Technologies, Inc, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dunn, Joseph, PurePulse Technologies, Inc, San Diego, United States; Ott, Thomas, PurePulse Technologies, Inc, San Diego, United States; Clark, Wayne, PurePulse Technologies, Inc, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Pulsed light is produced using engineering technology that multiply power many fold. Power is magnified by accumulating the electrical energy in an energy storage capacitor over relatively long times and releasing this stored energy to do work in much shorter times. The result is a very high power during the duty cycle, with expenditure of only modest average power consumption. For food and packaging applications, a new method uses the bacterial power of an intense pulsed light to extend the shelf life of foods and kill microorganisms on packaging materials. Baked goods, seafoods and meats, fruits and vegetables and many other foods show significant reductions in microbial burden, enhanced shelf life, added safety, and no change in nutritional properties after pulsed light treatment.
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Costs; Food preservation; Food products; Light absorption; Meats; Microorganisms; Packaging; Packaging materials; Ultraviolet radiation; Water treatment; Antimicrobial effects; Bactericidal powders; Baked goods; Carbon-to-carbon double-bond system; Pulsed-light treatment; Seafood; Shelf life; Food processing

Authors: McCloskey W.D.
Title: Ice storage puts cooling costs on ice
Affiliations: Baltimore Aircoil Co
Authors with affiliations: McCloskey, W.D., Baltimore Aircoil Co
Abstract: Ice-storage cooling systems in use worldwide, from Chicago to Osaka to Lyon, demonstrate savings in both capital and operating costs and space use. The technology holds promise as well in environmental protection and offers refrigerant choices that eliminate CFCs. Ice storage systems work by building and storing ice at 32°F on the surface of coiled evaporator tubes. The costs savings of cooling by ice storage are twofold, resulting both from reduced water requirements and from the potential for off-peak ice building. In the US, for instance, more and more institutions are reaping environmental rewards from ice storage, such as the Univ. of Miami, Montgomery College and USF&G among others. Ice-storage systems on these campuses use ammonia as refrigerant, eliminating CFCs.
Index Keywords: Chlorofluorocarbons; Cold storage; Condensers (liquefiers); Coolants; Cost effectiveness; Energy efficiency; Environmental protection; Evaporators; Heat transfer; Ice; Refrigerants; Technology; Cost savings; District cooling; Energy savings; Ice storage systems; Cooling systems

Authors: Nelson Bernard W.
Title: Turning the page on HVAC retrofit
Affiliations: Arnold & O'Sheridan Inc, Brookfield, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nelson, Bernard W., Arnold & O'Sheridan Inc, Brookfield, United States
Abstract: Milwaukee's Public Library undergoes an HVAC systems retrofit to cut utility bills and improve comfort and storage conditions. The retrofit, which will save an estimated $50,000 a year, is part of the energy-management plan developed in the early 1980s. Initially, savings were achieved by replacing magnetic ballasts with electronic ballasts and 40-watt lamps with 34-watt lamps. Over-illuminated areas were delamped. The building's energy-use indices were reduced to 63,200 Btu/square-foot/year, which translated into an annual utility cost of $303,200. The retrofit was divided into four phases, with 13 of 25 HVAC systems to be upgraded. Each HVAC system was tested for controllability and operating sequence. Total air volumes were trend logged at one-minute refresh interval to assess control-loop stability.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Controllability; Cooling; Digital control systems; Energy conservation; Energy efficiency; Energy management; Energy utilization; Heating; Retrofitting; Temperature control; Ventilation; Airflow probes; Cold-deck dampers; Energy monitoring; HVAC; Variable frequency drives; Libraries

Authors: Chu P.C.W.
Title: High-temperature superconductors
Affiliations: Univ of Houston, Houston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chu, P.C.W., Univ of Houston, Houston, United States
Abstract: Physicists have discovered more than 100 superconductors with critical temperatures that exceed those of the best conventional superconductors. The novel materials raised many questions, perhaps foremost among them: Can superconductors follow in the footsteps of their cousins, the semiconductors, and dramatically change our lives for the better? A qualified `yes' is not overly optimistic, because superconductors can touch every aspect of our existence that involves electricity. Superconducting trains, nearly perfect, large energy storage systems and ultrafast computers are not realistic goals at the moment, but plenty of other applications are, in principle, possible soon: efficient generation, transmission and storage of electricity; detection of electromagnetic signals too small to be sensed by conventional means; protection of electrical grids from power surges, sags and outages; and the development of faster and more compact cellular communications technology. This paper discusses the fundamentals, materials, prototype products and applications - present and future.
Index Keywords: Magnetic resonance imaging; SQUIDS; Superconducting devices; Superconducting wire; Superconductivity; Industrial applications; Yttrium barium copper oxide; High temperature superconductors

Authors: Dvornikov A.S., Rentzepis P.M.
Title: Accessing 3D memory information by means of nonlinear absorption
Affiliations: University of California Irvine, Chemistry Department, Irvine, CA 92717, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dvornikov, A.S., University of California Irvine, Chemistry Department, Irvine, CA 92717, United States; Rentzepis, P.M., University of California Irvine, Chemistry Department, Irvine, CA 92717, United States
Abstract: A novel method for accessing information from two-photon 3D volume memory devices is presented. We have used the decrease in laser intensity induced by two-photon absorption as the means for reading 3D information. The ratio of the initial laser intensity to the intensity after two-photon absorption is increased drastically by passing both beams through a second and fourth harmonic crystal. This means eliminates the need for focusing and collecting lenses and the disadvantages associated with the fluorescence method of reading information. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Electron energy levels; Energy gap; Fluorescence; Focusing; Lasers; Lenses; Light absorption; Molecules; Optical data storage; Photons; Three dimensional; Electronic state; Ground state; Harmonic crystals; Laser intensity; Metastable state; Optical transitions; Transition probability; Nonlinear optics

Authors: Hoagland W.
Title: Solar energy
Affiliations: W. Hoagland & Assoc, Boulder, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoagland, W., W. Hoagland & Assoc, Boulder, United States
Abstract: Every year the earth's surface receives about 10 times as much energy from sunlight as is contained in all the known reserves of coal, oil, natural gas and uranium combined. This energy equals 15,000 times the world's annual consumption by humans. People have been burning wood and other forms of biomass for thousands of years, and that is one way of tapping solar energy. But the sun also provides hydropower, wind power and fossil fuels - in fact, all forms of energy other than nuclear, geothermal and tidal. Technology will allow radiation from the sun to provide nonpolluting and cheap fuels, as well as electricity. It is unlikely that a single solar technology will predominate. Regional variations in economics and the availability of sunlight will naturally favor some approaches over others. Electricity may be generated by burning biomass, erecting wind turbines, building solar-powered heat engines, laying out photovoltaic cells or harnessing the energy in rivers with dams. Hydrogen fuel can be produced by electrochemical cells of biological processes-involving microorganisms or enzymes-that are driven by sunlight. Fuels such as ethanol and methanol may be generated from biomass or other solar technologies. At present, developed nations consume at least 10 times the energy per person than is used in developing countries. But the demand for energy is rising fast everywhere. Solar technologies could enable the developing world to skip a generation of infrastructure and move directly to a source of energy that does not contribute to global warming or otherwise degrade the environment. Developed countries could also benefit by exporting these technologies-if additional incentives are at all necessary for investing in the future of energy from the sun.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Energy storage; Fuels; Heat engines; Hydrogen; Solar cells; Wind power; Cheap fuels; Energy crops; Solar energy

Authors: Pfeilmaier Peter
Title: Aluminum electrolytic capacitors for DC/DC converters: the right choice saves volume and weight
Affiliations: Siemens Matsushita Components, Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Pfeilmaier, Peter, Siemens Matsushita Components, Munich, Germany
Abstract: Converters use entire banks of capacitors connected in series and parallel in their circuits. Capacitors limits the static converter voltage during line surges, smooth the link circuit voltage, protect the line from reactive commutation, store energy and provided pulse current. Choosing the right capacitor's has a major impact on the size and weight of DC/DC converter. Siemens Matsushita Components offers a wide-range of high-performance aluminum electrolytic capacitors for power applications.

Abstract: A simple method of estimation of equivalent series resistance (ESR) of energy storage capacitors from their transient response is proposed. Actual estimation of ESR of an energy storage capacitor carried out by this method indicates that it is not as accurate as the standard methods, but can obtain a reasonable estimate of ESR to help designers of capacitor discharge systems.

Abstract: The beam transport system for the HIMAC (Heavy-Ion Medical Accelerator in Chiba) facility is described which routes energy from the two synchrotron rings to individual radiation therapy rooms. Authors: Cavanaugh H.A.
Title: Aeroderivative flywheels target spikes and sags
Authors with affiliations: Cavanaugh, H.A.
Abstract: Dow-UT is developing the flywheel rotors in conjunction with several firms that specialize in making sophisticated motors and generators, including United Technolohies Automotive Inc (UTA), Detroit Mich. In one project, Dow-UT is supplying rotors for an advanced flywheel jointly under development by a unit of the Southern Company and UTA. Southern Development and Investment Group and UTA are creating flywheels to eventually provide electrical customers with uninterruptible power for sensitive electronic equipment, as well as the storage of low-cost electricity at night for next-day use. Flywheel rotors made from the high-strength graphite and glass composites that Dow is offering - similar to those used in aircraft wings and golf-club shafts - store energy much more efficiently than traditional metal rotors.

Authors: Douglis F., Krishnan P.
Title: Adaptive disk spin-down policies for mobile computers
Affiliations: Brian Bershad Univ of Washington, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Douglis, F., Brian Bershad Univ of Washington, Washington, United States; Krishnan, P., Brian Bershad Univ of Washington, Washington, United States
Abstract: Mobile computers typically spin down their hard disk after a fixed period of inactivity. If this threshold is too long, the disk wastes energy; if it is too short, the delay due to spinning the disk up again frustrates the user. Usage patterns change over time, so a single fixed threshold may not be appropriate at all times. Also, different users may have varying priorities with respect to trading off energy conservation against performance. We describe a method for varying the spin-down threshold dynamically by adapting to the user's access patterns and priorities. Adaptive spin-down can in some circumstances reduce by up to 50% the number of disk spin-ups that are deemed by the user to be inconvenient, while only moderately increasing energy consumption.
Index Keywords: Adaptive systems; Computer hardware; Computers; Hard disk storage; Disk spin-down; Mobile computers; Computer systems

Authors: Singer E., Ishai G., Kimmel E.
Title: Parameter estimation for a prosthetic ankle
Affiliations: Department of Biomedical Engineering, Technion, Haifa, Israel; Department of Agricultural Engineering, Technion IIT, Haifa, 32000, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Singer, E., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Technion, Haifa, Israel; Ishai, G., Department of Biomedical Engineering, Technion, Haifa, Israel; Kimmel, E., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Technion IIT, Haifa, 32000, Israel
Abstract: The mechanical parameters of a model of an energy storage and return ankle prosthesis are estimated for normal level walking by means of an optimization procedure. The walking cycle is divided into six fields, such that the power does not change sign within each field; the transition between successive fields occurs at zero power. The optimal spring stiffness as a function of time, is found by optimizing a quadratic cost function to minimize the difference between the estimated ankle moments and the moments in normal walking. The optimization is subjected to four continuous constraints within each field and to two continuity constraints for the transitions between successive fields. The time-varying spring stiffness and the implications of additional external energy are discussed and are presented as recommendations for the designer. © 1995 Biomedical Engineering Society.
Author Keywords: Ankle prosthesis; Normal walking; Optimization

Authors: Devres Y.O., Bishop C.F.H.
Title: The effect of potato store operation on energy usage and weight loss
Affiliations: Faculty of Chemistry and Metallurgy, Department of Food Engineering, Istanbul Technical University, Maslak-Istanbul, 80626, Turkey; Writtle College, Chelmsford, Essex, CM1 3RR, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Devres, Y.O., Faculty of Chemistry and Metallurgy, Department of Food Engineering, Istanbul Technical University, Maslak-Istanbul, 80626, Turkey; Bishop, C.F.H., Writtle College, Chelmsford, Essex, CM1 3RR, United Kingdom
Abstract: The effect of various storage parameters on the power usage and tuber weight loss for a fully refrigerated potato store were investigated. A computer model validated by detailed monitoring of potato stores was used for the calculations. The store parameters considered were: storage temperature, store relative humidity, local ambient conditions, store capacity or loading factor, half cooling time and the infiltration rate or air tightness of the store. The investigation showed that the power consumption was most affected by the storage temperature and the infiltration rate of the store, and that weight loss was most affected by the half cooling time. © 1995 Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Authors: Kuncoro Heru, Rao Yan Fei, Fukuda Kenji
Title: Experimental study on the geysering mechanism in a closed two-phase thermosyphon
Source title: Memoirs of the Kyushu University, Faculty of Engineering
Affiliations: Kyushu Univ, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kuncoro, Heru, Kyushu Univ, Japan; Rao, Yan Fei, Kyushu Univ, Japan; Fukuda, Kenji, Kyushu Univ, Japan
Abstract: An experimental study is carried out to investigate the mechanism of periodical boiling or geysering in a single-tube, closed two-phase thermosyphon made of glass to make visual observation possible. The filling percentage is 100% of the evaporator volume, and the working fluids are R113 and water. The system pressure fluctuation and the transient temperature profile along the thermosyphon are measured. The experiment with water reveals a pattern of geysering initiation that is different from the experiment with R-113. It is found from the water experiment that besides the physical properties of the working fluids and wall surface conditions, the temperature distribution or the internal-energy storage pattern may initiate a geyser, as long as the temperature distribution supports simultaneous boiling. In the case of R113 experiment, on the other hand, superheat is the driving force of a geyser. Contrary to the claim by previous studies, it is found that although during bubble expansion the evaporator pressure may increase, geysering may still occur.

Authors: Churchill T.A., Green C.J., Davidson B.R., Fuller B.J.
Title: An underlying mechanism for improved liver preservation with a combined histidine-lactobionate-raffinose flush solution
Affiliations: University Department of Surgery, Royal Free Hospital and School of Medicine, London, NW3 2QG, United Kingdom; Department of Surgical Research, Northwick Park Institute for Medical Research, Harrow, Middlesex, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Churchill, T.A., University Department of Surgery, Royal Free Hospital and School of Medicine, London, NW3 2QG, United Kingdom; Green, C.J., Department of Surgical Research, Northwick Park Institute for Medical Research, Harrow, Middlesex, United Kingdom; Davidson, B.R., University Department of Surgery, Royal Free Hospital and School of Medicine, London, NW3 2QG, United Kingdom; Fuller, B.J., University Department of Surgery, Royal Free Hospital and School of Medicine, London, NW3 2QG, United Kingdom
Abstract: In previous experimental liver transplant studies, it was possible to extend cold ischaemic time (CIT) by using a flush/storage solution combining histidine, lactobionate and raffinose (HLR). In this study, energy metabolism, glycolytic substrate (glucose) and anaerobic end-product (lactate) were examined in rat liver over 24 h of cold storage to determine the mechanism of action of the HLR solution. In livers subjected to simple flush and storage with the HLR solution. levels of ATP and ADP were considerably higher than livers stored with modified UW throughout 24 h of storage; at 4 h of storage, ATP and ADP levels were 1.1 and 3.1 μmol/g for HLR solution versus 0.18 and 0.81 μmol/g for UW solution. Total adenylate contents (TA=ATP+ADP+AMP) also remained 1-2 μmol/g higher in HLR-treated livers than those preserved in UW; TA values ranged from 3.8 to 5.7 μmol/g. Glucose increased to 20-35 μmol/g by 10-24 h of storage (similar to the UW group). Lactate rose to almost twice that in livers stored in UW; total lactate accumulation was approximately 10.0 μmol/g. This study demonstrated that the combined HLR solution is able to prolong the maximum 'safe' CIT by increasing anaerobic metabolism and consequently preserving liver energetics. The second part of the experiment examined the effect of continuous perfusion (with/without O2) over the 1st h of cold ischaemia. Under current methods of liver flushing and excision, the 1st h of cold storage may be the critical time of metabolic 'adjustment' since most of the pH and ATP changes occur during this period. Therefore, we tested the hypothesis that the combination of a simple flush with an additional brief 1-h perfusion period prior to storage would enhance the maintenance of hepatic energetics. There was no beneficial effect of 1 h of perfusion without O2 compared to simple HLR flush and storage. However, perfusion with O2 resulted in prolonged maintenance of high energy adenylates and total adenylates; at 10 h of storage ATP was 1.0, ADP 3.3, and TA 5.7 μmol/g. However, any improvement in ultimate viability following long-term storage of the livers in these two groups needs to be tested in an animal transplant model. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Turner A.S., Norrdin R.W., Gaarde S., Connally H.E., Thrall M.A.
Title: Bone mineral density in feline mucopolysaccharidosis VI measured using dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry
Affiliations: Department of Clinical Sciences, Colorado State University, Ft. Collins, 80523, Colorado, United States; Department of Pathology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, 80523, Colorado, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turner, A.S., Department of Clinical Sciences, Colorado State University, Ft. Collins, 80523, Colorado, United States; Norrdin, R.W., Department of Pathology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, 80523, Colorado, United States; Gaarde, S., Department of Pathology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, 80523, Colorado, United States; Connally, H.E., Department of Pathology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, 80523, Colorado, United States; Thrall, M.A., Department of Pathology, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, 80523, Colorado, United States
Abstract: Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) was used to determine the in vivo bone mineral density (BMD) and bone mineral content (BMC) of lumbar vertebrae in six cats affected with the inherited lysosomal storage disease mucopolysaccharidosis VI (MPS VI). DXA was also performed on MPS cats that had a bone marrow transplant (BMT) and total body irradiation (TBI) (MPS+BMT;n=7), normal cats that had a bone marrow transplant, and TBI (control+BMT; n=8) and normal cats (control; n=14). Following euthanasia, one of the lumbar vertebrae that had been scanned (L5) was harvested and bone volume (BV/TV%) was determined by histomorphometry. The in vivo BMD and BMD measurements were compared with the BV/TV%. There was a greater BMD and BMC in the MPS+BMT cats compared with the MPS cats but the difference was not statistically significant. However, there was a greater BV/TV% in the MPS+BMT cats compared with the MPS cats and the difference was significant (P=0.0152). Correlation between the noninvasive in vivo DXA measurements of BMD and BMC and the BV/TV% was significant (r2=0.767, P<0.0001; r2=0.504, P<0.0001). Noninvasive in vivo DXA was a rapid and precise method for measuring the lumbar BMD and BMC in cats and it correlated well with histomorphometric determination of bone mass. Further, the response of inherited storage diseases such as MPS VI to therapy, such as BMT, could be monitored in a longitudinal fashion using DXA. © 1995 Springer-Verlag New York Inc.
Author Keywords: Bone marrow transplantation; Cats; Dual energy X-Ray absorptiometry; Histomorphometry; Lumbar vertebrae; Mucopolysaccharidosis VI

Authors: Pollock C., Miti E.K.
Title: Isolated step up/down three-phase AC to DC power supply
Affiliations: Department of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4 7AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Pollock, C., Department of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4 7AL, United Kingdom; Miti, E.K., Department of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4 7AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: A new circuit for providing an isolated DC supply from a three-phase AC source is described. The circuit uses a very simple control scheme to ensure that the current drawn from the AC source is sinusoidal. Unlike previous circuits, the isolation is provided by integration of a second stage converter into the circuit such that pulses of energy are transferred from the input stage to a unique parallel resonant circuit which automatically transfers the energy to the load without any intermediate energy storage. The operation of the circuit is described and some experimental results are given. © 1995, IEE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Sadamori H., Tanaka N., Yagi T., Inagaki M., Orita K.
Title: The effects of nutritional repletion on donors for liver transplantation in pigs
Affiliations: First Department of Surgery, Okayama University Medical School, Okayama, 700, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sadamori, H., First Department of Surgery, Okayama University Medical School, Okayama, 700, Japan; Tanaka, N., First Department of Surgery, Okayama University Medical School, Okayama, 700, Japan; Yagi, T., First Department of Surgery, Okayama University Medical School, Okayama, 700, Japan; Inagaki, M., First Department of Surgery, Okayama University Medical School, Okayama, 700, Japan; Orita, K., First Department of Surgery, Okayama University Medical School, Okayama, 700, Japan
Abstract: It has been shown that the nutritional state of the donor may affect the outcome of liver transplantation. However, many donors staying in the intensive care unit for a long period are in a reduced nutritional state. In this study, we investigated the effects of various methods of nutritional repletion on the outcome of liver transplantation in pigs. Donor pigs were divided into three groups according to the nutritional pretreatment given for 7 days before harvesting: group I were fasted and received intravenous administration of saline; group II were fed orally; group III were fasted, but given 20% glucose intravenously. Donor livers were stored for 4 hr in cold Euro-Collins’ solution and transplanted. The serum AST level 24 hr after reperfusion remained at a lower level in group III compared with those in groups I and II. Bile production of the liver after transplantation was also well recovered in group III. The glycogen content of the liver at harvesting, which was completely consumed in group 1, was well preserved in groups II and III. These storages in both groups were rapidly consumed 1 hr after reperfusion. On the other hand, ATP content of the liver in groups I, II, and III, which were at a similar level at harvesting, were markedly decreased 4 hr after cold preservation and, 1 hr after reperfusion, recovered to 26%, 48%, and 73% of that before preservation, respectively. The mean survival time in group III was 37.2 days, significantly longer than 5.8±0.7 and 9.8±2.0 days in groups I and II, respectively (P<0.01). These results show that the favorable outcome of liver transplantation depends on the glycogen storage in the donor liver, and also on ATP generation after reperfusion. Furthermore, it was suggested that ATP generation was affected by some unknown factor related to the method of nutritional repletion. © 1995 by Williams and Wilkins.

Abstract: A compact Transversely Excited Atmospheric Nitrogen (TEA) Laser is described. A modified arrangement of an energy storage element in Blumlein excitation circuit decreased significantly the dimensions of the laser. By the use of a small low - inductance sparkgap, an efficiency of energy transfer has achieved value of more then 0.35%. With such a high efficiency the laser may operate at comparatively low charging voltage range of 3kV to 6.5kV, producing pulsed coherent radiation with peak output power of up to 300kW. A low charging voltage has been chosen to avoid electrical breakdown in the air in tropical climate. © 1995 SPIE. All rights reserved.

Title: Fundamental metabolic difference between cold stored lungs and livers and kidneys
Affiliations: Dept. of Visceral/Transplant Surgery, Universitat Bern, Inselspital, CH-3010 Bern, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Schilling, M., Dept. of Visceral/Transplant Surgery, Universitat Bern, Inselspital, CH-3010 Bern, Switzerland; Tilton, B., Dept. of Visceral/Transplant Surgery, Universitat Bern, Inselspital, CH-3010 Bern, Switzerland; Beltzer, F.O., Dept. of Visceral/Transplant Surgery, Universitat Bern, Inselspital, CH-3010 Bern, Switzerland; Southard, J.H., Dept. of Visceral/Transplant Surgery, Universitat Bern, Inselspital, CH-3010 Bern, Switzerland
Abstract: Short preservation times for lungs, are the main obstacle to exchange and increase the number of lung transplantations. In abdominal organ preservation UW solution has extended preservation times by including impermeable anions, adenosine and scavengers to prevent parenchymal cell swelling, to improve ATP regeneration and to inhibit reactive oxygen radicals. Metabolic changes in rabbit lungs, cold stored in UW-solution were compared with changes in rabbit livers and kidneys. Rabbit lungs swell during rewarming after a short storage period as opposed to livers and kidneys. They furthermore accumulate significantly more potassium while maintaining high ATP concentration throughout storage and reperfusion.

Authors: Le Brun N.E., Moore G.R., Thomson A.J.
Title: Magnetic circular dichroism spectroscopy of the iron cores of ferritin and bacterioferritin
Affiliations: Centre for Metalloprotein Spectroscopy and Biology, School of Chemical Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, NR4 7TJ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Le Brun, N.E., Centre for Metalloprotein Spectroscopy and Biology, School of Chemical Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, NR4 7TJ, United Kingdom; Moore, G.R., Centre for Metalloprotein Spectroscopy and Biology, School of Chemical Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, NR4 7TJ, United Kingdom; Thomson, A.J., Centre for Metalloprotein Spectroscopy and Biology, School of Chemical Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, NR4 7TJ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Ferritin and bacterioferritin (BFR) are iron-storage proteins that contain mineralized non-haem iron cores which have a maximum diameter of 80 A. The relationships between the magnetic properties and chemical characteristics of these cores are not fully understood, and to help define these we have used magnetic circular dichroism (MCD) spectroscopy in study of these molecules. The MCD spectra reported here are the first examples where this technique has been applied to a study of both the ferritin and the BFR core. It is clear that the two core types have different spectral characteristics in accord with their different chemical composition. At low temperature (<4K) the ferritin core displays a form of magnetic hysteresis which is not observed when the temperature is raised to 77 K. In contrast, the BFR core does not give rise to such an effect even at very low temperature. The data appear to indicate that the ferritin core is highly anisotropic at low temperature whereas the BFR core is not, and that spin relaxation between the ground state energy levels of the ferritin core is exceedingly slow. © 1995 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Abstract: In this paper, we will describe the basic mechanisms and dynamics of photorefractivity, and holographic grating formations in dye- and fullerene C60-doped nematic liquid crystal films. The effects are attributed to photo induced molecular axis reorientation in these nematic films. A nonlinear index coefficient n2 of 10-2 cm2/Watt can be obtained in a 25μm thick film, with an applied dc-voltage of -1 volt. In Fullerene C60-doped films, these laser induced gratings can be made permanent and electronically modulated; they can be turned off and on by an ac voltage with response times of ∼ 100 μs and a few ms, respectively. © 1995 SPIE. Authors: Miyahara Y.
Title: Jump-over method of the FEL interaction among electron beam bunches for increasing the radiation power
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: SPring-8, Kamigori, Ako-gun, Hyogo, 678-12, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyahara, Y., SPring-8, Kamigori, Ako-gun, Hyogo, 678-12, Japan
Abstract: A new method to substantially increase the FEL radiation power in an electron storage ring is presented. In this method, the storage ring is operated with many bunches, and the FEL interaction of a light pulse with the beam bunches is jumped over for several bunches by modulating the closed orbit distortion of the stored beam in synchronism with the FEL interaction. The interaction interval for each bunch is lengthened considerably, and the radiation damping proceeds for a longer time. The energy spread is much reduced and the radiation power can be increased more than a factor of 10. © 1995.

Authors: Saldin E.L., Sarantsev V.P., Schneidmiller E.A., Shimanskii S.S., Ulyanov Yu.N., Yurkov M.V.
Title: On a possibility of constructing a high-intensity, monochromatic, polarized gamma source at PETRA
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, 141980 Moscow Region, Russian Federation; Automatic Systems Corporation, 443050 Samara, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Saldin, E.L., Automatic Systems Corporation, 443050 Samara, Russian Federation; Sarantsev, V.P., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, 141980 Moscow Region, Russian Federation; Schneidmiller, E.A., Automatic Systems Corporation, 443050 Samara, Russian Federation; Shimanskii, S.S., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, 141980 Moscow Region, Russian Federation; Ulyanov, Yu.N., Automatic Systems Corporation, 443050 Samara, Russian Federation; Yurkov, M.V., Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, Dubna, 141980 Moscow Region, Russian Federation
Abstract: A possibility of constructing a high-intensity, tunable, monochromatic, polarized γ-source at the PETRA storage ring is discussed. It is proposed to produce γ-quanta by means of Compton backscattering of laser photons on the electrons. The laser light wavelength is chosen in such a way that after the scattering the electron does not leave the separatrix. Since the probability of the scattering is rather small, energy oscillations are damped prior to the next scattering. As a result, the proposed source can operate in a "parasitic" mode not interfering with the main mode of the accelerator operation. It is proposed to install at PETRA a tunable free-electron laser operating in the 20-50 μm wavelength band with peak and average output power ∼ 10 MW and ∼ 1 kW, respectively. This will result in the intensity of the γ-source ∼ 3 × 1012s-1 with tunable γ-quantum energy up to 60 MeV. Gamma sources with a similar principle of operation could be constructed also at other storage rings such as HERA, TRISTAN, LEP(LEP 2), ESRF, SPring-8. Such γ-sources could reveal unique possibilities for precision investigations in nuclear physics. © 1995.

Abstract: The synthesis of the hydrogen-storage alloy Mg2Ni has been carried out through a single-step mechanical alloying employing an energy ball mill. The synthesized ball-milled Mg2Ni alloy has been found to exist in the form of fine (nano) particles with sizes of about 40 Å. The nanoparticle form has been found to lead to easy activation for hydrogenation by annealing at 300 °C (about 10-4 Torr vacuum) for 30 min and hydrogen uptake has been found to commence from the first cycle itself. © 1995.

Title: Long-lived, doubly charged diatomic and triatomic molecular ions
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, Aarhus C, DK-8000, Denmark; Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Homi Bhabha Road, Bombay, 400005, India

Abstract: Lifetimes of doubly charged diatomic and triatomic molecules have been measured by monitoring the decay curves of such ions in a heavy-ion storage ring. CO2+, N2+, CO+, CSj+ and SH2+ are all found to possess long-lived components which survive for time periods greater than a few seconds. All these dications are found to be essentially stable and their ultimate destruction is due to interactions with residual gases in the ring. C02+ possesses many more lifetime components in the millisecond range than the isoelectronic N,+ ion. Translational energy spectrometry experiments on the latter species also fail to reveal any short-lived (microsecond) components. Ab initio configuration interaction calculations have been carried out and the potential energy curve for the lowest-energy metastable state of N2+ ('Ey) has been determined, along with Franck-Condon factors for vertical transitions to different vibrational levels from the ground state of neutral Nj; tunnelling times of each vibrational level have been computed. (formula present). © 1995 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Putet G., Picaud J.C., Salle B.L., Rigo J., Senterre J.
Title: Energy, protein and body composition in low-birth-weight infants
Affiliations: Department of Neonatology, Hopital Edouard Herriot, F-69437 Lyon, France
Authors with affiliations: Putet, G., Department of Neonatology, Hopital Edouard Herriot, F-69437 Lyon, France; Picaud, J.C., Department of Neonatology, Hopital Edouard Herriot, F-69437 Lyon, France; Salle, B.L., Department of Neonatology, Hopital Edouard Herriot, F-69437 Lyon, France; Rigo, J., Department of Neonatology, Hopital Edouard Herriot, F-69437 Lyon, France; Senterre, J., Department of Neonatology, Hopital Edouard Herriot, F-69437 Lyon, France
Abstract: In very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants, the achievement of adequate nutrition is very important for intact survival. The measurement of body composition as a result of given regimen will rapidly become available with dual energy X ray absorptiometry. At the present time, composition of weight gain is calculated by combining nutrient balance (metabolizable energy, protein storage) and indirect calorimetry (energy expenditure). In 72 VLBW infants, nutrient balance and indirect calorimetry were performed to determine utilization and storage of nutrients. Weight gain and it composition were compared in four groups of infants fed different regimen = unsupplemented human milk (HM, n = 10), HM supplemented with protein (HM + Pr, n = 15), HM supplemented with protein and energy (HM + Pr + En, n = 13) and preterm formula (PF, n = 34). Protein storage was significantly higher in infants fed HM + Pr (2.0 ± 0.3 g/kg/d) than in infants fed HM (1.6 ± 0.4 g/kg/d); that increase in protein storage is followed by a decrease in fat storage. The weight gain was higher in infants fed HM + Pr (16.7 ± 2.3 g/kg/d) than in infants fed HM (14.3 ± 3.1 g/kg/d), but no significant difference was observed. Absorbed protein was similar in infants fed HM + Pr (2.9 ± 0.5 g/kg/d) and in infants fed HM + Pr + E (2.8 ± 0.3 g/kg/d), but metabolizable energy was higher in the second group (103 ± 9 kcal/kg/d) than in the first one (88 ± 16 kcal/kg/d). This increase in metabolizable energy was followed by an increase in fat storage which explains the greater weight gain in infants fed HM + Pr + E. Weight gain and its composition were similar either in infants fed HM + Pr + E or in infants fed PF. Non protein energy storage is influenced by the protein/energy ratio and by the absolute amount of energy intake. From our data, it appears that an energy intake close to 120 kcal/kg/d with a Prot/En ratio close to 2.5 g Prot/100 kcal induced a weight gain of about 20 g/kg/d with 20% fat. It seems to be an appropriate goal for feeding a growing VLBW premature infants.
Author Keywords: energy requirements; nutrition; protein; very-low-birth-weight infants

Authors: Lebedev S.G.
Title: Radiation stability of thin targets in a high intensity particle accelerator environment
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Institute for Nuclear Research, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, 117312, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Lebedev, S.G., Institute for Nuclear Research, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, 117312, Russian Federation
Abstract: The features of radiation damage of thin targets under irradiation by light ions of high energy are considered. When the target thickness is less than the mean free path of the recoil nucleus in the target medium, the radiation damage which occurs is smaller than in the reverse condition. This is because the recoil nucleus may escape the target without energy loss. A comparison of the mechanical stability of carbon foils subjected to heavy and light ion irradiation has been made both in terms of a physical model of target failure and an experimental study conducted by the author. The results obtained are compared with the data obtained at the proton storage ring PSR of LAMPF. © 1995.

Authors: Moss I.
Title: To plan DSM programs, you need customer usage data
Affiliations: Duke Power Co, Charlotte, United States
Authors with affiliations: Moss, I., Duke Power Co, Charlotte, United States
Abstract: Duke Power Co is implementing aggressive and cost-effective demand-side management (DSM) programs that are intended to show a significant reduction in peak loads. The intent is to provide energy to its customers at the least cost while, maximizing the efficiency of the existing system. Duke's DSM programs are partnerships with its customers that encourage changes in energy consumption patterns to reduce the need for new generating facilities. The programs fall into three basic categories: energy efficiency, load shifting, and interruptible power. Energy-efficiency programs include commercial chillers, residential insulation, heat-pump programs, and small unitary HVAC units. Load shifting programs include off-peak water heating, commercial cool storage, and industrial heat treating. Interruptible power includes air-conditioning cycling. standby generation, and interruptible service contracts. To get a broad sample, Duke decided to monitor 200 residential and 300 commercial sites. For residential sites, total load plus three end-use loads were monitored. For commercial sites, total load plus an average of five end-use loads were monitored. This paper describes briefly how customers were selected, data transmitted, analyzed and applied.
Index Keywords: Electric power distribution; Electric power transmission networks; Energy management; Surveys; Demand side management; Duke Power Company; Peak loads; Electric utilities

Abstract: In order to keep pace with the growing market demands, a number of ceramic manufacturers are increasing their capacity with the use of light-weight lined kilns. The main key in achieving this goal is the heating coil carrier system.

Authors: Langner Gerald C., Lucero Jacobo P., Laux Matthew
Title: Evaluation of a reusable phosphor x-ray detector
Affiliations: Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Authors with affiliations: Langner, Gerald C., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Lucero, Jacobo P., Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States; Laux, Matthew, Los Alamos Natl Lab, Los Alamos, United States
Abstract: The images from a reusable storage phosphor X-ray detector are compared to those of a film-lead-screen combination at X-ray energies of approx.24 MeV, approx.2.5 MeV, Co-60, approx.300 kV, approx.150 kV, and approx.75 kV, which span industrial X-ray inspection energies. The signal of the latent image stored on the phosphor is proportional to the X-ray dose received and is extracted by stimulating the phosphor with a secondary source (HeNe laser). Blue light emitted by the phosphor is collected and detected by a photomultiplier tube, converted to a digital signal, and stored on 8 mm video tape or on a hard disk to be digitally enhanced. Background levels on the phosphor are virtually nonexistent, but the screens must be properly erased before each use to remove latent images from previous exposures. After the latent image has been extracted, the phosphor is erased and stabilized using lamps that emit light at 589 nm. It is then ready to record another image. Usually, the phosphor was exposed to 0.01 to 0.5 the dose received by the film. The reusable phosphor detects at the 3.3 percent level using a steel cylinder and steel image quality indicators, and at the 1.5 percent level using an inert, mock high-explosive cylinder with an aluminum quality indicator.

Authors: Philbin Matthew
Title: Sand reclamation 1995: is it time for your foundry?
Authors with affiliations: Philbin, Matthew
Abstract: Reclamation of spent foundry sand is inevitable as landfills continue to close and progress on reuse applications remains slow. Sand reclamation however is a confusing topic, with as many variables as any process in the foundry. To succeed, preparation and information are crucial. In general, the reclamation method to be used depends on the needs of the particular foundry: What works for this one may not work for the other. Still, no matter which method is employed, lump crushing and sand granulation is the first step. After that, the choice of system rests on the specific requirements: sand/binder system, tonnage, energy costs and space limitations. The purchase includes not only the reclaimer but also the components for screening, classification, storage and handling.

Authors: Hellmich W., Müller G., Krötz G., Derst G., Kalbitzer S.
Title: Optical absorption and electronic transport in ion-implantation-doped polycrystalline SiC films
Source title: Applied Physics A Materials Science and Processing
Affiliations: Physik Department E16, Technische Universität München, Postfach 20 24 20, München, D-85747, Germany; Forschung u. Technik, Daimler-Benz AG, Postfach 80 04 65, München, D-81663, Germany; Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Postfach 10 39 80, Heidelberg, D-69029, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hellmich, W., Physik Department E16, Technische Universität München, Postfach 20 24 20, München, D-85747, Germany; Müller, G., Forschung u. Technik, Daimler-Benz AG, Postfach 80 04 65, München, D-81663, Germany; Krötz, G., Forschung u. Technik, Daimler-Benz AG, Postfach 80 04 65, München, D-81663, Germany; Derst, G., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Postfach 10 39 80, Heidelberg, D-69029, Germany; Kalbitzer, S., Max-Planck-Institut für Kernphysik, Postfach 10 39 80, Heidelberg, D-69029, Germany
Abstract: Fine-grained (d≈0.1 μm), polycrytalline SiC films were prepared on top of insulating and optically transparent sapphire substrates by means of a thermal crystallization technique. Optical absorption measurements indicate that the individual SiC grains consist of relatively defect-free β-SiC surrounded by high-defect density grain-boundary material. Nominally undoped material exhibits a low de conductivity (δ≈10-8 Ω-1 cm-1) in the dark and an efficient photoconductivity apon illumination with short-wavelength UV light. The temperature dependence of the de transport exhibits a quasi-Arrhenius-type behaviour with average activation energies of the order to 0.6 eV. A characteristic feature of this kind of transport is a continuous increase in activation energy with increasing film temperature. Upon doping with N, P and Al ions, the average activation energy is decreased and room temperature conductivities of the order of 0.1 Ω-1 cm-1 are reached. Doping with B ions, on the other hand, only leads to high-resistivity material. It is shown that the electronic transport in doped SiC-On-Sapphire (SiCOS) films can be successfully modelled in terms of a grain-boundary-dominated conduction process. In this process thermal activation across potential barriers at the grain-boundary surfaces competes with funneling through these same barriers. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.

Title: The response to treatment of overweight in postmenopausal women is not related to fat distribution
Affiliations: Center Clinical and Basic Research, Ballerup Byvej 222, DK-2750 Ballerup, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Svendsen, O.L., Center Clinical and Basic Research, Ballerup Byvej 222, DK-2750 Ballerup, Denmark; Hassager, C., Center Clinical and Basic Research, Ballerup Byvej 222, DK-2750 Ballerup, Denmark; Christiansen, C., Center Clinical and Basic Research, Ballerup Byvej 222, DK-2750 Ballerup, Denmark
Abstract: OBJECTIVE: To investigate whether fat distribution or sex hormone status in overweight postmenopausal women do influence the response to treatment of overweight. DESIGN: Longitudinal, clinical intervention study of a 4.2 MJ diet daily with or without exercise. SUBJECTS: 98 healthy, overweight, postmenopausal women (age: 49-58 y, BMI: 25-42 kg/m2). MEASUREMENTS: Various fatness and fat distribution parameters (by dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry and anthropometry), sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), sex hormones, and the resting energy expenditure (REE) at baseline and after 3 months. RESULTS: Reductions in weight and fat were independent of the initial fat distribution and the REE, but were significantly associated with high initial SHBG levels. Furthermore, loss of fat was significantly and independently associated with increases in SHBG and reductions in central fat distribution. CONCLUSION: Postmenopausal women with an android and gynoid fat distribution respond with similar weight loss to treatment of overweight. Furthermore, a more healthy, less android, fat distribution and sex hormone status may be achieved with increasing weight loss.
Author Keywords: Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry; Energy expenditure; Fat distribution; Menopause; Sex hormones; Weight loss; Women
Index Keywords: androstenedione; estradiol; sex hormone; testosterone; absorptiometry; adipose tissue; adult; anthropometry; article; clinical trial; controlled clinical trial; controlled study; energy expenditure; estradiol blood level; exercise; female; hormone blood level; human; lipid storage; major clinical study; obesity; postmenopause; priority journal; skinfold thickness; testosterone blood level; weight reduction; Androstenedione; Anthropometry; Body Composition; Densitometry, X-Ray; Diet, Reducing; Energy Metabolism; Estradiol; Exercise; Female; Gonadal Steroid Hormones; Humans; Intervention Studies; Longitudinal Studies; Middle Aged; Obesity; Postmenopause; Sex Hormone-Binding Globulin; Testosterone

Authors: Keller A.A., Goldstein R.A.
Title: Oceanic transport and storage of carbon emissions
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Institute, P.O. Box 10412, Palo Alto, 94303, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keller, A.A., Electric Power Research Institute, P.O. Box 10412, Palo Alto, 94303, CA, United States; Goldstein, R.A., Electric Power Research Institute, P.O. Box 10412, Palo Alto, 94303, CA, United States
Abstract: Using a global carbon cycle model (GLOCO) that considers seven terrestrial biomes, surface and deep ocean layers based on the HILDA model and a single mixed atmosphere, we analyzed the response of atmospheric CO2 concentration and oceanic DIC and DOC depth profiles to additions of carbon to the atmosphere and ocean. The rate of transport of carbon to the deepest oceanic layers is rather insensitive to the atmosphereic-ocean surface gas exchange coefficient over a wide range, hence discrepancies between researchers on the precise global average value of this coefficient do not significantly affect predictions of atmospheric response to anthropogenic inputs. Upwelling velocity, on the other hand, amplifies oceanic response by increasing primary production in the upper ocean layers, resulting in a larger flux into DOC and sediments and increased carbon storage; experiments to reduce the uncertainty in this parameter would be valuable. The location of the carbon addition, whether it is released in the atmosphere or in the middle of the oceanic thermocline, has a significant impact on the maximum atmospheric CO2 concentration (pCO2) subsequently reached, suggesting that oceanic burial of a significant fraction of carbon emissions (e.g. via clathrate hydrides) may be an important management option for limiting pCO2 buildup. Our analysis indicates that the effectiveness of ocean burial decreases asymptotically below about 1000 m depth. With a constant emissions scenario (at 1990 levels), pCO2 at year 2100 is reduced from 501 ppmv considering all emissions go to the atmosphere, to 422 ppmv with ocean burial at a depth of 1000 m of 50% of the fossil fuel emissions. An alternative scenario looks at stabilizing pCO2 at 450 ppmv; with no ocean burial of fossil fuel emissions, the rate of emissions has to be cut drastically after the year 2010, whereas oceanic burial of 2 GtC/yr allows for a smoother transition to alternative energy sources. © 1995 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Index Keywords: air-sea interactions; anthropogenic effect; carbon cycle; carbon dioxide emission; carbon storage; climate change; oceanic transport; upwelling

Authors: Sinclair J., Hall C.E.
Title: Photosynthetic energy storage in aquatic leaves measured by photothermal deflection
Affiliations: Biology Department, Carleton University, 1125 Colonel By Drive, Ottawa, K1S 5B6, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sinclair, J., Biology Department, Carleton University, 1125 Colonel By Drive, Ottawa, K1S 5B6, Ontario, Canada; Hall, C.E., Biology Department, Carleton University, 1125 Colonel By Drive, Ottawa, K1S 5B6, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: In a study of photosynthetic energy storage efficiency (ES), the adaxial surface of the leaves of Vallisneria americana exhibited the highest ES values (22%) of the four aquatic plants examined. V. americana leaves have a dispersed structure and it was possible to measure the energy storage properties of the epidermal cells independently of the rest of the leaf. The abaxial epidermis had a higher value of ES at zero light fluence than the adaxial epidermis but ES in the abaxial epidermis declined much more rapidly with light fluence. Thus the abaxial epidermis is more suited to lower light fluences than the adaxial epidermis. ES declined as the pH rose from 4.0 to 8.0 at a constant dissolved inorganic carbon concentration. This paralleled the change from carbon dioxide to bicarbonate and suggests that these leaves utilise CO2 more efficiently than bicarbonate. ES increased by about 50% at pH 8.0 as leaf sections further from the leaf tip were examined which demonstrates that the older epidermal cells are less well able to use bicarbonate. Exposure to 30 min of a saturating light fluence caused the epidermal chloroplasts to move from the periclinal walls to the anticlinal walls. This decreased the photothermal signal by increasing the thermal diffusion distance and lowering the light fluence due to greater chloroplast shading. The latter effect increased ES. It appears that chloroplast movement could assist the epidermis to survive harmful light fluences. © 1995 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: chloroplast movement; photosynthesis; photothermal deflection spectroscopy; Vallisneria americana

Authors: Basto M.J., Figueiredo M.O., Legrand F., Chevallier P., Melo Z., Ramos M.T.
Title: Gold assessment in micas by XRF using synchrotron radiation
