Gama Pinto, 2, 1699 Lisboa Codex, Portugal
Abstract: The detection of sub-trace concentrations (ng g-1) of heavy elements in geological samples by X-ray fluorescence may be achieved by the use of synchrotron radiation (SXRF). Minimum detection limits range from a few μg g-1 to tenths of ng g-1 depending on the atomic number of the analyte vs. the matrix mean atomic number. Recently, the assessment of sub-trace Au contents in lepidolites from the Gonçalo lithium mine, northern Portugal, using SXRFA was described, and the optimal excitation energy established at 13 keV. New results from muscovite and lepidolite micas from various localities in Portugal are now reported. Experiments were performed at the LURE (Laboratoire pour l'Utilisation du Rayonnement Electro-magnétique), DCI (Dispositif de Collision sous Igloo) storage-ring with a Si (Li) detector, using local data handling and processing programs. A complex population of trace elements gives rise to interferences on the diagnostic Au-Lα line, namely from K-lines of lighter elements (Zn-Kα, Ge-Kα, Ga-Kα) and from the L-spectra ofTa and W, which were accounted forin data processing. Unfortunately, the lack of suitable standards currently hinders the presentation of reliable absolute figures for Au contents. © 1995.
Index Keywords: analytical method; gold; lepidolite; mica; muscovite; synchrotron radiation; XRF; Portugal, Goncalo Mine

Authors: Khoumeri B., Balbi N., Balbi J.H., Bighelli A., Tomi F., Casanova J.
Title: The reaction between 2-methoxyfuran and dimethylacetylenedicarboxylate: Thermochemical and kinetical data
Affiliations: Université de Corse, Centre de Mathématiques et de Calcul Scientifique, URA CNRS 2053, Quartier Grossetti-B.P. 52, 20250 Corte, France; Université de Corse, Laboratoire d'Hélioénergétique, URA CNRS, 2053, Route des Sanguinaires, 20000 Ajaccio, France
Authors with affiliations: Khoumeri, B., Université de Corse, Centre de Mathématiques et de Calcul Scientifique, URA CNRS 2053, Quartier Grossetti-B.P. 52, 20250 Corte, France; Balbi, N., Université de Corse, Centre de Mathématiques et de Calcul Scientifique, URA CNRS 2053, Quartier Grossetti-B.P. 52, 20250 Corte, France; Balbi, J.H., Université de Corse, Centre de Mathématiques et de Calcul Scientifique, URA CNRS 2053, Quartier Grossetti-B.P. 52, 20250 Corte, France; Bighelli, A., Université de Corse, Laboratoire d'Hélioénergétique, URA CNRS, 2053, Route des Sanguinaires, 20000 Ajaccio, France; Tomi, F., Université de Corse, Laboratoire d'Hélioénergétique, URA CNRS, 2053, Route des Sanguinaires, 20000 Ajaccio, France; Casanova, J., Université de Corse, Laboratoire d'Hélioénergétique, URA CNRS, 2053, Route des Sanguinaires, 20000 Ajaccio, France
Abstract: The Diels-Alder reaction between methoxyfuran and dimethylacetylenedicarboxylate, leading to a substituted oxanorbornadiene, has not yet been studied in terms of its thermodynamic and kinetic properties, in order to use this liquid phase reaction for storage and release of thermal energy. Here, the reaction enthalpy and kinetic parameters are determined by dynamic modelling which uses only the experimental temperature of the reaction mixture versus time and the known kinetic law (second order). NMR spectroscopy is used for structural identification of the adduct and for determining the relative ratio of reactants and product, allowing the kinetic constant to be obtained. Results obtained by modelling are compared with those of other Diels-Alder reactions currently studied. This reaction has suitable thermodynamic and kinetic properties for thermal energy storage and release. We discuss the conditions of such an application. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Diels-Alder reaction; Kinetics; Modelling; NMR; Reaction enthalpy

Authors: Su M.-Z., Zhao W., Chen W., Dong Y., Lin J.-H.
Title: X-ray storage phosphors, their properties and mechanism
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Peking University, Beijing, 100871, China
Authors with affiliations: Su, M.-Z., Department of Chemistry, Peking University, Beijing, 100871, China; Zhao, W., Department of Chemistry, Peking University, Beijing, 100871, China; Chen, W., Department of Chemistry, Peking University, Beijing, 100871, China; Dong, Y., Department of Chemistry, Peking University, Beijing, 100871, China; Lin, J.-H., Department of Chemistry, Peking University, Beijing, 100871, China
Abstract: X-ray storage phosphors doped with rare earth ions were synthesized and their properties with respect to applications were characterized. A simplified band model for the photostimulated luminescence (PSL) processes of Ce, Tb, Sm and Sm doped BaFX phosphors is proposed. For the PSL mechanism of divalent europium doped BaFX (XCl or Br) we found some special characteristics. On the basis of many experimental results we think that during photostimulation electrons are excited from F(X-) centers to a higher energy level and prefer transfer through tunneling rather than via the conduction band to recombine with the trapped holes, thus giving rise to the characteristic luminescence of the doped divalent europium ions. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Barium fluorohalides; Mechanism; Photostimulated luminescence; Rare earth doped phosphors; Storage phosphors

Authors: Aoki Ichizo, Kikkawa Yoshitsugi
Title: Technical efforts focus on cutting LNG plant costs
Affiliations: Chiyoda Corp, Yokohama, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Aoki, Ichizo, Chiyoda Corp, Yokohama, Japan; Kikkawa, Yoshitsugi, Chiyoda Corp, Yokohama, Japan
Abstract: Demand for liquefied natural gas (LNG) is growing due to the nuclear setback and environmental issues spurred by concern about greenhouse effect and acid rain, especially in the Far East. However, LNG is expensive compared with other energy sources. Efforts continue to minimize capital and operating costs and to increase LNG plant availability and safety. Technical trends in the LNG industry continue to aim at reducing plant costs. Key areas of technical development are reviewed, which include liquefaction process, acid gas removal, mercury removal, compressors, gas turbines, dynamic simulation, process control, and LNG storage and transportation.
Index Keywords: Compressors; Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Gas fuel storage; Gas plants; Liquefaction of gases; Natural gas transportation; Plant shutdowns; Process control; Acid gas removal; Heavy end removal; Liquefied natural gas plants; Train size; Liquefied natural gas

Authors: Tse M.F.
Title: Semi-structural hot melt adhesives based on crosslinkable functionalized polyolefins
Affiliations: Polymer Science Division, Baytown Polymers Center, Exxon Chemical Company, Baytown, Texas 77522, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tse, M.F., Polymer Science Division, Baytown Polymers Center, Exxon Chemical Company, Baytown, Texas 77522, United States
Abstract: A structural or semi-structural adhesive is usually applied to the substrates as monomers, oligomers, or melts of polymers with reactive groups and is then polymerized or crosslinked in situ in the joint between the substrates. We have been studying a number of crosslinked functionalized polyolefins blended with tackifier used as semi-structural adhesives for bonding to oily galvanized steel surfaces. The functions of takifier, surface properties of adhesive and substrate, geometry effects of lap joints, adhesive 7β, chain end defects, network chain length, and cure kinetics of these systems will be discussed. Our experimental results indicate that lap shear strengths of galvanized steel joints depend on adhesive storage modulus to the power of roughly 1/2. A rough estimate of the fracture energy of the adhesive bond, Ga, could be obtained from this relation. Although some estimated Ga values are too low while the others are too high, they seem to be in rough accord with the degree of interfacial bonding and the locus of failure of the lap shear bonds. © 1995, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: galvanized steel crosslink fracture energy storage modulus; Hot melt adhesive functionalized polyolefin tackifier automotive industry lap shear

Authors: Lu E.T.
Title: Constraints on energy storage and release models for astrophysical transients and solar flares
Affiliations: Institute for Astronomy, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lu, E.T., Institute for Astronomy, 2680 Woodlawn Drive, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Abstract: Rosner & Vaiana (1978) proposed an energy storage and release scenario to explain the power-law distributions of transients seen from a wide variety of astrophysical objects including the Sun. We consider whether such a scenario can account for the observed power-law distribution of solar flares. We discuss the quantitative constraints that arise for any physically realizable model of this type and show that such a model is inconsistent with solar flare energy storage in the coronal magnetic field. Not only does this rule out such a model for solar flares, but it also calls into question the application of these models for other astrophysical transients.
Author Keywords: MHD; Stars: flare; Sun: corona; Sun: flares

Authors: Jans W., Möbus B., Kühne M., Ulm G., Werner A., Schartner K.-H.
Title: Determination of absolute emission cross sections for electron-impact-induced line radiation in the vacuum ultraviolet
Affiliations: Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestrasse 2-12, Berlin, 10587, Germany; I. Physikalisches Institut der Justus-Liebig-Universität Giessen, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, 35392, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Jans, W., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestrasse 2-12, Berlin, 10587, Germany; Möbus, B., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestrasse 2-12, Berlin, 10587, Germany; Kühne, M., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestrasse 2-12, Berlin, 10587, Germany; Ulm, G., Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestrasse 2-12, Berlin, 10587, Germany; Werner, A., I. Physikalisches Institut der Justus-Liebig-Universität Giessen, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, 35392, Germany; Schartner, K.-H., I. Physikalisches Institut der Justus-Liebig-Universität Giessen, Heinrich-Buff-Ring 16, Giessen, 35392, Germany
Abstract: A method and an experimental setup have been developed for measuring absolute photoemission cross sections for electron-impact-induced line radiation in the vacuum ultraviolet (VUV). Unparalleled low uncertainties for the cross sections were achieved mainly from the use of the Berlin electron storage ring as a primary standard source in the VUV for the determination of the responsivity of the spectrometer–detector system used and from the use of a spinning rotor gauge as a secondary standard for the determination of the target gas density. As the first result we present a photoemission cross section for the Ar ii 3s3p62S1/2–3s23p52P3/2 transition at 91.98 nm for 2-keV electron-impact energy of 1.167 × 10−18 cm2 with a relative uncertainty of 4.4% (3̅√σ value). This low uncertainty demonstrates the suitability of the setup for further cross-section measurements. © 1995 Optical Society of America.
Index Keywords: Density of gases; Elementary particle sources; Fluorescence; Photoemission; Radiometry; Storage rings; Uncertainty analysis; Cross-section measurement; Electron impact; Electron impact energy; Electron storage ring; Emission cross section; Relative uncertainty; Spinning rotor gauges; Vacuum ultraviolets; Electrons

Authors: Jones David R.
Title: Small chiller system design
Affiliations: Angus-Young Associates, Inc
Authors with affiliations: Jones, David R., Angus-Young Associates, Inc
Abstract: Small chiller, notably under 125 tons, are the bulk of the chiller market. Over the years, the number of small chiller used in the hvac industry has increased to about 75% of the market. The average chiller size sold to this market segment is in the range of 50 to 60 tons. This trend is attributable to the combination of building owners desiring the better temperature and humidity control offered by hvac systems using chilled water-hot water air handlers, and the greater energy efficiency of modern building envelop design providing overall smaller cooling loads. This paper provides some useful rules of thus for the engineer and designer in applying small chiller.
Index Keywords: Climate control; Compressors; Energy efficiency; Engineers; Hot water heating; Pressure control; Refrigerants; Refrigeration; Systems analysis; Tanks (containers); Temperature; Thermodynamic stability; Chiller; Start stop cycles; Storage tanks; Cooling systems

Authors: Kaplan Gadi
Title: Power electronics in action
Authors with affiliations: Kaplan, Gadi
Abstract: As the voltage and current ratings and switching characteristics of power electronics devices and systems keep improving, the range of applications and electronic circuit concepts continues to expand. Areas that will be affected include lamp controls and power supplies to motion control, factory automation, transportation, energy storage, multimegawatt industrial drives, and electric power transmission and distribution. A new series that looks at devices and systems now evolving for ever more efficient control of power and energy is therefore necessary.
Index Keywords: Bipolar transistors; Electric power distribution; Electric power systems; Electric power transmission; Electric variables control; Harmonic generation; Microprocessor chips; Power converters; Technology; Thyristors; Harmonics; Power electronic devices; Power electronic systems; Power electronics

Authors: Niven Rex
Title: Power supply management
Affiliations: Univ of Melbourne, Melbourne
Authors with affiliations: Niven, Rex, Univ of Melbourne, Melbourne
Abstract: The power supply is perhaps the most critical part of a product. In order to avoid the occurrence of problems which are most likely to result to the interruption of power supply, careful management is very much needed. This article outlines several solutions for ensuring efficient supply.

Authors: Hatten Michael J., Morrison W.Bruce
Title: Commonwealth building: groundbreaking history with a groundwater heat pump
Affiliations: Oregon State Univ, Portland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hatten, Michael J., Oregon State Univ, Portland, United States; Morrison, W.Bruce, Oregon State Univ, Portland, United States
Abstract: The Commonwealth Building in Portland, OR, the first structure erected around late 1940s following the wartime moratorium on the construction of commercial buildings, featured the first major commercial installation of a central ground-coupled heat pump in the US. The groundwater heat pump system was designed to operate automatically in one of three modes based on the dominant building load as determined by outside air temperature. The original system incorporated two 70-ton heat pumps and two 200-ton heat pumps which were hermetically sealed centrifugal water chillers. Three wells were used to provide a heat source or heat sink, depending on the operating mode. The central heat pump plant's other unique features as well as its intriguing operational history are presented.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Buildings; Condensers (liquefiers); Cooling; Energy storage; Heat sinks; Heating; Hot water heating; Hydroelectric power; Structural design; Valves (mechanical); Water wells; Aluminum sheathing; Double-paned glazing; Groundwater heat pump; Thermal energy; Heat pump systems

Authors: Kemezis Paul
Title: Hanford's high price of peace
Authors with affiliations: Kemezis, Paul
Abstract: Fifty years after the first atomic bomb blasts, the US Department of Energy faces the new daunting task of cleaning up weapons plants. A plant such as one located at Hanford in Washington state appears on top of the priority list but budget cuts and politics hamper the project. On a 30-year timetable, the project has its budget drastically cut. Those entrusted with the task are therefore left with the option to look for privatization and outsourcing opportunities. Still, progress is clearly realized. For one, the agency no longer dumps untreated effluent into the ground. It also has began the process of converting uranium into plutonium and removing spent fuel, thereby reducing worker exposure.
Index Keywords: Containment vessels; Environmental impact; Facilities; Industrial waste treatment; Plutonium; Pumps; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste storage; Radioactive waste vitrification; Spent fuels; Contaminated soil cleanup; Groundwater pump and treat systems; Leachate collection and treatment systems; Plutonium processing plant; Radioactive wastes

Authors: Carocci Bruce
Title: Focal-plane-array camera eliminates mechanical parts and boosts resolution
Affiliations: FLIR Systems Inc, Portland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Carocci, Bruce, FLIR Systems Inc, Portland, United States
Abstract: A number of technological advances have enabled the latest infrared cameras to be handy, small, capable of digitally storing infrared images, have superior resolution and operated easily. A prime example in the Prism DS from FLIR Systems Inc. The camera design is made possible by the fusion of focal-plane-array (FPA) detector technology, the 486 microprocessor, PC card memory technology, and miniature Stirling coolers. The availability of Windows-compatible software for image analysis and report generation completes the package.
Index Keywords: Arrays; Computer software; Cooling systems; Data acquisition; Digital storage; Image quality; Imaging systems; Industrial applications; Infrared detectors; Infrared imaging; Energy collection efficiency; Focal plane array camera; Infrared camera; Stirling cooler; Cameras

Authors: Lu C.-F., Liu C.-C., Wu C.-J.
Title: Dynamic modelling of battery energy storage system and application to power system stability
Source title: IEE Proceedings: Generation, Transmission and Distribution
Affiliations: Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lu, C.-F., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Liu, C.-C., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan; Wu, C.-J., Natl Taiwan Univ, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: A useful and systematic dynamic model of a battery energy storage system (BES) is developed for a large-scale power system stability study. The model takes into account converter equivalent circuits, battery characteristics and internal losses. Both charging mode and discharging mode are presented. The model is expressed in equivalent transfer function blocks, and it can be easily used in dynamic stability analysis of a power system. To examine the dynamic behaviour of the model, applications to the damping of turbogenerator torsional oscillations are performed. Active and reactive power modulation by the BES can be controlled according to system requirements. Eigenvalue analysis and dynamic simulations are performed to demonstrate the damping effect of the BES.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Computer simulation; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Electric batteries; Electric converters; Electric losses; Electric power systems; Equivalent circuits; Oscillations; System stability; Transfer functions; Battery energy storage system; Turbogenerator torsional oscillations; Energy storage

Authors: Woldt E., Jensen D.J.
Title: Recrystallization kinetics in copper: Comparison between techniques
Affiliations: Institut fur Werkstoffe, Technische Universitat Braunschweig, Braunschweig, D-38106, Germany; Materials Department, Riso National Laboratory, Roskilde, DK-4000, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Woldt, E., Institut fur Werkstoffe, Technische Universitat Braunschweig, Braunschweig, D-38106, Germany; Jensen, D.J., Materials Department, Riso National Laboratory, Roskilde, DK-4000, Denmark
Abstract: Six different experimental techniques (electron backscattering (Kikuchi) patterns, calorimetry, micro-and macrohardness, orientation contrast scanning electron microscopy, and neutron diffraction) have been used to determine the volume fraction of recrystallized material X(t) in a series of partly recrystallized copper samples. Before recrystallization, the copper samples were cold-rolled to 92 pct reduction in thickness. The results obtained with the different experimental techniques are compared, and the applicability and accuracy of the six techniques are considered. While five of the techniques reveal the same kinetics, although with different degrees of accuracy, the texture measurements by neutron diffraction seem to indicate a faster recrystallization process. Finally, the recrystallization kinetics and stored energy aspects of the copper material are discussed with respect to the Johnson-Mehl-Avrami-Kolmogorov model. © 1995 The Minerals, Metals & Material Society.
Index Keywords: Calorimetry; Cold rolling; Electron scattering; Energy storage; Grain size and shape; Neutron diffraction; Recrystallization (metallurgy); Scanning electron microscopy; Volume fraction; Johnson-Mehl-Avrami-Kolmogorov model; Texture measurement; Copper metallurgy

Authors: Ruan D., Li W., He L., Hu Q.
Title: Phase diagrams of binary systems of alkylammonium tetrachlorometallates(II)
Affiliations: Central China Normal University, Wuhan, 430070, China
Authors with affiliations: Ruan, D., Central China Normal University, Wuhan, 430070, China; Li, W., Central China Normal University, Wuhan, 430070, China; He, L., Central China Normal University, Wuhan, 430070, China; Hu, Q., Central China Normal University, Wuhan, 430070, China
Abstract: The phase diagrams of four binary systems (C10H21NH3)2CoCl4-(C16H33NH3)2CoCl4, (C12H25NH3)2CoCl4-(C16H33NH3)2CoCl4, (C10H21NH3)2ZnCl4-(C16H33NH3)2ZnCl4 and (C12H25NH3)2ZnCl4-(C16H33NH3)2ZnCl4 were investigated by means of DSC. These six compounds and their binary mixtures can retain energies between 74 and 115 J/g during solid-state transformations at temperatures between 70 and 105°C, and they are therefore being considered for potential use in solar energy systems. © 1995 Akadémiai Kiadó.

Authors: Oelsner A., Fecher G.H., Ostertag Ch., Jentzsch Th., Schönhense G.
Title: Dichroic effects in photoemission from pure and oxidised rubidium and potassium monolayers on platinum (111)
Affiliations: Johannes-Gutenberg-Universität, Institut für Physik, D-55099 Mainz, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Oelsner, A., Johannes-Gutenberg-Universität, Institut für Physik, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Fecher, G.H., Johannes-Gutenberg-Universität, Institut für Physik, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Ostertag, Ch., Johannes-Gutenberg-Universität, Institut für Physik, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Jentzsch, Th., Johannes-Gutenberg-Universität, Institut für Physik, D-55099 Mainz, Germany; Schönhense, G., Johannes-Gutenberg-Universität, Institut für Physik, D-55099 Mainz, Germany
Abstract: Well-ordered monolayers of rubidium and potassium on platinum Pt(111) have been studied by LEED, angular resolved UPS and XPS excited by circularly polarised synchrotron radiation from the electron storage ring BESSY (Berlin). The order of pure and oxidised monolayers at T = 300 K was investigated by LEED. CDAD has been measured for the Rb 3d, Rb 4p and K 3p states in the case of the (√3 × √3)R30° structures of pure Rb and K. Exposure of oxygen to the alkali monolayers leads to disordered alkali oxide layers. After additional heat treatment ordered structures are observed again. In all cases of ordered monolayers CDAD asymmetries up to 30% are found. This is surprising, because the observed initial states have spherical symmetry in particular, at least the p1 2 state. We explain these results by photoelectron diffraction, including neighbouring adsorbate (Rb, K) and underlying substrate (Pt) atoms. Variations of the CDAD asymmetry between 0% and 30% are found to be dependent on the kinetic energy of the photoelectrons up to 190 eV and the angle of observation, respectively. © 1995.

Authors: Fisher F.S.
Title: Advanced pumped-storage project will play a versatile role in New Jersey
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: Mt. Hope Hydro, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fisher, F.S., Mt. Hope Hydro, Inc, United States
Abstract: Now more than 20 years old, the 2000 MW Mt. Hope pumped-storage project has reached an advanced stage of development. The changing nature of the regional power market in the northeastern USA has provided it with new marketing opportunities, but also new challenges. This article describes the project's evolution, its capabilities and its anticipated role in an increasingly competitive marketplace.

Authors: Rittase R.A.
Title: Two approaches to turbine upgrades: planned and unplanned
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Affiliations: Voith Hydro, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rittase, R.A., Voith Hydro, Inc, United States
Abstract: Turbine upgrades fall into two major categories: those planned in advance and those forced on an owner as a result of equipment failure. Out of necessity, the time schedule and strategy for carrying out the work are vastly different, depending on whether or not the unit can remain in service while preparing for the outage. PECO Energy has had to deal with both types of rehabilitations recently at their two hydro plants on the lower Susquehanna river.

Authors: Chiang S.J., Huang S.C., Liaw C.M.
Title: Three-phase multifunctional battery energy storage system
Affiliations: Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chiang, S.J., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Huang, S.C., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Liaw, C.M., Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: A three-phase multifunctional battery energy storage system (BESS) is designed and implemented. When the utility power is in normal condition, the proposed BESS can be arranged to shave the peak load or charge the battery bank. In either case, since the load unbalanced, harmonic and reactive powers can be compensated through the proposed active power filter control, the power factor is maintained at nearly unity and the line currents drawn from the utility are balanced and sinusoidal with very low distortion. As the utility power failure occurs, the proposed BESS can immediately supply uninterruptible power to the loads. In this case, an instantaneous control technique is developed to yield good three-phase voltage waveforms. The determination of the reactive components, the dynamic modelling, and the design of controllers for the proposed BESS are introduced. A 5 kVA prototype system is implemented and some experimental results are provided to demonstrate the functions and performance of the proposed BESS. Finally, the strategies for scaling up the power capacity of the proposed BESS are discussed.
Index Keywords: Active filters; Charging (batteries); Control equipment; Electric currents; Electric distortion; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electric utilities; Electric variables control; Equivalent circuits; Performance; Battery energy storage system; Power capacity; Three phase voltage waveforms; Uninterruptible power supplies; Secondary batteries

Authors: Skaer Mark
Title: Future of district heating and cooling
Affiliations: Engineered Systems
Authors with affiliations: Skaer, Mark, Engineered Systems
Abstract: Over the past decade, district heating and cooling has been revived. Many district energy systems have been established, and existing systems have been expanded. Technical innovations have been the driving force behind the continued expansion of district heating and cooling. These innovations have improve the economics of existing systems, and made the development of new ones feasible. Those in the business believe the next 10 years will be as strong.

Authors: Yamauchi Tadaaki, Tanaka Koji, Furutani Kiyohiro, Morooka Yoshikazu, Miyamoto Hiroshi, Ozaki Hideyuki
Title: Fully self-timing data-bus architecture for 64-Mb DRAMs
Affiliations: Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami-shi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamauchi, Tadaaki, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami-shi, Japan; Tanaka, Koji, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami-shi, Japan; Furutani, Kiyohiro, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami-shi, Japan; Morooka, Yoshikazu, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami-shi, Japan; Miyamoto, Hiroshi, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami-shi, Japan; Ozaki, Hideyuki, Mitsubishi Electric Corp, Itami-shi, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes a fully self-timing data-bus (FSD) architecture which includes a dual data-bus driven by the read-out data itself and a complementary output differential (COD) amplifier. The proposed COD amplifier achieves a high voltage gain and a high speed data transfer with low power consumption. The read-out data is transmitted from the COD amplifier to the output terminal without the timing control caused by the fluctuation of the device parameters. Therefore the proposed FSD architecture eliminates the timing delay and achieves a timing-free data transfer even in DRAMs with a small signal level at the sense amplifier and the data line. Applying this architecture to a 64-Mb DRAM, a fast column address access time of 16 ns and a RAS access time of 32 ns have been achieved.

Authors: Holland William
Title: Steam thermal storage
Authors with affiliations: Holland, William
Abstract: The feasibility of thermal storage by ice is considered as an ideal way to shift the electrical energy demand for air-conditioning from summer afternoon peak period to night time using lower priced electrical power to produce the ice. Already, there are systems using slurry for cooling applications, exploiting the use of off peak electricity. Thermal storage in building fabric is also a development of the basic night storage heater, again taking advantage of low cost off peak electricity. Further, it is noted that thermal storage could be incorporated into the heating system so that heat is stored upon surplus, and released when there is shortage.

Abstract: The Basis for Interim Operation (BIO) for the Receiving Basin for Off- Site Fuel (RBOF) facility at the Department of Energy (DOE) Savannah River Site (SRS) nuclear materials production complex developed in accordance with draft DOE-STD-0019-93, required a hazard categorization for the safety analysis section as outlined in DOE-STD-1027-92. The RBOF facility was thus established as a Category-2-facility (having potential for significant on- site consequences from a radiological release) as defined in DOE 5480.23. Given the wide diversity of spent nuclear fuel stored in the RBOF facility, which made a detailed assessment of the total nuclear inventory virtually impossible, the categorization required a conservative calculation based on the concept of a hypothetical, bounding reference fuel assembly integrated over the total capacity of the facility. This scheme not only was simple but also precluded a potential delayed in the completion of the BIO.The Basis for Interim Operation (BIO) for the Receiving Basin for Off-Site Fuel (RBOF) facility at the Department of Energy (DOE) Savannah River Site (SRS) nuclear materials production complex, developed in accordance with draft DOE-STD-0019-93, required a hazard categorization for the safety analysis section as outlined in DOE-STD-1027-92. The RBOF facility was thus established as a Category-2 facility (having potential for significant on-site consequences from a radiological release) as defined in DOE 5480.23. Given the wide diversity of spent nuclear fuel stored in the RBOF facility, which made a detailed assessment of the total nuclear inventory virtually impossible, the categorization required a conservative calculation based on the concept of a hypothetical, bounding reference fuel assembly integrated over the total capacity of the facility. Authors: O'Donnell S., Jeanne R.L.
Title: Worker lipid stores decrease with outside-nest task performance in wasps: Implications for the evolution of age polyethism
Affiliations: Department of Entomology, University of Wisconsin, 1630 Linden Drive, Madison, 53706, Wisconsin, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Donnell, S., Department of Entomology, University of Wisconsin, 1630 Linden Drive, Madison, 53706, Wisconsin, United States; Jeanne, R.L., Department of Entomology, University of Wisconsin, 1630 Linden Drive, Madison, 53706, Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: Recent models of energetically efficient division of labor in eusocial insects predict that risky tasks will be performed by workers with low nutrient content. We measured changes in workers' nutrient stores (chloroform: methanol extractable lipids) in relation to age-based division of labor in the eusocial wasp Polybia occidentalis to test this prediction. Distributions of age of first performance differed among task sets; tasks at increasing distance from the nest interior were performed later in life. However, individuals varied in the rate of passage through the task sequence. Weight of extractable lipids, corrected for differences in body weight, decreased with time elapsed since first performance of tasks outside the nest. Lipid content had a weaker negative relationship with adult age. Therefore, patterns of lipid decrease reflected individual differences in age polyethism. Age-based division of labor, with performance of risky tasks delayed until late in life by workers with depleted nutrient stores, may have evolved as an energy saving mechanism for insect colonies. © 1995 Birkhäuser Verlag.

Authors: Bryant J.P., Julkunen-Tiitto R.
Title: Ontogenic development of chemical defense by seedling resin birch: Energy cost of defense production
Affiliations: Institute of Arctic Biology, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Fairbanks, 99775-7000, Alaska, United States; Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, Joensuu, SF-80101, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Bryant, J.P., Institute of Arctic Biology, University of Alaska, Fairbanks, Fairbanks, 99775-7000, Alaska, United States; Julkunen-Tiitto, R., Department of Biology, University of Joensuu, Joensuu, SF-80101, Finland
Abstract: Whether production of chemical defenses by plants is or is not an energetically costly process is an important, but unresolved, question in chemical ecology. We suggest studies of the ontogenetic development of plant defense systems can help resolve the question. As an example of this approach to the cost question, we explore the problems associated with production of immobile chemical defenses that defend juvenile resin birches against browsing by mammals. From this exploration we draw two conclusions: (1) Shortly after germination, production of chemical defenses by small-seeded species, such as birch, is energetically costly. (2) Opposing selection for defense versus competitive ability in the seedling stage of birch has resulted in a trade-off in allocation of carbon to production of immobile chemical defense versus allocation of carbon to production of storage reserves. We suggest this trade-off results in a large indirect cost of defense because carbon used for production of immobile chemical defenses is unavailable for support of growth in the future, but stored carbon can be used to support future growth. © 1995 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Author Keywords: cost; ontogeny; Plant chemical defense; seedling; storage
Index Keywords: Betula spp.

Authors: Schmieg S.J., Belton D.N.
Title: Effect of hydrothermal aging on oxygen storage/release and activity in a commercial automotive catalyst
Affiliations: Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research and Development Center, Bldg. 1-6, 30500 Mound Road, Warren, MI 48090-9055, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schmieg, S.J., Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research and Development Center, Bldg. 1-6, 30500 Mound Road, Warren, MI 48090-9055, United States; Belton, D.N., Physical Chemistry Department, General Motors Research and Development Center, Bldg. 1-6, 30500 Mound Road, Warren, MI 48090-9055, United States
Abstract: We have studied the effect of hydrothermal aging on the oxygen storage/release and activity in a commercial automotive catalyst containing Pt, Rh, Ni, and Ce. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to measure changes in the oxidation state of the Ce and Ni present in the washcoat of the catalyst after various oxidation and reduction treatments and rate measurements of the carbon monoxide oxidation reaction were used to determine the reaction kinetics and activity. The catalyst was tested fresh and after hydrothermal aging at 1000°C under cyclic redox conditions. To determine which Ce species were present on the surface, we fit the XPS Ce(3d) data with combinations of spectra from standard materials (CeO2 and Ce2O3). Based on our measurements we conclude that aging the catalyst causes a loss of oxygen storage capacity due to sintering of the ceria particles which reduces the ceria/noble metal interaction and does not allow the Ce to cycle between oxidation states. In addition, hydrothermal aging causes the loss of oxygen storage of the Ni due to the irreversible formation of NiAl2O4. For the fresh catalyst, the observed kinetics for the uncycled carbon monoxide oxidation reaction show all of the signatures attributable to a catalyst with a high degree of ceria/noble metal interaction (complete suppression of the carbon monoxide inhibition effect, decreased sensitivity of the reaction rate to gas-phase oxygen concentration, and decreased apparent activation energy). Changes in the kinetics upon aging are consistent with a loss of ceria/noble metal contact area due to sintering of the ceria particles. © 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Automotive catalyst; Carbon monoxide oxidation; Ceria; Hydrothermal aging; Oxygen storage; Platinum-rhodium-nickel; Reaction kinetics; Sintering; X-ray diffraction; X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

Authors: Oliferuk W., Świa̧tnicki W.A., Grabski M.W.
Title: Effect of the grain size on the rate of energy storage during the tensile deformation of an austenitic steel
Affiliations: Institute of Fundamental Technological Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, Świȩtokryzska 21, 00-049 Warsaw, Poland; Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Warsaw University of Technology, Narbutta 85, 02-524 Warsaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Oliferuk, W., Institute of Fundamental Technological Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, Świȩtokryzska 21, 00-049 Warsaw, Poland; Świa̧tnicki, W.A., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Warsaw University of Technology, Narbutta 85, 02-524 Warsaw, Poland; Grabski, M.W., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Warsaw University of Technology, Narbutta 85, 02-524 Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: The effect of the grain size on the energy storage process in a low carbon austenitic steel deformed in tension is studied. The energy conversion at each instant of the deformation process is characterized by the instantaneous rate of energy storage, des dew, where es is the stored energy and ew is the mechanical energy expended on the plastic deformation. It has been shown experimentally that, in the initial stage of plastic deformation in this austenitic steel, the dependence of the rate des dew on ew exhibits a maximum. The location of the maximum depends on the grain size of the material. In fine-grained samples, the maximum appears at smaller strains. After reaching a certain degree of deformation, plots of des dew vs. the strain for the samples of both groups are practically the same. These results are interpreted in terms of the microstructural evolution during deformation. It has been shown that the grain boundaries favour the formation and affect the evolution of low energy dislocation structures. © 1995.
Author Keywords: Austenitic steel; Energy storage; Grain size; Tensile deformation

Authors: Burchanowski C., Moler R., Shope S.
Title: Scanned-beam x-ray source technology for photon backscatter imaging technique of mine detection: Advanced technology research
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of the Army, Communications-Electronics Command Research, Development & Engineering Center, Night Vision & Electronic Sensors Directorate, 10221 Burbeck Road, Suite 430, Fort Belvoir, VA  22060-5806, United States; Systems Support, Inc., 10024 Colvin Run Road, Great Falls, VA  22066-1832, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, P.O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM  87185-1182, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burchanowski, C., Department of the Army, Communications-Electronics Command Research, Development & Engineering Center, Night Vision & Electronic Sensors Directorate, 10221 Burbeck Road, Suite 430, Fort Belvoir, VA  22060-5806, United States; Moler, R., Systems Support, Inc., 10024 Colvin Run Road, Great Falls, VA  22066-1832, United States; Shope, S., Sandia National Laboratories, P.O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM  87185-1182, United States
Abstract: A very high power, state-of-the-art, scanning, x-ray source has been developed for use with an x-ray backscatter system that detects and images buried land mines. This paper describes the distinctive qualities of the x-ray source technology necessary to prove the feasibility of the mine detection technique in the field. The imaging system requires that an x-ray beam, having a nominal illumination area on the ground of two centimeters by two centimeters, sweeps across a width of three meters in a time of 15 milliseconds or less. The source must produce an integrated flux of 106 x-rays (min) at 120 kVp (min) for each pixel. The source technology is based on a plasma-focused electron beam operating up to 140 kilovolts with a current of 0.7 ampere. The electron beam is magnetically shaped to form a thin ellipse with dimensions of approximately one millimeter by ten millimeters. The scanner is designed to run continuously with target temperature of 160 °F (max). The overall design allows the scanner to run with operational and auxiliary power generators in the field. A unique 400 hertz, 440 volt, 3-phase, SCR-controlled, low energy storage DC source, with low ripple and 1% voltage regulation, supplies the scanner with 100 kilowatts of power at up to 160 kilovolts. The uniqueness of the mine detection technique and scanner design limits radiation hazards: (1) focussing and tight collimation minimizes stray x-rays; (2) the x-rays travels directly into the ground and are mostly absorbed; (3) radiation leakage from the source is not permitted; and (4) backscatter radiation is strongly localized around the irradiation area, is directed upward and has a small angular distribution. © 1995 SPIE.

Authors: Ulmer M.P., Purcell W.R., Matz S.M., Finley J.P., Cordes J.M., Wilson R.B.
Title: Concept for an all-sky low-energy gamma-ray observatory (ALLEGRO)
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Northwestern University, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Evanston, IL  60208, United States; Purdue University, Physics Department, 1396 Physics Bldg., W. Lafayette, IN  47907, United States; Cornell University, Astronomy Department, Ithaca, NY  14853, United States; Marshall Space Flight Center, Code E562, Huntsville, AL  35812, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ulmer, M.P., Northwestern University, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Evanston, IL  60208, United States; Purcell, W.R., Northwestern University, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Evanston, IL  60208, United States; Matz, S.M., Northwestern University, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Evanston, IL  60208, United States; Finley, J.P., Purdue University, Physics Department, 1396 Physics Bldg., W. Lafayette, IN  47907, United States; Cordes, J.M., Cornell University, Astronomy Department, Ithaca, NY  14853, United States; Wilson, R.B., Marshall Space Flight Center, Code E562, Huntsville, AL  35812, United States
Abstract: We describe a concept for a NASA mission to study gamma-ray bursts, pulsars, and hard x- ray transients. That a large area all sky monitor is an outstanding design was demonstrated by the BATSE (Burst And Transient Source Experiment) on board the Compton Gamma-Ray Observatory (CGRO). The proposed All Sky Low Energy Gamma-Ray Observatory (ALLEGRO) will combine the best characteristics of BATSE and OSSE (Oriented Scintillation Spectrometer Experiment), namely continuous all-sky coverage with a reduced background obtained from relatively narrow field of view collimation. The design goals call for an effective area of greater than or approximately equal to 2000 cm2 (in the 20- 200 keV range) provided by 35 separate detectors aligned to cover the entire sky, plus 1/8 ms time tagging of all events and energy coverage from 7 - 200 keV. We combine this with what have probably been the greatest advances in technology over the past few years, namely, advances in electronics, computing power, and data storage and retrieval. With these capabilities plus enhancements to the design based on our experience with BATSE and OSSE, we will explore the realm of high time resolution phase space with all-sky coverage at unprecedented sensitivity. Such a satellite will provide a myriad of fascinating studies of the hard x-ray sky. Three general areas where we expect to make major advances are the understanding of gamma-ray bursts, rotationally powered neutron stars, and binary x-ray sources. As an added bonus, this satellite will allow us to monitor the hard x-ray sky, provide hard x-ray maps, and even provide a stringent test of the general relativistic Shapiro delay. © COPYRIGHT SPIE. Downloading of the abstract is permitted for personal use only.

Authors: Freund A.K.
Title: X-ray optics at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, B.P. 220, Grenoble-Cédex, F 38043, France
Authors with affiliations: Freund, A.K., European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, B.P. 220, Grenoble-Cédex, F 38043, France
Abstract: The European Synchrotron Radiation Facility in Grenoble, France is the first one of the third- generation high-energy storage ring sources in the world and has been in operation for three years. It provides x-ray beams of unprecedented quality in an energy range from hundred eV to several hundred keV. In order to fully exploit the source quality adequate x-ray beamline optics are needed that can cope with not only the very low emittance but also the extremely high brilliance involving severe heat load. The strategies and the solutions of x-ray optics research and development at the ESRF that started seven years ago are described. The results of first experience gathered during more than two years of beamline operation on the performances of mirrors, single crystal monochromators, and multilayer structures exposed to these very powerful x-ray beams are presented, together with their mechanical supports for bending, cooling, and alignment. New developments like Bragg-Fresnel optics for microfocusing, x-ray phase plates for polarization studies, adaptive optics, cryogenic cooling, diamond crystals, and other relevant optics materials are included, too. It is shown that today the x-ray optics developed for the ESRF are capable of preserving the high quality of the x-ray beams, a result that was not clear at all a few years ago. © COPYRIGHT SPIE. Downloading of the abstract is permitted for personal use only.

Authors: Moon S.S., Nahm K.S.
Title: An improvement in the properties of hydrogen storage alloy by copper microencapsulation
Affiliations: Dept. of Chemical Technology, College of Engineering, Chonbuk National University, Chonju, 560-756, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Moon, S.S., Dept. of Chemical Technology, College of Engineering, Chonbuk National University, Chonju, 560-756, South Korea; Nahm, K.S., Dept. of Chemical Technology, College of Engineering, Chonbuk National University, Chonju, 560-756, South Korea
Abstract: A hydrogen storage alloy of LaNi5 was microencapsulated by electroless chemical plating with metallic copper. The surface morphology of the microencapsulated LaNi5 was studied for different electroless plating conditions. The deactivation, regeneration, and catalytic activity of LaNi5 were compared before and after the microencapsulation. The amount of Cu deposited on the LaNi5 surface increased with increasing concentration of the plating solution. A relatively smooth morphology was obtained by decreasing the plating rate. The extent of the deactivation of the microencapsulated LaNi5 was very low compared to that of LaNi5 and decreases with the number of the microencapsulation. Almost complete regeneration was achieved for microencapsulated LaNi5, but the extent of the regeneration decreased with the number of regeneration cycles at higher temperatures. The microencapsulated LaNi5 showed a higher catalytic activity for methanation of carbon monoxide, where the conversion was almost quantitative. © 1995.

Authors: Hu C.-K., Luther B., Kaufman F.B., Hummel J., Uzoh C., Pearson D.J.
Title: Copper interconnection integration and reliability
Affiliations: IBM Research Division and Semiconductor Research, Development Center, PO Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hu, C.-K., IBM Research Division and Semiconductor Research, Development Center, PO Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Luther, B., IBM Research Division and Semiconductor Research, Development Center, PO Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Kaufman, F.B., IBM Research Division and Semiconductor Research, Development Center, PO Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Hummel, J., IBM Research Division and Semiconductor Research, Development Center, PO Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Uzoh, C., IBM Research Division and Semiconductor Research, Development Center, PO Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States; Pearson, D.J., IBM Research Division and Semiconductor Research, Development Center, PO Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY 10598, United States
Abstract: A processing sequence to produce a multilevel Cu/polyimide structure which is stable in a corrosive environment is described. Using a combination of dry etching and chemical-mechanical polishing, a fully planarized Cu/polyimide wiring structure was obtained. This technology has been successfully applied to the fabrication of 64 kb complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor static random access memory (CMOS SRAM) chips. Chip functionality was not affected by 12 thermal cycles from 20 to 400 °C. The electromigration activation energy for evaporated Cu, Cu(Mg), Cu(Zr), Cu(Sn) and chemical vapour deposition (CVD) pure Cu was evaluated using a drift velocity technique. The mass transport rates of CVD Cu and evaporated Cu were found to be essentially the same, with an electromigration activation energy of 0.70 ± 0.05 eV. An Mg impurity in Cu enhances the electromigration damage rate in Cu, while Sn and Zr drastically increase the Cu electromigration failure lifetime. © 1995.

Abstract: By decelerating highly-charged, very heavy ions to low energies in the storage and cooler ring, ESR, a new brilliant source for projectile x-rays has been obtained. In a first precision spectroscopy experiment up to 2·107 stored bare U92+ ions have been decelerated down to 49 MeV/u before detecting the characteristic projectile x-rays associated with one-electron capture at the ESR gas target. The Lyman, Balmer and Paschen series are distinctly observed for hydrogenic U91+ ions. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Murakami M., Wolf A.T.
Title: Techno-political Water and Energy Development Alternatives in the Dead Sea and Aqaba Regions
Source title: International Journal of Water Resources Development
Affiliations: Nippon Koei Co., Ltd., Consulting Engineers, Research and Development Center, Koojimachi Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo (102), Japan; Department of Geography, University of Alabama, 202 Farrah Hall, Box 870322, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487, United States
Authors with affiliations: Murakami, M., Nippon Koei Co., Ltd., Consulting Engineers, Research and Development Center, Koojimachi Chiyoda-ku, Tokyo (102), Japan; Wolf, A.T., Department of Geography, University of Alabama, 202 Farrah Hall, Box 870322, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487, United States
Abstract: Water and energy will be key elements in any regional development schemes in arid regions, being the limiting factors for planned tourism/resorts, industry and commerce. Two regions may be particularly attractive for regional economic development planning: The Dead Sea region, including the territory of Israel, Palestine and Jordan; and the Aqaba/Eilat area, which includes Egypt, Israel, Jordan and Saudi Arabia. These two regions could act as showcases of cooperation between the countries of the Middle East. This study describes both technical and political priorities for water and energy development projects, including non-conventional alternatives, particularly proposed hydro-solar and seawater pumped-storage schemes with hydropowered reverse osmosis (RO). Technical and political implications of these projects are examined in a framework of inter-state regional economic cooperation. © 1995 Journals Oxford Ltd, All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Planning; Water Resources; developing region; economic cooperation; energy resources; international cooperation; political aspect; regional development; water resources; water resources development; Middle East, Aqaba; Middle East, Dead Sea

Authors: Carson Rob
Title: Flash memory: a 32Mbit NAND device
Affiliations: Samsung Semiconductor
Authors with affiliations: Carson, Rob, Samsung Semiconductor
Abstract: Samsung Semiconductor's new 32Mbit NAND Flash memory is fabricated using the same 0.5μm CMOS process the company has been using for years to produce its 4Mbit DRAM. The 32Mbit capacity represents the highest density Flash component available today. Moreover, it is hardware and software compatible with KM29V32000, which operates from a single 3.3V rail (or 5V±10%) and will serve as a cost-effective solution for portable mass storage and resident Flash array applications.

Authors: Valenti Michael
Title: Storing solar energy in salt
Authors with affiliations: Valenti, Michael
Abstract: The world's largest power tower being built by Bechtel in California's Mojave Desert incorporates Solar Two, one of the newest commercial solar energy systems. Solar Two will use molten salt to absorb solar energy and store that energy until it is needed to generate electricity. Bechtel engineers will use much of the existing heliostat field, power tower, electrical generator, and storage tanks from Solar One and will incorporate a new solar receiver, steam generator, and storage tanks to convert the site to molten-salt technology.
Index Keywords: Computer systems; Electric motors; Electric power generation; Energy storage; Fluids; Heat exchangers; Mirrors; Molten materials; Potassium compounds; Salts; Sodium compounds; Solar concentrators; Molten salt; Potassium nitrate; Power tower; Sodium nitrate; Solar one; Solar thermal systems; Solar two; Thermal receivers; Solar energy

Authors: Anon
Title: Soft start-stop system calms cable-drive spasms
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: The Brooks Construction Co. in Indiana, a producer of hot-mix paving products, uses a cable to pull a 6-ton hopper loaded with paving materials up to 45° incline to a position over one of four heated storage bins which, in turn, dispenses the materials to trucks for transport to the job sites. The abrupt accelerations and decelerations of a cable-driven hopper system produced a chronic maintenance headache for the company. Fortunately, with flux vector adjustable-speed drive, jarring starts and stops of a high-inertia cable system are eliminated, thereby boosting productivity, lowering power requirements, and reducing component wear and tear.

Title: Median peak detecting analog signal processor for hard disk drive servo
Affiliations: AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nagaraj, Krhishnaswamy, AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Lewis, Stephen H., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Walden, Robert W., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Offord, Glen E., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Shariatdoust, Reza S., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Sabnis, Jyoti A., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Peruzzi, Robert O., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Barner, Jeffrey R., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Plany, Joseph, AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Mento, Robert P., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Rakshani, Vafa A., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States; Hull, Richard W., AT&T Bell Lab, Murray Hill, United States
Abstract: An analog signal processor for hard disk drive servo is described. It performs servo demodulation by means of median peak detection which provides immunity against additive as well as multiplicative noise from the medium, unlike conventional methods. A novel circuit configuration has been employed to implement the median peak detector in an area and power efficient manner. The entire servo processor that includes the demodulator and 10 b A/D and D/A converters has been integrated into a single CMOS integrated circuit.

Title: Efficient low-voltage operation of a reverse-biased autoprepulse XeCl laser
Source title: Applied Physics B Lasers and Optics

Abstract: An improved version of the auto-prepulse excitation scheme for long-pulse operation of the XeCl excimer laser is reported. A pulsed reverse bias on the small peaking capacitance allows efficient (1.7%) operation at 100 mJ output level with a charge voltage limited to 5-7 kV. Analogies and differences with other long-pulse operation schemes are also discussed. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Wilson David D.
Title: Horizontal wells: oil and water can mix
Affiliations: Horizontal Well and Environmental, Consultants, Arvada, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilson, David D., Horizontal Well and Environmental, Consultants, Arvada, United States
Abstract: Little is know about horizontal directional drilling and horizontal well installation, to indicate if these technologies are performing well and/or cost-effective. However, some data have been gathered and analyzed by the Department of Energy (DOE) with regard to the performance of horizontal wells in the petroleum industry. In this study, DOE results were used to discuss the present state of horizontal well application in the environmental industry.

Authors: Zheng Z., Gu D., Anthony R.G., Klavetter E.
Title: Estimation of Cesium Ion Exchange Distribution Coefficients for Concentrated Electrolytic Solutions When Using Crystalline Silicotitanates
Affiliations: Kinetics, Catalysis and Reaction Engineering Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3122, United States; Sandia National Laboratory, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87185, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zheng, Z., Kinetics, Catalysis and Reaction Engineering Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3122, United States; Gu, D., Kinetics, Catalysis and Reaction Engineering Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3122, United States; Anthony, R.G., Kinetics, Catalysis and Reaction Engineering Laboratory, Department of Chemical Engineering, Texas A&M University, College Station, Texas 77843-3122, United States; Klavetter, E., Sandia National Laboratory, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87185, United States
Abstract: Polzer et al.’s method combined with Bromley’s method for estimating activity coefficients and a Langmuir isotherm for cesium in a simple simulated waste solution containing 5.1 M NaNO3 and 0.6 M NaOH was used to estimate distribution coefficients for cesium in a complex simulated waste solution characteristic of the radioactive tank wastes at Hanford and other U.S. Department of Energy sites. The ion exchange material was a hydrous sodium crystalline silicotitanate, labeled TAM-5, which is being developed by Texas A&M University, Sandia National Laboratories, and UOP Associates. Cesium distribution coefficients collected by Bray et al. on a NCAW simulated waste solution were predicted with deviations of less than 25% for solutions containing 1 M, 3 M, and 5 M Na+ and Na:Cs ratios of 103-108. The deviations were less than 5% for the solutions with 1 M Na+. Cesium distribution coefficients were also predicted and compared with values measured by Egan et al. for TAM-5 and for a storage tank supernate and a “newly generated” waste solution. Excellent results were obtained for the “newly generated” waste simulated solution, which did not contain potassium or rubidium. The predictions for the other simulated waste solution were significantly greater than the measured values, because of the presence of large concentrations of potassium or rubidium. The effect of competitive ion exchange between Cs, Rb, and K was not included in the theory. However, the effect of competitive exchange of Cs, Rb, and K appears to be greater for the Oak Ridge simulated waste solution than for the NCAW waste. © 1995, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Cesium; Crystalline materials; Electrolytes; Isotherms; Potassium; Radioactive wastes; Rubidium; Silicon compounds; Sodium compounds; Bromley method; Concentrated electrolytic solutions; Ion exchange distribution coefficients; Langmuir isotherm; Silicotitanates; Storage tank supernate; Ion exchange

Authors: Ertug Selcuk, Cimento Nuh
Title: Nuh cement industries expands clinker production to 2 million tpy
Authors with affiliations: Ertug, Selcuk; Cimento, Nuh
Abstract: When completed later this year, Nuh Cement's modernization of kiln line no. 2 will increase the plant's capacity to 2 million tpy. The plant's close proximity to its own port enables cement to be exported to the Middle East, Mauritius and Spain. Projects completed in 1994 include the installation of Fas-Lab Gamma-Metrics analyzer, assembly of trass mill, and clinker conveyor system capacity augmentation. Kiln no. 2 precalcination project is an on-going improvement effort. The construction of gypsum and trass crusher, and storage hall as well as the installation of port loading and transportation system are being considered. Nuh Cement is therefore understandably optimistic about its ready-mix concrete installations.
Index Keywords: Calcination; Coal; Concretes; Conveyors; Crushers; Energy utilization; Grinding mills; Gypsum; Lime; Marketing; Public policy; Rotary kilns; Cement mill; Clinker production; Ready mix concrete; Cement manufacture

Authors: Fortunati S., Di Schino G., Mattei I., Tamba A.
Title: New energy, cost and time saving transformation cycle for ferritic stainless grades
Affiliations: Centro Sviluppo Materiali spa, Terni, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Fortunati, S., Centro Sviluppo Materiali spa, Terni, Italy; Di Schino, G., Centro Sviluppo Materiali spa, Terni, Italy; Mattei, I., Centro Sviluppo Materiali spa, Terni, Italy; Tamba, A., Centro Sviluppo Materiali spa, Terni, Italy
Abstract: The annealing of hot rolled stainless steel coils represents a key critical step for the companies producing mainly austenitic grades when bigger quantities of ferritic grades must be processed. To support this production and marketing strategy, high investments and operating costs, as well as large mill space availability are needed. Ilva-Terni faced this complex situation with a structured R&D program. Aiming at by passing the standard bell furnaces annealing cycle with a new one based on the possibility to take advantage of the hot rolling heat to reduce investment costs and processing time without altering the final mechanical and corrosion resistance properties of the finished Cr sheets. The results of industrial campaigns are compared to those of similar products processed according to the traditional cycle. The new cycle proved to be applicable to all the straight chromium grades presently produced at Terni. Moreover, typical surface defects affecting the hot rolled ferritic grades like corrosion (caused by coiling water stagnation and atmospheric corrosion during storage) and halos (due to edge oxidation in bell furnaces), are completely avoided.
Index Keywords: Annealing; Chromium; Corrosion resistance; Ferrite; Heat treating furnaces; Hot rolling; Marketing; Production; Sheet metal; Bell annealing furnaces; Ferritic stainless grades; Investment; Surface defects; Stainless steel

Authors: Wang Xingyi, Lu Guanzhong, Wu Shangliang
Title: Nitric oxide reduction performance of automotive palladium catalysis
Affiliations: East China Univ of Science and, Technology, Shanghai, China
Authors with affiliations: Wang, Xingyi, East China Univ of Science and, Technology, Shanghai, China; Lu, Guanzhong, East China Univ of Science and, Technology, Shanghai, China; Wu, Shangliang, East China Univ of Science and, Technology, Shanghai, China
Abstract: Activity of three-way palladium catalysts was examined by means of a pulse-flam-microreactor. The effects of cerium on the catalytic properties of γ-alumina-supported palladium for the reduction of nitric oxide were studied with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR). The reduction of nitric oxide on the palladium catalysts is inhibited significantly by hydrocarbon. However, the reduction of nitric oxide was improved by the addition of cerium to the catalysts. The XPS and TPR studies showed that the presence of cerium provided palladium oxide in a hard-reduced state and suppressed the chemisorption of hydrocarbons on the palladium oxide. Additionally, cerium can increase the surface specific oxygen storage capacity and decrease the apparent activation energy for the reaction CO+NO→CO2+1/2N2. So a high conversion of NOx reduction could shift to a higher A/F ratio.
Index Keywords: Catalyst activity; Environmental protection; Nitrides; Palladium; Automotive palladium catalyst; Nitric oxide reduction; Reduction

Authors: Lin Qin, Yu Zhentao, Ye Wen, Liu Renmin
Title: Kinetics of hydrogen absorption in MmNiCoMnAl alloy
Affiliations: Univ of Science and Technology, Beijing, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Qin, Univ of Science and Technology, Beijing, Beijing, China; Yu, Zhentao, Univ of Science and Technology, Beijing, Beijing, China; Ye, Wen, Univ of Science and Technology, Beijing, Beijing, China; Liu, Renmin, Univ of Science and Technology, Beijing, Beijing, China
Abstract: The kinetic process of MmNi3.55Co0.75Mn0.4Al0.3 alloy absorbing hydrogen in α and α+β phases at the temperature range of 22-60°C has been studied. The results show that the kinetic process is controlled by chemical reaction in the α phase and the mechanism of hydrogenation kinetics is not affected by initial hydrogen pressure. In the α+β phase region, the speed of hydrogen absorption is controlled by hydrogen diffusion in the hydride. A reaction rate equation and apparent activation energy are obtained.
Index Keywords: Cobalt alloys; Energy storage; Hydrogenation; Nickel alloys; Hydrogen storage alloys; Hydrogenation kinetics; Rare earth alloys

Authors: Reynolds Patrick
Title: Debut delayed
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Authors with affiliations: Reynolds, Patrick
Abstract: Distributed, or modular, pump storage systems developed in the US are virtual off-the-shelf economic packages designed for localized load balancing and meeting demands peaks in the transmission grids. However, with the US new power capacity market being dominated by gas-fired generation, coupled with depressed electricity prices and utilities playing the wait-and-see investment game over deregulation, the project packages have remained not only on the shelf; in terms of convincing the market, they are effectively still on the drawing board.

Authors: Steer P.J., Tashiro C.H.M., Mcillveen W.D., Clement R.E.
Title: PCDD and PCDF in air, soil, vegetation and oily runoff from a tire fire
Affiliations: Science and Technology Branch, Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy, 2 St. Clair Av. W., Toronto, M4V 1L5, Ontario, Canada; Laboratory Services Branch, Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy, 125 Resources Road, Etobicoke, M9P 3V6, Ontario, Canada; Standards Development Branch, Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy, 7510 Farmhouse Court, Brampton, N1G 3X7, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Steer, P.J., Science and Technology Branch, Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy, 2 St. Clair Av. W., Toronto, M4V 1L5, Ontario, Canada; Tashiro, C.H.M., Laboratory Services Branch, Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy, 125 Resources Road, Etobicoke, M9P 3V6, Ontario, Canada; Mcillveen, W.D., Standards Development Branch, Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy, 7510 Farmhouse Court, Brampton, N1G 3X7, Ontario, Canada; Clement, R.E., Laboratory Services Branch, Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy, 125 Resources Road, Etobicoke, M9P 3V6, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: In early February 1990, vandals set fire to a used tire storage facility near Hagersville, Ontario, Canada, During the fire, the Ontario Ministry of Environment and Energy (MOEE) monitored the site and surrounding impact zone for numerous organic contaminants. Samples of air, soil, vegetation, runoff water, and oily residue were collected and analyzed for polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins (PCDD) and polychlorinated dibenzofurans (PCDF). Air samples produced complex incineration patterns with a large number of isomers detected. Total toxicity equivalents (TEQ) at 1 km downwind of the fire were an order of magnitude higher than those at 3 km downwind. Soil samples collected during the fire did not show elevated PCDD or PCDF concentrations, however, low concentrations were detected in vegetation collected at 100 m and 200 m from the site. PCDD and PCDF concentrations in the foliage decreased with time but were still detectable for at least 200 days after the fire started. As the tires burned, water used to extinguish the fire caused runoff of oil and oily water. Unique patterns of PCDDs and PCDFs were detected in these samples. © 1995 Kluwer Academic Publishers.

Title: Kinetics of Metabolism in Human Kidney Transplants Measured by Dynamic 31P NMR Spectroscopy
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section C Journal of Biosciences
Affiliations: Institut für Physikalische Chemie, United States; Institut fur Klinische Radiologie, Klinik und Poliklinik für Allgemeine Chirurgie, Westfalische Wilhelms-Universitat, D-48149 Miin-ster, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, United States; Klinik und Poliklinik für Allgemeine Chirurgie, Westfalische Wilhelms-Universitat, D-48149 Miin-ster, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Möller, H.E., Institut für Physikalische Chemie, United States; Gaupp, A., Institut für Physikalische Chemie, United States; Vermathena, V., Institut für Physikalische Chemie, United States; Vestring, T., Institut fur Klinische Radiologie, Klinik und Poliklinik für Allgemeine Chirurgie, Westfalische Wilhelms-Universitat, D-48149 Miin-ster, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, United States; Peters, P.E., Institut fur Klinische Radiologie, Klinik und Poliklinik für Allgemeine Chirurgie, Westfalische Wilhelms-Universitat, D-48149 Miin-ster, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, United States; Dietl, K.-H., Klinik und Poliklinik für Allgemeine Chirurgie, Westfalische Wilhelms-Universitat, D-48149 Miin-ster, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, United States; Buchholz, B., Klinik und Poliklinik für Allgemeine Chirurgie, Westfalische Wilhelms-Universitat, D-48149 Miin-ster, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, United States
Abstract: The technique of ex vivo 3P NMR spectroscopy has been used for the investigation of metabolic turnover in 15 cadaveric human kidneys obtained from brain-dead donors for transplantation. Measurements were carried out at 1.5 T time-dependently during regular hypothermic storage in histidine-tryptophan-α-ketoglutarate solution. The minimum delay between explantation and spectroscopy was 2 h 41 min. In one case of a discarded organ the measurements could be extended over a period of 161 h 35 min. A detailed kinetic model describing monoexponential ischemic phosphate turnover, which accounts for various interrelations of the NMR visible metabolites, has been derived. Averaged velocity constants of the decays of nucleotides and phosphomono- and -diesters ranged from 0.0047 to 0.294 h_1 at approximately 4° C. Intracellular pH decreased monoexponentially with an averaged velocity constant of 0.31 h-1. © 1995, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.

Authors: Walker L.O.
Title: Weight gain after childbirth: A women's health concern?
Affiliations: The University of Texas at Austin, 1700 Red River Street, Austin, 78701-1499, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walker, L.O., The University of Texas at Austin, 1700 Red River Street, Austin, 78701-1499, TX, United States
Abstract: Changes in health care delivery call for an integrative science of women's health care. A neglected area of such a science is the interrelationship between childbearing and chronic health conditions, such as obesity. Recent increases in guidelines for gestational weight gain (GWG) have raised concerns that these guidelines may contribute inadvertently to later obesity in women. On average, existing research shows that pregnancy accounts for small gains in postpartal weight, especially if the effects of aging are considered. However, there is great variability in postpartal weight gain, and some women, especially minority women, are more vulnerable to excessive weight gains following childbirth. Although GWG is an important predictor of postpartal weight gain, psychosocial factors, such as personal health patterns and stress, also may potentially contribute to women's weight gain after childbirth. Further research is needed to determine the impact of women's psychosocial context on postpartal weight. © 1995 The Society of Behavioral Medicine.
Index Keywords: aging; caloric intake; childbirth; disease association; energy expenditure; health care delivery; health hazard; human; lipid storage; obesity; pregnancy complication; primary medical care; psychosocial disorder; puerperium; reproduction; review; risk assessment; weight gain

Authors: Hanagiri T., Igisu H., Shiraishi T., Ikeda M., Yasumoto K.
Title: Effects of glucose on rat lung preservation: Report of a study conducted on an isolated lung reperfusion model utilizing another isolated lung as a "deoxygenator"
Affiliations: Second Department of Surgery, School of Medicine, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan; Department of Environmental Toxicology, Institute of Industrial and Ecological Sciences, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan; Department of Occupational Health Economics, Institute of Industrial and Ecological Sciences, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hanagiri, T., Second Department of Surgery, School of Medicine, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan; Igisu, H., Department of Environmental Toxicology, Institute of Industrial and Ecological Sciences, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan; Shiraishi, T., Second Department of Surgery, School of Medicine, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan; Ikeda, M., Department of Occupational Health Economics, Institute of Industrial and Ecological Sciences, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan; Yasumoto, K., Second Department of Surgery, School of Medicine, University of Occupational and Environmental Health, Yahata Nishi-ku, Kitakyushu, 807, Japan
Abstract: We describe herein a new experimental model in which an isolated rat lung was ventilated with a mixture of 95% nitrogen and 5% carbon dioxide to decrease the oxygen and increase the carbon dioxide in the perfused blood to create and maintain a gas composition similar to that of venous blood. By utilizing this system as a "deoxygenator," pulmonary functions, including gas exchange, could be measured for at least 60 min in isolated and preserved lungs on reperfusion. When the effects of glucose in the flushing and storage solution were examined, 5 mM glucose in the solution resulted in better preservation of the lung, as shown by a higher uptake of oxygen and a lower intratracheal pressure, than when no glucose was given. However, the presence of 50 mM glucose was not beneficial, but rather increased the wet/dry weight ratio of the tissue. © 1995 Springer-Verlag.
