Authors with affiliations: Budin, A.V., Russian Academy of Sciences Institute of Problems of Electrophysics, Dvortsovaya nab. 18, St. Petersburg, 191065, Russian Federation; Kolikov, V.A., Russian Academy of Sciences Institute of Problems of Electrophysics, Dvortsovaya nab. 18, St. Petersburg, 191065, Russian Federation; Levchenko, B.P., Russian Academy of Sciences Institute of Problems of Electrophysics, Dvortsovaya nab. 18, St. Petersburg, 191065, Russian Federation; Leontiev, V.V., Russian Academy of Sciences Institute of Problems of Electrophysics, Dvortsovaya nab. 18, St. Petersburg, 191065, Russian Federation; Makarevich, I.P., Russian Academy of Sciences Institute of Problems of Electrophysics, Dvortsovaya nab. 18, St. Petersburg, 191065, Russian Federation; Rutberg, P.G., Russian Academy of Sciences Institute of Problems of Electrophysics, Dvortsovaya nab. 18, St. Petersburg, 191065, Russian Federation; Shirokov, N.A., Russian Academy of Sciences Institute of Problems of Electrophysics, Dvortsovaya nab. 18, St. Petersburg, 191065, Russian Federation
Abstract: The main types of the electric discharge in hydrogen of high density (up to 30 g/dm3) with the current of up to 1 MA and the duration of pulse of up to 1.5 ms are considered. The aim of this study is to emprove the coefficient of transition of electric energy from the power supply source into the arc load. As a result of the research three main operating regimes of the discharge chamber were determined: monopulsed regime, multipulsed regime and stationary or short circuit regime. A dependance between the regimes and the value of the gap between the electrodes and the electrodes material was determined. The working range of the values of the gap between the electrodes was determined as 0.8-3.0 mm. The power supply is a capacitor bank with working voltage of 10 kV and electric capacity of 0.08 F, which consists of autonomously controlled modules. The oscillograms of current and voltage drop in the arc are presented. © 1995 IEEE

Abstract: Electromagnetic guns require pulsed power supplies that deliver energy to the gun breech in the 2-6 millisecond regime. A flywheel energy storage machine in which the disk rotor contains the field excitation windings appears to be a practical approach to meeting energy/power density requirements. The general concept of constructing an axisymmetric disk to obtain a radial to hoop elastic modulus ratio (Er/Eθ) that optimizes the strength of a radially thick disk is presented. A carbon fiber - epoxy rotor disk designed to operate at 650 meters per second rim speed with a 23% Copper conductor thickness fraction is reviewed. Results of sub-scale and/or sub-thickness spin test disks are also discussed. © 1995 IEEE

Title: CMOS scaling in the 0.1-μm, 1.X-volt regime for high-performance applications
Source title: IBM Journal of Research and Development
Affiliations: Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shahidi, G.G., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Warnock, J.D., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; McFarland, P.A., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Acovic, A., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Chappell, T.I., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Chappell, B.A., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Ning, T.H., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Anderson, C.J., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Dennard, R.H., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Sun, J.Y.-C., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Polcari, M.R., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States; Davari, B., Thomas J. Watson Research Cent, Yorktown Heights, NY, United States
Abstract: Deep-submicron CMOS is the primary technology for ULSI systems. Currently, the state-of-the-art CMOS device has a 0.25-μm effective channel length and operates at 2.5 V. As the CMOS technology is extended into the deep submicron range, it is estimated that the next generation will have a nominal channel length of 0.15 μm with a supply voltage of ≤2 V. In this paper, two potential technologies with application to 1.X-V CMOS are presented. First, a bulk CMOS technology with the nominal channel length of 0.15 μm is described. It is next argued that because of issues related to power dissipation, such a device may face problems when operated at its maximum speed-density potential in high-performance logic chips. CMOS on a silicon-on-insulator (SOI) substrate offers circuits with lower power at the same performance. Such a CMOS technology, with channel lengths down to less than 0.1 μm, is described next. This technology is particularly useful for applications near a 1.0-V supply. We describe, for example, a 512Kb SRAM with an access time of less than 3.5 ns at 1.X V. The clear power-performance advantage of CMOS on SOI over that of CMOS on bulk silicon in the 1.X-V regime makes it the technology of choice for sub-0.25-μm CMOS generations.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; Logic circuits; Performance; Random access storage; Semiconductor devices; Silicon on insulator technology; Substrates; ULSI circuits; CMOS devices; CMOS technology; Deep submicron CMOS; Logic chips; Nominal CMOS channel length; CMOS integrated circuits

Authors: Crockett R.G.M., Newborough M., Highgate D.J., Probert S.D.
Title: Electrolyser-based electricity management
Affiliations: Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield University, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Crockett, R.G.M., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield University, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Newborough, M., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield University, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Highgate, D.J., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield University, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom; Probert, S.D., Department of Applied Energy, Cranfield University, Bedford, MK43 0AL, United Kingdom
Abstract: A novel means for managing electricity, or energy supplies derived from electricity, is proposed. This is termed electrolyser-based management (EBM) and involves energy storage. The energy is stored as the chemical potential-energy of the hydrogen/oxygen-water reaction, with the input energy-conversion being performed by an electrolyser and subsequent regeneration to electricity via, preferably, a fuel cell. Proportions of the stored hydrogen and oxygen may be employed for combustion purposes, depending upon the application. Such a system has a unique energy-management capability in being able to provide a clean electricity-derived gas supply in addition to a managed electricity output. Furthermore, EBM systems, such as these, offer considerable scope for what can be broadly termed 'hydrogen economy' applications. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Chemical reactions; Combustion; Electric power generation; Electricity; Electrolytes; Hydrogen; Oxygen; Water; Electricity derived gas supply; Electrolyser-based management; Hydrogen/oxygen water reaction; Energy management

Authors: Stewart William E., Saunders Charles K., Gute G.Douglas, Stickler Lisa A.
Title: ICEPAK - modeling the ice-filling and ice-melting processes of thermal energy storage tanks
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, William E., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Kansas City, United States; Saunders, Charles K., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Kansas City, United States; Gute, G.Douglas, Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Kansas City, United States; Stickler, Lisa A., Univ of Missouri-Kansas City, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: This paper summarizes the capabilities of the ICEPAK software to model the ice-filling and ice-melting processes for rectangular ice storage tanks with multiple harvesting icemakers. The ICEPAK numerical model describes the geometry and quantity of ice filling a rectangular storage tank and the ice-melting behavior of particulate ice stored in the tank and calculates the tank exit water temperature as a function of time. Verification of the accuracy of the model was accomplished during ASHRAE research project RP-707, and the model results compare well with the experimental data for water level, exit water temperature, and quantity of remaining ice mass. ICEPAK is applicable to particulate ice in a tank with a bottom perimeter water outlet, rectangular storage tanks with up to four ice openings/harvester icemakers, for either ice-opening meltwater flows or uniformly distributed meltwater flows over the plan area of the tank.

Abstract: A plan to license and build a private, centralized fuel storage facility to temporarily store spent nuclear fuel was developed during 1994 by a consortium of nuclear utilities and a native American Indian tribe. Authors: Ganeriwala Surendra N.
Title: Characterization of damping properties of nonlinear viscoelastic materials
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Scientific Technologies Inc.,, Richmond, VA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Ganeriwala, Surendra N., Scientific Technologies Inc.,, Richmond, VA, USA
Abstract: The dynamic behavior of most polymeric materials become non-linear at a moderately large strain amplitude excitation. In order to optimize their uses for noise and vibration attenuation, it is necessary to characterize their damping properties as a function of strain amplitude. This work reports the strain amplitude dependent non-linear dynamic behavior of two elastomer compounds, NBR and Neoprene, studied at various frequencies and strain amplitudes using the Fourier transform mechanical analysis (FTMA) technique, developed by us. The basic theory and experimental results are presented for a one-dimensional isothermal simple shear deformation. The Green-Rivlin constitutive equation was used to model the observed behavior. The results indicate that a complete characterization of non-linear dynamic properties is rather complex. The energy dissipation is governed, however, by a simple mechanism. It is shown that the energy dissipation is governed only by the first harmonic loss modulus term of the Green-Rivlin representation, but the energy storage is related to many material functions. An expression for the energy dissipation of a non-linear viscoelastic material is derived. It is also shown that irrespective of the material constitutive law the energy dissipation can occur only at the frequency of excitation but it can be stored in a complex manner. The results are rather generalized to show that the amplitude dependence can be modeled by a power law function. It is also shown that an examination of the stress Fourier spectra can give a quantitative indication of material non-linearity and suggest a direction for developing an adequate model of these complex materials.
Index Keywords: Deformation; Dynamic response; Elastomers; Fourier transforms; Polymers; Strain; Stresses; Vibration control; Viscoelasticity; Energy dissipation; Green-Rivlin constitutive equation; Damping

Authors: Wendell Daniel, Kwan Shan
Title: Preliminary results of aquifer storage and recovery well testing City of Pasadena, California
Source title: International Symposium on Artificial Recharge of Ground Water - Proceedings
Affiliations: CH2M HILL, Santa Ana, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wendell, Daniel, CH2M HILL, Santa Ana, United States; Kwan, Shan, CH2M HILL, Santa Ana, United States
Abstract: The City of Pasadena, California, recently placed two Aquifer Storage and Recovery (ASR) wells into operation. Since that time, injection has been taking place intermittently into the two wells: the Garfield well (since October 1992), and the Jourdan well (since March 1993). As of April, 1994, the City has injected about 3,000 acre-feet (af) of potable water at rates of as much as 2,500 gpm. The wells are completed within the unconfined alluvial aquifer of the Raymond Basin. Two methods of injection are used to introduce water into the wells: 1) down the pump column; and, 2) in the space between the well casing and pump column. Observed drawup during injection is significantly different than that predicted from drawdown data and from projections based upon an ideal Theis-type aquifer. These data indicate well clogging during injection. However, post-injection specific capacity of production data appear similar to pre-injection values, indicating no remnant clogging of the well and aquifer. During injection testing the motors were allowed to back spin, and the feasibility of recovering energy during injection was evaluated. The payback period for marginal costs associated with power-generation facilities is about 3 years. Water quality data indicate that a generally good quality water is produced after injection and storage. Nitrate in the groundwater appears to behave conservatively.
Index Keywords: Groundwater; Potable water; Settling tanks; Water quality; Water wells; Well pumps; Well testing; Aquifer storage; Pump column; Recovery well testing; Well casing; Aquifers

Authors: Rasmussen Bob
Title: MPC system development a utility industry assessment
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Duke Power Co, Charlotte, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rasmussen, Bob, Duke Power Co, Charlotte, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy is currently pursuing development of a Multi Purpose Container System (MPCS) which would serve as a standardized packaging approach for bringing the nation's spent nuclear fuel from the utility sites into the federal spent fuel management system. Specifically, this system will enhance integration of the transportation, interim storage, and disposal components of the waste program. Such integration and standardization should result in economic and operational benefits to the Waste Disposal System. Consequently the Nuclear Industry is very supportive of the effort. This project will clearly create extensive interface challenges which must be overcome. An ongoing cooperative effort between the utilities, the DOE, and associated contractors will be necessary to ensure an optimum design and successful deployment.

Abstract: Information and data regarding the performance of spent nuclear fuel under long term dry storage conditions using the facilities at Idaho National Engineering Laboratory (INEL) are presented. Abstract: Combustion turbine inlet air cooling using thermal energy storage has proven to be a technically feasible method of combustion turbine capacity enhancement, based on numerous studies, technical papers and successful installations. The Burns & McDonnell TIP2 (Turbine Ice Peaking Power) Capacity facility at Lincoln Electric System was the first application of this technology. The second application was for a combined-cycle plant owned by the Public Works Commission (PWC) of Fayetteville, North Carolina. This thermal energy storage facility is currently the largest in the world. The project was completed in early summer of 1993 and has successfully operated during the summers of 1993 and 1994. Performance tests were conducted at the PWC Butler Warner Generation Station in the summer of 1994. This paper presents a case history of the PWC project, the performance test methodology, data, test results and conclusions.

Abstract: The Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority (PREPA) determined that their current distribution system was unsatisfactory for its customers in 1988. The system utilizes automatic load shedding for frequency regulation during the loss of a large generating station. This frequency excursion occurs within seconds after the trip. As a result of these occurrences, PREPA proceeded to evaluate several types of energy storage technologies and the installation of gas turbines (GT's) to stabilize their system and improve overall system response. This paper describes the power conversion system and the methodology PREPA used to determine the technical and economic advantages of a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS).

Authors: Kral S.F., Aslam M., Ribeiro P.F., Huang X., Xu M.
Title: Superconducting power delivery systems for transmission & distribution applications

Abstract: Transmission and distribution power systems are presently experiencing tremendous changes in both load requirements and system operation. End-users demand increased reliability and power quality. System operations change to optimize the distribution and number of generation sources to take advantage of load diversity and fuel availability. Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) and modern power electronics systems emerge as technologies enabling power utility systems to adapt to these changes. These systems deliver services unique and previously unavailable and we suggest the term Superconducting Power Systems to describe them. Babcock & Wilcox (B&W) is working with Anchorage Municipal Light & Power (ML&P) to design, manufacture and install a 50 MW, 1800 MJ system in Anchorage, Alaska. The system will be commissioned in early 1998.

Abstract: The impact on system costs of including a centralized interim storage facility as part of an integrated waste management system based on multi-purpose canister (MPC) technology was assessed in analyses by Energy Resources International, Inc. A system cost savings of $1 to $2 billion occurs if DOE begins spent fuel acceptance in 1998 at a centralized interim storage facility. That is, the savings associated with decreased utility spent fuel management costs will be greater than the cost of constructing and operating a centralized interim storage facility.

Source title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

Authors with affiliations: Moosavi-Red, H., Shiraz Univ, Shiraz, Iran
Abstract: This paper presents a band variable-inertia flywheel (BVIF) concept for the intermediate storage of recoverable energy for usage in the stop-go operation of a transit bus. A mathematical model is presented for the dynamics of the flywheel system, and some numerical results are presented for an evaluation of the performance of the BVIF system integrated into the 'real-life' operation of a bus. A considerable fuel saving and extended brake shoe life have been demonstrated.
Index Keywords: Braking; Dynamics; Energy storage; Evaluation; Flywheels; Fuel economy; Mathematical models; Numerical methods; Performance; Service life; Vehicle transmissions; Band variable inertia flywheel; Brake shoe life; Continuously variable transmission; Hybrid bus; Regenerative braking system; Variable mass moment of inertia; Buses

Authors: Tschegg E.K., Elser M., Stanzl-Tschegg S.E.
Title: Biaxial fracture tests on concrete - Development and experience
Affiliations: Institute for Applied and Technical Physics, University of Vienna, A-1040 Vienna, Austria; Institute for Meteorology and Physics, University of Agriculture, A-1180 Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Tschegg, E.K., Institute for Applied and Technical Physics, University of Vienna, A-1040 Vienna, Austria; Elser, M., Institute for Applied and Technical Physics, University of Vienna, A-1040 Vienna, Austria; Stanzl-Tschegg, S.E., Institute for Meteorology and Physics, University of Agriculture, A-1180 Vienna, Austria
Abstract: Crack initiation and crack propagation in concrete buildings are mostly caused by a multi-axial stress field in the component. In order to simulate this realistic state of loading in the laboratory, a simple and handy apparatus for biaxial fracture tests was developed. Here, the principle of wedge splitting is applied and is extended by a hydraulic pressure device in order to realise the biaxial state of stress in the specimen. In this device, rectangular-shaped notched specimens were broken under a defined biaxial state of stress with stable crack propagation. The load-displacement curves that were then measured permit a characterisation of the biaxial fracture behaviour of the material. Thus, the specific fracture energy and a nominal notch tensile strength can be easily determined from these graphs. By means of this testing method the fracture-mechanical characteristics of concrete with diverse forms of aggregate (natural/crushed gravel) and under different storage conditions (wet/ dry) were defined. Construction details and considerations as to the testing facilities will be discussed. The various quantities influencing the biaxial fracture behaviour of concrete will be analysed in detail and will be discussed by means of a model. © 1995.
Author Keywords: biaxial tests; Concrete; cracking stresses; fracture behaviour; fracture energy; notched specimens; storage conditions; strains
Index Keywords: Characterization; Construction; Crack initiation; Crack propagation; Fracture; Fracture testing; Mechanical properties; Mechanical variables measurement; Models; Strain; Stresses; Tensile strength; Biaxial fracture test; Cracking stresses; Fracture energy; Hydraulic pressure device; Multiaxial stress field; Notched specimen; Storage condition; Wedge splitting; Concretes

Authors: Smith Jr. Thomas B., Macaluso Corinne J., Napoli Laura J.
Title: Providing public information for the multi-purpose canister (MPC) environmental impact statement (EIS)
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith Jr., Thomas B., Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Washington, United States; Macaluso, Corinne J., Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Washington, United States; Napoli, Laura J., Duke Engineering and Services, Inc, Washington, United States
Abstract: The fabrication and deployment of a multi-purpose canister (MPC) system for the management of civilian spent nuclear fuel has been proposed by the Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM). An Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) is being prepared to evaluate the environmental effects of the system and other technologies for managing spent nuclear fuel pursuant to the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). This paper focuses on the approach taken by OCRWM to provide information to the public and solicit comments on the MPC EIS.

Authors: Yokoyama R., Ito K., Yuasa Y., Matsumoto Y., Sakashita M.
Title: Multiobjective Optimal Unit Sizing of a Grid-Connected Photovoltaic System in Consideration of its Probabilistic Characteristics
Source title: Transactions of the Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers Series C
Authors with affiliations: Yokoyama, R.; Ito, K.; Yuasa, Y.; Matsumoto, Y.; Sakashita, M.
Abstract: A probabilistic approach to the optimal unit sizing of a grid-connected photovoltaic system without storage battery is presented. The surface area of the photovoltaic array, the capacity of the receiving device, and the electric contract demand are determined so as to minimize the expected values of the annual total cost and annual energy consumption subject to the loss of power supply probability, in consideration of probabilistic characteristics of solar insolation and electricity demand. This optimization problem is considered as a multiobjective one, and a discrete set of Pareto optimal solutions is derived numerically by using the weighting method. A case study on a system with the option of reverse power flow into the grid is carried out using measured data on solar insolation. The trade-off relationship between the two objectives is clarified and optimal values of the above design items are determined in relation to the loss of power supply probability. The results obtained by this probabilistic approach are compared with those for the deterministic approach. © 1995, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Economy; Energy Saving; Multiobjective Optimization; Photovoltaic System; Probalilistic Method; Reliability in Power Supply; Solar Energy; Systems Engineering; Unit Sizing

Authors: Miller D.L., Sheldon R.C., Manning M.A., Smith F.M.
Title: Long life reserve Li/SOCl2 battery
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference
Affiliations: Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, D.L., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States; Sheldon, R.C., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States; Manning, M.A., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States; Smith, F.M., Eagle-Picher Industries, Inc, Joplin, United States
Abstract: A battery has been developed which can satisfy the normal reserve application requirements of long storage life and high current discharge while also providing long active life and high specific energy. The 3 pound, 40 in.3 battery was designed to provide a maximum of seven months active life supporting pulses of 3.75 amperes at voltages over 8.0 volts while exposed to temperatures ranging from -35°F to +145°F. In this paper, the battery design, including the novel design characteristic of isolating individual cells while still using a common electrolyte reservoir, will be presented. Also presented is data obtained during environmental testing, both pre and post activation, as well as performance data during various temperature cycles during a seven month discharge and capacity data at select temperatures.

Authors: Licht Stuart
Title: Overview of aluminum/sulfur battery technology
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference
Affiliations: Clark Univ, Worcester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Licht, Stuart, Clark Univ, Worcester, United States
Abstract: Recently we introduced a new battery utilizing a sulfur cathode and aluminum anode. The Aluminum Sulfur cell, Ecell(theoretical)=1.8 V: 2Al+3S+3KOH+3H2O → 2Al(OH)3+3KHS Faradaic capacity of the Al/S battery (based on potassium salts) is 505 Ah/kg, and the theoretical specific energy is: 1.8 Volt × 505 Ah/kg = 910 Wh/kg The principal advantages of the system include its ability to function at and near room temperature, and the very high energy capacity of the anodic and cathodic materials. In this paper technological developments in the low, medium and high power density domains of the Aluminum/Sulfur Battery are discussed.

Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference
Affiliations: Bipolar Technologies Corp, Provo, United States
Authors with affiliations: LaFollette, Rodney M., Bipolar Technologies Corp, Provo, United States
Abstract: Batteries are considered to be high specific energy but low specific power energy storage devices. One significant class of batteries include the bipolar lead acid batteries. Early designs of these batteries have excellent performance however, due to self-discharge processes and cell leakage, their life is limited. Bipolar Technologies has been continuing the development of this class of batteries. The present work describes the more recent efforts in the development of commercially viable bipolar lead acid batteries capable of sub-second discharges at specific powers of 50 - 300 kW/kg. The design and performance of the batteries are also accounted for.

Authors: Young Charlotte, Metz William, Parker Gerald J., Macaluso Corrinne

Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab, Argonne, United States

Abstract: The Department of Energy recently completed the public scoping portion of its public participation program for the Multi-Purpose Canister environmental impact statement. This impact statement will be prepared to decide whether to design and implement Multi-Purpose Canisters for managing spent nuclear fuel at commercial power plants. Stakeholders were notified about this impact statement through traditional methods, such as the Federal Register, and more innovative ones, such as electronic media. Educational materials were available to stakeholders to help them better understand the Multi-Purpose Canister program. Finally, diverse techniques were used to solicit comments from stakeholders, including structured comment forms and a toll-free facsimile number. This varied public participation effort addressed the spirit of emerging regulations and elicited nearly 1,000 comments from stakeholders across the country.

Authors: van Dijk E., van Gelder P.
Title: A Resonant Series Counterpulse Technique for High Current Opening Switches
Affiliations: Laboratory for Power Electronics and Electrical Machines, Delft University of Technology, Mekelweg 4, NL-2628 CD Delft, Netherlands; TNO PML-Pulse Physics Laboratory, Schoemakerstraat 97, NL-2628 VK Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: van Dijk, E., Laboratory for Power Electronics and Electrical Machines, Delft University of Technology, Mekelweg 4, NL-2628 CD Delft, Netherlands; van Gelder, P., TNO PML-Pulse Physics Laboratory, Schoemakerstraat 97, NL-2628 VK Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: A counterpulse technique for the controlled interruption of very high currents in inductive storage pulsed power systems is described and analysed, and some simulation results of its performance are presented. The accompanying circuit comprises a pre-charged capacitor bank, connected in series with the inductive load, which has to be provided with a current pulse. Upon actuation, a resonant counterpulse current is created in the opening switch, connected in parallel with the current source and the load. In this way, the opening switch is opened at low current. A separate closing switch prevents closing of the opening switch at high voltage. Operation of the opening switch, often a mechanical switch, at low current and low voltage prevents arc erosion of the contacts. The advantage of this circuit compared to other counterpulse circuits is that the capacitor bank does not experience a voltage reversal. Electrolytic capacitors, which have a high energy density, are applied. The remaining energy of the capacitor bank after opening the opening switch, is transferred to the load. The required initial voltage of the capacitor bank is only a few hundred volts, whereas it may be above a kilovolt in other circuits. Another advantage of the method described here is that the load does not experience a pre-current, causing unwanted preheating of the load, before the resonant current is activated. At the moment, work is being performed at the Pulse Physics Laboratory to develop the resonant series counterpulse circuit for use with rail accelerators, which must be supplied with current pulses in the millisecond range up to the mega-ampere level. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric contacts; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Electric loads; Electric power systems; Electrolytic capacitors; Resonant circuits; Arc erosion; High current opening switches; High energy density; Homopolar generator; Rail accelerators; Resonant series counterpulse; Electric switches

Authors: Khalil A.
Title: Optimum utilization of solar energy in greenhouses
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Petroleum Division (Publication) PD
Affiliations: United Arab Emirates Univ, Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates
Authors with affiliations: Khalil, A., United Arab Emirates Univ, Al-Ain, United Arab Emirates
Abstract: The present study addresses the problem of poor climate control of the greenhouse environment in tropical regions and suggests possible on-line environmental control procedures and systems. The weather parameters as well as the greenhouse parameters influencing indoor climatic conditions are experimentally investigated and theoretically modelled in the United Arab Emirates (Latitude 24 °N). A model is formulated for the greenhouse energy balance including solar radiation, long wave thermal radiation, soil and plant evapotranspiration, thermal convection and heat storage. Experimental measurements and theoretical predictions of incident and transmitted solar radiation show excellent agreement. The energy balance model is applied on typical greenhouses under the local climatic conditions of the U.A.E to predict the inside temperature and relative humidity. The model includes the effect of rates of ventilation end evaporative cooling spray water.
Index Keywords: Atmospheric humidity; Energy utilization; Evaporative cooling systems; Evapotranspiration; Greenhouses; Heat convection; Heat radiation; Heat storage; Mathematical models; Solar radiation; Ventilation; Greenhouse energy balance; Solar energy

Authors: Hino Toshiyuki
Title: Performance evaluation of an ambient-energy heat pump system
Affiliations: Kajima Technical Research Inst, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hino, Toshiyuki, Kajima Technical Research Inst, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: This paper describes a unique heat pump system whose outdoor panels can exploit ambient energy surrounding a building for its heat exchange. The newly developed system was applied to a building and its performance monitored. The operational data analyses emphasized cooling cycle performance more than the heating cycle because the air-conditioning requirement is dominant in this application. As expected, wind and rain improved the heat dissipation capability of the outdoor panels. Because of well-designed ice storage coils, the observed coefficient of performance (COP), although not totally satisfactory, was considerably better than that of ordinary ice storage systems. With a seasonal performance factor (SPF) of 3.5, this system is estimated to be more efficient than solar-powered cooling systems. Heating operation under heavily frosted conditions showed that heat collection is possible without any need for defrosting. Possibilities for further performance enhancement were examined based on these data.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Buildings; Cooling; Cooling systems; Heat losses; Heat storage; Heating; Monitoring; Performance; Rain; Structural panels; Wind; Ambient energy heat pump system; Coefficient of performance; Heat collection; Heat exchange; Ice storage coils; Outdoor panels; Seasonal performance factor; Heat pump systems

Authors: Henderson John P., Lewis Tom M., Murrell Fred H., Mangra Danny
Title: Effects of radiation and creep on viscoelastic damping materials
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Materials and Vibration Engineering,, Beaverton, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Henderson, John P., Materials and Vibration Engineering,, Beaverton, OH, USA; Lewis, Tom M., Materials and Vibration Engineering,, Beaverton, OH, USA; Murrell, Fred H., Materials and Vibration Engineering,, Beaverton, OH, USA; Mangra, Danny, Materials and Vibration Engineering,, Beaverton, OH, USA
Abstract: The Advanced Photon Source (APS), under construction at Argonne National Laboratory (ANL), requires precise alignment of several large magnets. Submicron vibratory displacements of the magnets can degrade the performance of this important facility. Viscoelastic materials (VEM) have been shown to be effective in the control of the vibration of these magnets. Damping pads, placed under the magnet support structures in the APS storage ring, use thin layers of VEM. These soft VEM layers are subject to both high-energy radiation environment and continuous through-the-thickness compressive loads. Material experiments were conducted to answer concerns over the long term effects of the radiation environment and creep in the viscoelastic damping layers. The effects of exposure to radiation as high as 108 rad on the complex modulus were measured. Through-the-thickness creep displacements of VEM thin layers subjected to static loads of 50 psi were measured. Creep tests were conducted at elevated temperatures. Time-temperature equivalence principles were used to project creep displacements at room temperatures over several years. These damping material measurements should be of interest to vibration control engineers working with a variety of applications of fields ranging from aerospace to industrial machinery.
Index Keywords: Aerospace engineering; Creep; High temperature testing; Industrial applications; Machinery; Magnets; Storage rings; Vibration control; Viscoelasticity; Advanced Photo Source; Thin layers; Viscoelastic materials; Damping

Authors: Drobyshevski E.M., Rozov S.I., Zhukov B.G., Kurakin R.O., Sokolov V.M.
Title: Experiments on Simple Railgun with the Compacted Plasma Armature
Affiliations: Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, The Russian Academy of Sciences, 194021 St. Petersburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Drobyshevski, E.M., Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, The Russian Academy of Sciences, 194021 St. Petersburg, United States; Rozov, S.I., Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, The Russian Academy of Sciences, 194021 St. Petersburg, United States; Zhukov, B.G., Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, The Russian Academy of Sciences, 194021 St. Petersburg, United States; Kurakin, R.O., Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, The Russian Academy of Sciences, 194021 St. Petersburg, United States; Sokolov, V.M., Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, The Russian Academy of Sciences, 194021 St. Petersburg, United States
Abstract: Our objective was to elucidate the physical reasons of the velocity limitation in the plasma armature (PA) railgun at the 6 km/s level. To do this, we have designed a simple system having no vacuum and no preaccelerator. The 1–2 g mass projectile is launched at the maximum possible constant acceleration—the limit of the projectile strength or the electrothermal explosion of rail surfaces, while making use of the effects of the material strengthening under the great confining pressure and rail current redistribution due to the presence of conducting shields. Such an approach provides the maximum possible energy efficiency of the launcher at its minimum conceivable length (as short as 50–80 cm). This greatly simplifies the design and fabrication but leads inevitably to the idea of the “fixed round”—“one assembly-one shot”. Our experiments have confirmed the known hypothesis that the cause of the velocity saturation at the 6 km/s level is drag and decay of PA owing to the increase of the inductive counter-emf with velocity and overload of PA with the ablated matter. The use of a compacted PA allowed us to overcome the “6 km/s limit” and to launch a 1 g projectile to 7.1 km/s in a bore length of 56 cm at a total efficiency of 10%. We believe that the simplest way to further velocity increase, while taking advantage of the compacted PA, is to increase the barrel length along with a corresponding increase of the energy stored. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Acceleration; Electric charge; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric losses; Electromagnetic launchers; Energy conversion; Fabrication; Projectiles; Surfaces; Velocity; Electromagnetic acceleration; Electrothermal explosion; Kinetic energy; Plasma armature; Projectile velocity; Rail guns

Authors: Fingersh Lee J., Simms David A., Butterfield C.P., Jenks Michael D.
Title: Overview of the unsteady aerodynamics experiment Phase III data acquisition system and instrumentation
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fingersh, Lee J., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States; Simms, David A., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States; Butterfield, C.P., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States; Jenks, Michael D., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to describe the instrumentation and data systems utilized in the NREL Unsteady Aerodynamics Experiment (formerly the `Combined Experiment') Phase III with special emphasis on the new capabilities of the Phase III system. The Phase III data system has been designed to improve on the capabilities of the Phase I and II data systems and to add new functionality. The new system provides the capability to test more turbine parameters in a more controlled and reliable way and to allow relatively easy reconfiguration as needed for specialized tests. In addition, rapidly improving personal computer (PC) technology allows these data to be directly stored onto optical disk and postprocessed in a matter of minutes. Finally, PCs are now able to overlay real-time data and pressure distributions on the video images of the turbine in operation. This video information can then be stored on conventional videotape.

Authors: Bresie D.A., Bacon I.L., Ingram S.K., Kennington K.S., Weeks D.A.
Title: Spear Coilgun
Affiliations: Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bresie, D.A., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Bacon, I.L., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Ingram, S.K., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Kennington, K.S., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Weeks, D.A., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: The SPEAR, a recent development in coilgun technology, passively launches a projectile with a solenoidally wound armature. This paper describes the SPEAR, its electromagnetic operation, its construction, and the tests performed to prove its principle. It describes the composite stator sections and the glass reinforced armature coils. It describes how engineers at CEM-UT overcame the problem of keeping solid state switch volume low by employing a modular switch design with a unique snubbing circuit that reduces required volume. Results of test #5, described in the paper, show how well the operation of the SPEAR matches the computer simulation predictions. Conceptually, the proximity of the approaching armature electromagnetically drives a stator coil's current through zero. At zero crossing the stator freewheel switch turns off, preventing reestablishment of stator current as the armature moves away. As originally designed, the gun was to accelerate a 2 kg package to 2,000 m/s. The part built is expected to achieve 1,000 m/s with a 0.75 kg package. ARDEC sponsored the work under contracts DAAA21-91-C-0087 and DAAA21-90-C-0011. © 1995 IEEE

Abstract: On May 25, 1994, the Department of Energy published a Notice of Inquiry on Waste Acceptance Issues in the Federal Register. The Notice sought to examine with affected parties various options and methods for sharing the costs related to the continued on-site nuclear waste storage by eliciting their views. A summary of the responses and comments received are presented by both comment category and respondent category.

Authors: Buchheit J.M., Child C.L., Thomas Jr. C.D., Yu Yi Jung
Title: Yankee approach to disposal of Greater-Than-Class C (GTCC) waste
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Yankee Atomic Electric Co, Bolton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Buchheit, J.M., Yankee Atomic Electric Co, Bolton, United States; Child, C.L., Yankee Atomic Electric Co, Bolton, United States; Thomas Jr., C.D., Yankee Atomic Electric Co, Bolton, United States; Yu, Yi Jung, Yankee Atomic Electric Co, Bolton, United States
Abstract: Yankee Atomic Electric Company (Yankee) is in the process of decommissioning the Yankee Nuclear Station in Rowe, Massachusetts and recently finished segmenting reactor internal components. A small percentage of these components is considered Greater-Than-Class C (GTCC) Waste. GTCC Waste comprises that category of highly radioactive materials other than spent fuel or reprocessed waste which is required by Federal Regulation to be disposed of in a geologic repository. The Department of Energy was tasked with this responsibility. To complete decommissioning, a means for disposing of this material must be identified. This paper describes the steps Yankee has taken to assure that GTCC Waste can be treated like spent fuel for disposal purposes, and also addresses transportability and storage of this material.

Authors: Kawashima N., Yamori A., Minami S., Rahman H.-U.
Title: Improvement of Railgun Projectile using Higher Specific Weight Material
Affiliations: The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science 3-1-1 Yoshinodai Sagamihara, Kanagawa, Japan; Faculty of Engineering, Osaka City University 3-3-138 Sugimoto Sumiyoshi, Osaka, Japan; University of California Riverside, Riverside, Califronia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kawashima, N., The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science 3-1-1 Yoshinodai Sagamihara, Kanagawa, Japan; Yamori, A., The Institute of Space and Astronautical Science 3-1-1 Yoshinodai Sagamihara, Kanagawa, Japan; Minami, S., Faculty of Engineering, Osaka City University 3-3-138 Sugimoto Sumiyoshi, Osaka, Japan; Rahman, H.-U., University of California Riverside, Riverside, Califronia, United States
Abstract: A projectile using a metal powder buried in a polycarbonate one is used so that we can perform an impact experiment between materials of higher specific mass such as metal and metal. The projectile could be accelerated above 6 km/sec and it was comfirmed that the powder stayed in the original configuration in the polycarbonate base without any deformation during flight. To prove the effectiveness, impact experiments were perfromed in which the total weight and the diameter of projectile with and without the metal powder are fixed for comparison. Using 2.5 cm thick stainless steel as a target, the produced craters are compared. The crater made by the projectile with palladium (Pd) power is much deeper than the one with the simple polycarbonate projectile. Moreover, a two stage crater structure is obtained which implies that higher pressure and higher temperature impact has been realized. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Lehmann P., Peter H., Jamet F., Wegner V.
Title: Some Remarks concerning the optimization of a railgun system
Affiliations: French German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général Cassagnou, F 68301 Saint-Louis, France
Authors with affiliations: Lehmann, P., French German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général Cassagnou, F 68301 Saint-Louis, France; Peter, H., French German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général Cassagnou, F 68301 Saint-Louis, France; Jamet, F., French German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général Cassagnou, F 68301 Saint-Louis, France; Wegner, V., French German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général Cassagnou, F 68301 Saint-Louis, France
Abstract: Today the energy storage systems are still encumbering, therefore it is useful to think about the optimization of a railgun system in order to achieve the best performance with the lowest energy input. The important parameters in lowering electrical input energy are : the ratio of the projectile mass and the payload mass which has to be near unity, the inductance gradient L' of the rails which has to be high, the resistive losses in the rails and in the pulse forming network which have to be minimal. In this paper we present an overview of what can be done to enhance the efficiency of a rail launcher fed by capacitor banks adjusting the rails design, the launcher caliber and length in view to accelerate payloads of several kilograms up to velocities of a few km/s with the minimum of charged electrical energy. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Susoeff A.R., Hawke R.S., Morrison J.J., Dimonte G., Remington B.A.
Title: Design of an electromagnetic accelerator for turbulent hydrodynamic mix studies
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Susoeff, A.R., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore CA, United States; Hawke, R.S., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore CA, United States; Morrison, J.J., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore CA, United States; Dimonte, G., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore CA, United States; Remington, B.A., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, Livermore CA, United States
Abstract: An electromagnetic accelerator in the form of a linear electric motor (LEM) has been designed to achieve controlled acceleration profiles of a carriage containing hydrodynamically unstable fluids for the investigation of the development of turbulent mix. Key features of the design include: 1) independent control of acceleration, deceleration and augmentation currents to provide a variety of acceleration-time profiles, 2) a robust support structure to minimize deflection and dampen vibration which could create artifacts in the data interfering with the intended study and 3) a compliant, non-arcing solid armature allowing optimum electrical contact. Electromagnetic modeling codes were used to optimize the rail and augmentation coil positions within the support structure framework. Design of the driving armature and the dynamic electromagnetic braking system is based on results of contemporary studies for non-arcing sliding contact of solid armatures. A 0.6MJ electrolytic capacitor bank is used for energy storage to drive the LEM. This report will discuss a LEM and armature design which will accelerate masses of up to 3kg to a maximum of about 300go, where go is acceleration due to gravity. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Acceleration; Capacitor storage; Deceleration; Electric coils; Electric contacts; Electric currents; Electric drives; Electrolytic capacitors; Hydrodynamics; Linear motors; Optimization; Turbulent flow; Electromagnetic accelerator; Electromagnetic braking system; Electromagnetic modelling codes; Non arcing sliding contact; Solid armatures; Particle accelerators

Authors: Butyagin P.Yu.
Title: Relaxation of atomic structure on mechanical treatment of solids
Affiliations: Semenov Inst of Chemical Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Butyagin, P.Yu., Semenov Inst of Chemical Physics, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Prolonged mechanical treatment of powders results to processes of formation and decay of structure defects. In all materials, an ultimate state exists corresponding to a precise level of stored energy. Approaching this limiting state, the probability of partial or full relaxation of disordered structure grows and at the final state a dynamic equilibrium of the ordering-disordering processes exists. The main parameters of the energy storage and relaxation processes are discussed in this paper. In a mixture of solid reagents the situation is more complicated than in simple systems because the deformation and diffusion paths to relaxation are accompanied by a chemical reaction. In this case, progress to the limiting state may take place at explosive or quasi-explosive speeds.
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Chemical reactions; Crystal atomic structure; Crystal defects; Diffusion in solids; Electron energy levels; Grain boundaries; Order disorder transitions; Polymers; Relaxation processes; Solids; Amorphous structure; Dynamic equilibrium; Mechanical treatment; Order disordering processes; Solid reagents; Surface area; Powders

Authors: Lu Cheng-Yi, Hague Lisa, Padhye Vidya, Hill Robert
Title: Int. Space Station Alpha electric power system performance degradation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Rockwell Int. Corp./Rocketdyne Div.,, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Cheng-Yi, Rockwell Int. Corp./Rocketdyne Div.,, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Hague, Lisa, Rockwell Int. Corp./Rocketdyne Div.,, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Padhye, Vidya, Rockwell Int. Corp./Rocketdyne Div.,, Canoga Park, CA, USA; Hill, Robert, Rockwell Int. Corp./Rocketdyne Div.,, Canoga Park, CA, USA
Abstract: Performance of the International Space Station Alpha (ISSA) United States On-Orbit Segment (USOS) Electric Power System (EPS) will be degraded through the mission life of the station. The power generation photovoltaic array and thermal control radiator will be directly exposed to the natural environment and the environment induced after the station is built. These environmental effects result in lower array current and voltage output as well as lower radiator heat rejection capability. Aging is the major cause for the energy storage nickel-hydrogen (NiH2) battery performance degradation. Over time, there is an increase in the internal impedance, which results in a decreased efficiency as the battery ages. Design of the ISSA EPS takes into consideration the various equipment degradation modes, to make it compatible with the environments and to meet power, lifetime, and performance requirements.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Efficiency; Electric batteries; Electric impedance; Nondestructive examination; Performance; Spacecraft equipment; International Space Station Alpha (ISSA); Nickel hydrogen batteries; Performance degradation; Photovoltaic arrays; Thermal control radiators; Space stations

Authors: Barcaglioni M., Gaddi F., Giglioli R., Salutari R., Saraceno G.A., Zini G.
Title: Battery storage plant to improve energy saving and security of subway electric supply
Affiliations: C.R.I.T.A., Italy
Authors with affiliations: Barcaglioni, M., C.R.I.T.A., Italy; Gaddi, F., C.R.I.T.A., Italy; Giglioli, R., C.R.I.T.A., Italy; Salutari, R., C.R.I.T.A., Italy; Saraceno, G.A., C.R.I.T.A., Italy; Zini, G., C.R.I.T.A., Italy
Abstract: One of the possible actions to improve the management of underground railway plants is the insertion of a battery storage in subway substations. This provides the following main benefits: increase in the recovered braking energy; increase in the system security, as the energy stored in the batteries allows the trains to reach the nearest subway station in case of failure of the main power supply; decrease in the power peak with consequent savings in running and investment costs; improvement of the voltage profile on the dc line which produces a decrease in losses. In this paper the operation of a conventional substation equipped with uncontrolled rectifiers is investigated when a device called Static Watt Compensator (SWC), composed by a battery storage system with a fully controlled dc/dc converter, is connected to the dc bus-bar. A new Battery Supervision System (BSS), tested at the University of Pisa, is used for the on-line estimation of the battery state. For a case study related to the underground of Milan, line 3, a management strategy of the plant and a first economical feasibility are studied.
Index Keywords: Busbars; Costs; Electric batteries; Electric converters; Electric energy storage; Electric railroads; Improvement; Management; Security systems; Subway stations; Battery storage plants; Braking energy; Static watt compensators; Underground railways; Electric power systems

Authors: Babel Hank W., Jones Cherie A., Wilkes Donald R., Linton Roger C.
Title: Solar absorptance measurements in space on operational spacecraft
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: McDonnell Douglas Aerospace,, Huntington Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Babel, Hank W., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace,, Huntington Beach, CA, USA; Jones, Cherie A., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace,, Huntington Beach, CA, USA; Wilkes, Donald R., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace,, Huntington Beach, CA, USA; Linton, Roger C., McDonnell Douglas Aerospace,, Huntington Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: Spacecraft hardware such as radiators requires the maintenance of solar absorptance within tight bounds for their design life. Such hardware is sized in part based on the beginning- and end-of-life absorptance. It has been difficult to make accurate end-of-life determinations based on either ground based data or flight data. The synergistic effect of atomic oxygen, ultraviolet radiation, and contamination has made it difficult to duplicate space exposures in the laboratory. The absorptance of flight exposed samples brought back to earth are not representative of the conditions in space because of changes brought about by exposure to air. This paper proposes to augment the current in-space monitoring techniques with periodic, in- space, direct measurements of the solar absorptance on operational hardware. NASA funded AZ Technology to develop a portable, space-rated device similar to the LPSR-200 portable spectroreflectometer, a space portable spectroreflectometer (SPSR). This instrument is robotically compatible and can be run using spacecraft power or batteries. The instrument also has measurement storage capacity for later retrieval and evaluation. Although extensive development work has already been completed, authorization to build a unit for a flight experiment has not been received. The Russians have expressed an interest in having absorptance measurements made on their MIR I Space Station as part of the NASA/MIR flight experiments. Proposals are currently being made to obtain authorization for the construction and use of SPSR on NASA/MIR flight experiments, to help mitigate potential problems for the International Space Station Alpha (ISSA).
Index Keywords: Aerospace applications; Aging of materials; Energy absorption; Nondestructive examination; Radiation effects; Service life; Solar radiation; Space stations; Solar absorptance; Space portable spectroreflectometers; Space station Mir; Spacecraft hardware; Reflectometers

Title: Monitoring electric vehicle performance
Affiliations: Univ of Central Florida, Cape Canaveral, United States

Abstract: Modern data acquisition systems can help advance the electric vehicle technology through their capability to effectively monitor electric vehicle performance. Depending on the evaluation to be performed, the design of data acquisition system (DAS) requires three fundamental elements which are the units for data acquisition, analysis and presentation. Because energy aspect the vehicle can be tested, valuable information out of the raw and clattered data can be obtained during actual operation, on test track and in the laboratory through the help of DAS.

Authors: Dmitrievskii Yu.E., Gumelev V.Yu.
Title: Elemental composition of the electrode surface of lead-acid storage batteries

Authors with affiliations: Dmitrievskii, Yu.E., Ryazan' High Military Automotive, Engineering Sch, Ryazan', Russian Federation; Gumelev, V.Yu., Ryazan' High Military Automotive, Engineering Sch, Ryazan', Russian Federation
Abstract: Physical processes occurring on the positive electrode of lead-acid storage batteries have been analyzed. The elemental compositions of the surface of current-carrying elements and the active mass of positive electrode, not exposed to electrolyte, have been studied by methods of low-energy ion scattering spectroscopy and Auger electron spectroscopy. The Sb, S, and O impurities are shown to affect the elemental composition and resistance of current-carrying elements and the active mass. Antimony segregates at the surface and diffuses into the bulk of the active mass.

Authors: Wallace Gorman L.
Title: Solar one demolition and remediation
Affiliations: Southern California Edison Co, Rosemead, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wallace, Gorman L., Southern California Edison Co, Rosemead, United States
Abstract: Solar One was designed to demonstrate the feasibility of generating electrical energy from solar power using a central receiver concept. Although Solar One was successful, the oil-based Thermal Storage System (TSS), used to store heat energy for power generation at night, was not efficient. When the TSS was demolished for the installation of a more efficient molten salt system, a major effort was made to salvage or recycle all of its equipment and materials.

Authors: Stewart Jr. William E., Gute G.Douglas, Saunders Charles K.
Title: Ice-melting and melt water discharge temperature characteristics of packed ice beds for rectangular storage tanks
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart Jr., William E., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Gute, G.Douglas, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Saunders, Charles K., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: An experimental study was performed to model the melting behavior of a porous bed of ice in a rectangular storage tank. The ice and the storage tank were characterized by the dimensions of the tank, the ice particle geometry, the geometry of the ice store, the initial water level, and the inlet water distribution. Inlet water distributions were from above the tank, through either one or more individual rectangular openings, above the ice and smaller than the plan area of the tank, or by a nearly uniform distribution of inlet water through an inlet of the same dimensions as the tank plan area. The water outlet was located along the perimeter along the bottom of the tank. Using a laboratory-scale cool thermal energy storage tank, the effect on outlet water temperature was determined by varying the inlet water temperature, the inlet flow rate, the inlet water distribution, and the ice store geometry. The results of the study indicate that an approximately constant outlet water temperature near 0°C (32°F) is achieved by using a uniform inlet water distribution over the plan area of the tank. The uniform inlet water distribution yields a nearly constant heat transfer and ice-melting rate throughout the period of ice melt in the storage tank, with only a small increase in the outlet water temperature.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Heat transfer; Melting; Packed beds; Porous materials; Tanks (containers); Temperature; Water levels; Ice melting; Ice melting rate; Inlet water distribution; Melt water discharge temperature; Packed ice beds; Ice

Authors: Mornhed Goran, Casten Thomas R.
Title: Innovations in district heating and cooling 1984-1994 and their economic impact
Affiliations: Trigen Energy Corp, White Plains, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mornhed, Goran, Trigen Energy Corp, White Plains, United States; Casten, Thomas R., Trigen Energy Corp, White Plains, United States
Abstract: The period from 1984 to 1994 saw the concept of district heating and cooling revived. Many new district energy systems were established and existing systems expanded. The expansion can be attributed to technical innovations as well as institutional, environmental, and economic changes; no one event can be singled out as a main reason for the improved climate. The district cooling industry in particular, fueled by growing demand and technical innovation, experienced a period of unprecendented expansion. On the surface, the concept of district cooling would appear to be uneconomical. Although economic benefits can be achieved using traditional district cooling technology over individual building systems, the benefits from technical innovations during the last 10 years, such as low-temperature chilled-water storage, trigeneration, variable-speed-drive technology, and automation, have made district cooling more competitive and have contributed to industry growth. On the district heating side, innovations such as low-cost distribution technology and cost-effective cogeneration helped create a renaissance. The improved competitiveness of district heating and cooling has made the combined service attractive for users who now do not need to rely on either in-house heating or cooling plants. Ongoing innovations in the industry set the stage for continued expansion as district heating and cooling - district energy - move into the next century and help improve our urban environment more than ever.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Cogeneration plants; Cooling; Cost effectiveness; Environmental impact; Industrial economics; Plant expansion; Technology; Economic impact; Innovations; Technical innovation; Urban environment; District heating

Affiliations: Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Authors with affiliations: Batra, R.C., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States; Yang, J.S., Virginia Polytechnic Inst and State, Univ, Blacksburg, United States
Abstract: Toupin's version of Saint-Venant's principle in linear elasticity is generalized to the case of linear piezoelectric porous materials. That is, it is shown that, for a straight prismatic bar made of a linear piezoelectric material with voids and loaded by a self-equilibrated system of forces at one end only, the internal energy stored in the portion of the bar which is beyond a distance s from the loaded end decreases exponentially with the distance s.

Title: Optical proximity correction on attenuated phase-shifting photo mask for dense contact array
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Abstract: The application of attenuated PSM to dense contact array is restricted by intense optical interference of sidelobe peaks around hole pattern which is called proximity effect. In order to reduce the effect of proximity, it is necessary to optimize the transmittance of mask field and the exposing energy which cause mask bias. The vast of data are required for doing above job. Using simulation, however, by sidelobe, E- D curves can not be used directly to find the depth of focus. The criterion for sidelobe was defined to find process window from E-D curve. To reduce sidelobe in dense contact hole array, the auxiliary patterns were placed between holes. By simulations and experiments, attenuated PSM with auxiliary pattern could be applied effectively to the dense contact hole of 64MDRAM.

Authors: Weiner Maurice, Kingsley Lawrence E., Burke Terrence, Fonda Kevin, Youmans Robert J., Singh Hardev, Pastore Jr. Robert A.
Title: Modeling of fast conductivity phenomena in semiconductors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Weiner, Maurice, U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA; Kingsley, Lawrence E., U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA; Burke, Terrence, U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA; Fonda, Kevin, U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA; Youmans, Robert J., U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA; Singh, Hardev, U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA; Pastore Jr., Robert A., U.S. Army Research Lab., Fort, Monmouth, NJ, USA
Abstract: A simple transmission line model, which seeks to explain fast conductivity phenomena in semiconductors, such as photoconductivity or avalanching (induced by either light or displacement current waves), is proposed. The model relies on breaking up the semiconductor drift space into small cells, each of which contains an imaginary transmission line element so as to allow an electromagnetic wave to propagate away from the generated plasma. The same transmission line may be used to convey light energy produced in the semiconductor. The transmission line also serves as the energy storage element. Time varying nodal resistors, located at the transmission line junctions, control the conductivity. The nodal resistors embody the physics of the semiconductor, whereas the transmission line matrix accounts for energy spread. Slower semiconductor mechanisms, such as carrier drift, may be easily incorporated into the formalism, if necessary. The model points out the importance of triggering either an avalanche or displacement current wave in regions where the static field is high. Under certain conditions the model predicts a growing electromagnetic wave with sufficient amplitude to sustain avalanching.
Index Keywords: Electric conductivity; Optoelectronic devices; Photoconductivity; Semiconductor device models; Avalanching; Semiconductor conductivity; Transmission line models; Transmission line theory

Authors: Lachs W.R., Sutanto D.
Title: Application of battery energy storage in power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Power Electronics and Drive Systems
Affiliations: Univ of New South Wales, Sydney
Authors with affiliations: Lachs, W.R., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney; Sutanto, D., Univ of New South Wales, Sydney
Abstract: The key control elements of power systems are relatively slow mechanical devices, turbo-generator governors, transformer tap changers and circuit breaker contacts. Power system engineers have done a remarkable job developing a highly automated power system control with these constraints. However the evolution of more extensive interconnected power systems has made the transmission grid into the critical superstructure which is increasingly being disrupted by severe disturbances, causing extensive blackouts. The introduction of power electronics, microprocessors, energy storage and communications technology to supplement the mechanical devices and permit faster responses could provide better emergency control and so extend the capabilities of the existing transmission grid as well as providing savings.

Authors: Goodger E.M.
Title: Jet fuels development and alternatives
Source title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Goodger, E.M., School of Mechanical Engineering, Cranfield University, United Kingdom
Abstract: The jet engine group comprises aero turbines, ramjets and rockets, their level of performance increasing in that order, with fuel requirements showing both similarities and differences. The conventional fuel for aero turbine engines, for example, is aviation kerosine, several variants of which exist for specific applications. Aviation fuel specifications are invariably stringent, and variations with density are shown for typical properties. The dwindling availability of optimal crudes over the last 25 years has resulted in a general degradation in the quality of aviation kerosine, with adverse effects on combustion performance, emissions and engine life except where hardware solutions emerged in parallel. In fact, the reduction of emissions is seen to be more a matter of engine design than fuel technology. In the near term, supplies of kerosine may be supplemented from sources other than crude oil, whereas in the longer term, kerosine may be substituted by liquid methane and/or liquid hydrogen. In comparison with kerosine, liquid hydrogen produces more nitrogen in its combustion products on a fuel mass basis, but less on an energy basis, although the flame temperature is higher giving possibilities of more NO x. The fuel requirements of high energy content and storage stability apply across the board, but additional parameters of concern are heat capacity in the case of ramjets, and combustion-product chemistry with rockets, which demand a range of candidate high-performance fuels. © 1995, Institution of Mechanical Engineers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: aero gas turbines; alternative fuels; aviation; jet fuels; ramjets; rockets

Authors: Dasigenis Aris Theodor, Garcia-San Pedro Adolfo Reig
Title: Real-time hydro coordination and economic hydro optimization
Source title: IEEE Power Industry Computer Applications Conference
Affiliations: Network Management Technology, Inc, Sugar Land, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dasigenis, Aris Theodor, Network Management Technology, Inc, Sugar Land, United States; Garcia-San Pedro, Adolfo Reig, Network Management Technology, Inc, Sugar Land, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses the real-time aspects of the Hydro-Thermal Coordination problem. It describes the real-time modeling and monitoring of hydro resources, and the use of the resulting real-time hydraulic data in the on-line Economic Dispatch algorithm. A variable head, hydro loss model is incorporated that allows for on-line changes to the hydro topology. The method presented provides the operator with a current view of the available water resources, enables the validation of the real-time hydro data received from the field, and enables real-time optimization of the Hydro-Thermal Unit Commitment plan. The implementation of this approach on the Iberdrola system in Spain is described.

Authors: Kawashima Minoru, Dorgan Charles E., Mitchell John W.
Title: Hourly thermal load prediction for the next 24 hours by Arima, Ewma, LR, and an artificial neural network
Affiliations: Shimizu Corp, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kawashima, Minoru, Shimizu Corp, Tokyo, Japan; Dorgan, Charles E., Shimizu Corp, Tokyo, Japan; Mitchell, John W., Shimizu Corp, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Predicting the thermal load for the next 24 hours is essential for optimal control of heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems that use thermal cool storage. It can be useful in minimizing costs and energy in nonstorage systems. A cooperative research project between a U.S. university and a Japanese corporation investigated four generally used prediction methods to examine the basic models with variations and to compare the accuracy of each model. A cooling and heating seasonal data set with known next-day weather was used to evaluate the accuracy of each prediction method. The results indicate that an artificial neural network (ANN) model produces the most accurate thermal load predictions. After the initial comparisons with a computer-generated data set, the ANN model was applied to two measured building loads from another research project. These sets included typical measurement noise related to continuous field monitoring. The predictions of the next-day cooling load using the ANN prediction model were close to the actual data, even when the next-day weather was forecast. This confirms that the ANN model has sufficient accuracy and is the correct method for practical utilization in HVAC system control, thermal storage optimal control, and load/demand management.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Computer applications; Cooling; Energy conservation; Energy management; Forecasting; Heat storage; Heating; Mathematical models; Neural networks; Optimal control systems; Ventilation; Computer generated data sets; Measurement noise; Thermal cool storage; Thermal load

Authors: Hahne J.J., Herbst J.H., Upshaw J.L.
Title: Fabrication and Testing of a 30 mm and 90 mm Laminated, High L' Railgun Designed and Built at CEM-UT
Affiliations: Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hahne, J.J., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Herbst, J.H., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States; Upshaw, J.L., Center for Electromechanics The University of Texas at Austin BRC, Mail Code 77000 Austin, TX 78712, United States
Abstract: With the emphasis on moving railgun technology from a laboratory based setting out into the field, a new lighter weight and stiff railgun structure was designed at the Center for Electromechanics at The University of Texas at Austin (CEM-UT). This innovative design takes advantage of stainless steel laminations with a composite overwrap to provide radial and longitudinal support for the rail/insulator package. The goal of this design effort was to build a 90 mm bore gun with a 9 MJ muzzle energy and provide comparable stiffness to the hydraulically pre stressed 90 mm railgun at CEM-UT. The fabrication phase involved building a 90 mm x 7 m long railgun in conjunction with a 30 mm x 3 m sub-scale version for performance testing up to full design loads. The 30 mm subscale launcher has been successfully tested at CEM-UT up to its full current rating of 1.0 MA. With the outstanding results from the 30 mm sub-scale gun, the full scale 90 mm gun was completed and sent to the U.S. Army's Armament Research, Development, and Engineering Center (ARDEC) for testing while the skid mounted power supply is completed. A new and improved version of the original 30 mm subscale launcher was also designed and built by CEM upon request by U.S. Army ARDEC. This new design improved fabrication techniques as well as made the gun more durable for laboratory testing. The updated 30 mm railgun was also sent to U.S. Army ARDEC to be fired on their capacitor bank power supply. This paper discusses the problems encountered during the final assembly of the 90 mm skid gun and how these difficulties were overcome. The paper also discusses the successful testing to full load of a 30 mm one-third scale version of the 90 mm gun. The paper concludes with a brief discussion on an additional 30 mm laminated gun which was redesigned based on experience with the previous laminated gun assemblies. This gun was fabricated and sent to U.S. Amy ARDEC for testing in their facility. © 1995 IEEE
