Title: Thermal degradation of poly(ethyleneglycol)
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Ewha Womens University, 11-1 Daehyun-dong, Seodaemoon-goo, Seoul, South Korea; Department of Polymer Engineering, Chungnam National University, 220 Goong-dong, Yoosong-goo, Taejeon, 305-764, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Han, S., Department of Chemistry, Ewha Womens University, 11-1 Daehyun-dong, Seodaemoon-goo, Seoul, South Korea; Kim, C., Department of Polymer Engineering, Chungnam National University, 220 Goong-dong, Yoosong-goo, Taejeon, 305-764, South Korea; Kwon, D., Department of Chemistry, Ewha Womens University, 11-1 Daehyun-dong, Seodaemoon-goo, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: The thermal degradation of poly(ethyleneglycol) (PEG) with an average molecular weight of 4000 has been investigated from the point of view of developing PEG as a phase change material in thermal energy storage. The PEG was maintained at 80 °C for 1000 h in air and in vacuo. It was severely degraded in air; the melting point and heat of fusion were reduced by as much as 13 °C and 32 kJ/kg, respectively. In vacuo, however, almost no degradation was observed. Both the fresh and degraded PEG samples were examined by thermal and spectroscopic methods. The results suggest that the thermal degradation of PEG in air follows a random chain scission oxidation mechanism. This was confirmed by adding an antioxidant which successfully suppressed the degradation. © 1995.
Index Keywords: Addition reactions; Antioxidants; Melting; Molecular weight; Oxidation; Pyrolysis; Spectroscopy; Thermoanalysis; Heat of fusion; Melting point; Random chain scission oxidation mechanism; Thermal degradation; Thermal energy storage; Polyethylene glycols

Authors: Stewart Jr. William E., Gute G.Douglas, Saunders Charles K., Chandrasekharan Jay
Title: Development of a design procedure for thermal storage tanks utilizing technologies that separate the manufacture of ice from the storage of ice
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart Jr., William E., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Gute, G.Douglas, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Saunders, Charles K., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Chandrasekharan, Jay, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: This paper summarizes the results of ASHRAE research project RP-707, which concerned the development of numerical models to describe the geometry and quantity of ice filling a rectangular storage tank, the ice-melting behavior of particulate ice stored in the tank, and the experimental verification of the results as predicted by the numerical models. The development of the filling of a storage tank with particulate ice resulted in the code ICEPAC. The numerical models for establishing the ice-melting process are based on finite-difference methods of solving the Navier-Stokes equations governing the three-dimensional flow of melt water through the water in the tank. This part of the project resulted in the development of two codes, MSOLA and MELTCONTROL, which are executable on an appropriately equipped personal computer. The scale-model laboratory experiments were performed using a 1.2-m-wide by 2.4-m-long by 1.2-m-high rectangular tank. The results of the ICEPAC software were used as input data to the ice-melting software. The results of the ice-melting numerical simulations compare well with the experimental data for water level, exit water temperature, and quantity of remaining ice mass. The models are applicable to particulate ice of a size much smaller than the dimensions of the storage tank, a bottom perimeter water outlet from the tank, rectangular storage tanks with up to four ice openings, and for either ice opening melt water flows or uniformly distributed melt water flows over the plan area of the storage tank.
Index Keywords: Computer software; Finite difference method; Flow of water; Geometry; Heat storage; Ice; Mathematical models; Melting; Navier Stokes equations; Personal computers; Tanks (containers); Three dimensional; Ice manufacture; Ice melting; Ice melting software; Ice storage; Numerical models; Software Package ICEPAC; Software Package MELTCONTROL; Software Package MSOLA; Thermal storage tanks; Energy storage

Authors: Lederer Thomas, Rabus Hans, Scholze Frank, Thornagel R., Ulm Gerhard
Title: Detector calibration at the radiometry laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische-Bundesanstalt in the VUV and soft x-ray spectral ranges using synchrotron radiation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Physikalisch-Technische, Bundesanstalt, Berlin, Ger
Authors with affiliations: Lederer, Thomas, Physikalisch-Technische, Bundesanstalt, Berlin, Ger; Rabus, Hans, Physikalisch-Technische, Bundesanstalt, Berlin, Ger; Scholze, Frank, Physikalisch-Technische, Bundesanstalt, Berlin, Ger; Thornagel, R., Physikalisch-Technische, Bundesanstalt, Berlin, Ger; Ulm, Gerhard, Physikalisch-Technische, Bundesanstalt, Berlin, Ger
Abstract: In the vacuum ultraviolet and soft x-ray spectral ranges the radiometry laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt at the synchrotron radiation facility BESSY offers two different methods for the calibration of radiation detectors. The electron storage ring BESSY, in combination with suitable monochromators, reproducible produces monochromatic radiation of tunable photon energy, high spectral purity, and high radiant power which can be reduced by twelve orders of magnitude. With this source of monochromatic radiation a cryogenic electrical substitution radiometer (ESR) is operated as a primary detector standard in the photon energy range from 3 eV to 1500 eV. The ESR is optimized for synchrotron radiation, capable of measuring radiant power in the order of some μW with an uncertainty below 0.2%. Radiation detectors can be calibrated against the ESR with uncertainties well below 1%. Recent progress in this field will be demonstrated for the calibration of photodiodes. The electron storage ring BESSY is also used as a primary source standard, in the photon energy range from the infrared to the soft x-ray range. The spectral and spatial distribution of the broadband radiation, emitted in the range from 1 eV to 15 keV, is calculable from the known storage ring parameters with uncertainties from 0.04% to 0.35%, respectively. This allows the detection efficiency of energy-dispersive detectors such as solid-state detectors, charge- coupled devices, and others to be determined, provided the detector response function to monochromatic radiation is measured as well.
Index Keywords: Calibration; Radiation detectors; Radiometry; Synchrotron radiation; Ultraviolet spectroscopy; X ray spectroscopy; Soft X rays; Ultraviolet detectors; X ray detectors; Detectors

Authors: Elasser Ahmed, Torrey David A.
Title: Soft switching active snubbers for dc/dc converters
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC
Affiliations: Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, United States
Authors with affiliations: Elasser, Ahmed, Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, United States; Torrey, David A., Rensselaer Polytechnic Inst, Troy, United States
Abstract: A soft switching active snubber is proposed to reduce the turn-off losses of the IGBT in a current-mode controlled buck converter. The soft switching snubber provides zero-voltage switching for the IGBT, thereby reducing the high turn-off losses of the IGBT due to the current tailing. The proposed snubber uses an auxiliary switch to discharge the snubber capacitor. This auxiliary switch also operates at zero-voltage and zero-current switching. The size of the auxiliary switch compared to the main switch makes this snubber a good alternative to the conventional snubber or even to passive low-loss snubbers. The use of the soft switching active snubber permits the IGBT to operate at high frequencies, with low EMI and an improved RBSOA. The use of an active snubber allows recovery of part of the energy stored in the snubber capacitor during the turn-off. Finally, a generic snubber cell is identified for all the non-isolated dc/dc converters (buck, boost, buck-boost, Cuk, Sepic, Zeta).
Index Keywords: Capacitor storage; Electric converters; Electric currents; Electric losses; Electric power factor correction; Electric switches; Semiconductor devices; Switching functions; Auxiliary switch; Snubber capacitor; Soft switching active snubbers; Zero current switching; Zero voltage switching; Switching circuits

Authors: Hasan A.R., Kabir C.S., Wang X.
Title: Development and application of a wellbore/reservoir simulator for testing oil wells
Source title: Proceedings of the Middle East Oil Show
Affiliations: Univ of North Dakota
Authors with affiliations: Hasan, A.R., Univ of North Dakota; Kabir, C.S., Univ of North Dakota; Wang, X., Univ of North Dakota
Abstract: A comprehensive coupled wellbore/reservoir simulator was developed to study the behavior of a single-phase oil flow in the wellbore. The wellbore was modeled numerically in which mass, momentum, and energy of the fluid were conserved, while the reservoir fluid flow was treated analytically. Energy transport occurred through the tubular, cement sheaths, and the formation by conduction. However, both conductive and convective heat transport mechanisms were operative for the annular fluid. Heat losses through seawater and air were also modeled for a well producing in an offshore environment.
Index Keywords: Flow of fluids; Heat conduction; Heat convection; Heat losses; Heat storage; Mathematical models; Oil well production; Petroleum reservoirs; Seawater; Sensitivity analysis; Thermal conductivity of liquids; Well pressure; Wellhead pressure (WHP); Wellhead temperature (WHT); Oil well testing

Authors: Louthan Jr. M.R., Peacock Jr. H.B., Iyer N.C., Sindelar R.L.
Title: Transitioning aluminum clad spent fuels from wet to interim dry storage
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Authors with affiliations: Louthan Jr., M.R., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States; Peacock Jr., H.B., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States; Iyer, N.C., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States; Sindelar, R.L., Westinghouse Savannah River Co, Aiken, United States
Abstract: Continued corrosion, coupled with the age of existing wet storage facilities and the cost of continuing basin operations, including necessary upgrades to meet current facility standards, may force the Department of Energy (DOE) to transform these wet stored aluminum clad spent fuels to interim dry storage. This transition will require a sequence of drying and canning operations which will include selected fuel preparations such as vacuum drying and conditioning of the storage atmosphere. It was also demonstrated that successful interim dry storage may also require the use of fuel and canister cleaning or rinsing techniques that preclude the potential for the accumulation of chloride and other potentially deleterious ions in the dry storage environment.
Index Keywords: Aluminum alloys; Aluminum corrosion; Corrosion resistance; Nuclear fuel cladding; Radioactive waste disposal; Spent fuels; Aluminum clad spent fuels; Deleterious ions; Interim dry storage; Storage atmosphere; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Byler Eric A.
Title: Navigation, behaviors, and control modes in an autonomous vehicle
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Astronautics Group,, Denver, CO, USA
Authors with affiliations: Byler, Eric A., Martin Marietta Astronautics Group,, Denver, CO, USA
Abstract: An Intelligent Mobile Sensing System (IMSS) has been developed for the automated inspection of radioactive and hazardous waste storage containers in warehouse facilities at Department of Energy sites. A 2D space of control modes was used that provides a combined view of reactive and planning approaches wherein a 2D situation space is defined by dimensions representing the predictability of the agent's task environment and the constraint imposed by its goals. In this sense selection of appropriate systems for planning, navigation, and control depends on the problem at hand. The IMSS vehicle navigation system is based on a combination of feature based motion, landmark sightings, and an a priori logical map of the mockup storage facility. Motion for the inspection activities are composed of different interactions of several available control modes, several obstacle avoidance modes, and several feature identification modes. Features used to drive these behaviors are both visual and acoustic.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Inspection; Motion planning; Navigation systems; Radioactive wastes; Automated inspection; Feature based motion; Feature identification; Intelligent mobile sensing system; Landmark sightings; Obstacle avoidance; Mobile robots

Authors: Willliams Jeffrey R., Clark James R.
Title: Multi-purpose canister project
Source title: High Level Radioactive Waste Management - Proceedings of the Annual International Conference
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Willliams, Jeffrey R., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States; Clark, James R., U.S. Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: The U.S. Department of Energy's (DOE) Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM) has investigated various container systems for handling, transporting, storing, and disposing of spent nuclear fuel (SNF) assemblies in its Civilian Radioactive Waste Management System (CRWMS). The primary goal of DOE's investigations was to select a container technology that could integrate and standardize the handling of the vast majority of commercial SNF at a reasonable cost, while providing flexibility and ensuring the safety of the public and protecting the environment. Several alternative cask and canister concepts were evaluated for SNF assembly packaging to determine the most suitable concept. Of these alternatives, the multi-purpose canister (MPC)-based subsystem, as depicted in Figure 1, was determined to be the most suitable. Based on the results of these evaluations, the decision was made to proceed with design and certification of the MPC subsystem. A decision whether to fabricate and deploy MPCs will be made after further studies and the preparation of an environmental impact statement. This presentation summarizes the status of the MPC Project and related activities that have occurred since the 1994 IHLWM.
Index Keywords: Containers; Environmental protection; Radioactive waste disposal; Radioactive waste transportation; Safe handling; Spent fuels; Multi purpose canister project; Spent nuclear fuel (SNF); Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Chaala A., Kapoor M.P., Benallal B., Gulmissarian T.G.
Title: Stability and rheological properties of carbon black feedstocks
Affiliations: Laval University. Chemical Engineering Department, Ste-Foy., Quebec. G1K 7P4, Canada; Akad. Nefti i Gas named I.M.Gubkin, Petroleum and Gas department, 65 Leninsky Prospect, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Chaala, A., Laval University. Chemical Engineering Department, Ste-Foy., Quebec. G1K 7P4, Canada, Akad. Nefti i Gas named I.M.Gubkin, Petroleum and Gas department, 65 Leninsky Prospect, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kapoor, M.P., Laval University. Chemical Engineering Department, Ste-Foy., Quebec. G1K 7P4, Canada; Benallal, B., Laval University. Chemical Engineering Department, Ste-Foy., Quebec. G1K 7P4, Canada; Gulmissarian, T.G., Laval University. Chemical Engineering Department, Ste-Foy., Quebec. G1K 7P4, Canada
Abstract: The colloidal properties of carbon black feedstock from different origins (petroleum and coal) which may directly influence the carbon black quality have been investigated. The effect of feedstock asphaltenes on their colloidal stability on processing (storage, transportation and treatment) is summarized. A possible relationship between incompatibility of feedstock and structure-mechanical resistance is defined using a stability factor as a consolidated measure of capacity of dispersive system. The physical and mechanical effects are found to be pronounced at a particular phase change temperature state and leads to deformation of the structural system. A correlation between viscous flow activation energy and the stability factor is established and the colloidal stability of the system is defined. Copyright © 1995 by Marcel Dekker, Inc.
Author Keywords: asphaltenes; Carbon black; colloidal stability; rheological properties

Authors: Akhil Abbas
Title: Trends and status of battery energy storage for utility applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Akhil, Abbas, Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: There has been a steady effort to introduce batteries to the electric utility industry for large-scale energy storage in a load leveling mode. Utilities, however, have been relatively indifferent to this technology for a number of technical and institutional reasons, those primarily involving the economic viability of this technology in the load leveling mode. Today, due to analytical studies as well as changes in hardware design practice, batteries are being promoted for a wider range of high-value applications that go beyond load leveling, and potentially affect the transmission and distribution as well as customer-side operations of the utility. As a result, utilities are showing a renewed interest in battery energy storage and several utilities are evaluating battery energy storage projects.
Index Keywords: Electric frequency control; Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Electric power generation; Electric power transmission; Electric substations; Electric utilities; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Battery energy storage; Large scale energy storage; Load leveling mode; On site power quality enhancement; Storage capacity; Electric batteries

Authors: Corey Garth P.
Title: Development and testing of the AC battery system
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Corey, Garth P., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: In 1990, the Department of Energy tasked Sandia National Laboratories with the responsibility for technical oversight on a development contract awarded to Omnion Power Engineering, Inc. of East Troy, Wisconsin. Sandia assumed responsibility for managing the development and testing of the AC Battery prototype in collaboration with Omnion. The AC Battery is designed to provide up to 250 kW of power, 167 kWh of energy, on a single charge, and to provide up to 200 deep cycle discharges using 384 off-the-shelf, lead acid marine batteries. The unique features of the system and the most recent field testing results are reported in this paper.

Authors: Licht Stuart
Title: Reduction of non-traditional aluminum salts for novel aluminum batteries
Source title: Light Metals: Proceedings of Sessions, TMS Annual Meeting (Warrendale, Pennsylvania)
Affiliations: Clark Univ, Worcester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Licht, Stuart, Clark Univ, Worcester, United States
Abstract: Aluminum has the voltage, cost and capacity characteristics of a suitable material for batteries. An overview of the behavior of several new high capacity electrochemical storage systems based on aluminum metal anodes and a variety of cathodes including sulfur, ferrocyanide and permanganate cathodes is presented. Discharge of the batteries can result in non-traditional aluminum(III) salts, and the recovery of aluminum by reduction of these salts will be an important aspect of these cells. Traditionally the Hall-Heroult process had been used for reduction of aluminum and recovery of aluminum oxide, but several processes by reduction of aluminum sulfide have been previously explored. These alternate methods are not only relevant to aluminum production, but also to aluminum electrochemical energy storage and are reviewed.
Index Keywords: Aluminum metal anodes; Aluminum sulfide; Electrochemical storage systems; Energy density; Hall-heroult process; Nontraditional aluminum salts; Solution phase redox couples; Alumina; Anodes; Capacitance; Cathodes; Electric batteries; Energy storage; Metal recovery; Reduction; Aluminum

Authors: Nett J., Gernandt L.
Title: Inductive Acceleration of Moving Projectiles and Synchronization between the Driving Field and the Projectile Motion
Affiliations: French-German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général-Cassagnou, 68301 SAINT LOUIS CEDEX, France
Authors with affiliations: Nett, J., French-German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général-Cassagnou, 68301 SAINT LOUIS CEDEX, France; Gernandt, L., French-German Research Institute of Saint-Louis (ISL) 5 rue du Général-Cassagnou, 68301 SAINT LOUIS CEDEX, France
Abstract: One of the main problems of multistage induction launchers is the synchronization between the fields of the stator coils and the projectile motion. Numerical calculations with a simulation code as well as experiments to accelerate projectiles with initial velocities up to 500 m/s, carried out in a small calibre test launcher with a gas gun as preaccelerator and a single electromagnetic stage, showed the importance of the correct timing of the stator coil current in relation to the projectile position and velocity. Some typical test results are reported, discussed and compared with results of numerical simulation. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Matyac M.J., Christopher F., Jamison K.A., Persad C., Marshall R.A.
Title: Railgun Performance Enhancement from Distribution of Energy Feeds
Affiliations: Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate (WL/MNAA), Eglin AFB, FL 32542, United States; Science Applications International Corporation, Shalimar FL 32579, United States; Institute for Advanced Technology, Austin TX 78759, United States
Authors with affiliations: Matyac, M.J., Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate (WL/MNAA), Eglin AFB, FL 32542, United States; Christopher, F., Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate (WL/MNAA), Eglin AFB, FL 32542, United States; Jamison, K.A., Science Applications International Corporation, Shalimar FL 32579, United States; Persad, C., Institute for Advanced Technology, Austin TX 78759, United States; Marshall, R.A., Institute for Advanced Technology, Austin TX 78759, United States
Abstract: Both simple and complex railgun simulation codes predict improved railgun performance when the electrical energy feed points are distributed along the length of the rail pair. The work reported here is an experimental investigation to measure and quantify this enhancement for a 25 mm square-bore railgun using a solid metal armature. A test-bed railgun was designed to accept power feed at the breech and at any down bore location. The gun was powered by a 4.8 MJ capacitor bank that consists of 12 independently triggered modules. A test series that includes 16 shots with peak currents between 410 and 620 kA and projectile exit velocities between 23 and 3.0 km/s was completed for this study. This paper describes the railgun, the test series, and the data reduction techniques used to compare performance between breech fed and distributed energy feed point configurations. The compiled results support the theoretical prediction that a distributed energy feed railgun is more efficient than the simple breech fed configuration. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Babakov Y.P., Plekhanov A.V., Zheleznyi V.B.
Title: Range and Railgun Development Results at Ls&Pa “Soyuz”
Affiliations: “Energophyzika” Department of Lyubertsy Scientific and Production Association “Soyuz”, Sovetskaya st. 6, Dzerzhinskiy town, Moscow region, 140056, Russian Federation

Abstract: In the department “Energophyzika” LS&PA “Soyuz” range was created. It was equipped with an inductor with storage capacity up to 12.5 MJ energized by a solid propellant MHD generator and a capacitor bank (energy capacity up to 6 MJ). These systems deliver currents of 1 MA and 2 MA, respectively. Diagnostic, recording, and auto-calculation systems allow use of as many as 120 data channels with acquisition frequency up to 10 MHz. Recent technical successes in railgun construction, using special methods to compact plasma armature and produce high velocity trailing contact, creation of hybrid armatures, and optimizing acceleration made possible to gain velocities in the range of 6.2 to 6.8 km/s (masses of 3.8 to 10 g) and velocities 2.7 to 3.8 km/s (masses of 50 to 100 g) on railguns with length 2 to 4 m. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Emelin P.Y., Fridman B.E., Rutberg P.G.
Title: Application of Programmable Discharge of Capacitive Energy Store for Current Pulse Forming in Railgun and Electrodischarge Launcher
Affiliations: Russian Academy of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Emelin, P.Y., Russian Academy of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Fridman, B.E., Russian Academy of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Rutberg, P.G., Russian Academy of Sciences, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: This paper describes the pulse formation of a programmable multi-stage pulsed power supply for electric railguns. This power supply allows optimal operation of the railgun by maintaining a near constant acceleration force over the launch period. This constant force is gained by matching the voltage of the power supply to the variable inductance and resistance of the launcher. A way to estimate the load inductance is presented in this paper. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Dick W.J., Goldman E.B., Johnson R.F.
Title: Analysis of Components in Advanced Capacitive Pulse Forming Networks for Electric Guns
Affiliations: United Defense L.P., 4800 East River Road, Minneapolis, MN 55421, United States; Consultant, 6253 Ridgemont Dr., Oakland, CA 94619, United States; United Defense L.P., 4800 East River Road, Minneapolis, MN 55421, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dick, W.J., United Defense L.P., 4800 East River Road, Minneapolis, MN 55421, United States; Goldman, E.B., Consultant, 6253 Ridgemont Dr., Oakland, CA 94619, United States; Johnson, R.F., United Defense L.P., 4800 East River Road, Minneapolis, MN 55421, United States
Abstract: The development of high density, volume efficient capacitive pulse forming networks (PFNs), designed to maximize electrical energy transferred to the gun, is critical for the future weaponization of both electro/thermo-chemical and electromagnetic launchers. This work presents some design considerations for a fieldable PFN/launcher system. Three high efficiency designs (between 40% and 60%) incorporating series and parallel augmented launchers are described. The energy storage requirements and efficiencies for these systems are given. The PFN masses and volumes of these systems are calculated using state of the art component technology. Extrapolated values for component technologies frozen in the years 1997 and 2007 are used to determine the anticipated PFN mass and volume for each of the three systems. These values fall short of the design goals of the Electromagnetic Focused Technology Demonstrator (EMFTD) program without an aggressive technology development program for capacitors. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Augsburger B., Smith B., McNab I.R., Chen Y.G., Hewkin D., Vance K., Disley C.
Title: Royal Ordnance 2.4 MJ Multi-Module Capacitor Bank
Affiliations: Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; British Aerospace Defense, Royal Ordnance, Kings Meadow Rd., Nottingham, NG2 1EQ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Augsburger, B., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Smith, B., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; McNab, I.R., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Chen, Y.G., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue, San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Hewkin, D., British Aerospace Defense, Royal Ordnance, Kings Meadow Rd., Nottingham, NG2 1EQ, United Kingdom; Vance, K., British Aerospace Defense, Royal Ordnance, Kings Meadow Rd., Nottingham, NG2 1EQ, United Kingdom; Disley, C., British Aerospace Defense, Royal Ordnance, Kings Meadow Rd., Nottingham, NG2 1EQ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Maxwell Laboratories Inc. has designed and manufactured a 2.4 MJ multi-module capacitor bank to be used for the investigation of ETC technologies. The system was installed and accepted at the Royal Ordnance (R.O.) Faldingworth facility during the fall of 1993. This paper will discuss the pulsed power system design and typical test data acquired during manufacturing testing. The 2.4 MJ system is comprised of eight independent 300 kJ modules with a dual operating voltage of 11 kV and 22 kV, both voltages capable of the full 300 kJ energy storage. The capacitor bank modularity provides the user with pulse shaping flexibility by allowing for time-sequence firing of the eight 300 kJ units. The 2.4 MJ system can be operated in 300 kJ increments, allowing the user to control the energy storage volume needed for laboratory type testing. Each 300 kJ module is a stand alone capacitor bank equipped with six Maxwell 11/22 kV 50 kJ capacitors, two parallel output switches (Maxwell Triggered Vacuum Switch, TVS-40), output inductor, trigger generator, energy dumping system, and Maxwell designed fiber optic control circuits. This system was tested to demonstrate the overall electrical performance and power profile flexibility into a resistive load. Data will be presented to show the capacitor bank current output pulse variations, both in single-shot and time-sequence operation. The data will show the advantages of such a capacitor bank for laboratory type experiments and future fieldable energy storage systems. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Wey J., Lehmann P., Peter H.
Title: DES 3 MJ-Railgun experimental results at ISL
Affiliations: ISL, 5 rue du Général Cassagnou 68301 St. Louis, France
Authors with affiliations: Wey, J., ISL, 5 rue du Général Cassagnou 68301 St. Louis, France; Lehmann, P., ISL, 5 rue du Général Cassagnou 68301 St. Louis, France; Peter, H., ISL, 5 rue du Général Cassagnou 68301 St. Louis, France
Abstract: A capacitor bank, consisting of two stages, is used for experiments with a 50 mm round bore railgun at a maximum current of 2 MA. The railgun is fed at two different points in order to test the DES-railgun concept. An appropriate design and material choice of metallic projectiles, accelerated from the rest position, allow the current to be injected at the front side and to be distributed over the whole armature. It is shown that the contact between rails and projectile is maintained with a dominant metallic value and transitioning to plasma arcs has been seen only during short time intervals. Accurate voltage and current measurements allow evaluating of the ohmic losses and energy partition in the whole system. Measured values of rail resistance and inductance gradient are presented and compared to numerical simulations. The results of several shots are presented and compared to theoretical predictions. For a stored energy of 1.96 MJ, an overall efficiency of 21% is obtained with a projectile mass of 437 g accelerated to a velocity of 1370 m/s. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Puterbaugh R.L., Mongeau P.P., Acharya B., Curtiss D.
Title: Pulsed Disk Alternators as Energy Storage Devices for Electrothermal Chemical Guns
Affiliations: Kaman Electromagnetics Corporation, Hudson MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Puterbaugh, R.L., Kaman Electromagnetics Corporation, Hudson MA, United States; Mongeau, P.P., Kaman Electromagnetics Corporation, Hudson MA, United States; Acharya, B., Kaman Electromagnetics Corporation, Hudson MA, United States; Curtiss, D., Kaman Electromagnetics Corporation, Hudson MA, United States
Abstract: Electrothermal Chemical (ETC) guns require pulsed power supplies that deliver energy to the gun breech in the 1 – 5 millisecond regime. The most likely near term application for ETC gun systems is the U. S. Navy 127mm Mark 45 guns. Pulsed Disk Alternators (PDA) constitute a class of flywheel based energy storage devices that are ideally suited to the power levels, time constants and impedance matching needed by ETC guns. As a result of its unique geometry, the PDA has inherently high energy density compared to other energy stores that are under consideration for electric gun systems. PDA system elements and comparisons with capacitor based pulsed power supplies are reviewed. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric currents; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy storage; Geometry; Projectiles; Technology; Velocity; Conventional propellant guns; Electric gun systems; Electrothermal chemical guns; Pulse forming networks; Pulsed disk alternators; Electromagnetic launchers

Authors: Jamison K.A., Stearns R., Matyac M.J., Persad C., Marshall R.A.
Title: Behavior of Multi-tiered Copper Wire, Solid Armatures
Affiliations: Science Applications International Corporation Shalimar, FL 32579, United States; Institute for Advanced Technology, Austin Texas 78759, United States; Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate (WL/MNAA), Eglin, AFB, FL 32542, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jamison, K.A., Science Applications International Corporation Shalimar, FL 32579, United States; Stearns, R., Science Applications International Corporation Shalimar, FL 32579, United States; Matyac, M.J., Institute for Advanced Technology, Austin Texas 78759, United States; Persad, C., Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate (WL/MNAA), Eglin, AFB, FL 32542, United States; Marshall, R.A., Wright Laboratory, Armament Directorate (WL/MNAA), Eglin, AFB, FL 32542, United States
Abstract: Several types of polycarbonate carriers have been designed to support multiple copper wires in a solid armature launch package. The carriers allow for the insertion of conductor wires at different axial locations (tiers) in the launch package and provide initial contact loading between the wires and rails. This study began by investigating the possibility that armature electrical behavior could be obscured by conductive material in front of the primary current carrying elements. As the study progressed it became clear that more current was carried in the forward conductors than originally anticipated. This fact led to more detailed analytical and experimental investigations of insulator bodies equipped with several tiers of conductor wires. A mathematical model of the multi-tiered armature was developed to assist in defining the electrical behavior. A variety of configurations of these launch packages have been tested in a 25 mm railgun powered by a laboratory capacitor bank. The packages maintained low voltage operation while incurring electrical actions that would have melted the conductor wires if all of the current were confined in the rear most tier. The testing, modeling, and analysis of voltage shielding and current sharing are presented along with the test results from several firings of the 25 mm railgun. © 1995 IEEE
Index Keywords: Calculations; Capacitor storage; Electric conductors; Electric currents; Electric insulators; Electric wire; Electronics packaging; Mathematical models; Projectiles; Technology; Velocity; Electric energy guns; Multi tiered copper wire; Muzzle voltage probe; Solid armatures; Voltage shielding; Rail guns

Authors: Cavallo Alfred J., Keck Matthew B.
Title: Cost effective seasonal storage of wind energy
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cavallo, Alfred J., Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States; Keck, Matthew B., Princeton Univ, Princeton, United States
Abstract: Seasonal variation of the wind electric potential on the Great Plains could be a significant obstacle to the large scale utilization of wind generated electricity. Wind power densities usually are greatest during the spring, and decrease by at least 30 percent relative to the annual average in many areas during the summer months, when demand is highest. This problem can be overcome by using an oversized wind farm and a compressed air energy storage system (a baseload wind energy system). A minimum volume storage reservoir is needed to transform intermittent wind energy to baseload power, while a larger reservoir can be used to store excess power produced during the spring for either peak power or baseload output during the summer. The yearly average cost of energy increases by about 3 percent for the largest storage reservoir, indicating that seasonal storage of wind energy is economically as well as technically feasible.
Index Keywords: Compressed air; Cost accounting; Cost effectiveness; Electric energy storage; Electric power generation; Electric power utilization; Baseload power; Compressed air energy storage system; Wind power density; Wind power

Abstract: Transient energy management strategies are introduced via examining chip-on-substrate geometry and evaluating transient thermal management case study on PowerPC based model notebook computer. Cascaded frequency reduction, periodic heating and workload shifting techniques for dynamically controlling chip junction temperature are discussed. Model notebook computer case study indicates that it is possible to improve notebook computer performance dramatically by using high end processor and transient thermal storage cooling techniques.

Authors: Barak J., Adler E., Lifshitz Y., Levinson J.
Title: Detecting heavy ions and protons in space: single-events monitor
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Convention of Electrical & Electronics Engineers in Israel
Affiliations: Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Barak, J., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Adler, E., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Lifshitz, Y., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel; Levinson, J., Soreq NRC, Yavne, Israel
Abstract: The paper describes a single-board ionizing-radiation monitor which uses HM65162 SRAMs as sensors. They are sensitive to single event upsets and latchups, and can thus detect highly ionizing radiation and alarm in case of excess radiation conditions, like heavy solar flares. The monitor is a low cost, low weight (230 grams), extremely low power consumption (<15 μW) unit and is easily implanted in any satellite. It will serve on board of TechSAT, the Technion satellite.

Authors: Touchton George, Cohn Arthur
Title: Energy industry changes: the role of advanced combustion turbine technology
Affiliations: Electric Power Research Inst
Authors with affiliations: Touchton, George, Electric Power Research Inst; Cohn, Arthur, Electric Power Research Inst
Abstract: The Electric Power industry is in transition - where meeting the customer's individual variable power needs will count more than just providing gross kilowatt hours production or some theoretical 'generation mix' criteria. A number of advanced combustion turbine power plants are being developed for this market: the Intercooled Aeroderivative, the Humid Air Turbine/Cascaded Humidified Advanced Turbine, and the Compressed Air Storage with Humidification plants. Combustion turbines for the distributed generation application are also being emphasized. This success of all combustion turbine plants depend on meeting and maintaining the goals of high levels of durability, reliability, and availability. A number of technologies which EPRI has successfully applied that have materially assisted in meeting these goals are outlined.
Index Keywords: Availability; Combustion; Durability; Electric industry; Electric power plants; Reliability; Technology; Cascaded humidified advanced turbine; Combustion turbines; Compressed air storage; Humid air turbine; Intercooled aeroderivative; Turbines

Affiliations: Inst. of Physical-Organic Chemistry, Minsk, Belarus
Authors with affiliations: Agabekov, Vladimir E., Inst. of Physical-Organic Chemistry, Minsk, Belarus; Ignasheva, Olga E., Inst. of Physical-Organic Chemistry, Minsk, Belarus; Gudimenko, Yurii I., Inst. of Physical-Organic Chemistry, Minsk, Belarus; Belyatsky, Vladimir N., Inst. of Physical-Organic Chemistry, Minsk, Belarus
Abstract: The lithographic properties of the vacuum vapor deposited thin films based on the benzo[a]phenoxazine derivatives applied in the `all-dry' lithography process with laser patterning (λ = 266 nm) have been studied. As shown, film sensitivity and resolution, line-edge profile, dry etch resistance and stability under storage and ion implantation depend highly on the chemical structure of the side substitutes. It was found that the treatment of the films with B+ and P+ ions with dose equal to or more than 1.8*1015 ion/cm2 and energy equal to 30 keV results in the formation of thin carbonized surface film layer. Its chemical structure includes phosphorous compounds such as PhP3, (PhO)3PO, (PhO)3P in the case of P+ ion treatment. Modified films display higher dry etch resistance. The fluorination of the vacuum vapor deposited and modified films in C3F∞ plasma is under consideration.

Authors: Tunaboylu N.S., Collins Jr. E.R., Middlekauff S.W., Morgan R.L.
Title: Ride-through issues for DC motor drives during voltage sags
Affiliations: Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tunaboylu, N.S., Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States; Collins Jr., E.R., Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States; Middlekauff, S.W., Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States; Morgan, R.L., Clemson Univ, Clemson, United States
Abstract: Voltage sags are a common occurrence in power systems. Although a typical sag is only 5 to 20 cycles, electronic equipment may fail or 'trip.' A trip of industrial process equipment, such as a motor drive or programmable logic controller, may be extremely costly. Methods to improve the 'ride-through' capability of the equipment usually is a system solution: uninterruptable power supplies, motor-generator sets, etc. Often, only a few of the devices in an industrial process are very sensitive to sags. Therefore, a better solution is to desensitize the components which are affected by sags. Compared to ac variable frequency drives, dc motor drives are particularly susceptible to sags because they inherently lack electrical energy storage devices. The addition of capacitance on the dc-side of the drive will not improve ride-through and can be detrimental to controllability. Examples of dc drive response during sags are shown and methods for de-sensitizing dc motor drives for sag-related problems are discussed.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Controllability; DC motors; Electric energy storage; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Electronic equipment; Programmable logic controllers; Industrial process equipment; Ride through issues; Voltage sags; Electric power systems

Authors: Saito Takashi, Kibi Yukari, Kurata Mitsuyoshi, Tabuchi Junji, Ochi Atsushi

Affiliations: Material Development Cent, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saito, Takashi, Material Development Cent, Japan; Kibi, Yukari, Material Development Cent, Japan; Kurata, Mitsuyoshi, Material Development Cent, Japan; Tabuchi, Junji, Material Development Cent, Japan; Ochi, Atsushi, Material Development Cent, Japan
Abstract: Using newly developed Activated Carbon/Carbon composite (AC/C composite) as polarizable electrode, NEC has developed high-power Electric Double-Layer Capacitors (EDLCs). Ionic mobility of the electrolyte in the porous electrode has been improved by optimizing the thickness and the pore size distribution. High-power EDLCs (5.5 V·47 F, 15 V·15 F) with high rate discharge of 20 A current have been developed. A high-power EDLC (15 V·470 F) with 500 A discharging current has been also fabricated.

Abstract: The deformation behavior of simple and complex crystalline structures is examined by determining how the initial stages of deformation, by the movement of normal dislocations, can lead to energy storage. Several cases of deformed ordered materials are considered. Relaxation processes, as in simple metals, are shown to take place by conventional recovery and recrystallization mechanisms. Some examples in copper and its alloys are considered and the role of alloy hardening by solute or by dispersed particles, of recovery by cross-slip mechanisms, and of recrystallization by diffusional mechanisms examined.

Authors: Getkin A.V., Komar V.K., Shiran N.V., Shlyakhturov V.V., Nesterenko N.P., Krasovitskaya I.M., Kornienko V.V.
Title: Radiation damage of pure and doped KMgF3 crystals
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium & Medical Imaging Conference
Affiliations: Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Getkin, A.V., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Komar, V.K., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Shiran, N.V., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Shlyakhturov, V.V., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Nesterenko, N.P., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Krasovitskaya, I.M., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine; Kornienko, V.V., Inst for Single Crystals, Kharkov, Ukraine
Abstract: The radiation damage nature of pure and doped KMgF3 crystals was studied on the basis of the absorption, emission, excitation and thermoluminescence (TL) spectra. It is shown that the sensitivity of this material to the ionizing irradiation is defined not only own color centers but by the presence of oxygen impurities too. The availability of oxygen in KMgF3 is revealed in additional absorption and emission bands, high temperature (T > 400°C) peaks of TL, UV-energy storage. From the RE doped KMgF3 crystals the most illustrative results were obtained for EuF3 and Eu2O3 doped samples. High emission efficiency corresponds to the f-f transitions in Eu2+ ions and trap's structure is connected as with intrinsic point defects as with oxygen impurity contents. The most intensive TL-peak is at 390°C and in crystals with Eu2O3 it's in many times higher than in those with EuF3. It is shown that KMgF3:Eu2O3 is an effective dosimeter not only for X-ray but for UV-registration too.
Index Keywords: Crystal defects; Crystal impurities; Crystals; Doping (additives); Dosimeters; Europium compounds; Ion implantation; Light absorption; Light emission; Potassium compounds; Rare earths; Thermoluminescence; Europium oxide; Europium trifluoride; Light excitation; Oxygen impurities; Potassium magnesium trifluoride crystals; Rare earth ions; Radiation damage

Authors: Hounslow D.R., Grindley W., Loughlin R.M., Daly J.
Title: Development of a combustion system for a 110 MW CAES plant
Affiliations: Aero & Industrial Technology Ltd, Burnley, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hounslow, D.R., Aero & Industrial Technology Ltd, Burnley, United Kingdom; Grindley, W., Aero & Industrial Technology Ltd, Burnley, United Kingdom; Loughlin, R.M., Aero & Industrial Technology Ltd, Burnley, United Kingdom; Daly, J., Aero & Industrial Technology Ltd, Burnley, United Kingdom
Abstract: The use of stored energy systems is receiving increased attention for power generation and Alabama Electric Co-operative (AEC) have installed a 110 MW Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) plant at McIntosh, Alabama. The plant employs tandem high and low pressure fired expanders with the high pressure combustors operating at 44 atm and the low pressure units at 15 atm. Both are designed to operate with natural gas, or on No. 2 fuel oil, as a standby fuel. This paper describes the development of both the high and low pressure combustors for this unique application, the testing of prototypes at simulated conditions at up to 8 atm using customised test rigs and the definition of a design for application to the plant. Problems encountered during the first three years of operation are described and the solutions to overcome these are also presented.

Authors: Ehlers Jens
Title: Active and semi-active control methods in wave-structure interaction
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering - OMAE
Affiliations: Technical Univ Hamburg-Harburg, Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Ehlers, Jens, Technical Univ Hamburg-Harburg, Hamburg, Germany
Abstract: The rigid body motion of floating platforms can restrict operations like drilling, production, or crane manoeuvring. There are a variety of proposed passive, active, and semi-active motion reduction systems, such as fin and tank stabilizers, variable mooring systems, controlled and uncontrolled air-cushions, perforated pontoons, and columns with gas-spring-like tide tanks. All these methods can be classified according to the energy requirements, the energy absorption, and the energy storages. The theoretical and the experimental results for a semi-active method with open bottom chambers and air valves are presented. Even a quite coarse model leads to a fourth order bilinear equation system to which the classical design methods for linear controllers can not be applied. The numerically computed optimal trajectories can be used as a reference, but because of the computing time, they are still away from real-time applications. A control law determined by minimizing the time derivative of the Lyapunov function yields a very poor system behaviour. A heuristic control which is much more efficient is proposed and investigated. This control law is based on the physical insight and can be expressed by the very simple equations. For the leveling of initial states a comparison with the optimal trajectories and the optimal control signals is carried out. The performance index with the heuristic control law is 150% of the optimal index which is quite low compared with 420% for the Lyapunov type controller.
Index Keywords: Control theory; Energy absorption; Energy storage; Heuristic methods; Linear control systems; Lyapunov methods; Mathematical models; Motion control; Optimal control systems; Valves (mechanical); Air valves; Crane maneuvering; Floating platforms; Heuristic control; Motion reduction systems; Rigid body motion; Wave-structure interaction; Production platforms

Authors: Baldwin Thomas L., Tison Ken
Title: When reliable power is not good enough
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Authors with affiliations: Baldwin, Thomas L.; Tison, Ken
Abstract: Although the electric utility industry has done a good job of minimizing the long term outage, for some industries reliable power is not good enough. At present, the demand for premium quality power is increasing. In this study, the concept of premium quality power as a new technical solution which employs superconducting magnetic energy storage to provide carryover support during temporary disturbances is discussed. In addition, two organizations addressing power quality head-on are also considered.

Abstract: This report describes the background to, the methology used and the results of an air quality study conducted by Tech Environmental, Waltham, Massachusetts, in cooperation with Stone & Webster Management Consultants, Inc., New York City, New York, on behalf of Mt. Hope Hydro, Inc., the developer of the Mt. Hope Waterpower Project (`Mt. Hope' or `Project'). The objective of the study was to investigate Mt. Hope's effect on NOx and other air pollutant emissions from power plants in the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast states and the associated effects on air quality throughout this region. The study results demonstrate that significant air quality benefits will be achieved by introducing Mt. Hope into the regional power supply mix, in particular for the New York/New Jersey metropolitan area.

Title: Progress in large domain HTS levitator fabrication for frictionless bearing applications

Authors with affiliations: Sengupta, S., Superconductive Components, Inc, Columbus, United States; Gaines Jr., J.R., Superconductive Components, Inc, Columbus, United States
Abstract: By introduction of magnetic bearings, the efficiency of the flywheel energy storage (FES) could be raised to a useful level. However, the main drawback of these bearings is costly, elaborate control system which is required to keep them operational. Because of this, passive magnetic bearings involving superconducting materials combined with permanent magnets are considered. Thus, incorporating High temperature superconductor (HTS) bearings with the inertial rims made from high strength composite materials into ultra-high-speed flywheels and combining these new technology motor/generator, energy can be stored and released with very low loss.

Source title: Proceedings - SPE International Heavy Oil Symposium
Affiliations: Alberta Energy and Utilities Board
Authors with affiliations: Sadler, K.W., Alberta Energy and Utilities Board
Abstract: With increased focus on oil sands production to replace conventional oil, the Alberta Energy Utilities Board (EUB) sees bitumen production as playing an increasing role as a secure source of energy supply. The EUB forecast of bitumen production from in situ oil sands projects shows an increase from 21,500 m3/d in 1994 to 33,000 m3/d by the year 2000. This forecast and the historical drilling and production patterns associated with commercial, experimental and primary recovery projects is reviewed. In addition, comments on horizontal drilling activity and the production attributable to horizontal wells are provided.

Authors: Stewart Jr. William E., Gute G.Douglas, Chandrasekharan Jay, Saunders Charles K.
Title: Modeling of the melting process of ice stores in rectangular thermal energy storage tanks with multiple ice openings
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart Jr., William E., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Gute, G.Douglas, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Chandrasekharan, Jay, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Saunders, Charles K., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: A mathematical model and numerical algorithms for simulating the melting of saturated and unsaturated particulate ice stored in a rectangular storage tank is presented. The geometrical shape that is achieved by the ice particles in a closed-loop storage tank, using water in the tank, produced from an ice-maker above the tank uses the program ICEPAC, as reported in a companion paper. The melting behavior of the particulate ice is modeled with the program MELTCONTROL. The program MSOLA is used to establish the computation grid and meltwater flow streamlines for use as input to the program MELTCONTROL. The program MELTCONTROL can be used to predict the total time for the ice to melt, the remaining quantity of ice, and the optimum meltwater inlet flow conditions. Comparative studies can be performed by modeling a range of parameters, such as establishing the differences between ice-opening inlet flows and fully distributed inlet flows and the resulting outlet water temperature. The software developed is operational with a 32-bit Fortran compiler on a personal computer. The numerical predictions are also compared to the results of laboratory-scale experiments, as reported elsewhere. The numerical simulation results are in good agreement with the experimental data.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Melting; Particles (particulate matter); Personal computers; Program compilers; Software engineering; Tanks (containers); Ice maker; Ice openings; Ice storage; Thermal energy storage tanks; Ice

Abstract: Water power is an important part of planning for energy in the Indian subcontinent and Burma. Hydropower projects in the four countries of South Asia: Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and Burma are reviewed, focusing on the challenges of foundation problems, construction in seismic areas, storage in Karstic areas and long-term planning for large and complex water power and multipurpose projects.

Authors: Kilkis I.B., Sapci M.
Title: Computer-aided design of radiant subfloor heating systems
Affiliations: Middle East Technical Univ, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Kilkis, I.B., Middle East Technical Univ, Ankara, Turkey; Sapci, M., Middle East Technical Univ, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Radiant floor heating, with attributes such as decreasing space-conditioning loads, leveling peak loads, and exhibiting a better tie-in capability with heat pumps, is becoming a viable alternative for space heating and cooling in new or existing buildings when a retrofit is required. Generally, the retrofit is performed either by pouring a thin slab over the existing floor with the heating elements embedded in it or by attaching the heating elements to the subfloor from the joist space, if accessible. In this study, a computer program was developed for space heating from the joisted subfloor. Noting the energy storage in the heated floor and exposed building elements, a quasi-steady-state thermal model was employed, justified in practice by either continuous operation with water temperature modulation or intermittent operation with reasonably short off-periods. The algorithm is capable of predicting the required mean water temperature in a hydronic system when the floor construction details, tube spacing and material, heating load, and room characteristics are known. Alternatively, with a given limitation on the supply water temperature, the system can be optimally selected by reviewing and manipulating all the pertinent design variables. This paper explains the model and describes the computer program with a sample design.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Buildings; Computer aided design; Computer software; Cooling; Heat flux; Heat pump systems; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Hot water heating; Space heating; Temperature; Quasi steady state thermal models; Radiant floor heating; Radiant heating

Affiliations: EIC Lab, Norwood, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klein, J.D., EIC Lab, Norwood, United States; Clauson, S.L., EIC Lab, Norwood, United States
Abstract: Metallic perovskite contact layers enable fatigue-resistant ferroelectric memory capacitors to obtained. LaNiO3 films atop (100) LaAlO3 substrates exhibit metallic resistivity over a wide range of temperature and oxygen partial pressure. Subsequent deposition of PZT and LaNiO3 thin films atop LaNiO3/LaAlO3 provides parallel-plate ferroelectric capacitor structures. However, the quality of the PZT thin films cannot be reliably indicated by conventional means such as x-ray diffraction. Optical properties of the PZT layers were examined to discern differences in otherwise similar films. The suitability of Au/LaNiO3/PZT/LaNiO3/LaAlO3 devices for nonvolatile memory applications was surveyed through pulsed voltage testing. Observed 1-second remanent polarization (PR[1 sec]) exceeded 35 μC/cm2. Long-term memory was demonstrated for up to sixteen hours. No decrease in remanent polarization was apparent after more than 2×1010 switching cycles.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Energy gap; Lanthanum compounds; Lead compounds; Optical properties; Perovskite; Polarization; Random access storage; Remanence; Thermal effects; Thin film devices; Titanium oxides; Ferroelectric memory applications; Lanthanum aluminum oxides; Lanthanum nickel oxides; Lead zirconate titanate; Pulsed voltage testing; Ferroelectric devices

Authors: Deng Ed, Cuk Slobodan
Title: Single switch, unity power factor, lamp ballasts
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC
Affiliations: Power Electronics Group, Pasadena, United States
Authors with affiliations: Deng, Ed, Power Electronics Group, Pasadena, United States; Cuk, Slobodan, Power Electronics Group, Pasadena, United States
Abstract: Unity power factor, single active switch ac-to-ac converter topologies based on proper integrations of automatic current shapers and single switch inverters such as Class E converters are presented, which are suitable for lamp ballast applications. Descriptions of desirable mode of operations and the first order analysis are given. The proposed ballasts have the following salient features: unity input power factor and low crest factor lamp current, single active switch reducing circuit complexity, lossless switching, which are verified by the experimental results.

Authors: Appleton Stephen G.
Title: Field dependence of FMR in ferrites and implications for microwave absorber design
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Defence Research Agency, Poole,, Dorset, UK
Authors with affiliations: Appleton, Stephen G., Defence Research Agency, Poole,, Dorset, UK
Abstract: There are numerous potential uses for a microwave absorbent material whose absorption can be modified by an applied stimulus. This paper presents work to exploit the dependence of the microwave properties of ferrites on applied magnetic fields, and to develop such an absorbent material. Ferromagnetic resonance (FMR) is known to result in absorption of incident microwave energy at a characteristic frequency for any given ferrite. The FMR frequency is dependent on the anisotropy field Han, which in turn can be modified by chemical doping. Therefore, ferrite RAMs can be produced to operate at required frequencies through judicious choice of the ferrite. Furthermore, if Han is supplemented by an applied magnetic field Happ, the FMR frequency will be increased by an amount dependent on the strength of Happ and on the sense of anisotropy. The microwave permeability and permittivity spectra of a range of ferrites were measured as functions of Happ, using a vector network analyzer. These were used as input to a computer model for calculating absorber performance, and the effects of bias fields on a variety of absorber designs were predicted. A novel system was developed to apply large fields in test panels, for validating performance predictions.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electromagnetic wave absorption; Ferromagnetic resonance; Magnetic fields; Microwave devices; Network analyzers; Random access storage; Chemical doping; Microwave absorbent materials; Ferrites

Authors with affiliations: Gute, G.Douglas, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Stewart Jr., William E., Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States; Chandrasekharan, Jay, Univ of Missouri, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: The mathematical theory and numerical algorithms necessary to simulate the ice-manufacturing and ice-filling processes for thermal energy storage tanks are presented. They have been implemented within a computer program, entitled ICEPAC, that can be used by thermal energy storage tank designers to (a) minimize the overall dimensions of the tank needed for a given cooling capacity requirement, (b) minimize the overall tank volume left void after the ice-manufacturing process, (c) control the locations of the voids, (d) determine the optimum location(s) and dimension(s) of the ice-maker opening(s), and (e) ascertain the minimum water level required to fill the tank with ice.

Abstract: In this paper we present a new concept of production of a high intensity slow positron beam using an electron storage ring. We found that the intensity of a slow positron beam larger than 1013 e+ (s·mrad) can be achieved using a synchrotron radiation for the production e+-e- pairs.

Authors: Kang-Ning L., Perez R.A.
Title: A novel application of artificial neural networks to structural analysis
Affiliations: Graduate Institute of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, Chia- Yi, Taiwan; University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Mechanical Engineering Department, Milwaukee, WI 53201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kang-Ning, L., Graduate Institute of Mechanical Engineering, National Chung Cheng University, Chia- Yi, Taiwan; Perez, R.A., University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Mechanical Engineering Department, Milwaukee, WI 53201, United States
Abstract: In this work we use the continuous Hopfield network and the continuous bidirectional associative memory system (BAM) in order to develop two novel methods for structural analysis. The development of these techniques is based on the analogous relationship that results from comparing the energy functions of the above two models with that of the structural displacement method (i.e. the socalled stiffness matrix method) and it takes advantage of the fact that classical numerical methods do not have the characteristics of parallel computation that artificial neural networks have. Several examples related to structural deformation are used to illustrate the superiority of the BAM-based neural networks over other traditional numerical methods and the Hopfield model, especially for the case of large dimensional stiffness matrices. © 1995.
Author Keywords: neural networks; structural analysis

Authors: Anis Wagdy R., Abdulsadek Nour M.
Title: Energy losses in photovoltaic systems
Affiliations: Ain Shams Univ, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Anis, Wagdy R., Ain Shams Univ, Cairo, Egypt; Abdulsadek Nour, M., Ain Shams Univ, Cairo, Egypt
Abstract: Maximum power generated by photovoltaic (PV) arrays is not fully used. There are many reasons lead to energy loss. A main reason of energy loss during summer is the system design which necessitates PV array oversizing to supply load during winter season when solar energy is limited. Other reasons that cause energy loss are mismatch between array and load or battery, energy loss in batteries and loss due to PV array disconnect. The array disconnect loss takes place during summer season when storage battery is fully charged. To avoid the disconnect loss, a novel Battery Voltage Regulator (B.V.R.) that allows supplying the load directly from the array is used, when battery is fully charged. In this work energy losses have been analysed and it is divided into fundamental (unavoidable) and non fundamental losses. Both conventional (using conventional B.V.R.) and novel (using novel B.V.R.) PV systems are studied. A load consuming a constant power 24 hours a day through the year is considered. The climatic condition of Cairo city is regarded.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric loads; Photovoltaic cells; Solar energy; Systems analysis; Voltage regulators; Battery voltage regulator; Photovoltaic arrays; Energy dissipation

Abstract: The Multi-Purpose Canister (MPC) system, proposed by the Department of Energy (DOE), has been evaluated in the environmental impact statement (EIS). The environmental evaluation of deployment would include the MPCs role in all aspects of the waste management process including (1) transfers and storage of spent nuclear fuel at the utility sites and naval storage areas; (2) transportation of fuel from reactors to either an monitored retrievable storage (MRS) facility or directly to a repository; (3) handling and storage of spent nuclear fuel at an MRS; (4) transportation of spent nuclear fuel from an MRS or naval storage areas to a repository; and (5) surface-handling of spent nuclear fuel at a repository.

Authors with affiliations: Yu, Jenny Z., Drexel Univ, Philadelphia, United States; Ko, Frank K., Drexel Univ, Philadelphia, United States; Song, John W., Drexel Univ, Philadelphia, United States
Abstract: The dynamic mechanical behavior of Kevlar fiber reinforced composites over a wide range of frequencies was characterized to develop a fundamental understanding of the energy absorption of these composites under high rate of loading. Behavior of the materials under high frequency was estimated by generating the master curves of both flexural storage modulus and loss factor using the frequency-temperature superposition principle. Results indicate that with these composites, it is possible to achieve both high stiffness and high damping without trade-off. This is of great importance for structures when they are used under dynamic loading.

Abstract: The conceptual design of the Multi-Purpose Canister (MPC) developed for the Department of Energy (DOE) Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management included a depleted uranium (DU) shield plug. The Oak Ridge Y-12 Plant has extensive expertise and facilities for analysis and fabrication of DU components. A prototype shield plug, consisting of DU encased in stainless steel, is being made at the Y-12 Plant to demonstrate these fabrication and certification capabilities. The prototype shield plug will be used to characterize the properties of wrought DU, develop the material specification, and develop a baseline fabrication process for further definition of the shield plug and MPC system design.

Abstract: The enactment of the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in 1992 has directed the Department of Energy (DOE) to evaluate the feasibility of emplacing defense generated high-level radioactive waste into the civilian repository along with spent nuclear fuel from the civilian program. The Act also permitted the emplacement of DOE-owned spent nuclear fuel (DSNF) into the civilian repository with the payment of a fee. The DOE has initiated a system enabling the DSNF to comply with all the requirements imposed on the civilian program in order to be accepted for emplacement in the civilian repository.

Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy's Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management is developing a Multi-Purpose Canister (MPC) system to promote compatibility among the waste program elements of storage, transportation, and disposal. The development of an MPC system requires meeting various regulatory requirements. This paper discusses some of the regulatory issues associated with licensing the MPC for all phases of the program: storage, transportation, and ultimate disposal.

Abstract: The U. S. Department of Energy plans to use the Multi-Purpose Canister (MPC) to handle transportation, storage, and disposal of civilian spent nuclear fuel. However, several reactors are unable to accommodate these canisters. The Bare Spent nuclear fuel Transfer (BST) concept involves transferring and loading small numbers of assemblies from the spent fuel pool to an external transfer station containing the MPC. The paper addresses the total system life cycle cost implications of using BST at 20 sites (31 reactors) which are projected to be unable to use the large rail MPC.

Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Battery Conference
Affiliations: California Environmental Protection, Agency, Glendale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Steele, Nancy L.C., California Environmental Protection, Agency, Glendale, United States
Abstract: Air pollution modeling has shown that for California to achieve clean air goals, emissions from motor vehicles need to approach zero. Low-Emission Vehicle and Clean Fuels regulations require that a certain percentage of vehicles offered for sale in California have zero emissions, which today means vehicles powered by energy stored in batteries. Sitting and permitting hazardous waste storage and treatment facilities takes up to five years (or more), and thus all parties in California need to begin planning for EV battery waste management.

Abstract: With the proliferation of electromagnetic launch systems presently being designed, built, or studied, there appears to be no limit to their application. One of the intriguing applications is electromagnetically catapulting aircraft from the deck of an aircraft carrier. The U.S. Navy had foreseen the substantial capabilities of an electromagnetic catapult in the 1940's and built a prototype. However, it was not until the recent technical advances in the areas of pulsed power, power conditioning, energy storage devices, and controls gave credence to a fieldable electromagnetic aircraft launch system. This paper presents the U.S. Navy's Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System (EMALS) being developed in partnership with Kaman Electromagnetics (Hudson, MA). It addresses the EMALS's present design and the technologies involved, as well as the ship and operational impacts, advantages, disadvantages, and compatibility issues for today's and tomorrow's carriers. © 1995 IEEE

Abstract: The design and construction of a major electric gun facility at Green Farm in San Diego is described. The facility is driven by an 11 kV 32 MJ capacitor bank, arranged in 4 MJ modules that can be independently triggered to provide a choice of pulse shapes. The bank has powered a variety of EM and ET guns, including an 8-meter Single Shot Rail gun and a modified 5-inch Naval gun. World record high energy and high velocity shots have been achieved. The highest rail gun muzzle energy was 8.6 MJ and the highest muzzle velocity was 4.3 km/s with a plasma driven projectile of 0.64 kg, corresponding to a muzzle energy of 6 MJ. Intact projectile launch and flight was confirmed by high speed (8000 frames/ sec.) photography and flash X-rays. © 1995 IEEE

Abstract: A computer model is described for calculating energy consumption and moisture loss. The model uses data from an actual potato store in the Cambridge region of the UK. The differences between actual and calculated power consumption values for 1989-1990 and 1990-1991 seasons are +1·0% and -2·3% respectively. For the whole storage season, the weight losses are 5·09% and 5·02% for the 1989-1990 and 1990-1991 seasons, respectively. © 1995.

Abstract: Solid/liquid phase change heat transfer around cylinders occurs in many systems including latent heat thermal energy storage systems. In such systems, interaction of the heat transfer around the cylinders is often observed. Although several studies have reported on the heat transfer around a single cylinder, two or several cylinders, there have been no systematic studies to examine the effect of the initial superheat of water for solidification and the effect of the surface temperature of the cylinders for melting on the heat transfer. The purpose of the present study is to examine systematically the effects of the parameters mentioned above and the density inversion of water on the solid/liquid phase change heat transfer using two horizontal, vertically spaced cylinders. © 1995, The Japan Society of Mechanical Engineers. Title: Elastic energy storage in a leg mechanism for high speed legged locomotion
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Petroleum Division (Publication) PD
Affiliations: Istanbul Technical Univ, Istanbul, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Oral, Hamid A., Istanbul Technical Univ, Istanbul, Turkey
Abstract: Studies have shown that animals use spring motions in locomotion to achieve high speeds efficiently. For running legged vehicles, elastic energy storage is therefore essential. Higher speeds cause higher ground reaction forces on the feet, and these forces can be facilitated through elastic energy storage in the spring elements of a leg mechanism. A newly developed leg mechanism, Buraq, is studied for this purpose. Force analysis of the leg mechanism is carried out to identify the linkages with the same force variation characteristics of a mass-spring model. The study shows that changing these linkages with springs can help to produce the necessary thrust force for running legged vehicles.

Abstract: The characteristics of 300 kJ railgun(HYPAC) in ISAS is described. It has a very efficient energy conversion characteristics as this kind of high velocity railgun (7.8 km/s)and maximum of nearly 12% has been attained. The dependence of the efficiency on the stored energy of the power supply, projectile mass and the gun caliber is studied. The efficiency strongly depends on the caliber and increases as the caliber is increased. A measurement of an array of B-dot probe indicates that a growth of the secondary arc(S.A) has a vital role to reduce the efficiency. © 1995 IEEE

Abstract: Electrothermal accelerators were studied for the purpose of their application for pellet-injection in Tokamaks. Two theoretical models were developed. The first is based on magnetic hydrodynamics equations, the second is based on isobar approximation. Numerical calculations have shown there was a maximum in the curve of the total efficiency versus discharge region length, the value of the maximum being equal to 20% and higher. Experimental investigations carried out with the capacitive store element which stores 100 kJ of energy confirmed the theoretical figure for 2–15 g mass projectiles. The value of efficiency defined as the ratio of projectile kinetic energy to energy deposited into discharge was about 30%. The drastic drop of the discharge peak current was observed, so there is a possibility to increase the accelerator life time. © 1995 IEEE

Authors: Augsburger B., Smith B., McNab I.R., Chen Y.G., Edwards D., Gilbert S., Savell G., Robinson M., Chapman P.
Title: DRA 500 kJ Multi-Module Capacitor Bank
Affiliations: Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue San Diego, CA 92123, United States; DRA, Fort Halstead, Sevenoaks, Kent TN14 7BP, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Augsburger, B., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Smith, B., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue San Diego, CA 92123, United States; McNab, I.R., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Chen, Y.G., Maxwell Laboratories, Inc., 9244 Balboa Avenue San Diego, CA 92123, United States; Edwards, D., DRA, Fort Halstead, Sevenoaks, Kent TN14 7BP, United Kingdom; Gilbert, S., DRA, Fort Halstead, Sevenoaks, Kent TN14 7BP, United Kingdom; Savell, G., DRA, Fort Halstead, Sevenoaks, Kent TN14 7BP, United Kingdom; Robinson, M., DRA, Fort Halstead, Sevenoaks, Kent TN14 7BP, United Kingdom; Chapman, P., DRA, Fort Halstead, Sevenoaks, Kent TN14 7BP, United Kingdom
Abstract: Maxwell Laboratories Inc. has designed, manufactured and installed a 500 kJ multi-module capacitor bank at DRA Fort Halstead to be used for the investigation of ETC technologies. This paper describes the pulsed power system design and present typical test data acquired during manufacturing testing. The 500 kJ system is made up of ten independent 50 kJ modules with a dual operating voltage of 11 kV and 22 kV. The capacitor bank modularity provides the user with pulse shaping flexibility by allowing for time-sequence firing of the ten 50 kJ units. The 500 kJ system can be operated in 50 kJ increments, allowing the user to vary the amount of energy needed for laboratory type testing. Each 50 kJ module is a stand alone capacitor bank equipped with a Maxwell 11/22 kV 50 kJ capacitor, output switch (Maxwell Triggered Vacuum Switch, TVS-40), output inductor, trigger generator, energy dumping system, and control circuits. This system has been tested to demonstrate the overall electrical performance and system flexibility into a resistive load. Data is presented to show the capacitor bank current output pulse variations, both in simultaneous and time-sequence operation. The data shows the advantages of such a capacitor bank for laboratory type experiments and future fieldable power supply systems. © 1995 IEEE
